column2: THOUGH the Jewish Museum calls Jean-Claude Leveque its revolutionary - in residence, the clean-cut, clear-eyed (as they say) young Frenchman is not the sort of rebel to attract suspicious glances in Schrafft's.

GEOGRAPHICALLY, Madison Avenue and 57th Street do not meet where Carnegie Hall stands. Metaphorically, they will do so tomorrow night when Arnold Eidus and the Stradivari Chamber Orchestra give a concert in the venerable auditorium. For Eidus is a professional violinist who is also a vice president of a leading advertising agency, Ted Bates Company.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 14 -- Lehigh vanquished Cornell today, 33-2, for its second wrestling triumph of the week.

Fifty years ago today a young philosophy instructor who had become a disciple of William James at Harvard registered as the delegate from Wisconsin to the organizing meeting of the American Jewish Congress in Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The Small Business Administration announced the formation today of a Negro advisory council to help treat the nation's cities as "undeveloped nations."

Edited and Translated by Leon Surmelian from the Armenian. Illustrated by Stewart Irwin. 319 pp. Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press. $7.95. By Nancy Willard. 95 pp. New York: The Eakins Press. $4.95. And Other Stories. By Herbert Wilner. 247 pp. Indianapolis and New York: The Bobbs-Merrill Company. $5.50. Edited by Martha Foley and David Burnett. 363 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $6.50.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 14 -- For the first time in many years, reform - minded university students and educators are challenging policies of Paraguay's authoritarian Government and apparently getting away with it.

AIRPLANES and ships are being featured on British stamps. Next month Britain is planning release of three multicolored stamps (printed earlier this year) for the anticipated first successful flight of the supersonic Concorde plane, expected to be the world's fastest passenger aircraft.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 7 -- "We're headed for a more democratic church, one that belongs to the people."

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 14 -- Budget cuts made by the Republican - controlled Nassau County Board of Supervisors will result in the serious curtailment of many essential county programs, County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson has warned.
Can a Scorpio outride a Taurus in December even if the Taurus happens to be doubly influenced by a planet?

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 14 (AP) -- President Johnson today urged the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen and the management of three railroads to use "every effort to resolve their differences through the free process of collective bargaining."
By Stephen Jones. 307 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $5.95.

ANTIOCH, Calif. -- To the rugged Welshmen who worked the nearby coal mines a century ago, recreation usually meant getting drunk on Saturday night. The Welshmen are long gone, and only a few briar-matted graves, some partly overgrown coal dumps and hazardous mine shafts and a few skeletons of buildings remain to tell the inquisitive visitor where the roaring mining camps once stood.
There was no Bill Bradley Night scheduled at Madison Square Garden last night but 13,506 fans would have been ready to celebrate one at the drop of a hat.

Like Santa Claus, Michael Burke has been getting a lot more mail lately. Some of it applauds him for being one of the Young Turks behind the "palace revolution" in the big leagues. Some ask pointblank: "Will you be the next Commissioner of Baseball?"
PRAGUE, Dec. 14 -- Nearly four months after the Soviet-led invasion, the Communist party of Czechoslovakia appears to be in the greatest disarray and confusion since it took power in February, 1948.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- The United States has charged that hundreds of qualified American job-applicants are not being accepted for employment on the United Nations' staff.
MIAMI, Dec. 14 -- The Castro Government has intensified its drive aimed at "massively incorporating" Cuban women into the labor force.
Nelson Rockefeller has been called many names, but never Scrooge. And then here he is, two weeks before Christmas, ruining the holidays for half the big-name politicians in New York.
City Finance Administrator Fioravante G. Perrotta has offered the Nixon Administration a formula for a direct sharing of Federal tax revenues with state and city governments.

AT the highly respectable, not to say staid, Shakespeare Memorial Theater at Stratfordon Avon this year, history was made when, in Marlowe's "Dr. Faustus," the audience was shown not only the face that launched a thousand ships but her breasts and buttocks as well.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14 -- Two touchdown passes from Jim Hart to Bobby Joe Conrad and two magnificent goal-line stands enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to upset Cleveland, 27-16, today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Despite constant and growing complaints from Government departments and Congress over the role of the Bureau of the Budget, there is every likelihood that the bureau will continue to be execptionally powerful, though quiet, under President-elect Richard M. Nixon.

MONTREAL, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Port of Montreal may become a terminal for many of the general cargo vessels now going up the St. Lawrence Seaway, J. W. Pickersgill, president of the Canadian Transport Commission, said this week.
Faced by increasing pressures of a cost-price squeeze, grocery manufacturers are turning more and more to food brokers in moving their goods to the market place.
ATLANTA -- More than 200 of the South's 385 Negro elected officials gathered in Atlanta last week, and the most remarkable thing to many of those who saw it was that it had occurred at all.

MERIDA, Mexico -- The oldest ruins in Mexico are, strangely, ignored by most of the tourists who flock to the archeological areas of the Yucatan. They are in Dzibilchaltun, just six miles north of this lovely colonial city.
Translated from the Russian By Mirra Ginsburg. 192 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $3.95. (Ages 12 to 16)

PARIS -- South Vietnam's success in the peace talks here may depend to a great degree on how well Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky -- not so long ago a dashing fighter pilot and still an aviator at heart -- makes the awkward transition to backroom diplomat.

MIAMI, Dec. 14 -- While the New York Jets await the identity of their Western Division opponent in the American Football League championship game, several New York players will be trying to lead the league in various statistical categories tomorrow in their final regular season game against the Miami Dolphins.

WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 14 -- Ennui, the occupational hazard of most horse players, especially those who must wait nearly three weeks for their next local racing action, began to set in tonight with the start of the ninth event at Roosevelt Raceway.

I was not dismayed to read the report of William S. Gaud's remarks in The Times (Nov. 21) concerning the fact that the United States was "doing badly" in helping the developing countries. What does cause dismay and what is most disquieting to me is the fact that after twenty years of foreign assistance our emphasis and direction remain the same.
Marcel Philippe, who quit the Mater Christi track team last spring because he felt he "peaked too early," started the schoolboy indoor campaign in midseason form yesterday.

MURFREESBORO, Tenn., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Terry Bradshaw passed for 261 yards and two touchdowns and ran for two more scores today to lead Louisiana Tech to a 33-13 victory over Akron in the fifth annual Grantland Rice football game.

In the view of many a student, what goes on in college classrooms is often trivial, unreal, irrelevant in the revolutionary atmosphere of today. Such feelings are widely thought to have been a factor in the campus rebellions of months past.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- The boom in the construction of new tourist facilities in Florida, which has been going on for some years now, has skyrocketed this year, despite higher costs of materials, labor and mortgage money.

SAIGON -- Defense Secretary Clark Clifford's remark last week concerning his hopes for a withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam "within 40 days" -- or by the end of the Johnson Administration -- sent a shiver through the military establishment here.
Members of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union began early today to return to work at Consolidated Edison Company installations, bringing to an end their 13-day strike.

Ron Swoboda isn't sure he got answers for himself, and perhaps the only answer he gave anybody else was that the Mets might win a few more games next year. But he's glad he has seen Vietnam; it is real to him now.

PRAGUE -- To understand Communism's current crisis it is necessary to avoid Marxist formulations and recognize that each of the peoples involved have not behaved according to the dictates of pseudoscientific dialectic but according to national characteristics.

THESE are the neediest -- a blind mother struggling alone to keep a family together . . . a sick baby with no parents to care for her . . . a widowed father, distracted by grief . . . an elderly cripple, alone and afraid.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 11 -- The President of Nicaragua had his 43d birthday last week. There were receptions and expensive presents and signs over roads saying "Happy Birthday Chief."

COVE CREEK, N.C. -- A spectacular new showpiece in the Interstate Highway System -- one of those "Just look!" mountain roads -- has been opened to travelers. It is a stretch of Interstate 40 along the Pigeon River between here and Newport, Tenn.
HONG KONG Dec. 14 -- Recent developments in Com munist China's policy for rural areas are saddling the peasantry with heavy new economic burdens.
Michael L. Haider is a man who speaks directly and with authority.
" I was 20 years old," said a Harlem resident, now 38, "before I'd walk through 129th Street. That was a bad block."

Louis Fischer, in his letter of Nov. 17, cited Lenin's writings condemning imperialism and subjugation of other nationalities as a moral judgment on the Soviet military occupation of Czechoslovakia and the slow strangulation of that country's aspirations for enlarged freedom.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Letters and manuscripts of Joseph Conrad, William Butler Yeats, T. E. Lawrence and Kingsley Amis were sold to American dealers this week amid growing British concern over the flow of such papers to the United States.
How does Wall Street size up prospects for the stock market in 1969? In two words: cautious optimism.

Thirty years ago the City College campus was in turmoil. Student militants swarmed through the school, protesting Fascism, heckling the R.O.T.C., demanding jobs, urging political freedoms in college and confronting the administration.

TO THE EDITOR: THIS is a good example of how well the Penn Central Railroad does not serve the public. At 6 P.M. on Nov. 25, I attempted to purchase a one-way coach ticket, Yonkers, N. Y., to Montreal, from an agent on duty at one of the upper-level ticket windows in Grand Central Terminal.
The Whitney -Communications Corporation will buy Ar-t in America, a bi-monthly publiication for collectors and genjeral readers, John Hay Whitney, chairman of the corporation, announced yesterday.

In 1941, in the same mail that brought word from Columbia University that his doctorate of philosophy had been conferred, J. Glenn Gray received Greetings from the President. No fiction writer could get away with a thing like that; the irony is too precise. But there it was, so off he went to be inducted as a private.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Dec. 14 -- An assistant dean of students at the State University Center here has been held in contempt of court for refusing to tell a grand jury the name of a student involved in a 1967 campus theft.

PRAIRIE DU ROCHER, Ill. -- Just a few miles west of this southern Illinois town, in a valley paralleling the Mississippi River, stands one of the strangest, partly restored forts in North America. Called Fort de Chartres, it was erected in 1720 and rebuilt twice, in 1727 and 1753.
TOKYO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- About 30,000 Okinawans assembled outside Kadena Air Force Base today demanding the immediate withdrawal of B-52 bombers from Okinawa.
Sixty-five debutantes representing the United States and 17 other nations will be presented at the 14th annual International Debutante Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 30.

The owner of an automotive diagnostic center in Denver told a Senate subcommittee in Washington earlier this month that such centers -- specialists in analyzing auto ills -- should be divorced from the sale of repair services, as his is.

President Johnson is apparently determined to have one last talk with the leaders of the Soviet Union before he leaves office, and this is creating an awkward situation for his staff, for the Russians, and for the new Nixon Administration.

My sincerest compliments to Ronald Sullivan for an excellent representation of the Police Department's Family Crisis Intervention Unit in "Violence, Like Charity, Begins at Home," Nov. 24. He accurately presented a complex program with clarity and thoroughness.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 14 -- The big David Jones Department Store in Sydney is advertising drip-dry dresses "cool and uncrushable even in the hot Christmasy weather to come." A rival store, Waltons, advises customers to "buy now and have your screen door for Christmas."

A CONCERT pianist was speaking the other day of three pieces that were written for Artur Rubinstein: Stravinsky's "Petrouchka," Falla's "Fantasia Baetica" and Villa-Lobos's "Rudepoema." Only the first of these stayed in Rubinstein's repertory; it is now, in fact, a "classic" concert work, one that practically every young virtuoso likes to dig his fingers into.

IT is somewhat startling to find that the original cast recording of Zorba (Capitol SO 118), the musical adaptation of Nikos Kazantzaki's "Zorba the Greek," is far less reminiscent of that earlier musical evocation of Greece, "Illya Darling," than it is of "Fiddler on the Roof".

THE language of bidding is usually based on common sense and is easy to understand. But experts, if they so desire, can bid in a language which is completely incomprehensible to the average player. The higher flights of scientific fancy are barred in American tournaments, but the Europeans can and sometimes do employ elaborate artificial bidding sequences.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 14 -- The transfer of Michigan's executive power from Gov. George Romney to Lieut. Gov. William G. Milliken, his Republican understudy for four years, is expected to proceed smoothly.

In the upheaval that cost William Eckert his job as Commissioner of Baseball four years before his contract expired, the fact that all power resides in the hands of the owners of the 24 major league clubs was made public as never before. The owners who had taken the lead in deposing Eckert admitted it, citing the commissioner's lack of power as their mistake.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Wiltrud Drexel of Austria won the special slalom race for women at the 14th "Criterium of the First Snow" ski competition today.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 14 -- Utah's first computer manufacturer opened its doors this week in a wooden World War II barracks building.
And Other Stories. By John William Corrington. 286 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $5.95.
A total of 24 meets in the United States and Canada, compressed into 11 weekends, make up this winter's indoor track schedule announced by the Amateur Athletic Union.
A Russian Tale. Retold by Arthur Ransome. Illustrated by Uri Shulevitz. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus Giroux. $4.95. (Ages 6 to 9)

IF Congress wishes to elevate its prestige and influence as an integral part of the governmental process, is it not time that members of the legislative body abandoned their ban on television coverage of major floor debates and left it to the electronic news media, rather than themselves, to decide which committee hearings should be reported on the home screen?
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Economic activity in Illinois is expected to continue its upward trend in 1969, a poll of state business leaders by the Illinois Chamber of Commerce indicates.
Plays, Autobiographies, Opinions. Edited, with an Introduction, by Brooks Atkinson. 1,008 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.50.

Marcel Breuer, whose celebrated designs range from the Whitney Museum to tubular chairs, has just completed his first house since 1962. "! only do a fewmjust for the fun of it," he says. The challenge of the site, a rocky slope in Switzerland with a panorTnc view of Lake Maggiore and the Italian countryside, appealed to hr,.

Municipalities selling taxexempt revenue bonds would save at least $25.6-million in interest costs next year and at least $236. l-million in the 1968-75 period -if commercial banks were allowed to underwrite such issues.

" I DREAM about doing the Beatles," Bill Graham said, hunched over his desk in the crowded office of the Fillmore West. Outside the office, the ballroom--at night a huge hot space of close-packed bodies, blaring rock 'n' roll and swirling light--was empty and bright with afternoon sun; inside, everything was normally hectic--phones ringing and deals being dealt--but for a moment Graham was oblivious.

Not often has the crashing downfall of a series detective been depicted. This device demands much from the writer: it involves the destruction of a lovingly created brainchild, and it must be done with a strong measure of sympathy and understanding.
Christmas starts as early as July for many companies that produce and transport ornaments for the year-end holiday season.

IN her TV incarnation as Madge the Manicurist, Jan Miner has had no trouble convincing at least half of the people who watch her, including me, that a certain green liquid detergent makes a dandy hand lotion.

HUNTER, N. Y. -- Although the ski season just got under way in earnest, Hunter Mountain, here in the northern Catskills, was among those centers already in operation in mid-November. The reason was a 30-inch snowfall that appeared here unexpectedly and made Hunter Mountain's management readjust all its plans.

The key to "La Huelga Becomes 'La Causa,'" Nov. 17, and the foundation for the basic argument with the approach to the article, is contained in the statement that "it may be that farm workers really do not want a union."

A FIERCE fight from the first move sparks the three following Sicilian Defenses from the recent club match between the Manhattan and Marshall teams. Scoring 8-6, the Manhattan Chess Club annexed the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League.

GRAPEVINE, Tex., Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Dallas and Fort Worth buried the hatchet this week and broke ground for the world's largest airport, an 18,000-acre complex with a six-lane highway through the center and a price tag of half a billion dollars.

JOAN SUTHERLAND returned to the Metropolitan Opera in Bellini's "La Sonnambula." Said Harold C. Schonberg, "In this repertory it is still the most exciting voice in the world today. She apparently is never going to shape her vowels clearly and she still has a tendency to slide into notes, but it remains singing on a grand style, beautiful in tone and, in a word, unique."

To THE EDITOR: As a regular summer visitor to New York City, I was interested in the letter about the highway signs (Travel Section of Nov. 17), and I wrote Theodore Karagheuzoff, deputy commissioner of the New York City Traffic Department, about my experiences trying to find the Williamsburg Bridge.
LIMERICK, Ireland -- Autumn and winter days in Ireland are terribly soft, which means that it rains a lot. But the bargains available in off-season prices compensate for the oversoft climate.

BETHLEHEM -- The guards inside the Church of the Nativity wear no guns. They watch the pilgrims come and go, scanning them closely but unobtrusively. They are the guardians of the temporal peace as this hilltop town, the birthplace of Jesus, prepares for its second Christmas under Israeli occupation.

Construction crews yesterday completed a huge concrete shell for a $20-million building at Kennedy International Airport that Trans World Airlines described as the world's first airline terminal tailored to handle the big Boeing 747 jumbo jet.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 14 -- Despite substantially higher costs, new homes in the Minneapolis-St. Paul metropolitan area are selling at such a fast pace that mortgage lenders are finding it difficult to maintain a supply of money.

CARACAS -- Take a country that has had 57 years of military dictatorship in the 68 years of the 20th century. Take an aging party and entrench it in power for 10 years. Mix in a powerful military class and a tradition of violence.
WASHINGTON -- They're as camp as raccoon coats, as dated as bathtub gin -- yet the criminal anarchy laws of the 1920's are coming back into style as a way to deal with modern racial extremists.

A top French sociologist who started a debate in Europe by extolling the effectiveness of American managerial methods flew home last week, leaving another controversy simmering on this side of the Atlantic.

DEL NORTE, Colo., Dec. 14 -- Sheriff Forrest W. Robran of Rio Grande County in Colorado's San Luis Valley will face contempt-of-court charges here Dec. 23 on the ground he has been too lenient with prisoners, including first-degree murder defendants supposedly held without bail.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- By closing San Francisco State College a week early for Christmas vacation, Dr. S. I. Hayakawa has avoided a major test of his "hard-line" policy for dealing with the strike that has kept the campus in turmoil for weeks.

THESE days when the youngest child turns 6 and marches off to first grade, a mother has two alternatives: Either she wipes a tear and goes to the kitchen for a second cup of coffee or she wipes that tear and marches off to work. More women than ever seem to be choosing the second alternative. According to current statistics, most working women are wives with children from 6 to 17.
THE longest economic expansion in the nation has rolled hectically into its 95t consecutive month under a full head of steam but with problems mounting.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 14 -- President Johnson predicted today that the United States would not end the turmoil in its cities until it found a way for a poor man to buy his own home.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 14 -- New Zealand, which recently announced arrangements for a $500,000 sale of lamb to United States military commissaries abroad, hopes that the deal is only a small beginning in substantial American military trade.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 -- The question of what policy the Nixon Administration will seek in the Middle East is becoming a matter of confusion and concern for Israeli Government officials.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A Presidential study group has found a "quiet, slowly building crisis" in the suburbs, while the inner cities have been exploding in violence and turmoil.

WASHINGTON -- One of Richard Nixon's most successful tactics in winning the Presidential election was to attack the Johnson Administration for its foreign policy failings without spelling out in detail the course of action he would take as President. It protected his flexibility for the future.
ROME -- Italy, beset by labor strikes and student agitation, exchanged last week an "interim" government for a government "on probation."

WASHINGTON -- The delicate diplomatic maneuvering now characterizing U. S.-Soviet relations was highlighted last week by puzzling naval jockeying in the eastern Mediterranean. The United States appeared to be probing, the Soviet Union to be withdrawing.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- The army-backed regime emancipated the Greek armed forces from political control today by creating a unified and largely autonomous command.

In the fall of 1787, James Madison responded to opponents of the Constitution who were arguing that the separate states would be dominated by the central government. He said in the Federalist Papers that "beyond doubt the first and most natural attachment of the people will be to the governments of their respective states."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Following are members of the President's National Commission on Urban Problems, which recommended today a system of Federal revenue-sharing with the states and cities:

Acceptance by the International Yacht Racing Union of the three-man kel sloop Soling for the 1972 Olympic Games sailing last month focused attention on the fact that the class already was firmly established in the United States and that next summer the class would be represented on Long Island Sound.

Man's view of the universe has been likened to that of a lobster crawling on the floor of a murky sea. The lobster, as he looks up, is unaware of what he is missing because of the light-filtering effect of the water. Indeed his organs of sight have evolved to respond only to those wavelengths of light that provide significant illumination on the ocean floor.

It was in the early spring of 1945 that I first met the late Arthur Hays Sulzberger. I was then directing the Army Air Corps Convalescent -- Rehabilitation Service. The tempo of the war was high in Europe and ever increasing in the Pacific.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Dave Banducci, a reserve quarterback, kicked three field goals and threw a touchdown pass today to lift Humboldt State College to a 29-14 victory over favored Fresno State in the Camellia Bowl.

SAFETY harness proved its effectiveness in auto racing long ago, but how well do seat belts and shoulder belts function in passenger cars? And what can a driver or passenger do in the moment before the impact of an accident?

ROCKY HILL, Conn. -- A huge geodesic dome that provides protection for several hundred Triassic Age dinosaur footprints was opened to the public this autumn. The dedication ceremonies marked the formal opening of Dinosaur Park, the first major step in the projected development of a natural history educational center that may cost as much as $6-million.

An anonymous group of New York businessmen and civic leaders, operating through an informal organization called the 100 Club, is offering financial assistance to the families of city policemen killed in the line of duty.

But because it has grown so fast in a technological revolution of the last decade, the system is threatening to turn into an organizational Tower of Babel.

The election of Edward F. Paquette as senior vice president of the Rheem Manufacturing Company was announced last week.

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 14 -- Key leaders of the opposition in East Pakistan are ready to throw their support to Mohammad Asghar Khan. the former air force commander, as the candidate most likely to oust President Mohammad Ayub Khan in the election due to be held in little more than a year.

HONG KONG, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Doctors say that the Hong Kong flu, a malady that this colony refuses to claim, has run its course here after killing 32 persons and contributing to at least 100 other deaths.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Conference watchers are not surprised that the table has become an issue in the Vietnam peace talks. It has happened in other conferences between the United States and the Communists.

Built like a featherweight, but looking more like a millionaire jockey, Vincenzo Balestrieri accepted the Sam Griffith Memorial Trophy this week, which officially designated him the 1968 offshore driving champion of the world.

But because it has grown so fast in a technological revolution of the last decade, the system is threatening to turn into an organizational Tower of Babel.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Johnny Unitas, sidelined most of the season with a bad arm, returned to action today and threw one touchdown pass and engineered a 52-yard drive for another score to give the Baltimore Colts a 28-24 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

A recent poll among bettereducated, younger and high income whites and Negroes by "Psychology Today," a monthly magazine in California, showed that the majority believed that riots have positive, long-term effects in changing slum conditions.

THE PUBLIC BROADCAST LABORATORY ran aground for another time last night on Channel 13 with a poorly conceived and amateurishly produced series on "Can This Be America?" as seen through the eyes of independent film producers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 15 (AP) -- A rookie patrolman and his partner tonight captured an escaped convict who had eluded the police for a day and a half after allegedly stabbing the prison warden at whose home he worked.
The credit markets today begin to move into their last week of heavy financing activity of 1968 with a mixture of hope and worry.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 15 -- Plans of the Common Markets Executive Commission to curb farm surpluses by drastically reducing the number of farmers and small farms in the community have shocked agricultural organizations and brought charges that commission "technocrats" simply do not care about people.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 15 -- One of the first new bills expected to go through the South African parliament next month will preserve the anonymity of donors and recipients in transplant surgery.
A two-way radio communication system will be installed on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson (PATH) transit system by early 1971, the Port of New York Authority announced last week.

HONG KONG -- It is not damning with faint praise to say that a characteristic meal in some of Hong Kong's best-known restaurants -to judge from recent experiences here -- is not substantially different from the best to be found in New York's Chinatown.

PERU, Vt., Dec. 15 (UPI) -Twenty-two young hikers from upstate New York were marooned overnight in a snowstorm on a peak in the Green Mountains in southern Vermont. They stayed together and were found largely unharmed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Persons who are unemployed and not white are getting jobs through the United States Employment Service at triple their ratio to the general labor force, according to the Department of Labor.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a $3.5-million grant to be used mostly to help local community groups get money from government and private agencies.

HINGHAM, Mass., Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Three hitchhiking youths were killed today when a car crashed into the rear of another that they were helping to push in the rain. Dead on arrival at South Shore Hospital in Weymouth were Michael Beatty, 20 years old; Ernest Santoro, 17, and John W. Walker, 17, all of Boston.

The Board of Education's new decentralization plan should put the reorganization of the school system back into sensible perspective. It is a reminder that -in contrast to present chaotic and lawless power struggles -- decentralization requires an orderly transfer of functions and responsibilities, with each step painstakingly mapped out and the rights of all parties meticulously protected.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Fifty-two servicemen flew to Phoenix from Vietnam today for a week of lolling in the sun before continuing on to their homes. They will attend free movies, sports events, steak fries and other parties

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP) -Vaclav Pleskot, acting Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, arrived in Moscow today at the invitation of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, Tass reported. The news agency did not say what the two would discuss nor how long Mr. Plescot would be in Moscow.

The airline industry will take a close look at the cost of granting credit and the risks it involves in a seminar to be conducted by the Institute of Airline Marketing on Jan. 16-17 at the Princeton Inn in Princeton, N. J.

THE American Ballet Theater ended the first week of its month's season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night with a final performance of "Swan Lake." The company moves on to general repertory tomorrow.

A union and an association of college professors tomorrow enter a decisive contest in which one will emerge as the bargaining agent for the 4,500 permanent faculty members of the City University of New York.
PRAGUE, Dec. 15 (AP) -Late newspaper disclosed today some details of the economic reforms discussed in the Central Committee's communique.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 15 -- Eight persons were killed and five seriously injured when a truck carrying 30 persons smashed into a tree near Peshawar, in Northwest Pakistan today.

Since his New York debut, almost a year ago to the day, Mario Maya has doubled the size of his company. More important, he has added artistic depth to his own dancing. Possessing a secure rhythmic skill from the start, he has acquired some subtle but significant touches of stagecraft to round lout his characterizations.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Air Force, Navy and Coast Guard joined today to search for a missing twinengine C-119 Flying Boxcar with a crew of Air Force reservists that disappeared shortly after taking off yesterday from Roosevelt Roads Naval Air Station in Puerto Rico.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Officials said today that Jon Lindbergh had been asked to direct crews with sonar and deep-sea diving equipment in efforts to recover the wreckage of a plane that crashed Thursday with the loss of 51 lives.
Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo of New York charged yesterday that some social clubs licensed by his department were used as "gambling joints" and for the use of drugs.

ROME, Dec. 15 (AP) -- About 150 students staged a sit-down demonstration in St. Peter's Square below Pope Paul's window today, but policemen confiscated their placards before the Pontiff appeared to give his weekly blessing.

New Yorkers, digging themselves out from under the season's first heavy snowfall yesterday, could take comfort from the fact that the snow had held off until 20,000 Consolidated Edison employes began reporting back to their jobs after a two-week strike.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- A National Liberation Front delegation arrived today on its way to Paris to take part in the expanded talks.
The Alicia Patterson Fund announced yesterday the award of fellowships to four newspapermen and one newspaper woman for overseas travel and study in 1969.
Problems of theater leadership were discussed at the second session of the National Theater Conference, which is being held at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel.
For a few hours yesterday, the city was crowned with a diadem of snow.

THE owners of baseball, who resume their meetings this week, in Chicago, have been using words like "restructure" to describe what they are going to have to do to meet "the long-range needs of the game." It sounds suspiciously as though they considered the National Pastime just another American institution and their own position the standard one -- up against the outfield wall.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (Reuters) --Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, seemed today to rebuke President-elect Richard M. Nixon for urging that Washington's policy be based on a position of military strength.

Paul G. Hoffman, apostle and long-time practitioner of international development, marked his tenth anniversary as an administrator of United Nations development efforts last week in an atmosphere of increasing gloom.
A "willing partnership" that would open up the nation's Mississippi agricultural area to millions of tons of traffic in Canadian potash has been proffered to Middle Western railroads by barge lines.
DETROIT, Dec. 15 (UPI) -Gary Unger in his second season, registered his first National Hockey League three-goal effort tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 5-2.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 15 -Dr. L. Carl Brown, 40-year-old associate professor of Oriental studies and specialist in North African political history, will become director of Princeton University's program in Near Eastern studies effective Feb. 1, the university announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 15 -The Secor Farms horse show scheduled for today, was postponed because of an early morning snowstorm. Wayne Carroll, director of the show, said he would ask the American Horse Shows Association's permission to hold the event next Sunday.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. -Mark Hopkins, president of Williams College from 1836 to 1872, is news again in this college town.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15 -Steel market trends are being blurred by price influences.

The University of Detroit Memorial Building, described as looking like a Tijuana jail before its recent $28,000 paint job, will be the center of national basketball attraction tonight as Detroit and St. Bonaventure meet.
The American Stock Exchange plans to set up a Special Trust Fund that would voluntarily provide assistance to customers of a member concern in case of financial failure.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP) -Three dissenters who demonstrated in Red Square against the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia have started their exile in remote parts of the country, informed sources reported today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16 (AP) -- James J. Oestereich said today he was "very pleased" with the ruling concerning him because "it leaves the doors open for us to work in this country to change foreign policy."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- President Johnson lit the nation's Christmas tree today with a prayer for Americans to unite behind President-elect Richard M. Nixon and for "an early and durable settlement of the war."
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Second - ranked North Carolina routed Clemson, 90-69, in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Following is the official calendar of inaugural events in Washington, as made public by J. Willard Marriott, chairman of the Inaugural Committee:

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 16 -- Prime Minister Forbes Burnham and his Government sought today to retain power in this country's first general election since she achieved independence from Britain in May, 1966.

The Minnesota Theater Company, whose home is the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, will begin its first New York visit tonight with "The House of Atreus" at the Billy Rose Theater. It will be performed in repertory with "The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui," which opens next Sunday night.

FRESH shipments of folk art and toys are expected to continue to arrive at the United Nations Gift Center until Christmas. The shop, which specializes in crafts and gift items from the members of the United Nations, is in the General Assembly building, 46th Street and First Avenue, directly inside the visitor's entrance.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- The Senate and Assembly Judiciary Committees, many of whose members were sped here over icy highways by state policemen, refused in an extraordinary closed session tonight to receive the names of five legislators linked to the Mafia by an assistant state attorney general.
Dee Finch, who for 16 years was the straight-man partner of Gene Klavan on WNEW Radio's "Klavan and Finch" earlymorning show, has announced his retirement for medical reasons.

BEFORE the Oakland Raiders and Kansas City Chiefs went clankety-clanking toward the first division playoff in the history of the American Football League, Joe Namath of the Jets was asked to rate these two contenders. Rugged individualist that he is, the artful passer used no weasel words.
The Columbia Pictures Corporation's acquisition of its 86 per cent-owned subsidiary, Screen Gems, Inc., was approved yesterday by stockholders of both companies.
A novel method of helping to prevent its employes from getting the flu is being used by a concern here.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 16 -- The United States returned seven North Vietnamese civilian seamen to North Vietnam today. They had been in custody in South Vietnam for more than a year.
A number of new top management posts were announced yesterday.

The premieres of two Off Broadway plays have been delayed. "Riot," which was to have opened Sunday night at the Broadway United Church of Christ, will open Thursday night. "Little Murders," which had been scheduled for this Thursday night at the Circle in the Square is now due Jan. 5.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Army's swimmers beat Ohio University, 62-51, today and gave Jack Ryan his 100th victory as coach of the cadet natators. Double victories by Pete Sweesch in the 50 and 100 yard free-style and by Rick Rentz in the 500 and 1,000 yard free-style helped the Army cause. The cadets won eight of 13 events.
BOGATA, Columbia, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- President Carlos Lleras Restrepo today ended a state of siege -- one step short of martial law -under which the country has been ruled for 43 months.
Three of the world's major oil companies announced yesterday that they had chartered the largest vessel in the United States merchant marine, the 06,500-deadweight-ton tanker Manhattan.

HONG KONG -- The floating restaurants of Aberdeen Harbor in this pleasure-loving city have all the bad qualities. They are gaudy, noisy and crowded, like an electric circus, carnival and zoo with ballast.

Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine ruled yesterday that three voting machines in a disputed Bronx Assembly race had been tampered with after last month's election and directed the Board of Elections to use the election night count in certifying a winner.
The American Stock Exchange opened strong yesterday and then did a turnabout to close only slightly up.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- In a statement denying the Soviet allegations, the British Broadcasting Corporation said tonight: "This is another in a series of attacks on the B.B.C since Aug. 20, the date of the invasion of Czechoslovakia.
The average hourly wage of unionized building-trades workers in New York City rose to $5.95 on Oct. 1, a regional office of the United States Department of Labor reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The Government reported today that more than 700 meat packing and processing plants had closed during the first year of the new Federal wholesome meat law.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A sentence of life imprisonment imposed on a United States marine private in the death of two Vietnamese civilians last May was overturned today and all charges against him were dropped.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Mayor Lindsay conferred with federal officials today on two problems, welfare and cable television.
The London Stock Exchange closed firm yesterday as most sections recorded gains. Activity, however, was light.
ROME, Dec. 16 -- Premier Mariano Rumor outlined to Parliament today a sweeping program of reforms touching almost every sector of Italy's economic, political and social life.

Arnold Eidus, an executive with an advertising agency, conducted the Stradivari Chamber Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall and also doubled as violin soloist in three of the four works on the program.
JOSE TOSADO, a Pratt sophomore, is currently quite a distinctive basketball player. He is the only healthy member of the Pratt team. Seven players have the flu and two have sprained ankles.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The Committee on Trusteeship of the General Assembly adopted a resolution today calling on Britain to give up control of Gibraltar by Oct. 1, 1969.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -Militant students, prevented from holding a scheduled rally at San Francisco State College by an early shutdown of the campus for a Christmas holiday, instead gathered today in front of City Hall.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Gov. James A. Rhodes today appointed Municipal Judge Robert M. Duncan of Columbus as a justice of the Ohio Supreme Court. He will succeed Paul W. Brown, who today was named to take over as State Atorney General when William B. Saxbe becomes United States Senator in January.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Arnie Beswick of Morrison, Ill., set a track record of 194.36 miles an hour yesterday as he won the American Hot Rod Association super experimental stock championship at Central Florida Dragway.

William B. Lewis Jr., executive vice president of the Franklin National Bank, has been elected senior executive vice president and John Sadlik, administrative vice president, has been elected executive vice president.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- The constitutionality of New Jersey's controversial gun control law, which state officials regard as the toughest in the country, was upheld unanimously today by the State Supreme Court.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Indiana's basketball team squandered a 15-point lead, then fought off Loyola of Chicago in the final minutes for an 88-83 victory tonight.

HOUSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -The University of Houston outscored Kansas State, 11-8, in an overtime period tonight for an 87-84 victory. Steve Honeycutt of Kansas State missed a free throw with no time left in regulation play.
TOKYO, Dec. 16 -- The new Chief Executive of the Ryukyu Islands, Chobyo Yara, is a well-rounded man -- both in physique and in personality.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ordered today that the bank and brokerage records of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark be turned over to a special Essex County grand jury that is investigating alleged corruption in Newark's city government.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- A Soviet naval squadron consisting of two submarines and the surface vessels Ivan Kucherenko and Alatir arrived here today for a one-week goodwill visit.

MANCHESTER TOWNSHIP N. J., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A 25-yearold sailor was found dead today, apparently of exposure, in a wooded area here after being lost for several hours while taking a walk. He was Aerographer's Mate le Johnny J. Smith, a student at Lakehurst Naval Air Station.
Edward H. Vogel Jr., vice president-marketing of AnheuserBusch, the world's largest brewer, quit last Friday.

ALDERSHOT, England, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A young technician, whose lawyer said he lived as a Walter Mitty in a world of dreams, was convicted today of passing secret documents to the Soviet Union. He was fined $140.

ROME, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -Italy's balance of payments surplus in the first 10 months of 1968 was $700.2-million, according to the Bank of Italy. This compares with a surplus of $440.4-million in the similar period of 1967.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Researchers said today that the results of a questionnaire administered to Michigan high school seniors did not show that young people who use marijuana seek to withdraw from society.
NEWARK, Dec. 16 (AP) -State Education Commissioner Carl L. Marburger ruled today that boards of education could violate agreements with teacher organizations for the public good.
A patrolman on vacation chased an alleged mugger four blocks through the Bronx in his bare feet yesterday and shot him in the back after he failed to halt, the police reported.

The Southern Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended Nov. 30. Revenues for the period rose to $585,612,000 from $518,499,000 a year earlier, while net income rose to $78,438,000, equal to $1.59 a share, from $75,553,000, or $1.53 a share, in the 1967 period.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The Supreme Court took an unusual step today by agreeing to consider whether or not an Alabama judge was guilty of contempt of the Supreme Court.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- The Soviet Government newspaper, Izvestia, asserted tonight that the British Broadcasting Corporation was collaborating on an official basis with the Secret Intelligence Service, a British agency.

A new corporation that will build low-rent housing on a national scale has been organized by the Aluminum Company of America, a company that over the last decade has been involved in major urban developments in six cities.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A Pennsylvania man survived a 100-foot fall from the Mathews Bridge over the St. Johns River here today. James Johnson, 27 years old, of Pittsburgh, fell while working with a crew performing maintenance on the bridge.
A long-term military dictatorship, freed of constitutional trappings, seems to be in the making in Brazil.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Austin Carr hit two free throws with 6 seconds left to halt a Minnesota rally and enable seventh-ranked Notre Dame to post a 69-65 victory tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The Treasury bill rate rose sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
A 48-year-old lawyer pleaded not guilty in Federal Court yesterday to charges of conspiring to defraud the Government of mortgages for a $4,140,000 cooperative apartment project in Brooklyn.

The Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation reported yesterday net income of $26,861,000, equal to $4.61 a share, including profits of 96.9 per cent of the Reliance Insurance Company, acquired on a pooling-of-interest basis during fiscal 1968.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 16 -The Long Island paper Newsday said yesterday that a member of the Brookhaven Ethics Board had made a profit of $41,538 for himself and gained two big mortgages for his bank through a land deal that was supposed to be without profit.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The Hudson River Valley Commission has named Carl J. Mays, an unsalaried member of the agency since its inception in 1966, its paid executive director.

Thirty-six young women will be presented at he 47th Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria on Jan. 1. Mrs. Robert Stlth Williams Jr. is chairman for the event, a dinner dance for debutantes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon will pay an informal call on Secretary Gen eral Thant tomorrow afternoon. Mr. Nixon will be accompanied by the Secretary of Statedesignate, William P. Rogers, and by J. R. Wiggins, the United States Delegate to the United Nations.

The president of the United Federation of College Teachers yesterday challenged an assertion that the non-tenured faculty members at the City University represented by the union were largely city high school teachers who were union members before voting in a representation election at the university.

TOKYO, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -The Plunger will be the first nuclear-powered American submarine to visit Japan in seven months when she arrives at Sasebo tomorrow, the Japanese Foreign Ministry announced today.
The wholesale commodity price index remained unchanged at 98.5 on Friday from Thursday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The General Assembly voted today to ask the Security Council to "take all effective measures" to help oust the South African authorities from South-West Africa.

A tentative agreement for a North Atlantic longshoremen's contract -- providing a $1.60-anhour three-year wage-benefit package and the nation's first guaranteed annual wage for a 40-hour, 52-week year -- was reported to have been reached here last night.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Bill Austin, the Pittsburgh Steelers' coach, was dismissed today after winning only two games this season.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The Mexican Defense Department ordered the indefinite closing of the country's gun shops and armories today after the third terrorist bombing in three days.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 (AP) -The Baltimore Colt season ticket-holders, although assured seats for Sunday's Western Conference football playoff game here with the Minnesota Vikings, formed a line in subfreezing weather hours before the sale began today.
PRAGUE, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Tad Szulc, correspondent in Prague for The New York Times, was ordered expelled from Czechoslovakia today on charges of abusing his position as an accredited journalist.
ATLANTA, Dec. 16 (AP) -Coach Norm Van Brocklin of the Atlanta Falcons announced today the dismissal of the staff he inherited from Norb Hecker last October.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -The police today arrested Terence Tharme, 20 years old, the last member of a modern-day "Bonnie and Clyde" gang of five that had led policemen on chases through the Midlands countryside earlier this month.

Three members of the Black Panthers, who were arrested last August, after allegedly clashing with the police and firemen at the scene of a rubbish fire in Brooklyn, pleaded guilty to assault charges yesterday.

Abe L. Marks, formerly president and chief executive officer of Hartfield-Zodys, Inc., the retail chain, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer. Raymond L. Kaufman, a former senior vice president, has been named president.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The Chicago Transit Authority, a public agency operating local transit within Chicago and to some suburbs, announced today that its basic fare would be increased from 30 cents to 40 cents, effective Thursday.
THE company that improves the scenery but ruins the weekends for many a suburban crabgrass fighter, O. M. Scott Sons, has adopted an offbeat accounting method in the name of fiscal conservatism.

Sydney Gruson, who left the staff of The New York Times last April to become associate publisher of the Long Island newspaper Newsday, is returning to The Times as assistant to the publisher starting Jan. 15.
The University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team, convinced all but one of the voters in the writers' and coaches' polls this week that it was the No. 1 college quintet in the nation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Through his legislative lieutenants, President-elect Richard M. Nixon tossed back to the Johnson Administration today a decision on whether to press in the new Congress for immediate action on the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Ron Taylor, an agile 7-foot1-inch center, was the big man in the University of Southern California's 83-68 upset victory tonight over fourth-ranked and previously unbeaten University of Cincinnati.

Stocksholders of Basic Properties, Inc., approved at a special meeting here yesterday reorganization of the company into a real estate investment trust to be known as North American Mortgage Investors.

THE Giants have placed three players on the East team for the National Football League's Pro Bowl game in Los Angeles on Jan. 19. They are Spider Lockhart, the free safety; Homer Jones, split end, and Fran Tarkenton, quarterback.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -Jose Legra of Spain, recognized as the world featherweight boxing champion in Europe, will defend his crown against an Australian, Johnny Famechon, at London's Royal Albert Hall, Jan. 21, Mike Barrett, the promoter, announced today.

J. D. Levin Assoc., a new real estate concern; has been established by Jack D. Levin, with offices at 199 Lake Street in Upper Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Levin was formerly president of Beir-Higgins Realty Associates of Saddle River.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon's science adviser believes that a major task confronting the new Administration is to heal the breach between the scientific community and the Government -particularly the Defense Department.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 16 -- The campus of San Mateo College, the scene of violent student disorders last week, resembled an armed camp today.

UMUAHIA, Biafra (Nigeria), Dec. 16 (Agence France-Presse) -- Nigerian and Biafran forces battled fiercely today for the second day for control of Owerri, an important road-junction town that has been in federal Nigerian hands since mid-September.

The United States Supreme Court yesterday temporarily delayed the merger plans of the so-called Northern lines -- the Great Northern, the Northern Pacific and the Chicago, Burlington Quincy railroads.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Jim Jackson, stealing the spotlight from the Spencer Haywood-Bob Lanier duel, calmly sank two free throws with 25 seconds left to play tonight to lead the University of Detroit's quintet to a 71-68 victory over 11thranked St. Bonaventure.

The Bangor Punta Corporation filed a $7-million damage suit in Federal Court in Milwaukee yesterday against the American Machine and Foundry Company, the Harley-Davidson Motor Company and eight directors of Harley.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Pilots of Northeast Airlines have overwhelmingly voted to authorize a strike against the airline if necessary, a spokesman for the Airline Pilots Association, the bargaining agent, said today.

NONGKHAI, Thailand, Dec. 16 -- The Kings of Thailand and Laos came together this morning on a red-carpeted raft in the middle of the Mekong River to inaugurate an internationally sponsored power link between the Ubol Ratna Dam in northern Thailand and Vientiane, the Laotian capital.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16 -A majority of Americans believe that Richard M. Nixon will make a "good" President, according to the Gallup Poll.

A new process called "Firegard" for giving fire-retarding properties to cotton flannel was demonstrated yesterday by M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc. A fire torch applied to untreated flannel started a fire that consumed the material.

University theater must begin to address itself to problems that plague the university, the executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts told a group of community and academic theater directors yesterday at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel.

In what is again "the best of times and the worst of times," Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew and National Urban League Director Whitney M. Young Jr. have sketched wholly disparate urban programs that tell another tale of two cities.
GENEVA, Dec. 16 -- The United States is being given an additional year to save the special agreement on chemicals concluded at the Kennedy round of trade negotiations last year.
Cheap personnel management 5, 10 and 20 years ago is the cause of the city's manpower problems today, the city's Personnel Director said yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- Gov. John A. Volpe said tonight that he planned to remain at his post in Massachusetts at least until Jan. 20 before assuming his role as Secretary of Transportation in the Nixon Administration.
Nancy Richey was ranked No. 1 yesterday by the women's committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The long slide in mortgage prices and consequent rise in yields continued at this week's "auction" of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the agency disclosed today.

FRANKFURT, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- West German sales agents of two major French automobile manufacturers are cutting their prices following the West German Government's tax xrelief on imports, while two other important producers are keeping their prices stable for the moment.

The United States Attorneys for Brooklyn and Newark yesterday attacked a report that advised President-elect Richard M. Nixon to replace them and six other United States Attorneys "as quickly as possible."
FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 16 -Leonardo Ricci left yesterday for the United States, which he believes may be the first country to implement the ideals of a cultural revolution.

James Earl Jones, star of "The Great White Hope," has one of Broadway's most taxing roles. But it is not stopping him from taking on two morning performances every day this week through Friday in an abbreviated version of Charles Dickens's "A Christmas Carol."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Advice both good and bad is beginning to engulf the new President. His own advisers and task forces, the experts -- or at least the old hands -- of the outgoing Administration, the powerful sages of Capitol Hill, and a variety of other sources -- for instance, the President's National Commission on Urban Problems -- are piling pressure upon pressure.
JOLIET, Ill., Dec. 16 (UPI) -Two robbers wearing ski masks and short coats took $150,000 today from the National Bank of Joliet, the police said.
Senator Eugene J. McCarthy says that the Defense Department has become "the strongest independent power in world affairs" and has gone beyond "the effective control of the Congress."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The State Department said today that Ambassador Jacob D. Beam had been directed to ask the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry for an explanation of Mr. Szulc's expulsion.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 16 -- The Luxembourg Communist party, the only one in Western Europe to support the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia, made important gains in general elections yesterday.
The Transit Authority warned yesterday that without larger capital budget allocations for 1969-70, the 20-cent fare could be maintained only with "extreme difficulty."
Yeshiva University, led by the 15-point performance of Stuart Poloner, a sophomore, drubbed City College of New York, 57-41, last night at the loser's Wingate gymnasium.
The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company announced yesterday the designation of two officers as executive vice presidents for administration and the appointment of two new executive vice presidents.
HAVANA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Five Cuban exiles from Miami, seized after landing with weapons on the northern coast on Dec. 2, will be turned over to revolutionary courts, the Government announced today.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- Earl W. Bridges, chosen today for his third straight term as Republican Majority Leader of the State Senate, expressed coolness about the New York City decentralization plan.

Bond Stores, Inc., has announced the election of Irving Moselowitz as president. Mr. Moselowitz, who has been executive vice president, succeeds Ellis H. Schechtman, who was elected chairman. He will continue to hold the position of chief executive officer.

A Federal judge has ruled that the copyright owner of cartoons drawn in 1932 by "Dr. Seuss," the well-known author-illustrator of children's books, may produce dolls based on the drawings without the permission of the cartoonist.

City officials made plans yesterday to cope with the effects of a strike by fuel oil deliverers and at the same time urged New Yorkers to conserve fuel by maintaining lower temperatures in their houses and apartments.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 16 -- The bitterly divided board of directors of Air West, object of a take-over bid by Howard Hughes, failed to produce a quorum today at a special meeting to consider a rival offer.
The Interbank credit card system, which has emerged as the largest in the nation, announced two major additions yesterday.

IF YOU hated "Futz!" I should imagine that you would positively detest "Beclch," Rochelle Owens's latest play to reach New York, which last night slithered into the Gate Theater, belching fire, brimstone and bad taste.

John D. Hill was named yesterday to the new post of staff vice president and trade regulation counsel for the Radio Corporation of America. He will be responsible for furnishing legal advice to the company on all trade regulation matters affecting its operations.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 16 -- The Silvermine College of Art, situated on the NorwalkNew Canaan town line, resumed classes today following the collection of $85,000 in student donations over the weekend.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of a Selective Service law of 1967 that restricts the right of young men to go to court to challenge actions of their draft boards.

Attorney General Ramsey Clark will leave -- that was a foregone conclusion even without the campaign "promise" made by Candidate Nixon in the heat of summer's law-and-order rhetoric -- but it suddenly seems possible that some of Mr. Clark's crime-fighting ideas will stay on.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Archbishop of New York, arrived in Frankfurt today on the first leg of a round of Christmas visits to American troops around time world.
TRENTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -Robberies in New Jersey increased almost 60 per cent during the first nine months of the year over the corresponding period in 1967, according to figures released today.
Two imported car makers have increased prices on their automobiles while a third has cut the price by $91 on its 1969 model.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court left standing today a Los Angeles court order forbidding persons connected with the Sirhan B. Sirhan case from discussing the evidence outside the courtroom.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- France's severe exchange controls are forcing funds back into the depleted reserve coffers of the Bank of France and helping the country repay some of its shortterm debts, official sources reported today.

In the rugged reality of pro football, the New York Jets are delighted that the Kansas City Chiefs and the Oakland Raiders must meet in a playoff Sunday to determine the Western Division qualifier for the American Football League championship game Dec. 29 at Shea Stadium.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A British-entered Hillman Hunter, driven by Andrew Cowan, arrived at Warwick Farm on the outskirts of Sydney today to win the 10,000-mile London-toSydney car marathon.
MIAMI, Dec. 16 (AP) -Cassius Clay, the former heavyweight boxing champion, entered Dade County Jail today to serve a 10-day sentence for an old traffic charge.

OVER the amplified telephone hook-up yesterday at Madison Square Garden, the coach of the Brown University hockey team, Jim Fullerton, was telling newsmen about some of his players who will be on display Thursday in the opening of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Hockey Festival.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The State Department said today that the weekend arrests in Brazil "present serious potential problems" but it made no move to suspend diplomatic relations.

Reports that King Hussein of Jordan has indicated willingness to accept an autonomous Arab state on the west bank of the Jordan River open prospects of a way toward peace in the Middle East, even though Amman has since issued a denial of sorts.

"The Mad Show," the revue that opened in 1966 for a run of 871 performances at the New Theater, will be brought back there Saturday afternoon for 13 matinees. A similar repeat engagement took place at the New Theater during last year's holiday period.
MIAMI, Dec. 16 -- Andres Nasario Sargen, leader of the Alpha 66 anti-Castro exile organization here, denied today that his group had any connection with the Central Intelligence Agency.
LA PLATA, Md., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Judge Perry G. Bowen Jr. of Charles County Circuit Court struck down as unconstitutional today Maryland's law banning contests and games by gasoline service stations.

The Chicago North Western Railway Company, a subsidiary of Northwest Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it had placed an $11-million order for 41 heavy-duty, 3,600 H.P. diesel locomotives. They will be built by the General Motors Corporation and delivered in January and February, North Western said.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- Britain and Nigeria called on secessionist Biafra today to open land routes into its territory for the passage of relief supplies.
Kay Francis, the actress, left an estate valued at more than $1-million, the bulk of it going to the Seeing Eye, Inc., of Morristown, N. J., an institution for training guide dogs for the blind.
MADRID, Dec. 16 -- Four hundred and seventy-six years after King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella ordered the Jews expelled from Spain, the Spanish Government declared tonight that the order was void.

Lew Alcindor remains a basketball legend at Power Memorial Academy. His fabulous statistics -- 2,067 points and 2,002 rebounds in four seasons -- are almost as familliar to the students as the school song. They know, too, that Power won 71 of 72 games during Lew's stay at the school, losing only to DeMatha High of Hyattsville, Md., 46-43.
Another major airline -Trans World Airlines -- has agreed to opn its "V.I.P. club" to all passengers, rather than to limit membership to selected customers.
AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- Jordanian and Israeli forces exchanged fire for 15 minutes today south of the Allenby Bridge, a military spokesman announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The vogue in Washington this season is pragmatism. Presidentelect Nixon is being described as a pragmatic man. When he introduced his Cabinet and it turned out to be George Romney and eleven fellows named Clyde, the press hastened to reassure us that they were all right because they were all pragmatists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -J. Edgar Hoover, for 44 years the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Richard Helms, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, will remain in their present posts for at least the first year of the Nixon Administration.
The state named a new acting trustee for the Ocean HillBrownsville schools yesterday, and a few hours later Rhody A. McCoy was reinstated as administrator of the Brooklyn demonstration district.

In hopes that the city's heterogeneous population will "Cross at the Green Not in Between" the Traffic Department has posted warning signs in English and eight foreign languages. But the language experts of the agency have proved themselves not as au courant with the genders of French nouns as they might be.
Gene Shue, coach of the Baltimore Bullets, was named yesterday as coach of the Eastern team for the National Basketball Association All-Star game scheduled for Jan. 14 in Baltimore.

Chester M. Brown, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, announced yesterday he planned to retire March 1, 1969, and to relinquish his position as chairman at the end of this year. The 61-year-old Mr. Brown, who joined Allied in 1929, said he would continue as a director of the company.

Sixty city bus drivers, describing themselves as "mainly of Irish or Italian descent," filed suit here yesterday contending that a recent promotion test they failed was unfairly geared to favor Negro applicants.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Bill Bowrey, Ray Ruffels, Phil Dent and John Alexander were named today as Australia's team to defend the Davis Cup against the United States at Adelaide beginning Dec. 26.
Many persons prominent in business, religion and politics paid tribute last night to Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, at a testimonial dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria.
Mrs. Florence Murphy of Staten Island took a train to Albany Sunday night and then hiked to her hotel through snow-clogged streets, "like a pioneer," she said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that for the first nine months of this year reported crime in the United States increased 19 per cent over the corresponding period in 1967.

A champagne supper will be held in the Grand Ballroom at the Americana tomorrow night after the American premiere of "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang," the motion picture based on the book by lan Fleming, at Loew's State 2.

The Detroit Edison Company reported yesterday operating revenues of $440,939,416 for the 12 months ended Nov. 30. This compared with $410,070,811 a year earlier. Net income edged ahead to $60,509,183, equal to $1.91 a share, from $60,121,501, or $2.06 a share, in the 1967 period.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is remembered by former residents of New York, and many have sent contributions to the 57th annual Christmastime appeal, as they have to previous ones.

ST. CROIX, Virgin Islands, Dec. 11 -- The "American Paradise," as license plates proclaim the United States Virgin Islands, is less than idyllic for thousands ands of alien workers who are low paid, substantially taxed and denied most of the social services, including a public school education for their children.
The Hong Kong flu continued its coast-to-coast onslaught yesterday, hitting the Northeast particularly hard, forcing several colleges and universities to close early for the year-end holidays.

Eddie Donovan, the New York Knickerbocker general manager, and George Lee, the San Francisco Warriors' coach, faced different problems the day before their teams' National Basketball Association game tonight at Madison Square Garden.
PHILADELPHIA -- There was once a young woman who walked into her closet and found she didn't have a thing to wear.
DeCoppet Doremus, a major member firm of the New York Stock Exchange dealing in odd-lot orders, will pay out Christmas bonuses reduced to between 30 and 40 per cent of the 1967 disbursements.
Steel production edged up 0.7 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The former president of the Douglas Aircraft Company testified yesterday that information about an earnings decline at Douglas in 1966 had been given to Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith four days before it was made public.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The odds are 20 to 1 against snow and at least 6 to 1 against precipitation of any kind when Richard M. Nixon takes the Presidential oath on Inauguration Day, Jan. 20.
EVERY December, in keeping with the holiday spirit, the Mets present themselves what seems to be a National League pennant, documented in color film.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Marine Pvt. Stanley J. Luczko, sentenced two years ago to life in prison for murdering two Vietnamese peasants, walked out of the Portsmouth naval prison today a free man.
LONDON, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- Exclusive television rights for the 1970 World Soccer Cup finals in Mexico have been sold to a Mexican millionaire for $1.6-million.
The stock market tried yesterday to continue Friday's move toward a year-end rally but the effort quickly ran out of steam.
MIAMI, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Angel Cordero Jr. rode two winners at Tropical Park today to bring his total for the year to 323.
A battle for control of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company appeared to be developing yesterday between the Lykes Corporation and the Signal Companies, Inc.

Short-term interest rates climbed sharply yesterday, pushing Treasury bill rates to a record as Wall Street became more convinced that the Federal Reserve was going to move somehow toward tighter credit conditions soon.
