A man being chased after he was alleged to have tampered with parking meters flagged down a motorist on the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive yesterday morning, ordered the driver out of his car at gunpoint and made off with the automobile.

A sold-out performance of the Hanukkah Festival for Israel Bonds at Madison Square Garden last night enabled Edward G. Robinson, the film star, to celebrate his 75th birthday with close to 20,000 people.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Deep in the heart of fashionable Georgetown, a giant computer is busily scanning nearly five miles of invitation lists.
Senator Charles H. Percy plumped here yesterday for Federal tax incentives to companies that develop enterprises in ghettos.

The charade over table shapes for the expanded Paris peace talks seems almost criminal when casualties on both sides are rising again in Vietnam and American dead have crossed the 30,000 mark. The impatience expressed by Defense Secretary Clifford is fully warranted, but excessive pessimism is not.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if unions could force companies to bargain although certification elections had not been held. The fact that a majority of the workers signed up with the union is sufficient to force bargaining, the National Labor Relations Board maintained.
The problem in the metropolitan area yesterday was crystalline, brittle and nearly colorless -- ice.

The First National Bank of Chicago, second-largest bank in that city with over $6billion in assets, has announced a reorganization of its senior management to take effect Feb. 4, when Homer J. Livingston, chairman of the bank, is to retire.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Proposed new rules for determining the location and design of Federally aided highways drew unanimous opposition today from the country's 50 Governors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -United States officials said today that they believed the reports that North Vietnam was preparing to release some captured American pilots during the Christmas season, but they had no official confirmation from Hanoi.
Unbeaten Columbia, paced by Heyward Dotson, its all-Ivy League guard, routed Lehigh, 85-47, for its fifth straight victory of the season last night at the winner's University Gym.
RUTHERFORD, N. J., Dec. 16 -- New York University's quintet raced to a 48-21 half-time lead and coasted to an 88-47 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson tonight.

Those swingers who have the stamina and the funds will be able to bring in the New Year until 8 A.M. under special cabaret regulations announced yesterday by Consumer Affairs Commissioner Gerard M. Weisberg.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16 -- Prof. Henry A. Kissinger of Harvard gave his last seminar today in "Government 259: National Security Policy" before going to Washington to play the game for real.

A FLOOD of letters protesting the timing and interpretation of legislation prohibiting, beginning March 1, 1969, the discharge of human waste from boats in the waters of New York State has prompted the Water Resources Commission to schedule a public hearing on the matter Jan. 10 at the State Health Department Auditorium, 84 Holland Ave., Albany.
KANSAS CITY, Dec, 16 (AP) -- A four-player trade with the Houston Astros of the National League was announced today by the Kansas City Royals, a 1969 American League expansion club.
Another set of price increases was announced yesterday by major chemical producers.

BLACKPOOL, England, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- A fight scheduled for tomorrow in Liverpool between Henry Clark of Los Angeles and the former British heavyweight champion, Brian London, was canceled today when London injured muscles in his back

BONN, Dec. 16 -- Josef Hermann Dufhues, a leading Christian Democratic politician who was once considered as a candidate to become Chancellor, gave up all party posts today because of ill health. He recently left a hospital after treatment for what was described as internal inflammation and the effects of overwork.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Doctors pronounced the Apollo 8 astronauts in perfect health today for their journey around the moon and predicted that the pilots would avoid illness in space like the colds that plagued the first three-man Apollo flight in October.

Paula Sylvester, an extraordinarily fluent flutist, paired last night at Carnegie Recital Hall with Anthony Newman, a similarly proficient harpsichordist, in a sonata program that put one in awe of the duo's ability to flood the air with streams of brilliantly played notes.

The E. F. MacDonald Company announced yesterday an agreement in principle with the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to purchase 31 A. supermarkets in Southern California for cash. The amount was not disclosed.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UPI) -The Chicago Black Hawks recalled Dennis DeJordy, a goalie, from their Dallas minor league affiliate today and returned Jack Norris to the Texas club

The Landau-Banker Realty Corporation, with offices at 770 Lexington Avenue has been formed by Samuel J. Landau and Joel I. Banker. The company will act as a general real estate broker and will undertake realty development projects.

Ken Swenson of Bayside, Queens, the top-seeded player, defeated Steve Diamond of Lafayette, 8-4, yesterday in his opening match in the New York City public schools indoor tennis championships at the HiWay Tennis Club in Brooklyn.

WHEN the bidding reveals an eight-card fit in a major suit a partnership seldom has to look any further for the right denomination. One of the rare exceptions occurs when both hands have 4-3-3-3 distribution, as on the diagramed deal, played in the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship in the recent Fall Nationals in Coronado, Calif.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Eleventh-ranked Kansas withstood a late Murray (Ky.) State comeback to post a 72-59 victory tonight. Jo Jo White was the Jayhawks' star as he scored 10 straight points as Kansas widened its margin from 14-2 to 24-7, and then stole the ball twice and streaked for layups when Kansas opened a 48-26 gap early in the second half.

David M. Kennedy, who has been named by President-elect Richard M. Nixon to be Secretary of the Treasury in the new Administration, is facing a substantial financial sacrifice in moving to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Robert H. Finch, chosen to be Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Nixon Administration, said today that his first task would be to make the Great Society programs work.
LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -Britain named a new chief envoy to Communist China today but the nomination of an acting charge d'affaires underscores the chill in London's relations with Peking.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The French Government moved on three fronts today to rally the battered morale of its supporters.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Colts, Coastal Division champions, placed eight men on the Western Conference team for the National Football League's annual Pro Bowl Jan. 19 at the Coliseum here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The United States contributed a million dollars today to the United Nations Population Trust Fund to finance projects in countries requesting aid for family-planning programs.

PARIS, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -Thirteen young men and a female student went on trial here today on charges of having hurled bombs at police stations in Bordeaux last July shortly after the spring student-worker strikes.

Like time and the river, J. Edgar Hoover is apparently destined to go on forever. President-elect Nixon has followed Presidents from Calvin Coolidge on in keeping him as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WHEN Jeanne Crain was going through what she calls her "glamorous period" at 20th Century-Fox in the early 1950's, the studio issued a biography of her stating she didn't know how to cook. In fact, it said she couldn't even boil water.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -Paul Ricca, 71 years old, one of the last of the old Al Capone gang, appeared for two hours today before a Federal grand jury investigating organized crime, but there was no indication whether he had cooperated with the jurors. He has been granted immunity from prosecution in return for testimony about the underworld.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said today that Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford had again "shown a gift for saying the wrong thing at the wrong time."
Led by Johnny Conforti, who scored 35 points, the St. Francis basketball team easily vanquished Hunter, 94-45, last night at the 69th Regiment Armory.
BONN, Dec. 16 -- The United States Army recreation center at Berchtesgaden plans a ceremonial ribbon-cutting tomorrow opening an exhibit of Hitler's life in the underground rooms and tunnels.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A middle-aged gunman who is believed to have staged 10 holdups in Essex County in recent months escaped with $2,730 today in a robbery at the Main Savings and Loan Association.

PARIS, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Jacques Koscziusko-Morizet, 55 years old, was appointed yesterday as the French permanent delegate to the North Atlantic Council, replacing Roger Seydoux, who has been named ambassador to Moscow.

ROME, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Pope Paul VI has appointed one of his former secretaries, Archbishop Antonio Travia, as his official almoner to the poor, the Vatican announced today. The office distributes Vatican subsidies to the poor, to orphans and to the sick.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday summoned all the department's superior officers, from captain on up, to discuss the problem of policemen sleeping when they are supposed to be patrolling the streets.
A 31-year-old housewife was found raped and slain near the body of her 2-year-old son yesterday in their apartment overlooking Long Island Sound near the Throgs Neck Bridge.

The Oxford and Cambridge Shakespeare Company will perform "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and the revue "Strictly for Kicks" from Sunday afternoon through Jan. 4 on the Columbia University campus. It will appear at the Wollman Auditorium, near Broadway and 115th Street.
The fourth annual dance for the benefit of Sb Christopher's School in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will be given Saturday night at the Roosevelt Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee recommended today that the Assembly continue the United Nations interest and presence in Korea under the auspices of the United Nations Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 16 -President Arthur da Costa e Silva and the armed forces moved today to consolidate the new political control they imposed on Brazil during the weekend.
In a selling rush, potato futures prices dropped sharply yesterday on no particular news.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 -- William E. Simkin will resign as director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to become chairman of a threemember arbitration panel that will study wage incentive arrangements of production and maintenance workers in the steel industry.

A suit by the Sinclair Oil Corporation to bar the Federal Government from approving an application by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation for a 300,000-barrel-a-day refinery in a free-trade zone in Machiasport, Me., was dismissed yesterday by the Federal Court in the Southern District of New York.

State Senator Seymour R. Thaler charged yesterday that the Lindsay administration had "deliberately bled and starved" the city's 19 municipal hospitals by diverting $200-million that should have gone to those institutions over the last three years.
The smallest of the three major news magazines, the U.S. News and World Report, had the worst year as far as advertising pages go.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- China had an excellent grain harvest this year and commune members sold surpluses to the state after meeting delivery quotas.

Almost nothing has yet been accomplished by a "crash program" to remedy decaying conditions found more than a year ago by a state inspection of Greenpoint Hospital, an investigative hearing was told yesterday.

Track and field took two steps yesterday toward popularizing the sport during the four-year interval between Olympic Games.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 17 -- Damage suits on behalf young Negroes killed and injured by state highway patrolmen during racial conflicts at Orangeburg, S. C., last February will be filed in Federal Court against the South Carolina Highway Department.

VIENTIANE. Laos, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Heavy fighting between North Vietnamese forces and Laotian troops was reported today near the village of Thateng, a key road junction in the Boloven Plateau about 350 miles southeast of here.
RICHMOND, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Third-ranked Davidson, its attack dulled by a week off for examinations, had to resort to ball-freezing tactics tonight to squeeze out a 62-60 triumph over Richmond's five.
PARIS, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- Five men shot and wounded a bank messenger and robbed him of $28,000 in central Paris early today.

OH dear! I feel like one of nature's Bob Crachits forced by cruel circumstances into playing Scrooge. I feel like a host wanting to honor a most welcome guest and then seeing him slip on the porch. I feel wretched.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., proposes to expand its community-antenna television business through an acquisition of three privately owned West Coast companies, it was disclosed yesterday.
American Metal Climax, Inc., announced here yesterday the signing of an agreement that might lead to the development of a major bauxite-alumina complex in Australia.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company had the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or any year in its 68-year history in the periods ended Oct. 31, it was reported yesterday.
LISBON, Dec. 17 -- A new political movement appeared in Portugal today and urged Premier Marcello Caetano to take decisive steps to liberalize this authoritarian state.

Georg Solti, the 56-year-old Hungarian conductor, yesterday was officially appointed musical director of the Chicago Symphony. Carlo Maria Giulini, 54-year-old Italian, was named principal guest conductor. Both contracts are for three years, beginning in September 1969.

PARIS, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Riot policemen chased roving bands of youths through the Latin Quarter here tonight and set up posts to prevent a new wave of student unrest from turning into an open revolt, as it did last spring.

NEWCASTLE, England, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A "kill for thrills" trial ended today with 11-year-old Mary Flora Bell found guilty of manslaughter with diminished responsibility of her 13-year-old playmate, Norma Joyce Bell, innocent of all charges.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 17 -- A moderate government backed by large doses of United States financial assistance appears to have defeated its Marxist-oriented opposition in the general election.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Clark Graebner, who is fighting to regain a place on the United States Davis Cup tennis team for the challenge round against Australia Dec. 26, showed considerable improvement in a workout against Bobby Lutz today.
Fordham, often pictured as a cluster of Roman Catholics joined to the world by a subway and sometimes separated from that world by religious discipline, yesterday detailed plans to change its image.
More and more New Yorkers were without heat yesterday as fuel tanks went dry and the strike of oil deliverers continued.
The Automobile Club of New York recommended yesterday that parking violations be handled at informal hearings in a new administrative bureau rather than in Criminal Courts.

Amos Vogel, director of the New York Film Festival and the Lincoln Center Film Department since their inception in 1963, is resigning from both positions Jan. 1. This is one result of the financial problems that face the performing arts center.
The first and only $3-million day in Florida horse-racing history took place at Hialeah Park on Widener Day in 1965.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Flyers, weakest scoring team in the National Hockey League, staged a scoring spree for the first time this season tonight and whipped the Pittsburgh Penguins, 8-2, to climb out of last place in the West Division.

THE Whitney Museum's annual exhibition of contemporary American art, which this year is devoted to new sculpture, is the kind of event that pleases the public -- or at least attracts it in large numbers -- while quietly infuriating much of the professional art world.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Federal Reserve Board increased its discount rate to 5 1/2 per cent from 5 1/4 today "in furtherance of a policy of restraint" on the booming economy.

MOZART'S "Don Giovanni" came around for the first time this season last night at the Metropolitan Opera. The familiar sets and costumes by Eugene Berman were supplemented by a cast with enough newcomers to lend special interest to the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The civil rights achievements of his Administration, President Johnson said tonight, have brought Negro Americans to a mere beginning where, like his grandson, they have "just learned to walk."

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 17 -- George Cusimano, the leading rider at the Laurel meeting and the nation's leading apprentice rider, was rushed to Prince Georges County Hospital today after falling from his mount in the last race.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Second-ranked North Carolina controlled the backboards tonight in gaining a 94-67 victory over Virginia in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Despite strong opposition by the Soviet Union, the General Assembly created a broadly based committee today to bring wealthy and poor nations into agreement on a strategy for international development.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Princeton's younger but taller basketball squad, passing and shooting poorly and hardly doing any rebounding, lost to Rutgers, 61-60, tonight. It was the first time in 15 years the Tigers had been beaten on the Scarlet's court.

President Martha Peterson of Barnard College has announced the formation of an urban-studies major at the college. The new course of study is a result of recommendations made by the Committee on the City, one of two committees currently suggesting future programs designed to help the college relate more closely to the surrounding community.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Weather caused a 24-hour delay tonight in a much-protested underground nuclear test that had been scheduled for tomorrow as one of the biggest nuclear explosions ever to be detonated in the United States.

The promotion of Arthur P. Clow to the new post of executive vice president of the Western Electric Company was announced yesterday. A director of the company, he will now have general supervision of all government business.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Paced by Tom Deacon's two goals, Clarkson College overpowered Princeton, 4-0, today at Baker Rink.
The conflict between baseball's club owners and players over financing pensions and other benefits out of television revenue sharpened yesterday and spilled onto a public battleground.

A Government-imposed quota on imported steel was urged yesterday by Robert G. Welch, president of the Steel Service Institute.

ATLANTA, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- A fake detective and a tiny accomplice barged into a motel room before dawn today and kidnapped the daughter of Robert F. Mackle, millionaire Florida land developer and a friend of President-elect Richard M. Nixon.
Nate Thurmond sat on the San Francisco bench at Madison Square Garden for 48 minutes last night and became aware of the importance of Nate Thurmond to the Warriors.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The Atlanta Hawks downed the Chicago Bulls tonight, 87-83, for their fifth straight victory.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Four high-school students were arrested today on charges of selling heroin at Mount Vernon High School.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- William C. Foster, the director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, has submitted his resignation to President Johnson effective Dec. 31 to underline his desire to leave office by the time Richard M. Nixon becomes President.

Brazil's military leaders have again swept aside constitutional government and fastened a dictatorship on the country. President-elect Richard M. Nixon paid what was officially termed a "courtesy call" on Secretary General Thant yesterday and pledged his Administration's "continuing support" of the United Nations.

SAIGON, Wednesday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Enemy gunners fired mortar shells and rockets into half a dozen allied military posts late yesterday and early today. United States spokesmen said that damage and casualties were light.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Cornell's hockey team scored three goals in less than six minutes in the second period at Lynah rink tonight and went on to rout St. Lawrence, 7-1.
Shea Stadium, where Matt Snell runs over people and Gerry Philbin knocks people down, was the scene of some cold-weather heroics yesterday morning.

Rhody A. McCoy was reinstated as administrator of the Ocean Hill - Brownsville district's schools without the knowledge of or consultation with Dr. William D. Firman, the state trustee who had suspended him.

Mrs. Rose Shapiro, former president of the Board of Education, declared yesterday that the board's new decentralization plan would perpetrate a fraud on the community because it would in no sense "resolve the critical problems of improving the education of deprived children."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Navy narrowed to two concerns today the competitors for a contract to develop a versatile new fighter plane.
Merck Company says it has Government approval to market a single-injection vaccine for measles and will make it available to doctors shortly after Jan. 1.
MIAMI, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Angel Cordero, edging closer to the 1968 riding championship, rode three winners at Tropical Park today.

The Overseas Press Club of America issued a statement yesterday protesting what it termed the unwarranted expulsion by Czechoslovakia of a correspondent of The New York Times, Tad Szulc. He was ordered expelled Monday on charges that his activities were incompatible with his work as a correspondent.
WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The United States Grand Prix, already the richest grand prix race in the world, will double its purse offerings to $206,000 in 1969.

Eighty thousand doses of vaccine against the Hong Kong flu arrived at the city Health Department yesterday and will be distributed today to health centers, hospitals, nursing homes and homes for the aged that have requested it.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Rex Kern, Ohio State's injured No. 1 quarterback, watched from the sidelines today as his teammates drilled for their Jan. 1 Rose Bowl engagement with Southern California.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The machinery of the state lottery finally began to move today after being held up for more than four hours by the gust of wind last Dec. 5 in New York City that scattered thousands of tickets.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Cornell broke a three-game losing streak tonight by defeating Rochester, 67-63. Hank South of Cornell topped all scorers with 23 points.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Billy Hicke's two goals led Oakland to a 3-2 victory tonight over Minnesota.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands (UPI) -- Girls in miniskirts are less vulnerable targets when walking in nighttime traffic than those more covered, according to Jan Polak, president of the Safe Traffic Association. "The more leg, the earlier a driver sees somebody," he explained.

Junior High School 271 in Ocean Hill-Brownsville reopened peacefully yesterday under the supervision of Rhody A. McCoy, the reinstated district administrator.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- Twenty-five Northern California Kaiser Foundation hospitals and clinics limited their services today to the seriously ill as a strike by 3,400 workers went into its second day.

"Ballad for a Firing Squad" closed after its seventh performance on Sunday night at the Theater de Lys. The musical, originally produced by David Merrick as "Mata Hari," ended a pre-Broadway tour last December in Washington at a reported loss of $850,000.

WASHINGTON Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Returning to the Federal courtroom where he was conviced of grand larceny, conspiracy and tax evasion. Robert G. Baker argued today that the evidence used against him was "tainted" because it had been obtained by wiretapping.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 17 -- A majority of Americans with an opinion on the subject are now ready to let South Vietnam take over all the fighting and make all the decisions about peace and dealings with the Vietcong, according to the Gallup Poll.

Ernest Lehman has been signed to make his film directorial debut with the movie version of "Portnoy's Complaint," a novel by Philip Roth to be published by Random House in February. Twentieth Century-Fox will film it in association with Sidney Beckerman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis of Maine announced today that the state would ask the courts to force Secretary of Commerce C. R. Smith to approve a plan that would aid the New England economy by providing cheaper fuel oil.

It's getting tougher for homegrown Eastern tennis players to earn a high ranking, with such national stars as Arthur Ashe, Clark Graebner, Ron Holmberg and Gene Scott competing in tournaments in this section.

MORRIS PLAINS, N. J., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Two men with ski masks pulled over their faces, and brandishing a sawed off shotgun and a pistol, robbed the Morris Plains Savings and Loan Association of about $7,000 today.
Prices on the London Stock Market were firm in moderate trading.
MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The 27-girl Sarah Lawrence College chorus flew here tonight to give concerts in Moscow, Leningrad and Kiev.

Everett H. Erlick has been elected a group vice president by the board of directors of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., it was announced yesterday. He will be responsible for the company's corporate relations, government relations and the Washington office.

An indiscreet remark by a zealous young investigator of official corruption in New Jersey has prematurely stirred up a storm of such proportions that it can only be stilled now by full official disclosure of the known facts. Any other course is bound to leave a cloud of suspicion hanging over the entire Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Mrs. Aristotle Onassis slipped into Washington today and paid a noon-hour hospital visit to Mrs. Ethel Kennedy, who gave birth to a daughter last Thursday, the 11th child of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Minnesota Pipers defeated the Indiana Pacers. 111-109, tonight in an American Basketball Association game despite the absence of Connie Hawkins, out for his second straight game because of an arm injury, and Chico Vaughn, who has influenza.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The Treasury imposed new exchange controls tonight in an attempt to improve the effectiveness of Britain's import deposit plan. The impact of the plan was being subverted by the willingness of foreign suppliers to finance the required deposits.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- The first South African guided missile was successfully launched from the St. Lucia missile-testing site north of here today. It traveled about three miles. A second missile was later successfully fired on a four-mile flight.

A 27-game spring exhibition schedule, winding up with two games in New Orleans against the Minnesota Twins, was announced yesterday by the New York Mets. It will be the first exposure of the Mets to the state of Louisiana, and vice versa.
Mayor Lindsay agreed yesterday to meet on Friday with a 35-man committee of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to hear about changes the association would like in a new contract.

Trees trimmed with pearls that never saw an oyster and woman adorned with the genuine article provided the decor yesterday evening for the annual Christmas Pearl Gala, benefiting the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.

The Oratorio Society of New York is as much of an institution as the Rock of Ages, and it is almost as old. It began its "Messiah" performances in 1874 and Andrew Carnegie built Carnegie Hall to house the society.

TRENTON, Dec. 17 -- State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills, acting under orders from Gov. Richard J. Hughes, announced today that he would seek the convening of a special statewide grand jury to investigate the relationship of organized crime to the Legislature and other branches of government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The State Department said today that the situation in Brazil "appears to have calmed."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford's criticism of South Vietnam on the pace of the Paris talks has puzzled, embarrassed, pleased and pained official Washington.
Following are remarks by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary at a conference of police superior officers yesterday:

After eight straight days of advances, the American Stock Exchange index yesterday took its first nosedive since Oct. 29, closing at $33.07, down 18 cents. A total of 602 issues declined yesterday while 302 issues advanced and 138 were unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The Justice Department said today it had smashed a narcotics smuggling ring with the arrest of 25 persons in the Los Angeles area and the seizure of $1-million worth of heroin and cocaine near the Mexican border.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 17 (AP) -- The General Assembly's Administrative and budgettary Committee approved a resolution today to add Russian to the working languages of the Assembly and the Security Council.

KITTY HAWK, N. C., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Orville and Wilbur Wright were honored today in ceremonies marking the 65th anniversary of the first successful airplane flight by the Wrights, who were bicycle makers from Dayton, Ohio.
Hundreds of college students and teachers have been the victims of "one of the most vicious charter flight frauds" ever reported in the state, Attorney General Lewis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.

A court order enjoining the shipping industry here from interfering with plans of the Waterfront Commission to bring new dock workers into the Newark and Elizabeth area was not only affirmed yesterday, but apparently made more definite.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Judge Daniel P. Ward of the Illinois Supreme Court today signed an order staying the scheduled Jan. 31 execution of Richard Speck, convicted slayer of eight Chicago nurses in July, 1966, pending an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- Color motion pictures made from black-and-white film are being tested by the Air Force in Vietnam to penetrate camouflage methods of the Vietcong and North Vietnamese.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The District of Columbia City Council voted 8 to 1 today to instruct policemen here that they could not shoot at criminal suspects except under circumstances of extreme danger to themselves or to the public.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Senator George S. McGovern broke a long silence among critics of the Vietnam war today by denouncing Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam as a "little tinhorn dictator" and by suggesting that the United States begin withdrawing its troops from Vietnam.
Mayor Lindday said yesterday that as far as he was concerned the 20-cent transit fare was not in jeopardy.

Longshore labor negotiations collapsed last night as an angry negotiating committee of the International Longshoremen's Association unanimously shouted its rejection of a new package offered by the waterfront industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Office of Foreign Direct Investment, which faces possible elimination when the Nixon Administration comes to power, went ahead today and issued enforcement guidelines on the assumption that it will still be in business next year.

A health panel told Mayor Lindsay yesterday that tuberculosis here was continuing "at an unacceptably high level" and that its elimination, particularly from slum areas, would be "extraordinarily difficult.''
Lee Trevino held a pitching wedge in his hand, but the 1968 United States Open champion talked more here yesterday about a No. 2 scoop shovel he'll soon be swinging.
ATHENS, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The passing of the traditional collection plate in churches throughout Greece will be banned Jan. 1, the Orthodox Church of Greece decreed today.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Winning seven of nine matches, Princeton's unbeaten wrestling squad downed Columbia, 28.6, today for its fourth straight.

TOKYO, Dec. 17 -- A United States nuclear-powered submarine now moving toward the coast of Japan is sending tremors of alarm through the country.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad said yesterday it was acquiring 557 new freight cars, 700 piggyback trailers and 20 diesel locomotives for delivery next year. The equipment will cost $21.2-million to build.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Braving icy winds sweeping off the Potomac, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson wound up her job as the nation's chief beautifier today by dedicating new fountains here in the capital.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Premier Todor Zhivkov of Bulgaria arrived today for meetings with Kremlin leaders. A brief announcement by Tass, the official Soviet press service, did not give the purpose of the visit or say how long it would last.
On clear, cold nights the city glitters as if a galaxy of unextinguished stars had spilled over from the sky.
MIAMI, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Mackle brohers pioneered the building of large, fully pre-planned communities in Florida, which have attracted thousands of families, mostly retired people, from the North.

Ted Bates has announced that its Canadian affiliate, Spitzer, Mills Bates, Ltd., will have a new chairman and president as of the first of the year. George E. Cross will be the chairman and Allan B. Yeates will replace him as president.
Tickets for the light-heavyweight boxing championship between Bob Foster of Washington, the champion, and Frank DePaula of Jersey City will go on sale today at the Madison Square Garden box office.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The House of Commons approved in principle today a bill to liberalize the grounds for divorce in England.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The once famous Edgewater Beach Hotel, which closed when its owners went bankrupt a year ago, will be sold to a group of investors planning three residential towers and a recreation complex, it was announced today.

The Federal Reserve's decision to raise the discount rate a quarter point, to 5 1/2 per cent, initially will cause a slight rise in fixed-income securities prices today, Government bond dealers predicted yesterday afternoon.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Frank R. Ahlgren, 65 years old, editor of The Memphis Commercial Appeal for more than 30 years, announced tonight that he would retire from the morning newspaper effective Dec. 31. Jack R. Howard, president of Scripps-Howard Newspapers, announced the appointment of Gordon Hanna, editor of The Evansville (Ind.) Press, as Mr. Ahlgren's successor.

"Both of you understood the roles you played and the need this country had for men of purpose who would not only challenge, but would lead--who would lead even at the sacrifice of themselves."

HONG KONG -- It is a place where doves coo and the name is Lin Yin Tai -- literally, a terrace in the shade of the forest.
The election of E. R. Rowley as a director of the Borden Company was announced yesterday. He is chairman and chief executive officer of the National Lead Company.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Auxiliary Episcopal Bishop of California, said today that he would go ahead with a third marriage despite a possibility of excommunication.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- The Belgian bank rate has been raised to 4.50 per cent from 3.75 per cent, effective tomorrow, the National Bank announced today. The rate was last changed on March 7, when it was reduced to 3.75 per cent from 4 per cent.

THE American Smelting and Refining Company continued to pursue an independent course yesterday, splitting the stock 2 for 1 and raising tile dividend. This complicated matters a bit for two ardent suitors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Johnson was hospitalized today with a bad cold and low-grade fever that aides said could be called the flu.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said tonight that he had to defend himself against "so-called friends," and he demanded that "irresponsible people" in the West be silenced.
Mayor Lindsay has tentatively decided to seek re-election next year and has begun a series of meetings to select a campaign manager.

The unemployment rate here declined to 2.9 per cent of the work force during the month of October, the city's Economic Development Administration reported yesterday. The unemployment ratio in the same month last year was 3.4 per cent.
An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended yesterday approval of the merger plans of the Chicago North Western and Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific railroads.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President-elect Nixon's press assistant said today "we do not anticipate any change in Mr. Nixon's position or in the price of gold."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Government accepted a deed today to 3,100 acres of Long Island wetlands as a gift from the Town of Oyster Bay, which hopes to thwart construction of a bridge over Long Island Sound.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- President Johnson has accepted the resignation of Fulton Freeman as Ambassador to Mexico, the White House announced today.

The administrator of Greenpoint Hospital told a state panel yesterday that he had been trying to get the institution's screens fixed for more than two years.
A spokesman here for Allied Chemical confirmed yesterday that the company was "out of the Tata deal" but declined to discuss the reason.
The Lindsay administration was charged yesterday with having allowed prostitution to become "wide open in this town."

The New York Urban League will mark the start of its 50th year on Jan. 5 with a New Year's Reception in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza. Other events celebrating the anniversary year will be the Frederick Douglass Dinner at the Americana on May 1, a block party in July and, tentatively, a Freedom Rally in Madison Square Garden.
SAIGON, Dec. 18 -- The South Vietnamese Government affirmed today that it would recognize a 24-hour truce beginning at 6 P.M. on Christmas Eve.
Howard L. Clark, chairman of the board of the American Express Company, has been named general chairman of the 1969 campaign for members and funds for the American Red Cross in Greater New York.

The up-and-down negotiations between waterfront workers of the International Longshoremen's Association and dock employers appeared to be on an up trend last night.

The Symphony of New York, a new orchestra under the direction of Joseph Eger, will make its debut tonight in Carnegie Hall. The major portion of the program will offer a mixed-media presentation of a sequence of Berlioz works, excerpts from "Lelio" and the "Symphonie Fantastique."
Hong Kong flu vaccine is expected to protect many but not all those who receive it.

A mild-looking 50-year-old former convict was arraigned in Federal Court yesterday on an indictment charging him and four other men with robbing a truck of the First National Bank of Passaic County, N.J., of $511,000 on Dec. 21, 1964.

Governor Rockefeller casttigated the railroad unions yesterday for "sabotaging" the Long Island Road. He also charged that New York City and Nassau County shared blame for the railroad's woes because of their failure to pay maintenance costs.

DESPITE a certain affinity for astrology ("l'm a Leo"), Anne Klein vehemently denies that she's a wizard. She doesn't look like a wizard, with her big graygreen eyes, slick blond hair and diminutive figure (5 foot 4 and on the curvy side).
Eight customs inspectors were given a total of $2,200 in Federal rewards yesterday for detecting and seizing large amounts of prohibited drugs at Kennedy International Airport.

Harvey Goldberg, a junior, won three events, the 200-yard butterfly and the 500 and 1,000 yard free-styles, to lead the New York University swimming team to n 64-40 rout of City College of New York last night at the losers' Wingate Pool.

Nixon.

Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., made a sharp recovery in the final quarter of its fiscal year ended Oct. 31 with net income of $14.7-million, equal to 81 cents a share, up from $4.6million, or 26 cents a share, in the preceding year.

The impact of the strike by fuel oil deliverers became more critical yesterday as hundreds of additional homes and apartment buildings exhausted oil supplies and 36 hospitals and nursing homes failed to receive promised fuel deliveries.
The city opened its counter-offensive against Hong Kong flu yesterday with inoculations as the epidemic continued to spread across the country.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -The F.B.I. arrested an Illinois National Guard captain, two sergeants and 29 other men today on charges of using false notices of membership in the guard to obtain draft deferments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The President-elect has reappointed J. Edgar Hoover as Director of the F.B.I., naturally, but Mr. Nixon apparently has failed to secure the services of Senator Eugene McCarthy as Ambassador to the U.N. Actually, if the two job offers had been switched. Mr. Nixon might have signed up McCarthy, too.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Two American priests belonging to the Oblate Order have been arrested in Recife, in northeastern Brazil. Charges of "serious subversive activities" have been brought against them by state security forces, according to information reaching Rio de Janeiro today.

GENEVA, Dec. 18 -- Dr. Ota Sik, the Czechoslovak economic reformer in exile, charged tonight that a warning by the Prague Government against his return had been "faked." Speaking in a telephone interview from Basel he said he might return to Czechoslovakia for a few days to assess conditions there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) An Administration official conceded today that the Government employed a full-time expert to help hungry foreigners but only had a part-time consultant on programs to feed hungry Americans.

Monica Evans has quit "The Mother Lover" because she was required to appear nude at the end of the second act in Jerome Weidman's new comedy. Miss Evans explained that the scene was not in the script she had read. Her successor has not been selected. The play is due Jan. 30 at the Booth Theater.
The escalation of interest rates in the American economy gathered force yesterday in the wake of the latest Government action to restrain inflation.
A proposed merger of the Norwich Pharmacal Company and Morton International, Inc., involving an exchange of stock valued at $185-million headed the list of corporate acquisition activity yesterday.

ARDSLEY, N. Y., Dec. 18 -Progress, in the form of construction for a new school here, roared on today, and bulldozers tumbled aside the shattered trunk of a 450-year-old oak sacrificed by a community that found itself with no alternative.

THE sled dog racing season comes each year as inevitably as the snows that make the sport possible. In New England the season begins on Dec. 28 and 29 at Tamworth, N. H. There will be 11 meets altogether until March 8 and 9 in New Hampshire, Massachusetts and Maine under the banner of the New England Sled Dog Club.

TRENTON, Dec. 18 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes warned the Republican leaders of the Legislature tonight that he would call a special session unless they agreed to witness the secret identification of six legislators who have been tentatively linked to the Mafia.

Brown Brothers Harriman Co. announced yesterday the appointment of Neil A. Morrison Jr., Edward P. Currier Jr. and William L. McLennan as managers. This post at the private banking concern is equivalent to that of vice president of an incorporated bank.

CHOREOGRAPHERS, unlike composers, do not come in the child-prodigy variety. Mozart's Cassation No. 1 in G, to which Michael Smuin has set his new ballet, "Gartenfest," for American Ballet Theater, was written when the composer was 13.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Siamese twins born to a 16-year-old West Virginia girl died today in the West Virginia University hospital here. The hospital administrator, Eugene Staples, said the twin girls died of pneumonia.

Former Police Commissioner Vincent J. Broderick said yesterday that the ability of the police to deter crime and apprehend criminals could be significantly improved if men were assigned on a basis of need rather than according to the three-platoon system.
A new bomb attempt against the police -- this time in Brooklyn's Brevoort section, a few blocks from Grand Army Plaza on the fringes of the BedfordStuyvesant area -- failed early yesterday morning.
MIAMI, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Fifteen persons from the fishing vessel Malibu, which sank off Jamaica last night, were rescued from a lifeboat this evening, the Coast Guard said.

MANILA, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -Mountain tribesmen in the southern Philippines introduced themselves as Christmas carol singers and killed seven person who let them into their house, the Philippine News Service said today. Quoting the police chief of Quezon in Bukidnon Province, 600 miles south of Manila, it declared four persons survived when they jumped out of windows.

D. K. Patton, a vice president of the Economic Development Council and a former management consultant with Dun Bradstreet, was named City Commissioner of Commerce and Industry by Mayor Lindsay, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- A bronze bust of Robert Frost, the poet, by the San Juan sculptor Jose Buscaglia, has been unveiled at the newly opened National Portrait Gallery here. It is the last portrait of Mr. Frost done from life.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- Pantelis Marketakis, a Greek political refugee who last month said he had been tortured in Greece, arrived in London tonight after convincing the Swedish police he was returning voluntarily to his homeland.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 (AP) -- The General Assembly overrode the objections of Britain today and called for ending British administration of Gibraltar by Oct. 1, 1969.

In his first major move affecting the McCall Corporation since he became president of Norton Simon, Inc., David J. Mahoney announced yesterday the formation of a new division, the McCall Publishing Company, and the election of Edward E. Fitzgerald as its president and Chief executive officer.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Army routed St. Francis of Brooklyn, 64-33, today for the unbeaten cadets' fifth victory.
TORONTO, Dec. 18 (AP) -Floyd Smith and Bob Pulford scored 47 seconds apart midway through the final period, sparking the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-2 victory over the Oakland Seals tonight.
Man, who wiped out such creatures as the dodo and the passenger pigeon, may be setting the stage for his own demise -- not with missiles, "but quietly, in the dark."

Ken Bernstein and Jay Millstein, sophomores, combined for 34 points, including 18 in the last eight minutes, to lead Ciy College to a 57-52 basketball victory over C. W. Post last night at the victor's court here.
ATLANTA, Dec. 18 (AP) -The Atlanta Hawks scored their sixth straight victory tonight, beating the Milwaukee Bucks, 122-116.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday a decline of $10-million in earnings for the three months ended Nov. 30. This reduced earnings by 3 cents a share, to 96 cents, despite a new high in revenues, which were $297-million over the like 1967 period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- On the same day that Presidentelect Nixon announced he would retain Richard Helms as the national spy boss, N.B.C. television presented "The Sunshine Patriot," yet another drama about life in the spy game.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -Thieves broke into a Pan American World Airways strongroom at Heathrow Airport here today and stole $250,000 worth of gold dust, diamonds and cash.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Daniel Patrick Moynihan announced today that he was President-elect Richard M. Nixon's choice as White House liaison man for District of Columbia affairs.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 18 -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, the Marxist opposition leader whose party was defeated in the general election Monday, vowed today to bring down a regime that he contended had won by fraud.

VIENNA, Dec. 18 (UPI) -Three members of Rumania's Communist party Executive Committee were released from their posts at a Central Committee meeting held in Bucharest Monday and Tuesday, the official Rumanian press agency reported today.

The Johnson Administration's pressure on Saigon to negotiate with the National Liberation Front for a political settlement in South Vietnam has received strong support from an article in the new issue of Foreign Affairs, written by President-elect Nixon's chief foreign policy adviser, Henry A. Kissinger.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- The suggestion that an independent Arab state be established on the west bank of the Jordan River in territory now occupied by Israel has become a highly charged political issue here.

"There must be a quotation from 'Alice in Wonderland' to cover this," one commodities broker said yesterday. He was commenting about the increase in the prices of gold and silver yesterday following a statement by David Kennedy, recently named Secretary of the Treasury for the incoming Nixon Administration.
BONN, Dec. 18 -- A coincidence of negligence and guilelessness put a copy of the Government's secret list of wanted criminals and criminal suspects into the hands of the East German Communists today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The military-backed regime of President Arthur da Costa e Silva issued a decree today authorizing the seizure of all "illicit" property and other holdings by Brazilians.
A study of police attitudes in New York City has found that patrolmen have a high level of dissatisfaction with their jobs and feel they are misunderstood by the public.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 (UPI) -- A small fire broke out today in the United States mission to the United Nations. A spokesman for the mission, situated across First Avenue from United Nations headquarters, said the fire had broken out in the 12-story building's maintenance section on the third floor and was extinguished in about 15 minutes.

LAS VEGAS, Dec. 18 -- Maj. John Des Jardins, a veteran of 100 bombing missions over North Vietnam in F-105 fighters, gunned the Air Force's newest fighter, an F-111A, down a blackened ribbon of concrete at Nellis Air Force Base, eight miles from this city's gambling strip.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- The father of a Pueblo crew member who is seeking his son's release said here today that he felt he had made "some progress" in talks in East Berlin with diplomats of the North Korean Embassy there.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court refused today to free Air Force Capt. Dale E. Noyd from confinement at Cannon Air Force Base in New Mexico.

Seventy feet beneath Riverside Drive at 138th Street, six men scrambled back and forth in front of a wall of bedrock at the end of a tunnel, jamming sticks of dynamite into about 45 precisely drilled holes.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 18 -Seton Hall made 28 of 36 foul shots en route to a 72-66 Metropolitan Conference victory over Hofstra tonight.
ROME, Dec. 18 -- Pope Paul VI today renewed his appeal to all men, and particularly "exasperated" youth, to observe Jan. 1, 1969, as a world day of rededication to year-round efforts for peace.

TOKYO, Dec. 18 (AP) -Japan's gross national product in fiscal 1967 to March 31 totaled $119.8-billion, ranking third in the non-Communist world. The figure showed a net increase of 13.3 per cent, or 17.5 per cent in normal terms over fiscal 1966.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon have managed what is probably the most civil and reasonable party power shift on record, but some transition strains are starting to show. Here and abroad, it is no longer irrelevant to wonder who is really in charge of the American nation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) The Government's chief prosecutor in the Robert G. Baker trial testified today that the former Senate Democratic secretary's best friend -- not an illegal wiretap -- had led him to information "that Mr. Baker's testimony was a fabrication."

MONTREAL, Dec. 18 (AP) -Yvan Cournoyer's goal with 3 minutes 25 seconds to play capped a rally that earned the Montreal Canadiens a 2-2 tie with the Los Angeles Kings in the National Hockey League tonight.

MIAMI, Dec. 18 (UPI) -Angel Cordero Jr., locked in a duel with Alvaro Pineda for the national riding championship, had three winners today at Tropical Park and raised his total for the year to 329. Cordero won aboard Brawny Lad ($16.60) in the first race,
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Dec. 18 -- Two elephants were killed and five passengers injured today when a train plowed into a herd of elephants 150 miles north of here.

The election of Robert G. Brandely as executve vice president of the East New York Savings Bank was announced yesterday. He joined the bank in 1939 and was elected controller in 1951. He became a trustee in 1966 and the following year was elected senior vice president.

THERE was an unexpected change in last night's program of the Boston Symphony in Philharmonic Hall. Erich Leinsdorf, just recovering from the flu (he had to skip last week's concerts in Boston) opened the evening with Rossini's "L'Italiana in Algeri" Overture instead of the Variations for Orchestra by Arnold Schoenberg.
ATHENS, Dec. 19 -- Three students who set up an underground organization to topple the army-backed regime in Greece were sentenced to jail today by a special military court in Salonika.

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Dec. 13 -- "I've fished for giant tuna and swordfish, but as far as I'm concerned there is more pleasure, more action -- a greater total experience -- in catching sharks," says John G. Casey, biologist and acting director of the Narragansett Marine.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- The General Assembly voted today to set up a special committee of three member states "to investigate Israeli practices affecting the human rights of the population" in Arab territories occupied by Israel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The White House party population was half its usual height and twice its usual size this week.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins said today they were calling Tom Webster from their Oklahoma City farm club for this weekend. Webster, a 20-year-old right wing, is the leading goal scorer in the Central Hockey League with 21 goals and 26 assists for 47 points.
A crude bomb -- some burned rags stuffed into a gasoline tank and containing powder from three shells -- was found yesterday in a police station-wagon outside headquarters on Centre Market Place.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 19 (Agence France-Presse) -- A 12-year-old girl and five boys between 14 and 15 were decorated here last night for military action in the ranks of the National Liberation Front, of Vietcong in South Vietnam.
Clarkson, shocked by Dartmouth College's four goals in the opening period, stormed back over the final two sessions to score a 9-4 victory last night in Madison Square Garden before 4,163 spectators.
Hayden, Stone, Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday a realignment of its top management.
NAPA, Calif., Dec. 19 (UPI) -- A berserk flour mill worker killed six of his seven children today, set his house on fire and killed himself.

The premiere of the musical "Dear World," starring Angela Lansbury, has been indefinitely postponed. The show was originally scheduled to open next Thursday night at the Mark Hellinger Theater. Alexander H. Cohen, the producer, said the critics would be invited "when the show's potential has been realized."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Johnson authorized today a sweeping expansion of United States airline service across the Pacific, one consequence of which is to make Trans World Airlines a round-the-world carrier.
"I understand," the questioner asked Rabbi Samuel I. Porrath," that the T.T.T. Institute is the only one of its kind in the country."

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP) -- May Britt was granted an uncontested divorce from Sammy Davis Jr. today after testifying that in their seven-year marriage: "There was no family life to speak of." The entertainer and the Swedish-born actress were separated Nov. 1, 1967.

An Olympic Airways plane carrying Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and 152 other passengers to Athens was delayed in leaving Kennedy Airport for more than four hours last night while the police searched for a "bomb."
Passengers boarding the Transit Authority's 4,285 buses may have to produce the exact fare -- or a 20-cent token -- to spare the drivers the need of making change and the danger of being robbed.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Daniel (Danny the Red) Sohn-Bendit, a leader of last spring's student revolt in France, said today that the French Government had refused to let him enter the country to visit his brother for Christmas. Mr. Cohn-Bendit is a West German citizen.

The Board of Estimate yesterday authorized the three cable television companies now operating in New York to originate their own public service and "social, cultural and artistic programs." At the same time, the board gave the city's Director of Franchises the power to decide what movies and other programs could be shown on subscribers' screens.
EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Northwestern fought off a second-half rally by Ohio University and went on to defeat the Bobcats, 89-80, tonight despite 43 points by Gerald McKee of the losers.
Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's reorganization of the city government had backfired by making it more difficult for officials to make decisions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- The Defense Department identified today 16 United States servicemen killed in Vietnam. Among them was Specialist 4 Kenneth C. Major Jr. of the Bronx, of the Army.

JAKARTA, Indonesit (UPI) Dec. 19 -- The army said today that Chinese Communists had printed massive amounts of counterfeit Indonesian currency to subvert the economy. The counterfeit rupiahs are stored in Singapore for shipment into Indonesia early next year, the Army said.

PAHUTE MESA, Nev., Dec. 19 -- What may have been the largest atomic bomb ever set off in the United States -- about 50 times as powerful as the World War II Hiroshima bomb -- was detonated 4,600 feet underground here today.
Flu victims who are also forced to combat the cold may be more likely to suffer complications as a result of their illness, Dr. Edward O'Rourke, city Health Commissioer, said yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday dedicated the new home of the 69th Police Precinct station at 9720 Foster Avenue in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. Mr. Lindsay, who arrived by heli copter from City Hall for the late - afternoon ceremony, termed the $1.2-million building an "excellently equipped, modern facility.
Gerard M. Weisberg, City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, and 10 other persons, including two deputy city commissioners, were appointed to the Criminal Court by Mayor Lindsay last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Representatives at the National Liberation Front in Paris today listed the three prisoners to be released as Thomas Nelson Jones, Donald L. Smith, and James W. Brigham. A Pentagon spokesman in Washington said its list of captured showed a Specialist 4 Thomas N. Jones, Pfc. Donald G. Smith and Specialist 4 James W. Brigham Jr.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Shocked that eight policemen had been indicted for abusing Negroes during last summer's racial disturbances, political leaders of this old textile town called a public hearing tomorrow to discuss disciplinary action.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- Dame Gladys Cooper, star of the British stage, was surprised last night when an unscripted butler brought on champagne shortly after the curtain rose at St. Martin's theater.

Salo W. Baron, Jewish historian, will receive the $1,000 literary award given annually by B'nai B'rith to a writer who "makes a positive contribution to contemporary literature by his authentic interpretation of Jewish life and values."
Fifteen men and two women were indicted by a New York County grand jury yesterday as alleged members of a $6.5-million-a-year numbers racket.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic in the week ended Dec. 14 totaled an estimated 14.4 billion ton miles, up 4.7 per cent from the level in the comparable 1967 week.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- Gov. John A. Volpe proposed today a modernization of Massachusetts state government under a Cabinet of 11 major offices.

QUANLOI, South Vietnam, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- American officers said here today that constant air and ground attacks on infiltration routes had seriously affected North Vietnamese efforts to mass troops for a new offensive against Saigon.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Boston College defeated Fairfield University, 81-69, tonight behind the 25 points and 20 rebounds of Terry Driscoll.

TRENTON, Dec. 19 -- Republican leaders today called a special session of the Legislature for Dec. 27 to name a bipartisan committee to investigate charges that some members are "too comfortable with members of organized crime."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee was told today that salesmen in the drug industry and retail pharmacists have been "spreading the false gospel" that medicines sold under a brand name are more reliable than the less-expensive generic preparations.

The election of W. E. Tucker as a director and executive vice president of the Caltex Petroleum Corporation was announced yesterday. He had been vice president in charge of manufacturing and engineering.
MELBOURNE, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Lawn Tennis Association of Australia has found sponsors for the 1968 Davis Cup challenge round with only seven days to spare.

NEWARK, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A three-member Federal District Court has ruled unconstitutuonal a 50-year-old New Jersey law against advocating refusal to enlist in the armed forces or denying aid to the United States Government during wartime.

Norman Thomas, six-time Socialist party candidate for President, died in his sleep yesterday at the Hilaire Farm Nursing Home in Huntington, L. I., where he had been a patient for the last year. He was 84 years old. He lived at 106 Goose Hill Road, Cold Spring Harbor.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A goal by Andre Lacroix with 33 seconds to play gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 5-5 tie with the Minnesota North Stars tonight in a National Hockey League game. The Flyers trailed at one stage, 4-1.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a seat at the record price of $335,000, or $20,000 above the previous high on Dec. 5.
Geoffrey Chaucer suddenly is enjoying a vogue on the stage. Two musicals, inspired by his tales, are scheduled for production here.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- The police in Norton, 20 miles south of here, confirmed today that the plate number on the blue Volvo seized by the F.B.I. in Florida, had been issued in the name of George G. Deacon, 28 years old, who once lived at the Picnic Cove Trailer Park in Norton with his wife, Dorothy.
When the conversation turns to publicly-held agencies and the name of the Forbes Advertising Company comes up, the reaction is usually, "who?" or "what?"
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 19 -- President Arthur da Costa e Silva began today to extend his broad new political powers to the Brazilian economy.
Normally, the Metropolitan Opera is prepared for it respiratory problems.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 19 -- Leaders of Al Fatah, an Arab guerrilla organization, disclosed that a graduating ceremony for a "new and large class" of officers was held at the end of their training period at a secret advance base near the cease-fire line today.

Five teachers, two members of the suspended Ocean Hill-Brownsville school governing board, a parent and a well-known figure in the community were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn grand jury on charges of obstructing governmental administration.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- A 21-member New York State Crime Control Planning Board was created by an executive order of Governor Rockefeller today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Secretary of Commerce-designate Maurice H. Stans said today he hoped the income tax surcharge could be cut from 10 to 5 per cent next July 1 and eliminated entirely a year later.
Earl McCullouch, the Southern California hurdler who passed up the Olympics to play pro football for Detroit, has been voted rookie of the year on offense in the National Football League.
