Pressure on the United States Congress to restrict or prohibit cigarette advertising has mounted since the 1964 report of the Surgeon General's advisory committee linked smoking to lung cancer.

TOKYO. Dec. 19 -- Some 5,000 unionists from prefectures in Kyushu, Japan's southernmost island, participated in a rally in Sasebo today to protest against the visit of the United States nuclear submarine Plunger.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The death of David Jacobs, the lawyer who represented the Beatles and other show business personalities, was recorded as a suicide today at a coroner's inquest
ROME, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- An Italian law under which women could he jailed for adultery while their husbands could be unfaithful with impunity was abolished today as unconstitutional.
A series of musical evenings called "The Free Music Store" will be presented jointly by the New York Shakespeare Festival and station WBAI.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Goals by Eddie Westfall and John Bucvk in the last six minutes gave the Boston Bruins their third straight National Hockey League victory tonight, a 6-4 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings.
The New York City Opera will increase its top ticket price by a dollar, to $6.95, next spring.

The International Harvester Company reported yesterday that its net income rose in the final quarter of its fiscal year to $28,791,000, or $1.02 a share, from $25,524,000, or 91 cents a share, in the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1967.
TORONTO, Dec. 19 -- The Art Gallery of Ontario announced today that Henry Moore, the 70-year-old British sculptor, had promised to give it "a large and representative proportion of his work."
Changes have been made in the top management of Phipps Houses, a foundation established in 1905 that sponsors moderate-rental apartment developments here.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen beat the Long Island Rail Road to the punch yesterday by requesting a 60-day cooling-off period for Presidential fact-finding when a Federal injunction expires next Friday.
Democrats who were questioned yesterday about the prospect of facing Mayor Lindsay next year in another battle for City Hall said they thought they could win, but they were far from certain.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Clem Haskins sank a 30-foot jump shot and added two free throws in the final eight seconds tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 113-111 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks and put the Chicagoans in a fourth-place tie with San Francisco in the National Basketball Association's Western Division.

Senator Jacob K. Javits urged last night that the nations of Western Europe take the initiative in organizing a Middle East organization for economic cooperation, similar to the European Common Market.

GENEVA, Dec. 19 -- An informed American source predicted today that the total number of people in the combat zone of Nigeria and in Biafra who are dependent upon food from outside sources would double before the harvests next summer.
The Federal Reserve pressed on the credit brakes during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday showed.
The Rugoff theater chain yesterday clarified its policy on movie admissions, stating that $2.50 was its top price for tickets.
MIAMI, Dec. 19 -- An attempt to ransom 20-year-old Barbara Jane Mackle for $500,000 failed today when the police accidentally encountered two men who had picked up the money and sent them fleeing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- United States and North Korean negotiators discussed the Pueblo deadlock for nearly five hours at Panmunjon today, the State Department announced. It was the longest meeting in almost 11 months of desultory talks.
For cocoa futures yesterday's trading proved eventful.

PRAGUE -- The primordial problem of what Moscow calls the "Socialist commonwealth" is not the Czechoslovak crisis, but the Soviet crisis. If Russia doesn't adjust its economic and social system to contemporary requirements it must eventually face grave difficulties.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Federal budget for the present fiscal year is expected to show a small surplus, President Johnson reported today.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 19 -- As interest rate competition flared anew in Europe, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today of dangers facing the monetary system unless there is closer economic collaboration by the industrialized nations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19 -- An announcement by the Vietcong today that they had decided to release three American prisoners of war drew guarded reaction from United States officials in Saigon and condemnation from the Premier of South Vietnam.

The International Association of Concert Managers began its 21st annual convention yesterday at the New York Hilton. The aim of the convention is to explore the status and future of the concert field in North America.

Governor Rockefeller and Senator Jacob K. Javitz will be the first two speakers Monday at a hearing on the Medicaid program. The hearing, sponsored by the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, will be held at the United States Custom Court, Duane Street and Foley Square.

Spot checks in Manhattan and Brooklyn early yesterday morning found substantially more policemen patrolling the streets than were evident during a number of earlier checks in which policemen were seen sleeping in their patrol cars.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 -- A national campaign by students to gain the vote for 18-year-olds and to scrap the Electoral College system was announced today by students at the University of the Pacific in Stockton, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The profit margins of manufacturing corporations were down slightly in the third quarter, whether measured as a percentage of gross income or as a percentage of stockholders' equity, the Securities and Exchange Commission, said here today.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 19 -The final countdown began tonight for the launching Saturday of the Apollo 8 astronauts on their planned moon-orbiting voyage.

PRAGUE, Dec. 19 -- The Czechoslovak Government expelled today another Western newsman, the second this week, ordering the immediate departure of Allan Tillier, a correspondent of the magazine Newsweek.
A fencing match between New York University and Cornell, scheduled for tomorrow, was postponed yesterday because of an outbreak of flu on the N.Y.U. team. No new date was set.
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Lloyd Bucher, wife of the skipper of the Pueblo, said today she had received no word of his possible release.

LIKE love and money, you can't have too much safety. Until a year goes by without a single boating mishap or fatality on the water, efforts at encouraging and honoring those who strive hardest toward maintaining pleasure boating as a recreation will undoubtedly keep growing.

KARLSKOGA, Sweden, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- A 3-year-old boy who was clinically dead after having been lost 24 hours in snow-covered forests outside Karlskoga was reported in good condition today. Doctors said that his body temperature was down to 55 degrees and that his heart had stopped when he was found.

The latest meeting of the Central Committee of Czechoslovakia's Communist party accomplished virtually nothing toward solving any of the country's urgent political and economic problems. Instead it pointed up the basic deadlock that prevails among the major forces almost four months after last August's invasion. This impasse helps explain, for example, why in the face of the nation's admittedly serious and deteriorating economic situation the actual measures now announced are so relatively unimportant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee reopened today the question of whether United States Navy destroyers intruded into North Vietnamese territorial waters before they were attacked in the Gulf of Tonkin in August, 1964.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A difference of emphasis emerged today between the New York Stock Exchange and the Investment Company Institute on the top-priority questions that should be examined in the Government's impending special study of institutional investors.
OTTAWA, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau didn't have enough money to pay for the Chinese food he ordered for himself and a "pretty young lady" last night.
SAIGON, South Vietnam Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- United States servicemen killed in Vietnam during the week ended last Saturday totaled 222, a military spokesman said today.

Carlo Maria Giulini started his second week as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic last night at Philharmonic Hall with a program about as different from the first week's as human sensibility can devise.
A spokesman for the United Federation of Teachers yesterday denounced the Board of Education's operating budget estimates for the year beginning July 1 as an "unconscionable hoax."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Johnson, who was hospitalized here yesterday with flu-like symptoms, continued today to show improvement. Doctors said it would be several days before they had test results that would enable them to tell if the President had the flu, and if so, what strain.

GENEVA, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Two Greek Orthodox bishops have resigned "for reasons of health." the church's office here announced today. It said the bishops, Metropolitan Damaskinos and Metropolitan Titus, were the fourth and fifth bishops to resign since Archbishop Hieronymos became Primate of Athens and all Greece.

CARACAS, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- The Government announced today that the 500-ton Cuban fishing boat Alecrin, captured Nov. 20 in Venezuelan waters, had been released. It said 36 of the 38 crewmen aboard also had been liberated.

"The Sudden and Accidental Re-Education of Horse Johnson," in which Jack Klugman is starred, will close after its fifth performance tomorrow night. Douglas Taylor wrote the play, sponsored by four producers, Gene Persson, Orin Lehman, Jay Harnick and Cora Gay Carr.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 19 -- Bob Fauser and Gary Baum scored 24 and 20 points, respectively, tonight to pace Bridgeport University to an 88-75 Northeast Collegiate Basketball League victory over Adelphi University.

Taxi fleet owners, who have long had a cat-and-mouse relationship with their drivers, are trying to gain the upper hand with the installation of a new meter that is expected to divert several million dollars a year from the pockets of dishonest drivers to the accounts of the owners.

The unanimous United Nations call for Soviet-American talks "at an early date" to limit and reduce nuclear missiles opens an opportunity for imaginative statesmanship for the Kosygin, Johnson and Nixon Administrations. Unless the talks are begun before Jan. 20, a delay of many months and perhaps a year or more appears likely -- at possible great costs to the world.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Vietnamese say that the new head of the Vietcong's negotiating team in Paris. Tran Buu Kiem, betrays in his soft and singing accent his origin in the Mekong River delta in his country's South.

MIAMI, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Three persons -- Mr. Deacon, the unidentified older man involved in today's incident, and an unidentified woman -- were being sought by the F.B.I. today in connection with the Mackle kidnapping.
PARIS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- French gold and foreign currency reserves rose $60.6-million in the week ended Dec. 12. This compared with a gain of $75.8-million the previous week.
JERUSALEM. Dec. 19 -- Even before the battle for Jerusalem had ended here in June last year, small monuments to the Israeli soldiers who died in the fighting began to dot the former Jordanian sector.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce C. R. Smith declined today to testify before a Senate subcommittee on his deferral of Maine's application for a free trade zone and promptly was warned that he might be subpoenaed.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 19 (Agence France-Presse) -- Lord Brockway, British Labor peer, said here today that he would seek a Christmas truce in the Nigerian civil war during talks tomorrow with Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the Nigerian chief of state.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Leaders of the Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen ordered the union's 13,000 members today to strike against the nation's railroads at 6 A.M. Jan. 16.

HONG KONG, Dec. 19 -- Peking's implicit reservations about the expanded Paris talks on Vietnam reflected today in a message to expressing the belief that the Vietnamese "People's war" would "win final victory."
Joseph Aitcheson Jr. or Laurel, Md., rode 36 winners in 1968 and captured the steeplechase riding championship for the fifth time, the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association announced yesterday.
PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Mayor Kramer said tonight he had asked a Municipal Court Judge Ervan F. Kushner to take over and reorganize the Police Department.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19 -- The Soviet Union has disclosed that physicists at the world's most powerful atom smasher, south of Moscow, have joined scientists elsewhere in a search for the quark, the hypothetical particle that some have suggested is the elementary building block of all matter.

MEN in helmets, with bayoneted rifles, parade in the church hall. "Prepare to kill!" smashes out the order. "Kill!" And bayonets flash forward to within less than an inch of the audience's front-row stomachs.
C. H. Masland Sons, a manufacturer of rugs and carpets, announced yesterday it would increase prices of most of its grades of carpet by about 4 per cent, effective Jan. 1.

PORT HURON, Mich., Dec. 19 (AP) -- John S. Swainson, 21 years old, son of former Gov. John B. Swainson, pleaded guilty today in Circuit Court to a charge of possessing marijuana. The younger Swainson, of East Detroit, was released without bond by Judge Stanley C. Schlee, pending a presentencing report.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- The main Political Committee voted 96 to 0 tonight to recommend to the General Assembly the establishment of a permanent 42-nation committee to plan world use of the ocean bottom for peaceful purposes only.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 19 -- A substantial spurt in demand for Texas oil led the Texas Railroad Commission today to increase January production by 84,388 barrels a day over the latest estimates of actual production.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 19 -- St. Peter's College defeated Jacksonville University, 92-80, tonight at Jersey City Armory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- John W. Sweeterman, publisher of The Washington Post, has been given the additional title of vice chairman of the board of The Washington Post Company.
Gene Roberts, chief of The New York Times bureau in Saigon, was named yesterday as the newspaper's national news director.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon is attempting to shield his new Administration against any possible conflicts of interest.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Bob Bissell, assistant trainer for the New Orleans Saints of the National Football League, has been hired as football trainer for West Virginia University. Bissell was trainer for Eastern Illinois University from 1966 to 1968, when he joined the Saints.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 19 (UPI) -- The Minnesota Pipers traded Steve Chubin, a guard, and a high draft choice to the Indiana Pacers today for Mike Lewis, 6-foot-7-inch forward.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 19 -- Zambians voted today in the nation's first postindependence general election. Indications were that the turnout had been extremely heavy and that there were no serious disturbances.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Intelsat 3, the new commercial communications satellite, sped through space today toward a lofty position where it will more than double trans-Atlantic satellite telephone and television channels.
A small Swiss bank pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court here to an indictment that charged violation of the margin requirements of the Federal Reserve Bank.
A woman patient was found dead at 9:45 A.M. yesterday after an ambulance and a passenger car collided at Rutgers and Madison Streets on the Lower East Side. Three men and a policeman were injured.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Government sources said here today that a top-level meeting of the Soviet-bloc Warsaw Pact military alliance, scheduled for this month, had been postponed until February. The postponement, it was said, was decided upon to give the Communist leaders an opportunity to assess the policies of the Nixon administration and of a federal government to take power in Czechoslovakia on Jan. 1

IRVINGTON N. J., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Irvington Draft Board disclosed today that it had denied an appeal by Mark Rudd, who was expelled from Columbia University for leading the student rebellion there last spring, for a 2-A occupational deferment as a "revolutionist."

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to build a basic oxygen steelmaking unit adjacent to its Edgar Thompson works in Braddock, Pa. Estimated cost of the projects ranges from $35-million to $40-million.
A special Federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted four lawyers yesterday on charges of defrauding the Small Business Administration of $250,000.
A tentative agreement in the strike of fuel oil deliverers here was announced last night by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board.
TARBORO, N. C., Dec. 19 (AP) -- A 17-year-old Rocky Mount girl was sentenced to death today in Edgecombe County Superior Court.
ATLANTA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Directors of Atlanta International Raceway and the Michigan International Speedway have agreed to a merger, effective with the 1969 season.

GENEVA, Dec. 19 -- The Swiss Government announced today that it would consider nationalizing the arms industry as a result of disclosures that Swiss-made guns and munitions had been illegally shipped to Nigeria.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Clark Graebner, determined to win back a spot on the United States Davis Cup tennis team, improved his hopes today by downing Charlie Pasarell, 7-5, 12-10. It was a pressure-packed practice match in which the two teammates were graded for their performances.
TEL AVIV, Friday, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Israeli jets bombed guerrilla posts today after a bazooka attack on an Israeli mobile patrol in the northern sector of the Jordan valley.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Shortly before 3 P.M. today, Alfonso Arenales, a political officer on the State Department's Cuba desk, received a phone call from Henry Taylor, the department's man in Miami, who gave him what is becoming a familiar message.
The Board of Estimate unanimously overrode the opposition of real estate developers yesterday and conferred landmark status on the 18 houses of Schermerhorn Row.

HONG KONG, Dec. 19 -- The announcement today that the Vietcong plan to release at least three prisons in Tayninh Province was ambiguous but left open the possibility that other American captives and South Vietnamese prisoners might also be released in other areas.

News that President - elect Nixon anticipates no change in position on the price of gold put gold shares in reverse in early dealings on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. However, renewed buying by speculators led to further gains toward the close.
The New York Jets ended their longest vacation in five months yesterday and began the countdown for the American Football League's championship game by working out in Shea Stadium.
THE Winter Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today at the New York Hilton.

The owners, or their representatives, of the 24 major league baseball teams will gather in Chicago today, determined to choose a new commissioner of baseball and to reorganize his office. Many have vowed to keep the meeting going until agreement is reached.

PUT an elephant's foot in an antiques shop on Third Avenue, and five years from now there's no telling what will have happened. Pachyderm hoofs may be doubling as hassocks or bases for cocktail tables, or the same stuffed skin may stand gathering dust in the same Third Avenue antiques shop.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Governor Rockefeller today declared half-day holidays for state employes on the days before Christmas and New Year's Day. Skeleton forces will be maintained to provide essential services.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 19 -- Israel's first heart transplant patient, Itzhak Sulam, died this morning. He lived two weeks after his operation, performed at Beilinson Hospital, in nearby Petah Tikvah, but had never regained consciousness.

Joseph Eger had an excellent idea last night in launching his new orchestra, the Symphony of New York. With a gesture quite flamboyant enough to please the arch-Romantic Hector Berlioz himself, Mr. Eger closed his first program with excerpts from Berlioz's "Lelio" and the "Symphonie Fantastique."

Reginia Resnik, being a determined woman, sang her first Carmen of the season at the Metropolitan Opera last night despite an attack of the flu. As Rudolf Bing put it, when he announced Miss Resnik's condition from the stage just before the performance began, it was a nervy and very professional thing to do.

ROME, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- The Italian airline Alitalia announced tonight the cancellation of 27 international flights during the next two days because of a planned 24-hour strike tomorrow by its ground staff.
Erv Levin scored 21 points last night to lead Lehman College to its sixth victory in eight outings, 74-50, over Marist at the winner's Bronx gym.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19 -- The city's grand jury indicted a former Republican candidate today for allegedly attempting to buy Republican votes for the election in January in the state Legislature for a successor to Gov. Spiro T. Agnew.
AYER, Mass., Dec. 19 -- An Army lieutenant who was AWOL and who also had applied for conscientious objector status has been shipped to Vietnam from the Fort Devens stockade near here.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Doug Mohns and Bob Schmautz scored third-period goals for Chicago tonight as the Black Hawks battled to a 2-0 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Salaries of members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff may be increased to $50,000 a year if a proposal drafted at the Pentagon is approved by the executive branch and Congress. Other officers and enlisted men would also get raises.
Two leaders of last month's mental hospital strike were ordered yesterday to be released from jail at noon Tuesday so they can spend Christmas with their children.

The city's first Model Cities construction began yesterday. in the East New York section of Brooklyn, where Mayor Lindsay, wearing a yellow helmet and carrying a sledge hammer tied with a red ribbon, broke down the doors of a vacant apartment house scheduled for rehabilitation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Seven South Vietnamese civilians were killed today in three terrorist grenade incidents in the Saigon area. One explosion, in which three women died occurred two blocks from the biggest United States post exchange in Saigon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, branded Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam a "mini-dictator" and a "fraud" tonight.
MONTICELLO, N. Y.. Dec. 19 -- Ever since skiing blossomed in this busy Sullivan County country a few decades ago, the emphasis always has been on the beginner. And, it's been for good reason.

ALTHOUGH football coaches don't always agree with the description, football officials are human. Because fallibility is an integral part of their heritage, the whistle-tooters do make mistakes. But the amazing part of it is that they err so infrequently. Despite the fact that they are called upon for hundreds of split-second decisions, perceptions and hairline calls in every game, they are correct somewhere between 99 and 100 per cent of the time.

At the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, Carl. H. Huebner has been appointed senior vice president, Roland Maycock has been advanced to senior vice president and general counsel and Otto J. Fleig has been named vice president and treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- A private organization to fight hunger and malnutrition in the United States was formed today. It pledged to "monitor" Government programs to make sure that the poor got fed.
TOKYO, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- The United States has accepted Japan's proposal to hold talks here Dec. 27-28 on easing Japanese import curbs, the Foreign Ministry said today.
A "changing of the guard" at the Scott Paper Company and the Eastman Kodak Company was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The price of gold fell back in European markets today following overnight reports that President-elect Nixon did not anticipate a change in the $35 official gold price.
James J. Hackett and James W. Harrell have been named executive vice presidents of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., a leading, diversified textiles producer.

PARIS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Marielle Goitschel did a slalom with her car in the courtyard of the Elysee Palace today and then went in to join 25 other Olympic medal winners for lunch with President Charles de Gaulle.
A New York Yacht Club cruise itinerary that had one less race than usual, but remained about the same in total mileage, was made public at the club's annual meeting last night.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
In fairly heavy trading, stocks on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department's final report of the year today estimated the 1968 production of corn for grain at 4,374,840,000 bushels.

OTTAWA, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press) -- External Affairs Minister Mitchell Sharp told the House of Commons today that the Government intends to ratify the treaty barring the spread of nuclear weapons before the end of the year.

Prices of Treasury securities, pushed down partly by the Federal Reserve, dropped sharply yesterday.

The tentative agreement reached in the fuel-oil delivery strike last evening will bring cold comfort to residents of this city unless the union membership comes to its senses and ratifies the contract worked out by its leadership. WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Wilbur J. Cohen, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today announced two Federal grants that he said virtually completed allocation of about $15-million in Federal funds for the nation's rat control program.

Only one major issue separated the waterfront management and longshoremen in their contract talks last night, and although mediation efforts were continuing it appeared virtually certain that dockers would resume their strike tonight.

Miss Sophie Jane Engelhard was presented last evening at a dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Engelhard of Far Hills, N. J., in the Rainbow Room. The debutante and her mother received 400 guests.

MIAMI, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Angel Cordero Jr. was shut out at Tropical Park today, leaving his total winners for the year at 329 and giving Alvaro Pineda a chance to close the gap in the battle for the 1968 jockey championship.

WHILE the more flamboyant conglomerates, covering a broad range of activities, ride the wings of speculative enthusiasm, the Citizens Utilities Company shows how an unlisted company that plods along unspectacularly can grow steadily as a congeneric company.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., the conglomerate concern that is battling with the Atlantic Richfield Oil Company for control of the Sinclair Oil Company, confirmed yesterday it had acquired an interest exceeding 10 per cent in the outstanding common stock of Arthur G. McKee Co.

Four persons were killed late last night when their car, struck broadside at an intersection in the Bronx, ripped through a restraining fence, plunged 25 feet onto the tracks of the Penn-Central Railroad and exploded in a ball of fire.

The stock market went on a wild roller-coaster ride yesterday.
Brooklyn College, led by Al Litman, Mel Goldstein and Dave Gershon who scored a total of 61 points, defeated Paterson State, 101-92, last night at the Kingsmen's gym.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The United States warned North Vietnam today that an attack on Saigon by Communist ground forces might have serious consequences. The warning hinted at the possibility of an indefinite delay in meaningful peace talks and a resumption of bombing in North Vietnam.
SAN JUAN, P.R. Dec. 19 -- Governor-elect Luis A. Ferre named 10 Cabinet members today to his government, which takes power Jan. 2.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Ron Perry came back to badger his former teammates on the Miami Floridian team tonight as the guard now playing for New York scored 24 points in leading the Nets to 119-110 victory in the American Basketball Association.

IGUALA, Mexico, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A bus bound for Acapulco plunged into a 900-foot ravine today. The police reported that 25 of the 46 passengers were killed. The bus left the road when it swerved to avoid hitting a speeding car, the authorities said.
The police barricades in front of Public School 39, at 216 East 126th Street in East Harlem, have been dismantled and stacked next to the dingy tenements that surround the school.

The engagement of the Minnesota Theater Company, which opened Tuesday night at the Billy Rose Theater, has been extended a week to Jan. 11. The troupe is giving repertory performances of "The House of Atreus" and "The Resistible Rise of Arturo UI."

LONDON, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- Britain's automobile exports in 1968 will total a record 790,000, the Minister of Technology Anthony Wedgwood Benn, forecast in Parliament tonight. He said this would be 12.5 per cent more than in the previous highest year 1964.

Columbia University has opened a major campaign to attain first rank in teaching and research in the life sciences, an area in which it has lagged in recent years.

An Atlanta man filed a Federal court suit here yesterday against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., contending the brokerage firm relied on "false reports" in recommending stock in which he invested heavily and apparently lost money.

"The Car Lover," a short play by Bruce Jay Friedman, author of "Scuba Duba," has been added to the one-act play program Elaine May is directing at Stage 73, 321 East 73d Street. Martin Duberman will be represented by "History" and Terrence McNally by "Next."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- Army troops were called back into Caracas today for the first time since the election Dec. 1, following two guerrilla attacks in the area.

The Eastman Kodak Company has leased 200,000 square feet of office space, 11 floors, in the 45-story Interchemical Building, which is being completed at 1133 Avenue of the Americas, on the west side of the avenue between 43d and 44th Streets.
The creation of a new corporate position -- vice president of advertising and sales promotion -- was announced by Trans World Airlines. Lawrence V. Stapleton was elected to the post.

Nearing the close of its second week, the 57th annual appeal for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund exceeded the half-million-dollar mark yesterday, with gifts running almost $68,000 ahead of the record 1967-68 Christmastime appeal.
Kenneth Swensen of Bayside and Sandy Schwartz of Lincoln reached the final of the Public High Schools indoor tennis championships yesterday.
Vince Lombardi, general manager of the Green Bay Packers, was named today to receive the New York Catholic Youth Organization's John V. Mara Memorial Sportsman of the Year Award.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Mild earth tremors jarred the cities of Peshawar, Rawalpindi and Lahore today. No loss of life or property damage was reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the week ended Dec. 14 were an estimated $1,295-billion, an increase of 8 per cent above the $1,195-billion for the corresponding sales period last year.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 19 (Agence France-Presse) -- At the end of November, new immigrants to Rhodesia this year numbered 11,164, P. K. van der Byl, Minister of Information, Immigration and Tourism, said tonight.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The College of the Virgin Islands has received the final $633,000 of a $2-million pledge from U.S. industrialist Henry H. Reichhold, a United States industrialist, a college spokesman announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Nearly all of the royal family escorted Queen Elizabeth II when she went to the Imperial War Museum Thursday night for a preview of the television film "The Life and Times of Admiral the Earl Mountbatten."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Niagara College, led by Calvin Murphy's 31 points, waged a see-saw battle with Bowling Green 100-92, tonight at the Cleveland Arena.

MARSEILLE, France, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Debbie Meyer, America's Olympic swim queen, won the women's 200-meter free-style and 50-meter butterfly events tonight in an international meet here.

Following are highlights in the flight plan of the Apollo 8 spacecraft, scheduled to be launched at Cape Kennedy today. The plan is subject to change at any time, depending on how the flight progresses. Times are Eastern standard.
Mrs. Theodora A. Randolph of Middleburg, Va., owner of Bon Nouvel, top steeplechase horse in the United States, during 1968, was the leading money-winning owner of jumpers, with earnings of $59,919.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Four Plainfield Negroes were acquitted early today in the fatal beating of a policeman during that city's 1967 racial disorder. The jury delayed verdicts on six other defendants in the case.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- A leading Soviet commentator, Yuri Zhukov, said today in the Communist party newspaper Pravda that elections in West Berlin would aggravate tension in Central Europe.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Dec. 20 -- Central Connecticut topped C. W. Post, 62-55, in a North-East Basketball League game tonight. Central's Howie Dickenman led the scorers with 22 points. Central Connecticut has a 4-2 over-all won-lost record and 2-1 in the league.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- A Government commission recommended today that the Kennedy silver half-dollars be replaced with coins of "sandwiched" metal alloys similar to the new issues of dimes and quarters.

SASEBO, Japan, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- The United States submarine Plunger tonight ended a three - day visit here. The 3,750-ton submarine is the first nuclear powered warship to visit Japan since a dispute over radiation leaks from another submarine seven months ago.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- A 17-year-old youth, told by a judge that "when you break the law you must pay the penalty," was lashed in court today 20 times on his bare back with a leather whip.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 21 -- Two United States jets dodged a hail of antiaircraft fire in North Vietnam Thursday, then dived against the guns with bombs.
The City University requested a $271-million operations budget yesterday for the coming fiscal year, an increase of $65-million over the current year.
101 MASTERPIECES OF MUSIC AND THEIR COMPOSERS. By Martin Bookspan. 511 pages. Doubleday. $7.95.

In an appearance before the City Planning Commission the other day Bronx Borough President Badillo rightly protested the distortion of a program that he, along with Manhattan Borough President Sutton, had proposed earlier. It is a distortion that risks new fiscal problems for the city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Held without a free throw for 35 minutes, Georgetown University converted five to defeat previously unbeaten Manhattan College, 63-57, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Army adopted today stiffer safety measures for testing lethal nerve gases and other persistent chemical agents at its Utah proving ground.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A soldier who left his "sanctuary" to join a demonstration here was arrested yesterday as protesters handed out leaflets advertising his presence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Louis Martin has resigned as deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee to return to his former position as an executive of Sengstacke Publications, publisher of the Chicago Defender. His resignation was announced yesterday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 20 -- An order was served today on Mohammad Asghar Khan to appear before a Dacca court Jan. 4, to answer a charge that last Friday he violated a Government order prohibiting the assembly of more than five persons in a public place.
Frank Aikman Jr., president of the Long Island Rail Road, yesterday rejected as untrue the charge that he was the "puppet" of Dr. William J. Ronan, Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman.

This week, when Harold A. Bilby left his office at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, he took with him into semi-retirement memories of how he helped rescue a Long Island bank, his part in seizing a Japanese restaurant in Brooklyn and his role in the development of the system of routing symbols used on checks.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon yesterday named Charles W. Yost, a 61-year-old retired career diplomat, as chief United States representative at the United Nations.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- Pope Paul VI tonight delivered a Christmas message of deep pessimism over the temporal prospects ofman, urging a renewal of Christianity as "the true and the highest hope" for salvation.

A zippered briefcase containing $22,900 in cash, lost in a snowbank near 55 West 14th Street and found by three mailmen on a postal truck, was returned intact yesterday to Kenneth Clark, a 41-year-old American actor who has appeared in many Italian-produced films.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Temple University won the first game of the New Mexico Lobo Invitation college basketball tournament tonight, defeating Fordham, 72-60.
CAMDEN, N. J. Dec. 20 (AP) -- An irate father charged in a $250,000 damage suit today that Santa Claus uttered obscene remarks to his 5-year-old son in a taped telephone conversation last year.

BLAUVELT, N. Y., Dec. 20 -Officers of the Dominican College of Blauvelt announced plans today for a $1.5-million cultural resources building that will have a library with a capacity of 100,000 volumes, administrative offices and a 1,200-seat Little Theater.

HOUSTON, Dec. 20 -- Despite ambitious hopes for a lunar orbital flight by Apollo 8, an almost infinite number of things could go wrong with the mission, and the spacecraft might get no nearer to the moon than the shores of Florida.

MIAMI, Dec. 20 -- The F.B.I. said tonight that Gary Steven Krist, charged in the Mackle kidnapping, escaped from a California state prison in November, 1966, while serving a term for automobile theft.

Producing concert versions of opera on a shoestring budget, presumably to give young singers a chance, is one of the recurring dreams of musical life in this city. The Ruffino Opera Association "is a nonprofit educational association set up to benefit gifted young artists and present them to a public in a professional atmosphere."

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 20 -- An aide to a State Senate crime committee who had charged that an Assembly committee chairman told her he was under "pressure" from a Mafia leader told her story tonight to a representative of the State Attorney General's office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -The next Secretary of Agriculture said today that some Federal programs would be necessary to keep farm production in line with domestic and foreign demand and to remedy the "income gap" for farmers.

The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory hopes to photograph the Apollo 8 spacecraft repeatedly with its giant astronomical tracking cameras until the craft has flown perhaps two-thirds of the way to the moon.
For a man who once was accustomed to figuring in terms of millions of men and millions of votes, yesterday was a time for considering the prospects of only one man.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Doctors at the Cleveland Clinic said today Ohio's second and the world's 100th heart transplant patient had made a "fantastic" recovery.
Seventy-nine persons were killed in traffic accidents here last month, compared with 51 in November, 1967, the Police Department said yesterday. This was a rise of 55 per cent.
More than 100 people were made homeless last night when a four-alarm fire swept through three buildings on 138th Street between Lenox and Seventh Avenues.
Winter officially arrived today under calamitous conditions for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who are unfortunate enough to live in oil-heated buildings.
ATHENS, Dec. 20 -- A 35-year-old Greek who says he fled from kidnappers who had forced him to testify that he was tortured by the Greek regime, flew back to Athens tonight.
CAN American silver by a Rhode Island counter-feiter command prices equal to those paid for work by a patriot immortalized by Longfellow?

THE most pertinent seasonal reference for an art column appearing in New York the Saturday before Christmas is probably that sales in the galleries have been lively. "I don't know where all the money comes from," one dealer said, in a state of blissful fatigue.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced late yesterday that at the request of the Mates Investment Fund, Inc., it had temporarily suspended the right of the mutual fund's shareholders to cash in their shares.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal appeals court is to view some news films Monday, then sit Tuesday to hear the appeal of Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatrician, convicted with three others on charges of conspiring to counsel young men to evade the draft.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Colts have been established as an 11-point favorite over the Minnesota Vikings in the Western Conference title game Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Justice Department today charged nine members of the South Carolina Highway Patrol with willfully shooting into a group of Negro students during racial disturbances in Orangeburg, S. C., last February.
BRUSSELS, Saturday, Dec. 21 -- Ministers of the six-nation European Atomic Energy Community provided a last-minute rescue operation this morning for the beleaguered agency.

Don Shula, whose Baltimore Colts experienced a year of frustration in 1967 but came back to win the National Football League's Coastal Division title this season, was named yesterday as the United Press International's National Football League coach of the year for 1968.
JERUSLAEM, Dec. 20 -- Official sources acknowledged today that Israeli jet planes were being used regularly, as few as one or two at a time, to reply to border actions by Arab terrorists.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 20 -- After 156 days of relatively comfortable captivity in Cambodia, 11 American servicemen left Pnompenh today and passed through here en route home for Christmas. The men are the crew of a supply boat that was captured last July 17 on the Mekong River when it strayed into Cambodia.
A $35-million take-over battle for the Tropical Gas Company began to take shape in Tulsa, Okla., yesterday.

PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer cast the tie-breaking vote today to block the suspension of eight Paterson policemen who had been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the civil rights of Negroes.

At three o'clock on the afternoon of July 12, 1954, Joseph Gianani placed a pillow on the sill of his tenement window and began his daily contemplation of Third Avenue. It was his favorite hour. All night he dug for Con Edison.

A one-million-share block of Pan American World Airways, Inc., was traded yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, raising speculation on Wall Street that an attempt to take over the largest international airline might be under way.
HOUSTON, Dec. 20 -- Why is the United States about to hurl three of its brave citizens toward the moon?
The Apollo voyage to the moon represents a new and exciting plateau in the ancient art of navigation.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Prime Minister Wilson hoped to make a dramatic mission during the Christmas holidays to Lagos to arrange a cease-fire in Nigeria's civil war, but, it was disclosed today, African leaders rejected the plan as a stunt.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- The United States delegation here will for the first time in its history be headed by a highly trained professional diplomat when Charles W. Yost takes over the post under the Nixon Administration.

Statistics compiled by the City's Health Department yesterday showed that the rate of death here last week rose to a point higher than the highest level reached during the last major flu outbreak in 1957.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP) -- One person was killed and another injured today when a storage tank ruptured and sent tons of molasses cascading over a two-block area. The name of the victim ws not learned immediately.
Those high-speed express trains to Washington, long promised but long delayed by a series of technological snags, will start operating on a limited basis Jan. 16.

MIAMI, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Muhammad Ali says jail is teaching him to appreciate the value of a dollar. The deposed heavyweight champion is serving a 10-day sentence for a 1967 traffic violation, working as a trusty in the kitchen of the Dade County Jail.
WARSAW, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Polish Government announced several high-level changes today, including the appointment of Stefan Jedrychowski as Foreign Minister.
Led by the shooting of Ray Hodge and the rebounding and scoring of Oliver Featherston, Wagner's high-scoring Sea Hawks crushed Elizabethtown, 114-83, before 800 fans at Sutter Gymnasium last night.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Pounding a table, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi accused students of endangering freedom in their country.
Tickets for the 18th week of the Metropolitan Opera season will go on sale tomorrow at noon at the box office. Casts and conductors are as follows:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Thomas P. Raimondi won a 10-day postponement today in his arraignment on a charge of trying to bribe a State Senator to deliver Republican votes in the upcoming legislative election of a Governor.
The moon -- now the target of man's highest transports -- has long been the coolest inspiration of his spiritual and poetic raptures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- If their outlets could be seen from above, building lots with a patented shape would look like champagne glasses laid on their sides. The stem of one is next to the bowl of the adjoining lot.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Government officials said today that a Federal "strike force" to combat organized crime would be sent to Newark next month.

Concert managers in New York, sometimes called the "music capital of the world," are using a great deal of red ink this season. Ticket sales are down, often drastically, from last season. While few persons with official knowledge will comment publicly, the decline in audiences is privately estimated at between 7 and 40 per cent.

LONDON -- The Royal Air Force Ten Ton Club, open to those who have been at the controls of an aircraft flying at 1,000 miles an hour, is being closed to new members because it is becoming too large; there are nearly 1,300 members.

Ronald Ziegler, Mr. Nixon's press spokesman, said in New York that the President-elect planned to spend summer holidays in California and winter holidays at Key Biscayne during his years in the White House. Mr. Ziegler said he did not know what disposition would be made of Mr. Nixon's cooperative apartment at 810 Fifth Avenue.
The following are among the special musical programs arranged by the churches of the city for tomorrow, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day:

OFFHAND I can think of few play titles less liable to attract me to a theater than that of the musical "Dames at Sea," which opened last night at the Bouwerie Lane Theater. And when I noted it was coyly subtitled "the new-30's musical" I remembered that we were now living in the 60's and felt slightly, mildly squeamish.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 20 -- Barry White scored 27 points and snared 18 rebounds in leading Hofstra to a 92-70 Middle Atlantic Conference victory over West Chester State tonight.
MIAMI, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- A Philadelphia saleswomen said today the man who hijacked an Eastern Air Lines DC-8 to Cuba while cradling a little girl in his lap was her former husband.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The sudden impulse of a group of young New York businessmen and a phone call across half the world in the middle of the night has saved next week's Davis Cup challenge round in tennis from financial distress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Treasury bill rate rose to historic highs at today's auction from Monday's levels, the Treasury disclosed today.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 20 (Agence France-Presse) -- Emperor Haile Selassie appealed today to both sides in the Nigerian civil war to observe a one-week truce during the Christmas and Moslem Id al Fitri holidays, it was officially announced here.
The Board of Regents and Governor Rockkefeller have decided to undertake a "major examination" of the quality, cost and financing of the state's public school system.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- North Vietnamese and Vietcong representatives, genially mingling with Western newsmen at a reception tonight, said they expected the talks here to continue despite a harsh exchange of charges and countercharges yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal Heart Institute lost its fourth transplant patient in less then three weeks yesterday when the body of Aldo Martine, 43, of Port Colborne, Ont., rejected a transplanted heart given him Nov. 12.
ROME, Dec. 20 -- A high school student was injured today in a clash with policemen during a demonstration called to protest proposed school reforms.

The election of John J. Sweeney as president of the Guild of Catholic Lawyers of the Archdiocese of New York was announced Thursday. Mr. Sweeney is a partner in the law firm of Sweeney, O'Donoghue Cunningham here.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Twenty-one students were arrested and seven policemen slightly injured today in recurring violence at Calumet High School on the South Side.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Baltimore Bullets broke loose from a 30-27 first-quarter advantage to crush the Chicago Bulls, 125-102, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Soviet Union orbited the 261st in its Cosmos series of earth satellites today, Tass, the official press agency, reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department forecast today that production of winter wheat to be harvested next year will drop to 1,115,465,000 bushels, a decrease of 9 per cent from the 1968 record crop.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 20 -- Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, head of the federal Nigerian Government, today ordered a two-day Christmas truce in the 18-month civil war with secessionist Biafra.

Discussing with newsmen yesterday his selection of Charles W. Yost as the new United States Representative to the United Nations, President-elect Richard M. Nixon gave a candid glimpse of the process of putting together an administration.

Stanley L. Juroff was appointed yesterday director of corporate services at Crowell Collier and Macmillan, Inc. Mr. Juroff had been associated with The New York Times for more than 20 years, most recently as assistant manager of general services.

TOMS RIVER, N. J., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A woman and two of her children were killed and a third child injured critically today when fire swept their two-story frame house here. Killed were Mrs. John Murphy, 38 years old, and her children, Elaine, 6, and John Jr., 3. Another daughter, Seery Ann, 7, was listed in critical condition.

The 22-year-old son of the owner of a cafeteria in the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn was shot and killed yesterday during an attempted holdup, the police reported. The victim, Santos Morales of 355 East 4th Street, Brooklyn, was at the counter when a gunman entered and demanded money.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Only 24 hours after a United States thermonuclear blast that shook the Nevada desert, the General Assembly unanimously asked today for a suspension of all nuclear tests.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The 1969 Professional Golfers' Association championship, which had been canceled during a dispute with the breakaway touring pros, was reinstated today by the P.G.A.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 20 -Eldridge Cleaver, the fugitive Black Panther leader, must appear in court here Monday or cost his supporters $50,000.

The landmark designation affirmed by the city for Schermerhorn Row did more than save the South Street Seaport preservation project and the Brooklyn Bridge Southeast urban renewal plan from destruction by speculators. The prompt action by the Board of Estimate raises hope that things are changing in New York.
THE trans-Pacific airline-route decision left Wall Street with a great sense of frustration and a sense of waiting for the other shoe to drop.
The American Stock Exchange had a heavy trading day yesterday, with more than 9,603,000 shares changing hands. It was the eighth heaviest day of trading this year.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 20 -- King Hussein, in an impassioned address on the Moslem feast of Id al Fitr, appealed last night to the Arab states for more aid because he had decided to devote all the funds he now received from the Arab world to strengthen his armed forces.

The Waterfront Commission announced yesterday the suspension of four longshoremen's registrations for gambling activities. Those suspended were Frank Guzzolina, Port Reading, N. J.; Calbin McCoy, Newark, and John A. Bolino and Amadeo Camera, both of Brooklyn.
Clarkson's Golden Knights, the pretournament favorite, won the eighth annual Holiday Festival last night in Madison Square Garden by beating Yale's Ivy League squad, 9-3.

The Lindsay administration urged the City Council yesterday to postpone action on bills extending rent control until the completion of a study of complaints of soaring rents and until the real estate industry submits plans for self-regulation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- New orders for durable goods dipped in November after their big jump in October, but they remained at a high level, the Commerce Department reported today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 20 -- The military regime of President Arthur da Costa e Silva eased today the complete censorship it imposed on Brazil a week ago.

Wally Lemm, coach of the Houston Oilers, was named yesterday as coach of the Eastern squad for the annual East-West American Football League All-Star game to be played Jan. 19 at Jacksonville, Fla. Lemm's Oilers finished second in the eastern division of the A.F.L. this season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -President Johnson left his sick bed today and spent some time working on official papers at a table in his room.

THE days of the respectable Republican cloth coat may be gone forever. Yesterday Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, wife of the President-elect, added a Persian lamb coat to a closet that already contained a luxurious blond mink, and Tricia and Julie Nixon got what apparently were their first real fur coats.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 20 -- Negotiations between the United States and North Korea over the release of the Pueblo crew remain cloaked in a thick mantle of secrecy, although reports continued today that the talks were nearing a climax.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Sweeping both of their matches today, Nichols School of Buffalo and the University of Toronto School earned qualifying berths in tomorrow's final competition at the 21st annual Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 10 -- President Kenneth Kaunda was officially declared re-elected today.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 20 -- Ohio State's football squad arrived today as snow flurried in the hills above the Rose Bowl where the Buckeyes meet Southern California on New Year's Day.

Every day in the past week, frozen orange juice futures jumped the 3-cents-a-pound daily limit. The buying pressure came mainly from speculators convinced that the recent cold spell in Florida would cut the crop.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Forbes Burnham's People's National Congress, polled 60,353 more votes than Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan's People's Progressive party in Monday's election, official returns showed today.

MIAMI, Dec. 20 -- Barbara Jane Mackle, who was kidnapped Tuesday and buried in a box for 80 hours, was found in a Georgia woodland today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation after her parents paid $500,000 ransom, J. Edgar Hoover, F.B.I. director, said tonight.

The Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, largest of the mass presentation parties here, was held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Only 74 of the 85 debutantes expected showed up for the presentation ceremony in the hotel's Grand Ballroom, the other 11 have fallen victim to the flu.

Robert F. Six, president of Continental Airlines, told the line's employes yesterday that the company was "profoundly aware of the responsibility entrusted to it" by the decision and pledged "every effort to showing ourselves worthy of the confidence."
All but one of the 16 men whom Mayor Lindsay appointed to Criminal or Family Court benches were approved by the New York Bar Association's judiciary committee.
BERLIN, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- East Germany said today that West Germany's plan to elect its next president in West Berlin would be "a deliberate, serious provocation."
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The nation's automobile plants turned out fewer cars this week as the industry limited its production schedule to a five-day week.

SOME of the finer points of baseball have yet to be clarified: Is a pitcher an "independent contractor," as George Meany has maintained, or is he an employe, and are managers and coaches to be regarded as "supervisors" and thus part of management? Once these matters are brushed back, the national pastime will be able to move on to a broader question: Will there be any games next season?

PRAGUE, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Stanislav Razl, Czechoslovak Minister of Chemical Industries, was asked today by the Czech National Council to form the Government of the new Czech Socialist Republic, which comes into being Jan. 1.

The Fuller Brush Company, which started 55 years ago in a Somerville, Mass., basement and made the door-to-door salesman's smile and knock part of the American way of life, yesterday became a subsidiary of Consolidated Foods Corporation.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation's sales subsidiary moved yesterday to increase prices for aluminum electrical conductor. It indicated it meant business this time.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 -- A fist fight marred efforts today of a group of conservative San Fernando Valley State College students to examine "the causes of campus violence."

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Two former Nazi officials were convicted today of helping to send 100,000 mentally and physically handicapped persons to what the Nazis termed "mercy killing'' deaths.
The London Stock Exchange closed slightly firmer yesterday. Industrial leaders were generally a little higher. Oils and banks also turned firmer.

Carmine G. De Sapio was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus and to shake down Consolidated Edison for construction contracts.

The Hanna Mining Company said yesterday that it had received word that the Justice Department had decided against further appeal of its civil action against the company. That would bring to a close an action challenging the accounting principles followed in contracts under which Hanna supplied nickel to the Government in the Korean war stockpiling program, Hanna said.

MUNICH, West Germany, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- A 30-year-old man who the police believe was trying to kill himself with gas caused an explosion today that killed him, injured 10 others and wrecked a four-story building.
Mr. and Mrs. C. Francis Smithers of 2 Riverview Terrace and Barboursville, Va., gave a dinner dance last night at the St. Regis Sheraton Roof to honor their daughter, Miss Mary Vey Smithers.

ATHENS, Dec. 20 -- The Greek regime empowered the Justice Ministry today to reprieve Alexandros Panaghoulis, the army deserter who received two death sentences last month in his abortive attempt to kill Premier George Papadopoulos.
We hope that the Scrooges in Congress will at this season take note of other peoples' generosity in providing assistance to the poorer countries of the world.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Miami of Florida played clutch basketball by making two free throws and two layups in the final 42 seconds tonight to down Yale, 77-71, in the first round of the Marshall University invitation tournament.

The Federal Government borrowed $2.7-billion yesterday by selling Treasury bills, the most riskless and the most readily marketable of securities, at interest rates as high as 6.71 per cent, the highest such figure on record.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Mayor Lindsay called today for "revolutionary changes" in this country's approach to urban problems.

CORNWALL, Ontario, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A high Government official said tonight that Canada and members of the St. Regis Indian reservation had reached a temporary compromise over the question of free access to the United States-Canadian border by the Indians.

Contributions to the 57th annual appeal for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund come from many walks of life, all with a desire to help the less fortunate and sometimes asking that specific cases be aided.
A 64-year-old branch of the Brooklyn Public Library has temporarily closed because of continuing thefts, shouts of obscenities and threats to its staff by 14- and 15-year-old youths in the area.
The Mobil Oil Corporation is discountinuing its Mobil Economy run.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- On the basis of what happened tonight at Cobo Arena, the New York Knickerbockers did exactly the right thing yesterday when they traded Walt Bellamy and Howie (Butch) Komives to the Pistons for Dave DeBusschere.

HAMBURG, Germany, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Alexander Hembluck, who for eight years waged a one - man terror campaign against West German railroads, was sentenced to eight years at hard labor today. Hembluck, who called himself Phantom Roy Clark, once demanded $175,000 to stop planting bombs on tracks and in rail stations.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 20 -- The building of monuments in Arab Jerusalem to honor the Jordanian war dead has been suspended by Israeli authorities pending an examination of the issue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman today set the 1969 national sugar consumption quota at 10.6 million short tons of raw sugar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Twenty-seven women and a dog named Prince marched nearly two miles to the White House today with a wreath and a batch of telegrams urging President Johnson to end the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The presidents of the nation's three television networks told the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence today that no Government agency could challenge the industry's news judgment.

ROSLYN, L. I., Dec. 20 -- Philip P. Gross, retired president of Kelmont Modes, Inc., New York City, manufacturers of women's coats, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in his home here at 32 Middle Neck Road. His age was 75.
The Penn Central Company is scheduled to include the New Haven Railroad in its operations effective Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The X-15 rocket-plane program has ended, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

TAIPEI, Taiwan -- It is ironic that in this city with American inhabitants that number in the tens of thousands, you rarely encounter an American in any of the city's hundreds of restaurants. Ironic because Taipei probably has the best and widest variety of Chinese restaurants in the world. And this is a time when Chinese cooking is enjoying its greatest prestige in the history of the West.
Longshoremen from Maine to Texas went on strike last night as Federal mediation efforts failed.

Novella Nelson, an actress who is rehearsing for an Off-Broadway production of "Horsemen, Pass By," a play drawn from the poetry and letters of William Butler Yeats, which is scheduled to open in January, took time off from Yeats last weekend to make her official debut as a nightclub singer at the Village Vanguard.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Dave Dover and Ernie Hardy led a second-half Harvard rally tonight as the Crimson scored a 78-65 upset victory over Rutgers.
The police yesterday charged a 41-year-old Bronx man with criminally negligent homicide in the deaths of four persons in an automobile accident Thursday night.

THE Winter Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which continues today at the New York Hilton with Open and Limited Pair events at 1:30 P. M. and 7:30 P. M., traditionally includes a Christmas surprise in its schedule.

WIESBADEN, West Germany, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- West Germany last month had another massive trade surplus -- 2.03-billion marks (about $509-million), almost double the 1.17-billion marks (about $292-million), in November, 1967, it was announced today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham arrived here today to speend Christmas with United States troops. He said he would spend five days in various parts of the country.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 20 -- Vice President Humphrey's plan to return to teach in Minnesota has upset Republican hopes of continuing progress toward domination of state politics and has aided the political fortunes of his own Democrat-Farmer-Labor party.
MADRID, Dec. 20 -- The Spanish Government has expelled Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon Parma, Carlist pretender to the throne.

Just a year ago she was the toast of Broadway, a featured player who provided the two bright spots in an otherwise forgettable musical, "Henry, Sweet Henry." She was acclaimed as the next musical star, nominated for a Tony award, glowingly reviewed in her nightclub act at the Upstairs at the Downstairs and apparently destined to own any musical stage on which she appeared.
Thursday's strong comeback in the stock market failed to carry through yesterday and prices resumed the downward trend that began early in the week.
Leonidas Lipovetsky is that rare artist who performs more interestingly in the first half of his recital than he does in the last.
BONN, Dec. 20 -- The West German Government announced the acceptance in Washington today of Bonn's newly designated Ambassador to the United States, Rolf Friedemann Pauls.
A Columbia College disciplinary tribunal has imposed suspended sentences on 60 students accused of participating in last spring's occupation of five university buildings.

BENARES, India, Dec. 14 -- "Drink Dimagheen," urges an advertisement painted on a wall near the main bathing place on the River Ganges in this holy city of the Hindus, "a unique mental tonic. A boon to students and lawyers."
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 20 -- The Secor Farms horse show, postponed last Sunday because of the snow storm, has been rescheduled for tomorrow.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- The American Motors Corporation said today it is acquiring Canadian Fabricated Products, Ltd., of Stratford, Ont., a small manufacturer of auto soft trim. The acquisition probably will be for cash and is the first in years for American Motors.

The creative director of Marsteller's New York office, Louis A. Magnani, a vice president, has been appointed to the top creative job of the agency, a new post -- vice president-creative.

MONROE INGBERMAN, formerly of Chicago and now of New Paltz, N. Y., and Michael Becker, Ralph Chafetz and Andrew Bernstein, all of New York, won the knockout team champion at the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Tournament,

Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks continued to lead the National Hockey League in total points, but he now shares first place in goals with Phil Esposito of the Boston Bruins, according to statistics released yesterday.
The plot on which the 21-story office building at 460 Park Avenue stands has been sold by the estate of Marion Davies to the Nock Corporation for $2.1-million.
SYLVANIA, Ohio, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Nicoline Loche of Argentina and Nino Benvenuti of Italy were named boxers of the month today by the World Boxing Association.
A handful of students from a Brooklyn high school have done what thousands of demanding, protesting and demonstrating New York City teenager faied to: They got their Christmas holidays back.

Two men indicted last Friday with Carmine G. De Sapio, former Tammany Hall leader, on charges of a bribe conspiracy and shaking down Consolidated Edison for construction contracts pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court here.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- A Soviet space scientist today wished the Apollo 8 astronauts a successful flight and said that completion of their mission "would represent a new contribution to the exploration of space."
EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Don Adams and Dale Kelley combined for 42 points as Northwestern trounced Washington State, 77-61, for its sixth straight victory tonight.

When the new freighter Delta Mexico was delivered last week to her owners, Delta Steamship Lines of New Orleans, it marked the completion of the largest ship replacement construction program in the company's 50-year history.

There are some people who have better things to do with their time than last-minute Christmas shopping. They go to black tie dinner dances. There were two of them last night, rather small for such events, but then, of course, they were private. Mr. and Mrs. Deane F. Johnson, who were married here Nov. 9, were guests of honor at a party at El Morocco co-hosted by four members of Mrs. Johnson's family.

HOUSTON, Dec. 23 -- (UPI) Col. Frank Borman, the Apollo 8 commander, took some gentle ridicule from mission control here today about his fear that the astronauts were interrupting a football game during their telecast from space.

The Police Department's former expert on the Mafia, Ralph F Salerno, said last night that the crime syndicate was "involved in millions of dollars of urban-renewal construction work" in the Buffalo area.

TRENTON, Dec. 23 -- Senator Frank X. McDermott, the Republican Senate majority leader who has vowed to "name names" in the New Jersey Mafia scandal, accused State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills tonight of "sitting" on allegations that six legislators have ties to organized crime in the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The State Department confirmed today that a United States missionary imprisoned by the Cuban Government since April, 1965, has been released and has requested repatriation.
Harlem's Negro merchants and clergymen, alarmed by what they regard as a rising tide of criminal violence by blacks against blacks, are demanding harsh punitive action.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Dec. 23 -- Theodore F. Stevens, a Republican, was appointed to the United Sates Senate today to fill the vacancy created by the death of Alaska's senior Senator, E. L. Bartlett, a Democrat.
Jack Resnick Sons, builder-owner of residential and commercial property, has named Frank A. Cardo a vice president of the organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- The Soviet Union and Japan, two of the major countries influencing the world's free sugar market, signed today the new international sugar agreement designed to stabilize prices.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 23 -- The military regime of President Arthur da Costa e Silva arrested the editor in chief of this city's leading newspaper last night after he spore out against the censorship that has virtually eliminated news from Brazil's press, radio and television.

Chatham Township in New Jersey has wisely decided to halt the dumping of garbage and sewage on its dump along the northern periphery of the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge Wilderness. Poisonous seepage from the dump has been a serious threat to the wildlife which the refuge was only recently established to protect.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -- Workmen today raced against time to fit a new mast on the Ondine II, Sumner A. Long's ocean racer, in time for the start of the Sydney-Hobart Ocean Classic Thursday.

ROME, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -- At the 1967 Synod of Bishops, most of the leaders who attended tried to damp down Vatican fears of serious danger from doctrinal errors and unorthodox experiments in many countries.
Mayor Lindsay signed a bill yesterday extending the protection of the city's law against discrimination to physically handicapped people.

A memorial service for Norman Thomas, who ran as Socialist party candidate for President six times during his lifetime campaign for social justice, was held yesterday at the Community Church. It was attended by about a thousand people, among them Mayor Lindsay.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The United States Davis Cup team rounded off its grueling preparation today for the challenge round matches against Australia, because their No. 1 hope, Arthur Ashe, was still nursing a "tennis elbow."
Wagner College routed City College of New York, 93-60, last night at the losers' Wingate Gymnasium.

WESTON, Conn., Dec. 23 -- Raymond Rodgers, emeritus professor of banking at the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, died today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived on Lyons Plain Road.

HOUSTON, Dec. 23 -- The three Apollo astronauts have carried to the vicinity of the moon an encapsulated bit of the earth -- its life-supporting environment, some of the life that evolved there and some of the ingenuity characteristic of that life.
The United States Steel Corporation revised its price for hot-rolled sheets yesterday, putting it at $117 a ton, effective Jan. 1, instead of the $125 announced earlier.

One afternoon last summer at the Republican National Convention in Miami, where Governor Rockefeller was about to be beaten by Richard M. Nixon for the G.O.P. Presidential nomination, the Governor was dragged into a cocktail party by Perry B. Duryea Jr.
"The Sound of the Underground," a concert scheduled for Friday and Saturday at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden, has been canceled.
Judge Edward Weinfeld of the United States District Court here yesterday set Feb. 18 as the date for pretrial motions to be argued in the indictment of Roy M. Cohn, a New York lawyer and businessman.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The president of the Sierra Club says the conservation group will press for enlargement of Grand Canyon National Park and the new Redwood National Park.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Jose (Mantequilla) Napoles knocked out Lennox Beckles, of Guyana, in the first round of their junior welterweight bout last night.
The New York Jets were installed yesterday as the betting favorite over the Oakland Raiders for the American Football League championship game Sunday at Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A studious variation on the traditional high school senior-class trip to Washington -- often a superficial lark -- is taking shape here just in time to focus on the incoming Nixon Administration.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Oakland Oaks of the American Basketball Association released Andy Anderson, a guard, today.

A new 24-hour telephone service for the latest ski reports is in operation. By dialing LY 4-7500, skiers can obtain information on snow con-East, including New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Vermont, New Hampshire and Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The United States prepared messages of appreciation today to foreign governments whose good offices had been requested to help obtain the release of the Pueblo crew from captivity in North Korea.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A Penn State tackle, Dave Bradley, suffered a minor nose cut today in a workout for the Orange Bowl game with Kansas on Jan. 1. The Nittany Lions held one closed-session drill working on new plays.

ATLANTA, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The profits from next Monday night's Peach Bowl game here between Florida State and Louisiana State are earmarked for the blind. Unfortunately, it appears there might not be anything left after expenses.
CATANZARO, Italy, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- An Italian court sentenced 73 Mafia gangsters today to prison terms ranging from three months to 27 years.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 23 -- A tentative settlement in the week-old strike against 25 Kaiser Foundation Hospitals and was reached early today after weekend negotiations in Oakland.

LEW ALCINDOR is coming to town, a fact that used to send chills up and down the spines of opposing coaches and players. Lew and his University of California, Los Angeles, teammates are in the Holiday Festival basketball tournament that begins Friday at Madison Square Garden.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Buster O'Brien, a quarterback at the University of Richmond, was ruled eligible today for postseason competition by the eligibility committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
Almost from the start, the flight of Apollo 8 has depended in precise and somewhat complex ways on one of the most familiar, but most mysterious, forces in the universe -- gravity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today the first operational grant under the model cities program -- $5.2-million for the first year of Seattle's five-year plan.

THAT sweet little innocent, Heidi, could have intruded on the television screens last Sunday to erase the closing stages of a football game in Oakland and not one viewer could have objected. But when she showed unexpected muscle in a similar situation at the same site a month ago, she precipitated so violent a protest that the telephone switch-board in the National Broadcasting Company blew a fuse and was rendered inoperative.

Robert Todd Lang has been elected a director of Botany Industries, the diversified producer and retailer of apparel. Mr. Lang is a partner in the law concern of Weil, Gotshal Manges, New York.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The sun came out today after two days of rain and sent Blue-Gray football coaches and their players out to the practice field to catch up on their drills.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The police laid a dragnet today for 21 prisoners, four of them convicted killers, who broke out of a "rat-infested 16th century asylum" while fellow convicts covered their noise by singing "Silent Night."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Sixteen qualified minority group applicants will be offered direct commissions as officers in the Coast Guard Reserve, it was announced today. The new officers will be part of an enlarged service recruitment program aimed at minority groups.

Prices of apparel are expected to rise in the new year, mainly because of increasing labor costs sustained by both the manufacturers and their suppliers, Chester H. Roth, chairman and chief executive officer of the Kayser-Roth Corporation, said yesterday.

MIAMI, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- More details of the Barbara Jane Mackle kidnapping case came to light today while the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched for a "sweet and charming" blonde sought as one of the abductors.
