The volume of commercial paper outstanding soared $1.4-billion during November to a new high of $22.2 billion, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

CAIRO, Dec. 23 -- High Egyptian officials said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and President Gamal Abdel Nasser discussed the possible resumption of Egyptian-American diplomatic relations in their long, drawn-out talks, which continued this evening.

The New York Stock Exchange, eyeing the problem of divorce and family disputes, has tightened up one of its rules on the handling of customer accounts.

The appointment of Henry Garfinkle, formerly president, as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the American News Company was announced yesterday. TRENTON, Dec. 23 -- The conviction of the black militant writer LeRoi Jones for possession of weapons was reversed today by an appeals court that found that the trial judge's charge to the jury was improper and prejudicial.
Steel production edged up eight-tenths of one per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Extraordinarily high levels of carbon monoxide forecast for the Lower Manhattan Expressway could block the construction of that controversial project, the city's Environmental Administrator said yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Auto repairmen in Europe are about as popular as a flat tire in the Lincoln Tunnel.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Rescue workers searched for survivers in the smoldering wreckage of a holiday passenger train packed with children that collided with a freight train last night 25 miles from here, killing at least 43 persons. Fifty-seven were injured and many were listed as missing.

The Ford Foundation cautioned yesterday against rushing into reforms of the present welfare system without summiciently researching the alternatives, and announced $830,000 worth of grants to study the problems.

Despite increased earnings in the final quarter, Deere Co. reported yesterday lower sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

ANYONE willing to pay $60 to $100 for dinner for four, or say $50 for lunch in one of the dozen or so New York restaurants that are renowned for haute cuisine and clientele to match, can reasonably expect to receive more than he bargained for these days.

Short-term interest rates continued to soar yesterday as the credit markets reacted again to the Federal Reserve's decision last week to escalate the war against inflation.

Major plumbing contractors in the metropolitan area were ordered yesterday by the State Supreme Court to halt practices described by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz as monopolistic and restrictive to free competition.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The Right Rev. James A. Pike was banned today from preaching in the California diocese of the Episcopal Church because he married a third time without church approval.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 24 -- A Union County jury was declared hopelessly deadlocked and dismissed today after failing to reach a verdict in the case of the last of 10 defendants accused of murdering a policeman during the 1967 racial disturbance in Plainfield, N.J.
Postal authorities are investigating the case of a wayward mailman who was seen depositing Christmas mail in an Upper West Side trash basket.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Negotiators at the stalled conference on Vietnam here started an unofficial Christmas recess today, similar to the ceasefire that both sides proclaimed unilaterally in the fighting.

Mrs. Henry Duncan Wood 3d, chairman of the Greensleeves Ball, scheduled for tomorrow at the Roosevelt Hotel, has announced cancellation of the event because of the influenza epidemic. The three debutantes who were to be presented at the ball will bow instead at the 1969 ball at the Pierre on Oct. 17.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Sheriff Louis A. Heyd said today that he believed several of the 21 Orleans Parish prison inmates who escaped Saturday were being harbored by their families and friends.
HONOLULU, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The three-month marriage of Wendell Phillips, a 46-year-old oil millionaire and archeologist, to a 19-year-old family friend was ended today.
TULSA, Okla., Dec. 24 (UPI) -- The University of Tulsa named Vincent J. Carillot, a Michigan State University assistant, as head football coach today.

LOS ANGELES -- It is fashionable in certain lofty intellectual circles to disparage cultural centers, as though the building of a large, new complex devoted to the arts were somehow sure evidence of their betrayal.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Robert McKinley of the United States and Alan MacDonald of Australia, each rated the top junior tennis player in his country, suffered stunning upsets today in the Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Ask John Mackey to describe the Cleveland Browns' defense and the Baltimore Colts' tight end sounds as though he's speaking of his own teammates.
LANDMARKS OF MAPMAKING. Maps chosen by R. V. Tooley. Text by Charles Bricker. Preface by Gerald Roe Crone. 275 pages. Elsevier: New York Graphic Society. $32.50.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Libya celebrated the 17th anniversary of her independence today with rallies in major cities, a big military parade in Tripoli and the inauguration of Libyan television.
MONTREAL, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Montreal of the National Hockey League returned a wing, Bob Berry, to Cleveland of the American Hockey League today.

CAIRO, Dec. 24 -- The United Arab Republic showed no change in its position concerning a settlement of the Middle East crisis in a communique made public jointly with the Soviet Union today. It was issued as Foreign Minister Andrei A.

TRENTON, Dec. 24 -- State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills accused Frank X. McDermott, the Senate Republican majority leader, today of trying to use reports that the Mafia was linked to some legislators to bolster "his personal political ambitions."
A 28-year-old window washer was rescued by a fellow worker yesterday after he dangled for 20 minutes 28 floors above the street at the Graybar Building, 420 Lexington Avenue, at 43d Street.

TURIN, Italy, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Gianni Agnelli, president of Fiat, and his brother Umberto led the list of taxpayers published today by the Turin municipality. The list put the automobile magnate's income at the eqivalent of $568,000 and his brother Umberto, who also has interests in Fiat and in other subsidiaries of the automobile company, was asssessed $41,600 in taxes on an income of $284,800.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Carrying placards and chanting anti-American slogans, 45 youthful Israelis protested today, against the United States' involvement in Vietnam. The boisterous demonstration, held in check by a large contingent of Israeli police in front of the United States Embassy, was organized by the Israeli Communist party.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Churches around the nation's moonport today planned special Christmas prayers and pealing of bells for the safe return of the three Apollo 8 astronauts.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Dec. 24 -- The Di Georgio Corporation, in a recent announcement, disclosed its intention to abandon a once-flourishing agriculture empire in California's land-rich southern San Joaquin Valley.

A shortage of heat, vaccine and blood plagued the city yesterday as the Hong Kong flu epidemic continued, and the Health Commissioner warned that many sick people might die unless emergency fuel deliveries were made.
HONG KONG, Dec. 24 (AP) -- North Vietnam praised its Roman Catholic clergy and laymen today for "killing the United States aggressors -- the best offerings to the infant Jesus Christ."
A ribbon of bitter cold wrapped around the northern tier of the nation yesterday, and states from New England to Virginia were greeted with fresh snow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- In the last two days Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky has edged the South Vietnamese Government closer toward dealing politically with its battlefield enemy, the National Liberation Front.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Arthur Ashe's troublesome tennis elbow and an outbreak of other nettling injuries threw a somber cloud over the heavily favored United States team as the Americans and Australians prepared for the draw today in the 58th Davis Cup challenge round.

The human celebration of the Nativity and the pagan festival of war collide this Christmas morning, 1968. In Bethlehem and Jerusalem, the barbed-wire barriers are down, but tension remains high in the ancient land of Biblical prophets and disciples. In Saigon and Danang a Christmas truce silences the mortars and bombers, but only temporarily. In the chancelleries of the superpowers, the arms establishment still dominates the peace establishment.

IT is indeed disillusioning to learn that there are some people in this world who do not believe in Santa Claus. They are to be pitied. In their blindness they will not see the jolly old elf come whisking down the chimney with his sack of goodies. In their ignorance they will not know what he left under the tree for the deserving -- more or less -- little boys in sports.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Topweighted Rising Market and seven rival speed horses were entered today in the $25,000 added Palos Verdes Handicap, the feature race of Santa Anita's opening-day card on Thursday.

UMUAHIA, Biafra, (Nigeria), Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Biafran forces are observing the truce ordered by Colonel Ojukwu in spite of "provocations" from Nigerian forces, according to a communique issued today.
The Cunard Line cruise liner Carmania, temporarily black-balled by the Coast Guard for safety reasons, left Port Everglades, Fla., for New Orleans yesterday.

SEATTLE, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The United Control Corporation has posted a $6-million bond required by the Federal District Court while it appeals a patent infringement suit it lost to the Safe Flight Instrument Corporation, White Plains, N. Y., it was announced today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- The Soviet Union announced today that three researchers had completed a year's stay in an isolation chamber in an experiment designed to test life support systems for prolonged interplanetary space flights.
The Gulf Oil Corporation set off dynamite charges last week at Heianza Island, Okinawa, during site-dedication ceremonies for its $30-million terminal for crude oil transshipment.
No adults were allowed on the ice yesterday morning at the skating party benefit for the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary at Rockefeller Center, and that was just fine with everybody.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Labor Department said today that it planned to require that an hourly minimum wage of at least $1.60 be paid all foreigners entering the United States on work permits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would permit telephone companies to put into effect on Jan. 1 revised tariffs affecting customer-owned equipment attached to the companies' lines.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 24 -- The Soviet-Egyptian statement issued in Cairo was seen here as evidence that the two countries felt that they should keep the door open for a dialogue with the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The United States Government has decided in principle to transfer six C-97 Globemaster cargo planes to American voluntary relief agencies, officials reported today. The planes would be used to ferry relief supplies to Biafrans and other victims of the Nigerian civil war.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 24 -- The five United States representatives who are scheduled to meet with the Vietcong tomorrow afternoon to discuss the release of three American prisoners of war spent today working out a series of contingency plans.

Mayor Lindsay visited the Upper West Side yesterday and praised community participation in a major urban renewal program there. And a group of neighborhood residents demonstrated that community involvement could mean braving the icy wind to criticize the Lindsay administration's housing policies while the Mayor was hailing them.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Bob Hope and his troupe, continuing their Christmas tour, got a tumultuous welcome today from 10,000 United States servicemen on a hillside amphitheater ringed with Marine guards.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith declared its support for school decentralization here yesterday, but it said it was opposed to "community control that would place the whims and wishes of a locality" over the authority of the city and state.

The Bank of America has promoted Robert W. Long to senior vice president, Rudolph A. Peterson, president, announced yesterday from San Francisco headquarters. Mr. Long will continue to direct the extensive agricultural activities of the nation's largest bank.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI) -- For all those people who didn't see the Oakland Raiders beat the New York Jets last month, the California team is planning a repeat performance Sunday.

MARSEILLES, France, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The leftist National Students Union, which played a leading role in riots last spring, elected as its new president Tuesday a "moderate" opposed by both orthodox and pro-Chinese Communists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it would investigate increased rates proposed by American Airlines, Braniff Airways and United Air Lines for carrying general commodities before making a decision on whether the rates can be put into effect.
ABOARD U.S.S. YORKTOWN, at Sea, Dec. 24 -- After a round-trip to the moon, one of the first things Apollo 8's astronauts will do is ride a bicycle that gets them nowhere.

DENVER, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Denver Post and trustees of The Denver Post Employes Stock Trust charged today that Samuel I. Newhouse, the newspaper publisher, violated the Sherman and Clayton Antitrust Acts by attempting to monopolize the news dissemination business.
HOUSTON, Dec. 24 -- Col. Frank Borman, commander of the Apollo 8 spacecraft, offered a Christmas Eve prayer today from lunar orbit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Early returns from a Government study indicate that malnutrition in America is a serious problem that afflicts not only the poor but some middle-class people as well, especially teen-agers

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Auxiliary Bishop of California, said today he would celebrate a Christmas holy communion despite a "personal request" from his superior, Bishop C. Kilmer Myers, that he be barred from the Episcopal pulpit.

"Love Match," the new musical starring Patricia Routledge as Queen Victoria that was to open in February, has been canceled. The Broadway house for the show, estimated to cost more than $500,000, was not booked by the producers, Ivor David Balding and Elliot Martin.
On the first Christmas three Wise Men looked skyward and began following a star to Bethlehem. This year three men looked earthward and followed a man-made course around the moon.
MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Champion 2-year-olds from the United States and Canada are among the 107 nominees for the $100,000 Flamingo Stakes to be run at Hialeah on March 4.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Pictures of the moon from Apollo 8 flashed across television screens in Western Europe today, and Europeans cheered the space venture as a triumph.
SO HUMAN AN ANIMAL. By Rene Dubos. 267 pp. Charles Scribners Sons. $6.95.

The United States Steel Corporation yesterday appointed Thomas W. Hunter as administrative vice president-steel operations and Robert A. McClure as vice president-sheet and tin operations, both effective Feb. 1.

IN the growing pantheon of America's space effort there are already many titans. John H. Glenn Jr., Alan B. Shepard Jr., Walter M. Schirra Jr. and the rest of the astronauts have all received confetti tributes and have had their praises sung on bubble gum cards.
With the American Football League's most valuable player, Joe Namath, at the controls, the New York Jets went through a 75-minute drill yesterday at Shea Stadium.

The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria will be the setting for the Korean Night Ball Saturday at 8 P. M. The party is to raise money to build a school for Korean language and culture at the Korean Cultural Center, 307 Fifth Avenue.

HOUSTON, Wednesday, Dec. 25 -- The three astronauts of Apollo 8 yesterday became the first men to orbit the moon. Early today, after flying 10 times around that desolate realm of dream and scientific mystery, they started their return to earth.

CORK, Ireland, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- The Queen Elizabeth 2, on its shakedown cruise, answered a call for help today from a tugboat whose engine room was flooding. The Cunard liner stood by until another tug took the endangered vessel in tow.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Erich Barnes, the old man of Cleveland's defensive backfield, set his sights today on trying to shut out Willie Richardson, the Colts' top receiver, when the teams meet Sunday.

HOUSTON, Dec. 24 -- For the first time human beings took a close look today at the earth's nearest celestial neighbor, viewing it from many angles to seek out clues to the events that formed its awesomely rugged terrain.
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 24 -- Tears of joy flowed freely here today as the 82 survivors of the Pueblo embraced wives, children and parents in Christmas reunions.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 25 -- The allies and the Vietcong put separate cease-fires into effect yesterday to mark Christmas, but not all the guns fell silent.

MIAMI, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Angel Cordero and Alvaro Pineda clashed head on for the first time at Tropical Park today in their battle for the 1968 jockey championship, but their confrontation was overshadowed by a $51,994.40 Big Perfecta.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 24 (UPI) -- The Kentucky Racing Commission announced these 1969 racing dates today:
MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- United States Olympic swimmer, Debbie Meyer, has been selected in Cuba as the athlete of the year, Havana Radio reported today.

GREENBELT, Md., Dec. 24 -- There was no cheering, but there was relaxed satisfaction today at Goddard Space Flight Center when the first three men ever to do so disappeared behind the face of the moon.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 24 (UPI) The police said a 10-year-old girl was abducted today from a Y.M.C.A. building. The police said a man was reported to have been seen taking the girl wrapped in a blanket from the building and tossing her into a 1959 model car.
BETHLEHEM, Israeli-Occupied Jordan, Dec. 24 -- Christmas Eve was celebrated today at the birthplace of Jesus with all its traditional pomp, but with a large number of Israeli guns covering the city.
The usually staid Supreme Court building in Foley Square took on the appearance of a Hollywood set yesterday, but a plot twist definitely not in the script put an end to the filming.
HOUSTON, Dec. 24 -- The Apollo 8 astronauts can enjoy a Christmas dinner, but they must keep a firm hold on it, lest it float out of reach in the weightless condition of the Apollo 8 spacecraft.
THE National Broadcasting Company's television network stayed on the air throughout Monday night in anticipation of the insertion of Apollo into lunar orbit at approximately 5 A.M. yesterday.
A surge of late shopping since last weekend has turned one of the most uncertain Christmas selling seasons in years into another record holiday performance.

A Florida youth has captured top individual honors in Amateur Athletic Union Junior Olympics swimming for the fourth consecutive year, the A.A.U. announced yesterday. Joey Pupello of Tampa swept six division categories.

"Coppelia" has sometimes been called a cold-hearted comedy. But Enrique Martinez's new production for the American Ballet Theater, unveiled yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is a warm-hearted romp in which farce triumphs over pathos. In other words, it's great fun.
A Federal judge issued an order yesterday blocking implementation of a 23 per cent rise in loading and unloading fees charged truckers by pier operators on New York's waterfront.
The city's new Mobile Consumer Protection Office, a converted bookmobile salvaged from the Department of Purchase, was placed on display at City Hall yesterday.

More talk about the recent freezing weather in Florida and frost warnings for last evening caused orange juice futures to go up the 3 cents a pound daily limit yesterday for the seventh trading session in a row.

The village of Hastings-on- Hudson, N. Y., spent a week last year paying tribute to its eminent artist-resident of 20 years, the sculptor Jacques Lipchitz. In a reciprocal gesture, Mr. Lipchitz gave 10,- 000 fellow townsmen "Heaven and Earth," an 11-foot bronze he made for the new village library.
Joe Namath was named yesterday the most valuable player in the American Football League poll of sports writers and broadcasters and also selected as player of the year in a poll of A.F.L. coaches.

Mrs. Lillian Roberts and Robert Fuller, jailed as leaders of the recent strike against state mental hospitals, were released from Civil Jail at noon yesterday after their sentences under the Taylor Law were reduced at the direction of a judge.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would follow other producers in setting hot-rolled sheet prices at $117 a ton and hot-rolled bands at $110 a ton, effective Jan. 1. These levels are $8 a ton below the increase originally proposed by the United States Steel Corporation and are the levels selected by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The new 90-foot aluminum mast of the Ondine II of Larchmont, N. Y., has been bolted together and placed but the 73-foot ketch will not be tested before the start of the Sydney-to-Hobart race on Thursday.

HARPER WOODS, Mich., Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Dozens of motorists fanned out through Detroit's northern suburbs today in search for their cars, which had been wrecked in collisions during a freak snowstorm and then abandoned.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Post Office Department today reported only a few scattered problems, none of them major, in its work of getting holiday mail delivered by Christmas Eve.
Mrs. Dorothy Sorlingas, the wife of a retired longshoreman, began Christmas shopping for her husband, daughter, two grandchildren and a horde of relatives back in September.

As a means of protecting the public and making policemen "feel more responsible" for their actions, two City Councilmen yesterday introduced legislation that would require all city policemen to wear name plates.
All-day efforts failed to dislodge the 167-foot coastal tanker Mary A. Whalen, which spent yesterday slowly but steadily leaking oil after running aground at the breakwater at Rockaway Point, Queens.

TOKYO, Dec. 24 -- Nationalist China's merchant fleet will grow with the acquisition of two new Japanese-built freighters that are nearing completion in Osaka.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department today listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

IN Wall Street circles, there is a feeling that the performance mutual funds may have gone too far in their quest for stocks that advance spectacularly. There is also fear that 1968 may go down as the year in which the cult of performance became a curse.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A blind Milwaukee couple, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Northrop, werer obbed of all their Christmas shopping money -- $53 -- last week by a man who said he was a hippie.
Around the world and in distant space, a billion Christians and millions of others celebrate the festive holiday of Christmas today.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- The Argentine Government ended a 21-month wage freeze today and authorized an 8 per cent salary increase as well as raises in minimum-wage and family allowances.
MUNICH, West Germany, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Arndt von Bohlen und Halbach, the only son of the late Alfried Krupp, will marry Henriette von Auersperg, an Austrian Princess, next spring.

George T. Pfifer has been elected treasurer and Nelson Stone secretary of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation. They will assume these posts Jan. 1 in addition to their duties as vice presidents. George J. Wade, who had been secretary and treasurer, will retire but remain as a consultant.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- Henry R. Labouisse, Executive Director of the United Nations Children's Fund, made an urgent appeal today for a peaceful solution to the Biafran conflict, and said that this was "the only real hope for saving the several millions of Nigerian children who are facing frightful starvation and suffering."
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 24 -- The crew of the intelligence ship Pueblo returned to the United States today in time for Christmas with many of their families.

AFTER Jan. 11, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and socialites such as Mrs. Winston F. C. Guest and Mrs. Edwin Hilson may have to find a new local hairdresser. Norbert, the suave Frenchman who has been coiffuring many a famous head, will have to close the door of his gilded salon at 10 West 58th Street.

BRADFORD, Pa., Wednesday, Dec. 25 -- An Allegheny Airlines jetprop plane with 45 persons aboard crashed last night in rugged terrain during a heavy snowstorm while attempting to land at Bradford Regional Airport 15 miles south of here.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Apollo 8 "looked like a star" in pictures made by the United States Naval Observatory last night, Dr. Gerald E. Kron, director, said today. He described the photographs as "very successful."

BUJUMBURA, Burundi, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Six former Government ministers and members of Parliament were sentenced to 10 years in prison for writing and distributing an open letter against President Michel Micom bero, who overthrew the Burundi monarchy in November, 1966.

The Overseas Press Club sent a protest yesterday to the President of Brazil, Arthur da Costa e Silva, over the arrest of Alberto Dines, editor in chief of Jornal do Brasil, and urged that the President intervene in the case.
ALBANY, Dec. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller today commuted the life sentences of four prisoners, all convicted of murder.
SOUTH was given a most acceptable Christmas present on the diagramed deal, played Saturday in the Knockout Championship in the Winter Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association.
Nationalist China is meeting with increasing success in its effort to turn African nations away from Communist China.
Blood, Sweat and Tears, the rock group that was supposed to have died several months ago, has released its second album.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- A passenger train hit a crowded bus at a crossing in western Turkey today and dragged it for 150 yards. Police reports said 14 persons were killed.

Trading slowed markedly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and prices closed mixed. The exchange's index of stock prices was down 2 cents to $32.97. During the course of the comparatively quiet day the index moved in a narrow range.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 24 (AP) -- An assertion was made here today that a Hungarian counter-intelligence agent worked for six years at a United States intelligence headquarters in Munich, West Germany, sabotaging intelligence operations against Hungary.
HOUSTON, Dec. 24 -- Following are excerpts from radio messages between Apollo 8 and the Manned Spacecraft Center's control room here during the orbiting of the moon.

HOUSTON, Dec. 24 -- The Apollo 8 crewmen capped their historic orbiting of the moon today by stamping hitherto unseen lunar features with the names of several dozen astronauts, space agency officials and friends.

One year ago, less two days, the New York Knickerbockers were beaten, 114-105, by the Philadelphia 76ers and William (Red) Holzman, the club's chief scout for 10 years, replaced Dick McGuire as coach.
TOKYO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- More than 50 persons were injured today when about 500 members of rival leftist student groups battled with iron pipes, planks and rocks at Tokyo University's medical college.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- As the New Year's gift season approaches, complaints are being voiced in the press that the Soviet Union, the world's leading railroad nation, cannot meet the demand for electric toy trains for its youngsters.

TORONTO, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- An Ontario Appeals Court judge disclosed yesterday that threats had been made against his life after he dismissed a claim made by Leitch Gold Mines against Texas Gulf Sulphur Company for $45000-million or ore rights worth $2-billion.

MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Fourteen horses were entered today for tomorrow's $15,000 Christmas Handicap at Tropical Park. The entries were headed by Foxcatcher Farm's Angelico and Carolawn Stable's Subpet.

Akira Kurosawa, who has been hospitalized in Kyoto, Japan, for the last week, has withdrawn as director of 20th Century-Fox's "Tora! Tora! Tora!" The Japanese director was supervising the location sequences of the drama about the attack on Pearl Harbor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- After waiting in line up to five hours, hundreds of American servicemen telephoned home today. The calls, limited to three minutes each, were placed at the U.S.O. lounge in Saigon.

SCARSDALE, N. Y. -- Word had spread in the neighborhood that the tree was up, so the children -- and adults, too -- came to look in wonder at the glistening balsam in the living room of Mr. and Mrs. Earl L. Dibble.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- For the man or woman who has everything -- how about a reserved seat for Christmas?

CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Pickands Mather Co. said today that exclusive iron-ore exploration rights in a 4,000-square-mile area of the Ivory Coast Republic had been granted to a Pickands Mather subsidiary.

BOSTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- The Massachusetts Executive Council commuted today the life sentences of two men convicted in the $1.2-million Brink's holdup here almost 19 years ago, making them eligible for parole.
The premiere of "Celebration," the Tom Jones-Harvey Schmidt musical, has been set back from Jan. 19 to Jan. 22 at the Ambassador Theater. Low-priced previews will begin Jan. 10.

David W. Brumbaugh, who was recently elected chairman of the finance committee of Time Inc., will continue as executive vice president, a post he has held since 1960. Mr. Brumbaugh succeeds Charles L. Stillman, who remains chairman of the company's pulp and paper subsidiary, Eastex, Inc., and in other executive posts of Time-associated companies. Both Mr. Stillman and Mr. Brumbaugh are on the board of directors of Time Inc.

SEABROOK, Tex., Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Valerie Anders talked about landing a man on the moon, Susan Borman had her hair done and Marilyn Lovell napped on Christmas Eve after watching their astronaut husbands send back a telecast of the moon's surface.

ISTANBUL -- This city with its mosques and minarets on the banks of the Bosporus is certainly one of the most intriguing cities on earth. And one of the nicest things to be said of the restaurants here is that most of them have views to dine by that fairly ravish the eye.

Paul Robinson on the Cincinnati Bengals, the only running back to gain 1,000 yards in the American Football League this season, took rookie-of-the-year honors yesterday in the annual balloting by the league's 10 head coaches.
The Midwest Stock Exchange voted yesterday to resume a five-day trading week along with the rest of the securities industry. It also voted to cut trading hours by 90 minutes a day.

FRESNEDILLA, Spain, Dec. 24 -- The Apollo 8 spaceship was sliding past the moon's Sea of Fertility, and one of the astronauts was remarking, "The walls of the craters are terraced," when the telephone rang in the director's office at the space-tracking station here, 35 miles east of Madrid.

Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that it had received "a flurry of requests" from people who want to be on the first commercial flight to the moon. Pan Am said that there were about 100 names on the list.

"I think if we can get by Toronto, we'll be friends," Ray Bolger said with a chuckle to Agnes de Mille. Mr. Bolger was referring to the first out-of-town opening, on Jan. 27, of "Come Summer," a new musical that is being directed and choreographed by Miss de Mille, in which he is starred.
Hank Stram, the head coach of the Kansas City Chiefs and one of the top innovators in pro football, was named yesterday as coach of the West squad for the American Football League's all-star game.
An 18-year-old girl and a man in his late 50's were killed by a gunman last night in an apartment on East 57th Street.

A group of leading international scholars and bankers will meet at the end of next month in Oyster Bay, L. I., to debate proposals to increase the flexibility of foreign exchange rates, the Council on Foreign Relations announced yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- "Is it a coal bin? Or perhaps a labyrinth for children?"

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 -- Years of controversy over Government "management of the news" are being punctuated this month by one record that few people in or out of Government are disposed to dispute: seventeen years of systematic Federal regulation of the flow of information about atomic testing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court today granted Capt. Dale E. Noyd of the Air Force a Christmas Eve reprieve from confinement at Cannon Air Force Base in New Mexico.
The Apollo 8 astronauts pointed a battery of cameras out their windows yesterday and recorded mankind's first close-up, in-person scrutiny of the moon.
Intelsat 3-A, the new communications satellite that was launched a week ago, made its international debut last night by carrying two historic messages.
'Twas the day before Christmas and all through the house, not a creature was stirring -- except the merger mouse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Navy is hoping that a special court of inquiry on the loss of the intelligence ship Pueblo can clear up a number of outstanding questions concerning the amount of secret data captured by North Korea, the resistance offered by the crew and the reported beatings of crewmen after capture.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 24 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon visited for an hour this morning Barbara Jane Mackle, the Florida girl who was kidnapped last Tuesday and imprisoned for 80 hours in a coffin-like box underground.

BONN, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger today described the invasion of Czechoslovakia by Warsaw Pact forces in August as the most significant event of 1968 and one that made a joint Western defense policy a pre-requisite for future progress.
The London Stock Exchange was slightly irregular yesterday in very quiet conditions.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 12 -- Rigoberto Sandoval, a short, pudgy 40-year-old agricultural economist who worked his way through the University of Arizona and the University of California, expects to send some sparks through Honduras next year.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- The Federal Government announced today that it would be unable to accept the one-week Christmas truce proposed by Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A 10-day postponement to Jan. 15 in the strike deadline set by the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen was reported today by the National Mediation Board.

The United States proposal to cut back American military bases in Japan will contribute to the security of both countries by putting a sounder base under their friendship. It should ease the strains in relations caused by the Mutual Defense Treaty and help pave the way for continuation of that treaty in 1970 when it comes up for possible revision or renunciation. American bases have provoked mounting criticism in Japan lately.

The election of Joseph Weintraub as a director of the Continental Corporation and to the boards of the Continental Insurance Company, the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York, the Niagara Fire Insurance Company and the Seaboard Fire Marine Insurance Company, was announced here yesterday.

SAIGON, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- President Nguyen Van Thieu, in a talk transmitted by the Armed Forces Radio and Television Services tonight, thanked all men fighting with the South Vietnamese for "the assistance, the contributions and the noble sacrifice that you have made in our fight to safeguard independence, democracy, peace and justice."

BRUSSELS, Dec. 24 -- The leading French and Dutch aircraft companies announced today plans to work together in Belgium as a first step toward what they described as the eventual creation of an "European Aeronautical Industry."
"Futz!" will close New Year's Eve at the Actors Playhouse. The play by Rochelle Owens will have had a run of 233 performances. The author is currently represented by Off Broadway's "Beclch."

Northwest Airlines, which President Johnson last week decided should have a new Central Pacific route to the Orient, in addition to its existing great-circle route via Alaska, yesterday entered the dispute raging for control of Air West, which serves 100 communities in eight Western states and Canada and Mexico.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Woody Hayes, coach of the unbeaten Ohio State football squad headed for the Rose Bowl, was named coach of the year by the Football Writers Association of America today.

Seven cartons of Jewish religious articles, said to be the first officially sent to the Soviet Union since 1917, were placed aboard an Aeroflot airliner here yesterday for delivery to Yehuda Leib Levin, Chief Rabbi of Moscow.
The 13-story building at 609 Fifth Avenue, which is known as the KLM Building, has been sold for $6.1-million.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued a list of changes in ownership of securities filed recently by officers, directors and large stockholders in its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue an insiders' report yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Churchill Downs instructed its workmen today to delete the name of Forward Pass from all signs referring to the 1968 Kentucky Derby, but that only compounded the confusion.

Not a container trailer -- or any other kind of cargo -- was stirring on Pier 42 at Morton Street yesterday as a strong Hudson River wind whipped over the pier, one of hundreds made strangely quiet by the dock strike.

GENEVA, Dec. 24 -- The relief airlift from the island of Fernando Po to Biafra was resumed last night after an appeal to the Government of Equatorial Guinea by August Lindt, the representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross for Nigeria and Biafra, the committee announced today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 24 -- Starting virtually from scratch after World War II and fighting the lingering effects of wartime bitterness and persistent racial animosity, Japan has achieved a position in the Australian economy that many observers here consider dangerously dominant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- President Johnson gathered his family today for his last Christmas in the White House, thankful for the release of the Pueblo crew, heartened with the progress of the Apollo moon mission and hopeful "that peace on earth will soon be a reality."

The Amoskeag Company, a closed-end investment concern controlled by the F. C. Dumaine family of Boston, plans to seek tenders for up to 200,000 common shares of its stock in exchange for other securities it now holds, it was reported yesterday.
On this day of giving and getting, it is not hard to acknowledge that gifts involve power -- the power to reward and please, the power to deny and disappoint.
TARANTO, Italy, Wednesday, Dec. 25 -- Pope Paul VI celebrated Christmas midnight mass here for 15,000 workers and members of their families in a huge, echoing rolling mill.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 24 -- President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz ordered the release today of 121 persons arrested during four months of student agitation against the Government.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Robert H. Finch promises that the Nixon Administration will make racial equality a national goal but will not be intimidated by the activities of black militants.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Penny Ann Early, who wants to be a jockey, was issued a license today to ride at Santa Anita -- but only as an exercise girl. The California Horse Racing Board said that Mrs. Early could drill horses in workouts.

A suspended city detective, accused of trafficking in narcotics, took the stand in Federal Court yesterday and testified that he actually had been trying to set a trap for a suspected narcotics seller.
PRAGUE, Dec. 24 -- Premier Oldrich Cernik sought to calm the uneasy Czechoslovak people tonight, urging them not to lose heart in the present difficult situation.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec, 24 (UPI) -- Michigan is looking for a football coach to replace Bump Elliott, university officials said today.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia announced yesterday that David P. Eastburn, David C. Melnicoff, Joseph V. Vergari, and Joseph R. Campbell had been appointed senior vice presidents of the bank. All four men had previously been vice presidents.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- A group of teen-agers, part of 1,600 members of the United Synagogue of American Youth in Chicago for their 18th annual convention, prayed today that the Soviet Union would grant its three million Jewish citizens equal cultural and religious rights.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax, who quit baseball at the height of a brilliant pitching career, said today planned to marry the 23-year-old daughter of Richard Widmark, the actor. The 32-year-old Koufax said he and Ann Widmark have dated "for the past six months or so." No wedding date has been set, but Koufax said they would marry "sooner than later."

A 10-round middleweight fight between a former champion, Emile Griffith, and Doyle Baird of Akron, Ohio, scheduled for Jan. 3, has been postponed indefinitely because Griffith has the flu, Harry Markson, director of boxing for Madison Square Garden, said yesterday.
Any doubts that the University of California, Los Angeles, is the unanimous choice as the No. 1 collegiate basketball team in the nation were dispelled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department announced today the signing of a Food for Freedom agreement to furnish to Tunisia $15.5-million worth of United States agricultural commodities. The agreement, signed in Tunis, covers soybeans and cottonseed oil, wheat, cotton, tallow, feed grains and barley.

NIDRION, Greece, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Twin Christmas trees twinkled from the bow and stern of the yacht Christina today as Mr. and Mrs. Aristotle Onassis spent their first Christmas holiday together in a quiet family gathering. The former Mrs. John F. Kennedy's children, John Jr. and Caroline, are with them at the isle of Skorpios.
FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 24 -- Torquato Fallordi has been selling man-made Christmas trees for the last nine days in the Via di Ripoli on the edge of Florence.

CAIRO, Dec. 21 -- A portrait of President Gamal Abdel Nasser stared out over the vast and vacant auditorium of Al Azhar University. The palm-shaded campus was empty and hushed except for the cries of peddlers outside the great iron gates.

ATHENS, Dec. 24 -- Greek archeologists cutting a tunnel through the volcanic waste of a prehistoric eruption on the Aegean island of Thera have discovered the homes of people who lived there 3,500 years ago.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 24 (UPI) Mrs. Arthur Feil lost her purse with $40 in it nine days ago and when the purse was found, the money was missing. Tonight she got $40 in the mail with no explanation and no return address.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Twenty-five women won more than 335,000 ($800,000) today in soccer pools.

Christmas morning, by long custom, has an added pleasure for us at The Times: It provides a chance to say thanks to the old and new readers who have contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. On this, the 57th annual Christmastime appeal, we extend appreciation on behalf of the real people behind the anonymous cases whose lives will be made a little brighter across the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- The Defense Department said today that it was seeking more qualified Negro, Puerto Rican, Mexican-American and other minority group men to apply for admission to the military service academies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The budget deficit for the fiscal year 1968 shrank from $25.4-billion to $25.2-billion, the Treasury Department announced today in its final statement on the year that closed June 30.

THE season ends today for the George Washington High School swimming team a loser in New York's Public Schools Athletic League but a winner in history. In two meets this year a 16-year-old senior girl, Peggy Loewy, competed directly against boys for the only times in local memory. Her performances were not spectacular, but she scored a few points for her team.

The dates for the Spring Boston Gift Show have been changed to March 3 through 7 in order to avoid a conflict with the New York Gift Show, it was announced yesterday. The New York event will run Feb. 23 through 28.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand Dec. 25 (AP) -- Fifty men sat down to the traditional turkey and cranberry sauce at the South Pole today, but the Christmas dinner this year had an Oriental flavor. TORONTO, Dec. 25 (Canadian) Press) -- G. A. Gale, Chief Justice of the Ontario Appeal Court, said Tuesday he had received four telephone calls threatening his life on the evening of Nov. 29 and the morning of Nov. 30. Sales of used machine tools in November fell slightly from October but continued to run about 15 per cent above the level for the first nine months of 1968, the Machinery Dealers National Association announced yesterday.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 25 -- On the second day of Christmas, many Southern California horsemen will hew to local tradition and help Santa Anita Park begin its 32d winter season of thoroughbred racing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Dr. J. Allen Hynek, director of the Lindheimer Astronomical Research Center at Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill., viewed the Apollo 8 mission today as opening the door to the exploration of outer space by scientists.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Thousands of holiday skiers were cut off from the outside world in this leading French winter resort today by heavy snow.

Ralph Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, said yesterday that the present system of stock certificates should be changed in order to help solve the problem of the paperwork backlog on Wall Street.
ROME, Dec. 25 -- Pope Paul VI, in a Christmas message today, diagnosed for the second time in a week the ills of humanity and prescribed a renewal of devotion to Christian values as the cure.

HOUSTON, Dec. 25 -- Despite its threatening appearance in recent days the sun, by this evening, had not displayed a single major eruption since the three Apollo astronauts were launched into space last Saturday.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 25 -- The Nixons, as planned, spent a quiet Christmas day under clear blue skies and a warming sun.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UPI) - Postmaster General W. Marvin Watson said today that during the Christmas season this year the Post Office "spent less money to move more mail" than last year.

Phelps Dodge Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the election of its president, Edward H. Michaelsen, to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds Edgar P. Dunlaevy, board chairman, who is to continue in that post and as a director of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the parent company.

ATHENS, Dec. 26 -- Two Arab gunmen opened fire on a New York-bound Israeli jetliner as it prepared to take off from the Athens airport today. One of the 41 passengers was killed, the Boeing 707's port engines were wrecked and the plane caught fire.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Israel warned Arab Governments that back terrorists tonight that Arab airliners were as vulnerable as Israeli ones.
BEAVER FALLS, Pa., Dec. 26 (AP) -- A chartered bus veered off the Pennsylvania Turnpike early today, dropped down an embankment and flipped over, killing three persons.

Prices throughout the Government securities market staged a sharp rally yesterday, ending the steep slide in prices that had been going on ever since the Federal Reserve raised the discount rate more than a week ago.

Final results of 1968 operations of the Radio Corporation of America are expected to show record sales and net income, Robert W. Sarnoff, president and chief executive officer, said yesterday in his year-end statement.

Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona has made the logical move in deciding to oppose Speaker John W. McCormack for re-election in next week's House Democratic caucus. It is much better for House liberals to test their strength openly against the leadership than to engage in underground grumbling and dissidence.
The Paris stock exchange, the only European market operating yesterday, was narrowly irregular. International issues were quiet.

TOKYO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Imperial Household Economic Council decided today to increase the allowances of Emperor Hirohito and his family to meet the rising cost of living in Japan. An increase of 10 per cent was voted on the present $233,330-a-year living allowance.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Philadelphia 76ers ended Baltimore's nine-game winning streak tonight with a 125-120 National Basketball Association victory over the Bullets at the Spectrum.
GREENVILLE, N. C., Dec. 26 (AP) -- East Carolina came from behind in the closing minutes to trim Cornell, 74-67, tonight in the opening round of the first East Carolina basketball tournament.
HOUSTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- His family was very much a part of Capt. James A. Lovell Jr.'s thoughts today as Apollo 8 broadcast its final television show.

RICHMOND, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The American Novawood Corporation, in a suit filed in the U.S. District Court here today, charged the Atlantic Richfield Company with antitrust law violations. It asked preliminary injunctions that would prevent the proposed merger of Richfield and the Sinclair Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26, (Reuters) -- Leonid I. Sedov, a leading Soviet space scientist, said in a statement distributed today by the Soviet Embassy that Soviet scientists rejoice at the achievements of the Apollo moon flight.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 26 -- New England was one big icebox today. The temperatures dipped well below zero at most ski areas, and enthusiasts spent much of the day surrounding hot drinks in the lodges.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 26 -- One hundred and Fifty one United States servicemen died in combat in South Vietnam last week, the lowest number in five weeks.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Jimmy Roberts and Gary Sabourin scored within 90 seconds in the third period tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Snow plows reopened the road to this Alpine ski town today even as heavy snow and avalanches isolated at least one other resort
Only a fifth of the city's more than a million public school pupils attended classes yesterday on the first of the Christmas time "make-up" school days.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 26 (AP) -- An 18-year-old Israeli soldier was killed and three persons were wounded by mines in the Jordan Valley today, the army announced. A soldier was wounded when an army vehicle hit a mine a mile south of the Allen-by Bridge across the Jordan.

The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation announced yesterday the establishment of Principio Alloys near Columbus, Ohio, to conduct research and development in powered allow composition, alloy parts manufacturing methods and heat treatment of metals.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Alberto Dines, editor of the newspaper Jornal do Brasil, said today he had not been interrogated or given an explanation for his arrest while confined four days in the barracks of an artillery regiment near here.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26 -- Three young Russians who spent a year in a simulated spaceship in the Moscow area told, in interviews published today, about the frictions and problems that arose in their long isolation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has ruled that the Kaneb Pipe Line Company of Houston is not a holding company in its relationship with the Kansas-Nebraska Natural Gas Company.
After six sessions of declines the stock market moved slightly upward yesterday, as the traditional holiday period of strength got under way.

New York State taxpayers, facing an almost inevitable increase in state taxes at the approaching session of the Legislature, have a direct interest in reform of the state's whole budget-making process. As Controller Arthur S. Levitt has pointed out, the single annual budget is no longer adequate.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Friday, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The United States recaptured the Davis Cup from Australia today on the doubles triumph of Stan Smith and Bob Lutz over Ray Ruffels and John Alexander, 6-4, 6-4, 6-2.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (AP) -- George Allen was dismissed unexpectedly today as head coach of the Los Angeles Rams after three successful seasons because of what Dan Reeves, the club president, described as a personality conflict.

It looks as if a "stock exchange" for TV spot buying isn't too far off. Two of the nation's major research companies are seriously exploring the possibility of automated time-buying systems whose huge computer hearts would be programed with station rates, available time, audience profiles, costs per thousands and all those little tidbits that bring happiness to media men.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Don Freeman, hitting on 14 of 16 attempts from the foul line, scored 42 points tonight to lead Miami's Floridians to a 111-108 victory over the Houston Mavericks in an American Basketball Associaation game.

MIAMI, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Angel Cordero Jr. rode four winners at Tropical Park today to raise his total for the year to 342 as the Puerto Rican jockey widened his lead over Alvaro Pineda in their battle for the 1968 riding championship.
PRAGUE, Dec. 26 -- Czechoslovaks heard expressions of support tonight for two liberal leaders who have fallen from favor with the Soviet Union.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The frozen body of Pamela Powers, 10 years old, abducted here the day before Christmas, was found today in a culvert near an Interstate 80 interchange east of the city.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Penn State completed drills here today and will resume work Saturday in Miami for its Orange Bowl meeting New Year's night with Kansas Coach Joe Paterno called today's session "one of the best we've had here "
After two and a half days aground off Rockaway Point, Queens, the 167-foot tanker Mary A. Whalen was pulled free at 1:45 P.M. yesterday.

BRADFORD, Pa., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Twenty-one persons remained hospitalized today with injuries suffered in a Christmas Eve plane crash that killed 20.

The New York Pro Musica's production of "The Play of Herod" has undoubtedly seemed complete to the thousands who have seen it since it was first given in 1963, but a new, useful and moving element has been added to the 12th-century musical drama.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy has called for immediate withdrawal of "substantial numbers" of American troops from South Vietnam as the first step toward withdrawal of all foreign troops in 1969.

A protest by six of the seven black students at the Yale University Drama School in New Haven has resulted in the cancellation of Sam Shepard's new play, "Operation Sidewinder." Performances had been scheduled from Jan. 23 until Feb. 8 at the university's Repertory Theater.

ROME, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The Apollo 8 astronauts were invited today to spend their next vacations in Italy. The Italian National Tourist Board sent a cable to the homes of the three spacemen inviting them and their families to spend a free holiday in Italy.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 26 -- President-elect and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon sunned and rested today on Grand Cay, an uncharted island in the Bahamas.
Theodore Karagheuzoff, a low-key professional engineer, was named Traffic Commissioner by Mayor Lindsay yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The Chicago Bulls, led by 23 points from Jerry Sloan and 21 from Bob Boozer, defeated the Cincinnati Royals, 104-96, tonight.
Mediation efforts in the strike of longshoremen along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts will resume under Federal auspices this morning in a growing atmosphere of pessimism.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 26 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association will honor 17 former athletes now prominent in the entertainment field at a luncheon Jan. 7 in connection with the 63d N.C.A.A. convention in Los Angeles.

ATHENS, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- One passenger on the El Al plane, Joseph Engel of 1199 Broadway, New York City, said: "As we were ready to take off, the shooting started and I told my family to lie on the floor. There was some screaming inside the plane.
The Allied Chemical Corporation yesterday announced the election of John T. Connor as chairman and of Frederick L. Bissinger as president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 26 -- The navigational officer of the Pueblo disclosed today that he used fabricated charts to foil an attempt by the North Koreans to make it appear the intelligence ship was captured inside North Korean waters.
NEWARK, Dec. 26 (AP) -- More than 140 persons were left homeless tonight in a four-alarm blaze of unknown origin that roared through three tenements in the Central Ward.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries said yesterday they would spend almost $5-billion in 1969 on new plant and equipment. This would be by far the largest amount ever spent by any company on expansion in a single year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- The Arab commando organization that claims responsibility for the attack on the El Al plane accused the Israeli airline today of having carried out "aggressive military activity."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Lawrence F. O'Brien, Democratic national chairman, says the party emerged from the 1968 elections as a stronger, healthier organization that has proved itself capable of embracing "an open, and even turbulent, debate of the issues."

NORWICH, England, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Anthony Grey, the Reuters correspondent held in solitary confinement in Peking for 17 months, said in a Christmas telegram received by his mother today that he was being treated for pharyngitis, a mild throat infection, but otherwise was well.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- A correspondent of a Japanese newspaper, Chunichi, was taken prisoner by the Vietcong yesterday, a colleague said here today. The captured journalist, Yoshiko Sahashi, was sailing in a sampan on a Mekong Delta waterway when captured.

Dr. M. T. Mehdi, secretary general of the Action Committee on American-Arab relations, said yesterday morning in New York that the attack on an Israeli passenger jet in Athens was a "retaliation by the Arabs against Israeli aerial attacks on Arab villages in Jordan."

Merger activity continued strong yesterday, as several companies moved toward and away from acquisitions. The Jim Walter Corporation announced it would make a tender offer for any and all common stock of the United States Pipe and Foundry Company.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Ron Sellers, Florida State University flanker, was named Florida amateur athlete of the year today.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had imposed restrictions on the brokerage firm of Delafield Delafield, one of its partners and one of its former salesmen.

Eight months ago the first steps were taken that would lead the London hit, "Hadrian VII," to Broadway where it opens Jan. 8 at the Helen Hayes. Its crossing, if not exactly the stuff of sagas, nevertheless, embraces the range of trauma, hardship and problems that typically attend such trans-Atlantic undertakings.

TRENTON, Dec. 26 -- A high state aide confirmed tonight that a Democratic State Senator and two Assemblymen, one a Republican and one a Democrat, were among six legislators allegedly linked by state officials to the underworld.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation refused today to comment on a published report that a Federal grand jury was investigating an alleged plot by five men to assassinate the nine Supreme Court Justices by blowing up their courtroom.

MADRID, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Government declined today to confirm or deny that it had ordered the Bourbon-Parma family expelled. General Franco is said to prefer another line, the House of Bourbon, if the vacant throne has an occupant.
Labor negotiators began rolling up their sleeves yesterday for a big push at reaching several contract agreements here by the first of the year.
HOUSTON, Dec. 26 -- Apollo 8 sped earthward tonight toward a planned splashdown in the Pacific Ocean tomorrow morning and the end of man's first voyage around the moon.

Carla Fracci and Erik Bruhn will end their third joint season with the American Ballet Theater next week, rounding out another season as one of the most successful teams in American ballet -- a state of affairs traceable directly to a good connection by the telephone company.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The United States will give India two loans totaling $231-million under agreements signed today. One loan of $194-million will finance imports for industry and agriculture. The other loan, of $37-million, will finance imports of machinery for expansion of a fertilizer plant in Maharashtra State.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- North Vietnam and the Vietcong said in a joint statement today that if the United States really wanted an "honorable peace" in Vietnam, Washington and Saigon must accept at once their side's round-table proposal.

Thomson McKinnon, a medium-size and well-known member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, will change early in 1969 from a partnership to a corporation, a trend gaining momentum among Big Board houses.
BOSTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A Boston antipoverty trainee was arrested today and charged with stealing 352 Massachusetts welfare checks worth more than $100,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, today challenged 77-year-old John W. McCormack of Massachusetts for election as Speaker of the House in the 91st Congress.

HOUSTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The wives of the Apollo 8 astronauts plan to stay in their homes near their television sets and special radio receivers tomorrow as their husbands attempt the riskiest re-entry yet.

LIKE Earl Morrall of Baltimore, Bill Nelsen of the Cleveland Browns is a quarterback who rose from deep obscurity to direct a winning team in a championship game. The game is the one in Cleveland on Sunday for the National Football League title and matching the Browns and the Colts.

Patrolman Frank Gucciardi, a New York City policeman who was injured last spring during the Columbia University campus disorders, will be given an American Legion law and order citation Sunday on behalf of the society's regional organization.
The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company said yesterday that initial marketing of shares in its two new mutual funds would begin Feb. 1.

The promotion of Norman P. Schatton to senior vice president has been announced by the Alexander Summer Company of Teaneck, N. J., a real estate concern. Mr. Schatton has been with the company for 15 years, and is a specialist in the leasing of shopping center space.

HOUSTON, Dec. 26 -- After nearly a quarter-million-mile journey from the moon, Apollo 8' will shoot for a fixed point in the sky at the fringe of the atmosphere when its astronauts return to earth tomorrow.
MOSCOW, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Union launched Cosmos 262 today. The Soviet press agency, Tass, said the latest space satellite's initial period of revolution was 95.2 minutes.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- The Justice Department asserted today that the evidence in the trial of Dr. Benjamin Spock and three other men for conspiring to counsel evasion of the draft warranted a finding of conspiracy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham left South Vietnam today after a Christmas tour and said he would give President-elect Richard M. Nixon a report reflecting "cautious optimism." Mr. Graham is a friend of the President-elect.
HONG KONG, Dec. 26 -- Mao Tse-tung, Chairman of the Chinese Communist party, observed today his 75th birthday as his nation appeared to be entering a critical new period.

DALLAS, Dec. 26 -- A panel of eminent scientists painted a picture today of a brave new world, not very far off, in which diabetics would discard their insulin injections after being cured by permanent genetic surgery, infants with birth defects would be born anew, mental defectives would get healthy new genes, sterile women would bear their own children and people would duplicate themselves without sex.

The Griswold - Eshleman Company has announced the election of David Skylar and Perry L. Brand as executive vice presidents, giving the Cleveland-based agency a total of three. William V. Levy and James F. McManus were named vice presidents.

The management of Saks Fifth Avenue, the country's largest specialty-store chain, will pass next February for the first time in more than four decades to executives who are not members of the Gimbel family.
ONE of the major construction and real estate holding companies in Israel has granted its American shareholders a property interest guaranteed by an Israeli bank.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 26 -- Monmouth College of West Long Branch, N. J., and Upsala College advanced to the semifinal round of the New Jersey Kiwanis basketball tourney at Montclair State College's Panzer Gym tonight by scoring opening-round victories.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Jerry Wolman, the financially harried owner of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League, said today that he had not found a purchaser for the club, but he pointed out that he had until May, 1969, to do so if he could not solve his financial problems.

Columbia University and WCBS-TV will combine to produce "Black Heritage: A History of Afro-Americans," a series of 108 half-hour programs about the Negro experience in this country, beginning Monday, Jan. 6, on Channel 2.

Delinquency rates on bank loans to consumers dropped to record low levels at the end of October, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. On Oct. 31, the association said, only 1.46 per cent of all consumer loans outstanding were overdue 30 days or more, down from 1.54 per cent on Aug. 31. This was "the lowest Oct. 31 ratio recorded since this series began approximately 20 years ago," the report said.
A record $37,744,436 was contributed to the 1968 Heart Fund campaign, the American Heart Association reported yesterday. The previous high was $35,928,221 in 1967.

KOWTOWING to the infinite wisdom of the expert assayers of football, sideline observers never so much as questioned a couple of preseason estimates. They were so obvious that the fans merely nodded heads in agreement not even noticing the lack of originality in the phrasing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Census Bureau's new composite index of 12 "leading" economic indicators nearly leveled off in November after rising fairly consistently in preceding months, it was reported today.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- F. D. Robbins of Salt Lake City, the second-seeded player in the tournament, rallied today to whip Danny Birchmore of Athens, Ga., 5-7, 6-3, 6-2, in the Orange Bowl junior tennis championships and gain the quarter-finals.

All but obliterated in the grim tide of strike news that has enveloped the city in recent weeks is organized labor's assumption of direct responsibility for underwriting a pioneering project in physical, mental and vocational rehabilitation. The project was initiated five years ago by the New York City Central Labor Council, with the aid of $580,000 in grants from the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved the merger of the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, Philadelphia's largest bank, with a newly formed interim bank. The merger is a major step in the formation, by First Pennsylvania, of a one-bank holding company.

CHERRY HILL, N. A Columbia University disciplinary panel yesterday placed a law student on probation for participating in a demonstration that temporarily halted university registration last September. The student, Gustin I., Reichbach, is a leader of the campus chapter of Students for a Democratic Society.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Six members of Mexico's Olympic Military Battalion were killed today in a car crash on a Mexico City freeway. The Olympic Battalion was created earlier in the year to provide guards and guides for the Olympic Games.

TOKYO, Dec. 26 -- American and Japanese officials agree that the United States is surrendering virtually none of its military capability in this part of the world by its agreement to yield 50 military installations in Japan.

ADAM LONG GIMBEL, who yesterday announced his retirement on Feb. 1 as president of Saks Fifth Avenue, has been described as a "true Renaissance man in the world of retailing." THE 1969 New England Sportsmen's and Camping Show in Boston's War Memorial Auditorium in the Prudential Center will run Jan. 18 through 26.

Earnings of the Penn Central Company in 1968 will be "considerably better than for 1967," Stuart T. Saunders, chairman, said yesterday in a year-end statement.

The Union Dime Savings Bank announced yesterday a series of key management changes. Alan C. Thomas was elected mortgage officer in charge of the bank's $750-million mortgage portfolio. Max B. Meth was named to head the bank's data processing center.

RIVERS, Man., Dec. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Two meteorological technicians at the Canadian Forces Base here reported sighting the Apollo 8 spacecraft as it hurtled toward earth tonight. MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- At a time when college costs are climbing, recruiting has begun in the islands of poverty that dot Westchester's suburban affluence for the first class of a tuition-free college whose first entrance requirement is the inability to pay and the desire to learn.

HOUSTON, Dec. 26 -- Following are excerpts from the radio communications today between the Apollo 8 spacecraft and the Mission Control Center at the Manned Spacecraft Center here. The conversations were broadcast on television.

The Rangers and the Oakland Seals titillated a youthful, festive crowd at Madison Square Garden last night, piling up a total of 62 minutes in penalties while the New Yorkers, with no particular distinction save for their aggressiveness, scored a 3-1 victory.
AT 3 o'clock yesterday morning an orange tugboat headed up the Hudson, into the dark night and bitter, 22-mile-an-hour winds, beginning what should have been a five-hour trip to Hastings and back.

The wholesale commodity price index rose to 99.5 on Monday from 99.3 on Friday.
