WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -The Commerce Department estimated last week's department store sales at $1,404,000,000, up 2 per cent from the yearearlier $1,383,000,000. Total retail store sales were $8,871,000,000, up 1 per cent.
The recital by Joseph Schwartz, pianist, which was originally scheduled for tonight at 8:30 in Carnegie Recital Hall, has been canceled because of Mr. Schwartz's illness.

LIVERPOOL, England, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Nearly 10,000 of 11,000 longshoremen failed to report for work today after the Christmas and Boxing Day holidays and about 60 ships were left idle. The men had been told that they could have worked through their lunch hour and gone home early.

MERRICK, L. I., Dec. 27 -A 29-year-old housewife was shot and killed in her home here today while her 18-monthold son was sleeping in an adjacent bedroom and the family's German shepherd dog was in the house.
Federal mediation efforts in the week-old longshore strike recessed last night after a day of haggling over language in a new contract for the Port of New York.

William A. Casselman, executive editor of The New York Dail News, will retire Tuesday to be succeeded by Floyd Barger, the associate editor. The changes were announced last night by F. M. Flynn, president and publisher.

Three men, including a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner, are missing at sea aboard a 33-foot sloop that left Bristol, R. I., early this month bound for St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands by way of Bermuda.
The 82 crewmen of the intelligence ship Pueblo recently freed from North Korean captivity congratulated the Apollo 8 astronauts yesterday on their "tremendous achievements and triumphant return."

ADELAIDE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Clark Graebner capped a comeback campaign today by beating Ray Ruffels of Australia in a five-set duel that put the United States a step away from a five-match sweep of the Davis Cup.

In the first of two all-Bach concerts at Carnegie Hall, Alexander Schneider directed a chamber orchestra last night in a program of warm, homey Bach playing. As music, it was a bit overheated and unrefreshed by current trends toward a fast, fleet-footed style of baroque playing.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The 31st annual Blue-Gray football game tomorrow pits the Southerners' speed afoot against the passing of Greg Cook of Cincinnati in what both coaches agree should be a high-scoring game.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 27 -- Worcester Tech, the defending Worcester Junior Chamber of Commerce tournament champions advanced tonight to the second round of play with a 77-66 victory over C. W. Post College.
HOUSTON, Dec. 27 -- The first circumnavigators of the moon brought the epic flight of Apollo 8 to a safe and successful finish this morning with a pinpoint splashdown in the Pacific Ocean.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Pvt. John Robinson of the Marines, of Sarasota, Fla., has been released from the Portsmouth Naval Prison where he went on a hunger strike following a six-month sentence for taking part in a California antiwar demonstration.

The secretary to the chairman of the city's Office of Collective Bargaining has charged the Americana Hotel with racial discrimination because she and some friends were ordered from an elevator one midnight last month and interrogated about their presence in the hotel.
WASHINGTON -- The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic in the week ended Dec. 21 totaled an estimated 13.6 billion ton-miles -- up 5 per cent from the comparable 1967 week.

A recent national sampling of 10,000 American families indicates that there are twice as many major felonies, burglaries and personal assaults as find their way into the official statistics compiled by local police departments and published by the F.B.I. Without the hard facts, law enforcement and crime prevention cannot be effective.

The first two games of the 17th annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival basketball tournament proved to be mismatches at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. St. John's swept past Michigan State, 61 -- 51, and University of California, Los Angeles, overpowered Providence, 98--81, with neither winning team having a particularly good game.

EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The coaches whose teams meet tomorrow afternoon in the Sun Bowl football classic had little else but compliments for each other as the two squads took final workouts today.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Depauw controlled the boards and streaked to a 75-55 victory over Amherst, and Clark routed Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 79-55, today in the opening round of the fifth annual Worcester Jaycee holiday basketball festival.
Rebellious Democrats are looking for ways to preserve and organize the political energies stirred up by the Presidential campaign of 1968.

James M. Lundy, president of Macy's California, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of that store division of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., effective Feb. 1. Edward S. Finkelstein, executive vice president of the Bamberger's division of R. H. Macy, has been named to succeed Mr. Lundy as president of Macy's California.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -Demonstrations designed to continue the demand for the immediate withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam are being planned for Washington, D. C., during the Presidential inauguration. Rennie Davis, coordinator for the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam, said today a march from the White House to the Capitol will be held Jan. 19, as well as a counter-inauguration ball.
HONOLULU, Dec. 27 (AP) -Capt. Jim Holliday, pilot of Pan American Flight 812 from Fiji, said the Apollo 8 first appeared as a cherry red dot below the star Capella.

Estelle Liebling teaches only eight students a day at her studio on Central Park South. She used to work from 9:30 A.M. until 6:30 P.M., but a few years ago she had a heart attack. Now she is not allowed to take more than four students in the morning and four in the afternoon.

MONTREAL, Dec. 27 (AP) -Lorne (Gump) Worsley, the Montreal Canadiens' goalie who has been sidelined since late November with a nervous ailment, returned to practice sessions with the National Hockey League club today.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 27 (AP) -Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel expressed deep satisfaction at the announcement that the United States would sell 50 Phantom jets to Israel. "This is a positive conclusion of an effort which began early this year at the meeting between Premier Levi Eshkol and President Johnson," Mr. Eban said.

The Metropolitan Opera will present a new production of Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier" on Jan. 23, with Leonie Rysanek, Christa Ludwig, Reri Grist, Rosalind Elias and Walter Berry. Nathaniel Merrill is staging the opera, and the sets and costumes have been designed by Robert O'Hearn.

The Insurance Information Institute estimated yesterday that traffic accidents and road injuries in October cost the United States nearly one-fifth more than in October, 1967. The institute's October figures for what it called "the economic loss from America's highway carnage" rose from $1,167,856,000 to $1,390,695,000.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 27 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that he was opposed to the death penalty for Arab guerrillas.

MADRAS, India, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Eleven persons were arrested today in connection with a Christmas night attack by anti-Communist peasants on a Communistdominated Madras village in which 42 persons, many of them children, were killed.

ABOARD U.S.S. YORKTOWN, in Pacific, Dec. 27 -- Out of a gray mist and into a dark ocean, the Apollo 8 spacecraft splashed into the Pacific at 10:51 A.M., Eastern standard time, today within sight of the men who crowded the flight deck of this aircraft carrier.
LANESBORO, Mass., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The police reported today that three persons had been killed and four injured in a collision between two cars near here.
PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Security precautions have been reinforced at Orly Airport as a result of the attack in Athens, the police reported today.
IT was late in the afternoon and a freezing, bonewarping north wind ripped across Rikers Island, where 6,500 men are imprisoned.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- A $145,000 grant from the Ford Foundation is making it possible for Dr. Hugh Tracey to realize his lifelong dream of collecting the music of Africa and organizing it as an integral part of African culture.
TOKYO, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- A painting by Toulouse-Lautrec was reported missing today from an exhibition in Kyoto, according to the police. The painting, "Marcelle," is valued at $100,000.

The United States District Court for Massachusetts upheld yesterday the validity of certain patents relating to color television tubes held by the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. It also ruled that these patents had been infringed by Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.
National and foreign reaction yesterday to the success of the Apollo 8 mission was characterized by jubilation, awe and praise, according to correspondents of The New York Times.
WARSAW, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- The Polish Government has sent a letter of condolence to the Roman Catholic Church on the death of a prominent bishop in an unusual public gesture of courtesy.

DETROIT, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The water levels of most of the Great Lakes continued to drop as winter set in, a survey reported today. Except for Lake Ontario, which rose two inches, all the Great Lakes plus Lake St. Clair dropped an average of over an inch within the last 30 days, according to the United States Army Corps of Engineer district records.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 17 -- "About half of the population of Morocco is under 14 years old," said the young schoolteacher. "This is our real problem.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- A proposed Long Island Sound bridge between Rye and Oyster Bay, would be self-supporting, even if a second bridge were built across the Sound, according to a state engineering report.

"Dear World;" the new musical starring Angela Lansbury, will have its Broadway premiere at the Mark Hellinger Theater on Sunday evening, Feb. 2, it was announced yesterday by Alexander H. Cohen, the producer.

Former Mayor Robert B. Wagner, now the United States Ambassador to Spain, said here yesterday that he would "not exclude consideration" of a race for the late Robert F. Kennedy's Senate seat if the Supreme Court should order the post filled by election next fall.

MIAMI, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Angel Cordero Jr. rode another winner at Tropical Park today to raise his year's total to 343 and make it harder for Alvaro Pineda to catch him in the battle for the 1968 jockey championship.

READING, Pa., Dec. 27 -- St. Francis (Pa.) scored 51 points in the second half and trounced Hofstra, 92-67 in the first round of the Albright invitation tourney tonight. Three men reached the 20-point mark for St. Francis, Larry Lewis with 23, Norm Vanlier, with 21 and Mike Copeland with 20.
Price increases for two important metals -- nickel and copper -- were announced yesterday. Both metals have been in heavy demand.

DALLAS, Dec. 27 -- The formation of a new national agency to establish priorities in science and technology on the basis of the nation's longrange social needs was urged today by two leading spokesmen for science.

PRAGUE, Dec. 27 -- A highranking Soviet delegation arrived in Prague tonight for talks that could determine the fate of Josef Smrkovsky, the liberal chairman of the National Assembly who is popular in Czechoslovakia but opposed by the Soviet Union.
OTTAWA, Dec. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau left by air from Montreal today for a skin-diving holiday in the Gulf of Mexico area, his office here announced.

FORT EUSTIS, Va., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Catawba edged Hampton Institute 89-87, and Fort Eustis whipped Denison, 98-89, in two overtimes in the opening round of the Eustis Christmas invitation basketball tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent and her son, Patrick Lyndon, have gone off on a private vacation, the White House said today. A press aide said that they left Wednesday for a "private trip" but was unable to give the destination.
HOUSTON, Dec. 27 -- New Year's Eve came a little early today to the flight controllers here at the Manned Spacecraft Center.
GREENVILLE, N. C., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Air Force rallied in the second half for an 85-70 victory over Cornell in a consolation game of the East Carolina basketball classic tonight.

A bill making it a Class A misdemeanor for an art expert to authenticate a counterfeit work of art with intent to defraud will be re-introduced in the 1969 session of the Legislature, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has announced.

ATHENS, Dec. 27 -- The two Arabs accused of shooting at an Israeli jetliner at the Athens airport yesterday, killing a passenger, will be charged tomorrow with eight offenses ranging from murder to arson.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Johnson suggested today that future Federal revenues from the undeveloped shale oil resources in the West might be set aside as a fund for education.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's remarks telephoned to the Apollo 8 astronauts aboard the carrier Yorktown, as recorded by The New York Times:
ADELAIDE, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Donald Dell, the United States Davis Cup captain, said today he expected Arthur Ashe and Clark Graebner to help defend the cup next year.

"FORTUNATELY," said the coach, John Wooden, "our big man, Lewis, is a very good team man. Otherwise, the other players would be very resentful of the publicity and attention he receives. But this is not the case. Lewis is a very good team man."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 -- The Baltimore Colts reactivated today Timmy Brown, a halfback and a dangerous spot player, for Sunday's game here against the Cleveland Browns to decide the championship of the National Football League.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Utah State and Delaware are slated to provide the competition for Wisconsin and Marquette in the 1969 Milwaukee basketball tourney.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Danny Kelly scored 26 points, 10 within 85 seconds, today as St. Joseph's upset favored DePaul, 74-64, in the opening round of the eighth Quaker City basketball tournament. It was the first defeat in six starts for DePaul.

Within minutes of the Apollo 8 splashdown, the Havana radio broadcast a tape of the Voice of America's Spanish language description of the event. The transmission was the second of its type in Cuba's factual and comprehensive coverage of the lunar mission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The Army today awarded the General Motors Corporation a contract to produce more than $100-million worth of trucks and ambulances. The initial award -- design and test -- was $9.5-million.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -The Post Office Department announced today that how Senators and Representatives used their postal franking privileges in the future was "a matter strictly between the Member of Congress and his conscience."
Three key indicators of credit policy pointed toward tighter money during the most recent reporting periods, the Federal Reserve said yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- An airline pilot who sighted the blazing re-entry of Apollo 8 today said he had seen a red ball of fire followed by an incandescent white streamer that must have been almost 100 miles long.
PARIS, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -Prince Xavier of BourbonParma arrived in Paris today after another setback to his family's hopes of claiming the long-vacant Spanish throne.

A Bronx man and his wife were arrested yesterday after the police allegedly found narcotics valued at $1-million in the bedroom of their apartment. The man attempted to fire at detectives with a .38-caliber pistol, according to the police, but the gun misfired.

SEABROOK, Tex., Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The wives of the Apollo 8 crew whispered soft prayers, sipped champagne toasts and gave thanks to a thankful world today for the safe return from space of their hero husbands.

The most fantastic voyage of all times ended happily yesterday precisely at the preassigned moment and place. The travels that earned immortality for Marco Polo, Columbus and Magellan all fade before the incredible achievement of the Apollo 8 crew, Frank Borman, James Lovell and William Anders. Trailblazers for mankind, they flew to the neighborhood of the moon and returned safely to the earth that had given them birth.

ONE of the most embarrassing circumstances for a defender at the bridge table is to find the only lead that would allow a contract to be made. A fine example of this type of generosity occurred on the diagramed deal, which was played in an expert match.
Prices eased yesterday in light trading on the American Stock Exchange.

HONOLULU, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Unbeaten Columbia, holding a 41-25 half-time bulge, held off a second-half rally by Stanford last night to down the Indians, 69-66, in the opener of the Fifth annual Rainbow Classic.

BEIRUT, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Government rejected today a charge by an Israeli Cabinet member that the Lebanese regime was to blame for the attack yesterday on the El Al jetliner. The Israeli charge was made by Transport Minister Moshe Carmel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Communist China was reported to have resumed its nuclear testing program today with the explosion in the atmosphere of a device -- presumably thermonuclear -- having a yield of three megatons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The United States announced the completion of an agreement today to sell 50 F-4 Phantom jets to Israel. Delivery of the jets wilt start in late 1969 as Israel has requested.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 -Against the background of a player revolt, fan upheaval and bitter team-management relations, George Allen the deposed coach of the Los Angeles Rams, announced that he would "bear his pride" and return to the Rams if so asked by the club's owner, Dan Reeves.
GENEVA, Dec. 27 -- The relief agencies said today that the eight American planes would allow them to double the amount of food they could deliver.

The Modern Language Association of America opened its big annual conference here yesterday, and the language could hardly have been more contemporary: protests about the arrest of three men attending the conference, about the war in Vietnam, about racism in America, and about the plan to hold next year's conference in Chicago.
DENVER, Dec. 27 -- State tax increases totaling $97.3-million, in personal income taxes, have been recommended to Republican Gov. John Love.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27 (Canadian Press) -- At least 37 persons died accidentally in Canada during the Christmas holiday period, with Ontario and Quebec accounting for more than half the total. A survey from Tuesday evening to midnight Thursday showed 25 persons had died on the highways, eight in fires, one in a shooting mishap, one in a fall and one by freezing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie said today that American society was undergoing rapid change and that the nation must choose between peaceful political change and "the politics of confrontation, which can ultimately lead to antidemocratic repression."
TEL AVIV, Dec. 27 (AP) -Rage gripped Israel today at the attack yesterday on an Israeli airliner in Athens, and the press warned that the Government would decide on "a suitable reprisal" in due time.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Topseeded Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., easily disposed of Allan Fox of Los Angeles, 6-0, 6-2, as the annual Sugar Bowl tennis tournament opened today.
DETROIT, Dec. 27 (UPI) -Pete Stemkowski's unassisted goal with 5:22 to play tonight enabled the Detroit Red Wings to gain a 3-3 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania said today that he had assurances of a clear majority for election as Senate Republican whip, or assistant leader, in the new Congress.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Wagner College trounced St. Michael's of Vermont, 67-62, tonight at the LeMoyne College Christmas invitation basketball tournament. The high scorer for Wagner was Ray Hodge, with 18 points.
Helen Hayes said yesterday that she was "trying to beat the theater habit by doing an odd job in films."
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -Irene M. Roose said today that Navy officials had scolded her for telling a reporter that her son, a Pueblo crewman, was tortured by his North Korean captors.
DETROIT, Dec. 27 -- The General Motors Corporation recalled today 25,500 automobiles, all German-made Opels or Chevrolet Corvette sports cars, for correction of possible safety defects.

PUNTA ARENAS, Chile, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Max Conrad, the flier, waited on Adelaide Island in the Antarctic today for a break in the weather that would allow him to continue his around-the-world flight by passing over the South Pole.
The Foreign Ministers of three Southeast Asian nations have set an example in diplomatic finesse that deserves emulation.
Lower-than-expected Ghana central purchase figures released yesterday pushed cocoa prices up almost the penny-a-pound daily limit.

The first point of worry about the appointment of Walter J. Hickel as Secretary of the Interior is the slackness he demonstrated as Governor of Alaska toward the conservation of forests, waterways and wildlife. A second point is almost as disquieting. He stands for tight controls on petroleum imports, administered by Interior, which benefit the oil-producing states and the oil companies by gouging the public through higher prices.

Kirk Moritz of Old Westbury, L. I., the first-seeded player in the 18 years and under class, defeated Cleveland Lynn of Springfield Gardens, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in a quarter-final round match of the Eastern junior indoor tennis championships at Sterling Indoor Tennis Court in Corona, Queens. Mike Apfelbaum of Roslyn Heights,' I. I., the second-seeded player, won from Philip St. Gt'Ol'geS of Bedford, N. Y.. 2-6, !1-7, 6-!.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Psychiatric testing for Carl D. McHone, 24 years old, of Marietta, S. C., was ordered yesterday by a Federal judge here. McHone is charged with threatening President - elect Richard M. Nixon's life Nov. 26 in Lanham, Md.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- An East squad with four of the strongest runners in college football will battle a strong passing West squad in the 44th annual Shrine football game tomorrow in Candlestick Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -The steepest inflationary spiral in 17 years climbed further in November with a rise of four-tenths of 1 per cent in the Consumer Price Index. The rise wiped out pay gains of 45 million workers, the Government said today.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Dec. 27 -- Chris Feder and Mike Fitzgerald, defending champions, advanced to the semi-finals of the winner's bracket tonight in the fourth annual C. W. Post wrestling tournament. Feder, Post's heavyweight, scored two pins and a decision while Fitzgerald, the 145-pound champion from Moorhead State in Minnesota, recorded one pin and two decisions.
MADRID, Dec. 27 -- "What is a duchess for, if not to defend the poor? A duchess must be good for something besides going to charity teas."

A former helicopter pilot and head of the New York City Police Department's aviation bureau was named manager yesterday of the new East 60th Street Heliport in midtown Manhattan. He is Kenneth C. Johnston, a native of Brooklyn who began his aviation career in 1941 as a transport pilot for the Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -The United States balance of trade, distorted by the strike situation on the waterfront, returned to surplus in November after a deficit in October, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Following is the official transcript of President Johnson's news conference today at the White House:
LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Fifty-two persons were killed on British roads over Christmas -- 18 fewer than during the holiday period of last year, the Ministry of Transport said today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Ten persons described by the police as "hippie types" were jailed today on murder charges after a 19-year-old girl was found dead in a Haight-Ashbury apartment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson says the thing she's happiest about leaving behind after five years in the White House are all the early morning, often ominous, telephone calls to the President.

The New York Rangers yesterday reactivated Rod Gilbert, a right wing, and Ed Giacomin, a goaltender, for tonight's National Hockey League game against the Canadiens at Montreal.

C. B. McCoy, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said yesterday he expected his company's earnings for 1968 to be almost 20 per cent higher than in 1967 and sales to rise about 12 per cent.
Two officers of the Yale Express Company Systems, Inc., found guilty of fraud by a jury last October, were sentenced here yesterday in Federal Court.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Dick Barnett's field goal with 1 minute 9 seconds left to play broke a tie tonight and gave the New York Knickerbockers a 111-109 victory over the San Diego Rockets in a National Basketball Association contest.
BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins added Johnny Bucyk to their injury list today. The wing had a severe charley horse.

The mass absenteeism of pupils on the days designated as make-up time for the schooling lost during the long teachers' strike has made a mockery of education itself. The conviction of Louis E. Wolfson, the financier, for conspiracy and the unlawful sales of the stock of Continental Enterprises, Inc., was affirmed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- The Canadian mission announced today that George Ignatieff, Canada's permanent representative, would be transferred to Geneva as chief of the Canadian disarmament delegation there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 -The winner in a bitter dispute over the proposed take-over by Howard Hughes of Air West, Inc., remained in doubt today hours after balloting at a special stockholders' meeting.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26 -- A seemingly innocuous redistricting has aroused fears among Muscovites, chronically unhappy over the slow process of getting into good housing, that things may get worse instead of better.
GREENVILLE, S. C., Dec. 27 (AP) -- New York University overwhelmed Furman, 95-63, tonight and moved into the final of the Poinsettia basketball tournament.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27 -- South Vietnamese forces made frequent contact with the enemy during the last 24 hours, but United States troops found little action.

SIOUX CITY, Dec. 27 (AP) -An Ozark Air Lines DC-9 jet with 62 passengers aboard crashed into heavy snow in a grove of trees on take-off from the Sioux City Airport this morning, but no one was killed or seriously injured.

AS a publishing year, 1968 was no annus mirabilis (that means it was no seven-day wonder). Literary historians are not going to mark off the date in red or give it a separate chapter in the literary chronicles when they come to write them. It was a respectable year rather than a spectacular one.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -Bobby Hull, the Chicago Black Hawks' ace, will have to keep his mouth shut for six weeks.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Negotiators trying since June to settle a conflict between Cyprus's Greek and Turkish communities completed today the second phase of their talks. They announced they would begin the third phase on Jan. 20.

A strike scheduled for 12:01 A.M. today on the Long Island Rail Road was averted last night when President Johnson named a Presidential emergency board. His action automatically stayed a walkout for 60 days.

Two barges carrying more than a million gallons of gasoline and oil collided last night in the Kill Van Kull, between Staten Island and New Jersey. One of them exploded, leaking a stream of burning gasoline 100 feet wide and beaching in a fiery mass not far from the St. George Ferry Terminal.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 21 -- Australia is reassessing her defense position in the light of the coming British withdrawal from Southeast Asia to be completed in 1971 and of the uncertainties of Vietnam. A new military program to be announced early next year is expected to provide for expanded Australian forces in Malaysia and Singapore.

The incoming Nixon Administration was urged yesterday by the chairman of the state's Joint Legislative Committee on Welfare to delay national implementation of a simplified welfare application system because, he said, it might cause an immediate 50 per cent increase in the welfare rolls.
STONEWALL, Tex., Dec. 27 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Johnson arrived at their ranch near here this afternoon after a flight from Washington.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 27 -- Pakistan, Turkey and Iran called on outside powers today to keep out of the Persian Gulf when Britain withdraws from the area in 1971.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- All movies, plays and television shows will be subject to censorship by an Argentine Government agency under a decree published today.

The use by a midtown employment agency of the word "Harvard" in its name was barred yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice who ruled that the word belongs solely to the 302-yearold university in Cambridge, Mass.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Indonesian troops killed seven members of a Communist guerrilla group from Sarawak last Sunday. Antara, the official news agency, reported today. No Government casualties were reported in the clash with 3 guerrillas.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 -A threatened new crisis on the embattled San Francisco State College campus, which is scheduled to reopen on Jan. 6, may have been eased by new faculty moves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Johnson said today that Cyrus R. Vance, deputy chief of the United States delegation to the Vietnam talks, had told him he believed the talks could move to substantive matters dealing with a peace settlement after Mr. Vance's return to Paris.

Randolph and ArthurT. Hadley 2d. She was graduated from the Milton (Mass.) Academy and attends the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She is a member of the Junior Asemblies.
"South Pacific," the Pulitzer Prize-winning musical, will be next summer's attraction at the Jones Beach Theater, opening July 2. It will be presented nightly at 8:30 through next Labor Day.

NOBLESVILLE, Ind., Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Hamilton Southeastern School officials said today a Quaker teacher had been dismissed for refusing to sign a loyalty oath in support of the United States and Indiana constitutions and laws. Supt. Leo W. Marshall said Tom Sulanke, 22 years old, was relieved of his teaching assignment Dec. 13, three-and-one-half months after joining the school system.

NEWARK, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A team of medical examiners today declared Mark Rudd, a leader of the student rebellion at Columbia University last spring, "permanently rejected" for induction into the armed forces.

A new information service office to help businessmen and property owners in blighted areas of central Brooklyn solve their insurance problems was opened yesterday.

ATHENS, Dec. 30 -- Two Arab terrorists told a Greek magistrate today that they had obeyed orders from their Beirutbased organization when they attacked an Israeli airliner in Athens Thursday. The attack led to the Israeli reprisal raid on the Beirut airport Saturday.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 30 -- In a slight change of plans, President-elect Richard M. Nixon will leave his vacation retreat here tomorrow morning and fly to California, where he will attend the Rose Bowl game on New Year's Day.

The American Motors Corporation announced yesterday the final scheduled payment of $10-million on its short-term bank loans, thus eliminating the company's short-term debt. The payment, from operating funds, marked the last in a series of payments which in 19 months reduced the company's short-term indebtedness from $95-million to zero.

GANGTOK, Sikkim, Dec. 22 -- The king sipped sweet vermouth and served whisky to his guests. Two clowns with ear-to-ear leers sculptured on their masks did cartwheels on the lawn. The palace band played "Dixie" and "There Is a Tavern in the Town."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey said in a New Year's statement today that the men who will lead the nation in 1969 "deserve our help and respect."

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 30 -The former head of a suburban school district who resigned following a controversy over his liberal policies has been named Superintendent of Schools here by the trustees of the Berkeley Unified School District.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -A Federal grand jury today indicted Theodore A. Jones, director of the Illinois Department of Revenue, on charges of income tax evasion.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Pete Maravich scored a record-tying 53 points tonight to pace Louisiana State to a 94-91 victory, over previously undefeated Duquesne and the championship of the All-College basketball tournament.
Peck Peck, which operates a group of women's sportswear shops, has announced the promotion of John I. Gotlinger to executive vice president from vice president. He continues as treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Before the latest outbreak in the Middle East, the Soviet Union approached the United States with a proposal for a new joint effort to promote a Middle East settlement. The United States is drafting a reply.
Champagne drinkers were advised yesterday to be wary of popping corks while celebrating New Year's Eve.

Mayor Lindsay filed with the Legislature yesterday 10 police and crime bills that would greatly increase the penalties for mugging, prostitution and the illegal possession of dangerous drugs, and would abolish the Police Department's three-platoon assignment system.

IN an expansive mood, after Christmas pheasant shared with newsmen invited to the Board of Governors' room yesterday to sample the delights of the New York Stock Exchange Luncheon Club, the president of the exchange disclosed that the Big Board was having trouble making money on the little guy's business.

TRENTON, Dec. 30 -- Assistant State Attorney General William J. Brennan 3d publicly confronted three New Jersey legislators in the crowded Assembly chamber here today and accused them of being "entirely too comfortable with members of organized crime."
Twenty years after leaving Frank B. Sawdon, Inc., Jerome Bess is returning Jan. 1 as a principal, executive vice president and general manager.
A new system that will allow emergency calls from the city's 3,100 outdoor telephones without the deposit of a dime has been announced by the New York Telephone Company.
MIAMI, Dec. 30 -- Penn State converted its defense to a 4-4-3 holding unit two years ago for the prime purpose of stopping rollout quarterbacks who could run as well as throw.

PARIS -- If you are an old stick-in-the-mud and can't bear to leave Paris because even under those cold, gray skies, it is still the most beautiful city in the world, don't fret; there is much to console you while you're here, much that is quite beyond belief.

The executive committee of the Queens County Democratic Organization voted last night to recommend Sidney Leviss to succeed Mario J. Cariello as Borough Preident. Mr. Leviss, 50 years old, is Deputy Borough President. Mr. Cariello is scheduled to become a State Supreme Court Justice tomorrow. His successor will be elected by the members of the City Council from Queens, of whom seven are Democrats and one is a Republican.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- George P. Shultz, Secretary of Labor-designate, put jobs for slum dwellers at the head of his priority list today.

TO the three most important people in the sport -the fan, the player and the coach -- hockey often is three different games, seen from different perspectives and with varying emotions. The transfiguration of Reg Fleming into the Rangers' most exciting player is a case in in point.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- Anna Karavayeva, 75-year-old Soviet writer, was awarded the Order of Lenin for her services to Soviet literature, it was announced today. Her novels include "Timber Mill" (1928), "Fires" (1943), "A Running Start" (1948), and "Dear Home" (1950).

The birth of 1969 will mark the demise of the 96-year-old New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. While corks are popping and horns are tooting elsewhere, the corporate entity that nominally owned and operated the bankrupt railroad will quietly expire at 11:59 o'clock tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- An Argentine bank was ordered today to call a special meeting of shareholders to approve or reject an allegedly irregular issue of stock purchased by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- The deputy head of the United States delegation to the Vietnam talks here, Cyrus R. Vance, and the chief South Vietnamese negotiator, Pham Dang Lam, called off a scheduled strategy meeting today because they had nothing new to talk about.
H. Hentz Co. said yesterday that John A. McGowan and Otto F. Rehders would become general partners Jan. 1.

Dr. Michael Turoff of 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, will be installed as president of the Second District Dental Society of New York on Jan. 13 at 8:30 P.M. at society headquarters, 111 Fort Greene Place, Brooklyn.

KYOTO, Japan, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- A $97,000 painting by Toulouse-Lautrec that disappeared from an exhibition here Friday was found today by a mechanic under a parked truck, the police reported. The painting, "Marcelle," was on loan here from the Museum of Albi, in southern France.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- Pope Paul VI, in a message to President Charles Helou of Lebanon, deplored today the Israeli attack upon Beirut International Airport Saturday and expressed the hope that the country would shun violent countermeasures.

Lew Alcindor, whose lot it is to travel around the country with the University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team to overwhelm all opponents, preformed his task with imposing efficiency last night before a hometown audience against a home team.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 30 -- Monetary authorities of Western Europe are taking a dim view toward proposals put forward by a number of economists and academicians that would permit wider fluctuations of currencies in the exchange markets.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 30 -Trygve Lie, the first Secretary General of the United Nations, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in Geilo, a winter resort northwest of here. Mr. Lie, who held the key world organization post from 1946 to 1953, was 72 years old

FOLLOWING the Baltimore Colts' decisive victory over the Cleveland Browns for the championship of the National Football League, it was decided not to award one game ball -- the symbolic token of victory -- to an individual hero. Rather 46 game balls would be awarded, one for every member of the squad and one for each of the six coaches.

The election of David C. Scott, president of the AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company, as chief executive officer was announced yesterday. Mr. Scott replaces Robert S. Stevenson, chairman and the chief executive officer since 1955, effective tomorrow.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 30 -The pilot of the Middle East Airlines jet that was about to take off when it was blown up by Israelis Saturday denied tonight that an Israeli soldier boarded his plane and ordered the passengers to disembark at gunpoint.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 30--Ronald Sullivan, a New York Times reporter, declined today to appear before a grand jury here to testify about an article he wrote disclosing that numbers and horse race bets were being taken in the Hudson County prosecutor's office.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -A challenge to local control of Federal food stamp and commodity distribution programs for the poor was upheld today in the Federal District Court here.

CONCEPCION, the Philippines, Dec. 24 -- This small town, the traditional center of rural dissidence in central Luzon, presents a relaxed and smiling aspect in marked contrast to the tense and fearful mood encountered here at the height of Communist-led Hukbalahap revolt and terrorism in the fifties.

TRENTON, Dec. 30 -- As the testimony of William J. Brennan 3d unfolded here today, the tension that gripped the crowded Assembly chamber rapidly dissolved, and by the end of the long afternoon, friends of Mr. Brennan were visibly disturbed.

PARIS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Jacques Hemon, 53 years old, who received a new heart in a transplant operation on Nov. 17, died Friday after his body rejected the new heart, the Foch Hospital announced today. There have been 10 transplant operations in France.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Gerald Colella's Stockholder, taking the lead midway through the stretch, hung on gamely today at Tropical Park to win the $3,500 featured allowance purse by a head.
Assemblyman Stanley Steingut said yesterday that he would resign as leader of the powerful Brookln Democratic organization if he were elected minority leader of the assembly.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- John Roche, South Carolina's sharp-shooting guard, tallied 24 points tonight as the Gamecocks upset 11th-ranked La Salle, 62-59, to win the eighth Quaker City basketball tournament at the Spectrum.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Toledo Blade announced today the retirement on Jan. 1 of Edward P. Fallen, the newspaper's managing editor for the last 16 years. Joseph J. O'Coner, an assistant managing editor, was named to succeed Mr. Fallen.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -The City Council today adopted a $500-million plan to extend the city's subway system with a series of tunnels that would make it possible to raze the downtown elevated structure that gave the Loop its name.
The Parks Department will play rival to house parties and nightclubs tomorrow by staging a New Year's Eve party at the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park.
HONG KONG, Dec. 30 -In a New Year's message to "American friends," President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam extended today his thanks to those in the United States who oppose the Vietnam war.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- Tibetan refugees broke into the Chinese Communist Embassy grounds here today, smashed windows and chased blue-clad officials with sticks and stones.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 30 -- The exhilaration that most Israelis felt after the commando attack Saturday night at the Beirut airport is beginning to dissolve in frustration and argument.
Steel production rose 3.8 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday, bringing 1968 output to 3.5 million tons above the 1967 level.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Sacred Heart Academy, a prominent Roman Catholic school here for girls, will close in June because of a shortage of nuns and lay teachers.

The Dow Chemical Company raised the price of iodine 6 cents a pound yesterday, du Pont raised polyethylene packaging films by 2 to 2 1/2 cents a pound, and price increases for nickel, copper and steel spread.

The demand for more vigorous leadership which found expression among House Democrats last week when Representative Morris Udall challenged Speaker McCormack has now come to the surface in the Senate. Like Mr. Udall, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts has shown commendable initiative in his decision to oppose Senator Russell Long of Louisiana for the post of assistant majority leader.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The Israeli Army said today that Arab commandos shelled five Israeli settlements last night in apparent reprisal for Israel's raid on Beirut's airport Saturday. The town of Hebron on the west bank of the Jordan River was placed under curfew in anticipation of further unrest.

TRENTON, Dec. 30 -- Shortly before 2 o'clock this afternoon, 31-year-old David Friedland, accompanied by his father, entered the crowded Assembly chamber, paused for a moment and looked unsmilingly up at the gallery as it filled with people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior announced Monday the establishment of a Washington employment agency for Indians The operation, known as a Field Employment Assistance office, has been running experimentally since last summer.
Finance Administrator Fioravante G. Perrotta ordered yesterday an intensive investigation of tax-exempt properties in the city.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- London insurance underwriters agreed today to accept claims of some $18-million arising from Israeli troops' destruction at Beirut of eight aircraft operated by Middle East Airlines.
The New York Knickerbockers, like everyone else, are looking forward to a pleasant New Year's Eve.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- A high Soviet planning official has conceded that Soviet production of consumer goods has not been able to keep pace with rapidly rising purchasing power, but he ruled out price increases as a solution on the ground that they would be contrary to Government policy.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Representativeelect Allard K. Lowenstein said today that an emergency relief program for Biafra would be set up in the United States in the next week.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- California, setting a Far West Classic free-throw record, overpowered Arizona State, 93-81, for fifth place in the holiday basketball tournament today. The Bears hit on 31 of 33 foul shots.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Dr. John W. Norcross, president of the Massachusetts Medical Association, said today that some doctors had stopped treating Medicaid patients because they got lower than usual fees and the state was behind in payments.
SEATTLE, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Art Harris and Bob Rule scored 24 points each to lead the Seattle Supersonics to a 120-118 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.
THE biggest swings in bridge occur when both sides have fine distributional fits and decisions have to be made at the slam level without either side being sure of what contract can be made.

RICHMOND, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A hearing on court action to block the proposed merger of the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Sinclair Oil Corporation was continued in United States District Court here today.

The Cubiculo, the new experimental theater of the National Shakespeare Company, at 414 West 51st Street, presented another dance evening last night with a program by Dance Theater Workshop. Most of the six works were seen previously as part of the Workshop's regular seasons.
Vincent L. Broderick, the Police Commissioner Mayor Lindsay did not reappoint in 1966, said yesterday that he was considering running for the Democratic mayoral nomination next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it would postpone until June 30 its proposed change in the tax treatment of certain restricted stock transfers.
Tired old 1968 is dragging itself into history and leaving behind some unfinished business in Advertising Land.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A project under the Federal model cities program that includes a proposal for legalized prostitution in isolated areas of the city won approval today from the Detroit Common Council by a 6-2 vote.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy's bid for a Senate leadership role involves a serious gamble with his prospects for capturing the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1972. A number of leading Democrats, some of them friendly to the Kennedy cause, thought today that the Massachusetts Senator had considerable to lose politically if he failed to unseat Senator Russell B. Long as majority whip and little to gain if he succeeded.

WEST TISBURY, Mass., Dec. 24 -- The wind blew a gale from the southwest all night and all the next morning, and it seemed as if it would continue through the afternoon, making it ideal for duck hunting.

TORONTO, Dec. 30 -- In antiquity, Knidos was famous for its medical school and the observatory of its most distinguished resident, the astronomer, Eudoxus. It was probably more widely acclaimed for its wine and it was certainly most celebrated -- sometimes in song -- for a woman in marble -- the Aphrodite of Knidos by Praxiteles.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- The French Foreign Minister, Michel Debre, reiterated today his Government's call for Big Four efforts in the Middle East but at the same time made it clear that France was seeking negotiation and discussion only, and not a summit meeting.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A Boeing 707 operated by the Israeli airline, El Al, was delayed 45 minutes because of a bomb scare as it taxied for take off at London airport tonight. The scare as it taxied for take-off during a fruitless search.

Adam Baumgold of New York upset Kirk Moritz of Westbury, L.I., the top-seeded player 6-1, 6-1, in the semifinals of the Eastern junior indoor tennis championship at the Sterling Club in Corona, Queens, yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Ron Holmberg and Jim McManus won the Sugar Bowl doubles title today by beating Cliff Richey and Tom Edlefsen, 6-1, 1-6, 6-2. Earlier Richey defeated Holmberg for the singles crown.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Major collective bargaining settlements this year reached a record median of 6.6 per cent in increased wages and benefits, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
EVERGREEN REVIEW READER 1957-1967. Edited by Barney Rosset. Illustrated. 776 pages. Grova Press. $20.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Mr. and Mrs. William Shepherdson Abell of Chex Chase, Md.. gave a supper dance tonight at the Sulgrave Club here in honor of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Elaine ^bell.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A question of a possible conflict of interest was raised today in connection with Secretary of Commerce C. R. Smith's postponement of action on a proposal for a foreign trade zone and oil refinery in Maine.
The city's Health Department arranged for the delivery here yesterday of 20,000 additional doses of Hong Kong flu vaccine but warned that the critical shortage of blood was continuing.
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -A 27-year-old crewman of the Pueblo told today of having been beaten by North Korean interrogators with a 2-by-2 until the board broke.
If Beatrice Joyce, the founder and president of the International Debutante Ball, weren't a "take it as it comes" kind of parson, she could easily have a heart attack.
EUGENE, Ore., Dec. 30 -Senator Wayne Morse conceded today that he had lost his bid for a fifth term to Robert W. Packwood.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- Nancy Sinatra, singer and daughter of Frank Sinatra, announced today that she and Jack Haley Jr., a television producer, would be married. Mr. Haley produced Miss Sinatra's recent television special, "Moving With Nancy."
HOBART, Australia, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Light winds, an outgoing current and light rain tonight almost cost the 41-foot Sydney sloop Koomooloo the handicap honors in the 640-mile SydneyHobart yacht race.
The City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it had rejected 17 "low" bids by painters because they were too high.
The extreme tightness that developed Friday in the market for excess reserves of commercial banks eased yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Hanoi radio broadcast a complaint from the Pathet Lao today that United States planes were dropping four or five times as many bombs on Communistruled territory in eastern Laos as they did before the bombing of North Vietnam halted Nov. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A pocket guide to New Year's Eve:

DALLAS, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Dael Wolfler, head of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, said today the group would take no stand on a statement by more than 2,600 scientists decrying Pope Paul VI's ban on artificial birth control.

ABOARD THE QUEEN ELIZABETH 2, in the Atlantic, Dec. 30 -- Discord simmered aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 today between employes of Cunard and shipyard workers trying to complete the liner as she made toward Southampton at half speed.

GENEVA, Dec. 30 (AP) -Eight transports made available by the United States to the international relief airlifts may make it possible to feed an additional one million people or more in Biafra, relief officials said today.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The police said that a bank messenger had apparently been struck on the head and robbed of $15,000 in cash and checks at the State Capitol today. The messenger, Miss Linda Franzen, 21 years old, was found unconscious at the Capitol. She had a head injury, and her bank bag was missing.
HOUSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -The Apollo 8 astronauts talked hour after hour today into tape recorders, reviewing for space officials and scientists the flight that took them around the moon and back.

TOKYO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Mrs. Eisaku Sato, wife of the Japanese Premier, said today in a Japanese magazine interview that her husband beat her in the early days of their marriage and often -- in the fashion of well-to-do Japanese men -- consorted with geisha.

Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader who died on Dec. 19, has been memorialized in contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund by admirers mindful of his unceasingly offensive against social injustices.
Bob McMahon scored 28 points to lead Iona to a 98-88 victory over Illinois Wesleyan last night at Mount St. Michael High School, the Bronx.
The stokers' union that was involved in an eight-day wild-cat walkout at 11 Sanitation Department incinerators in November was fined $8,000 yesterday for violation of the Taylor Law.
The C.I.T. Financial Corporation announced yesterday that Calvin T. Kraus had been elected president of its subsidiary, the C.I.T. Service Leasing Corporation.
An American explorer who died 97 years ago in Greenland while heading a federally financed expedition was poisoned while trying to reach the North Pole, a Dartmouth College professor said yesterday.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 30, (AP) -- Oklahoma and Southern Methodist, teams that surprised even their coaches with 7-3 won-lost records this season, meet tomorrow night in the revamped Astro-Bluebonnet Bowl football game before an expected overflow crowd of 60,000 in the Astrodome.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Sirhan B. Sirhan has been cleared of any wrongdoing in the theft two years ago of a check for $81.57, the Los Angeles Police Department reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Del Crandall, former catcher for the Milwaukee Braves, was appointed today to manage the Los Angeles Dodger farm club at Albuquerque, N. M., in the Texas League.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Tuesday, Dec. 31 -- Israel fought back in the Security Council last night and early today against apparently unanimous censure of her commando raid against Lebanon's civilian airport at Beirut.

Trygve Lie served the United Nations as Secretary General during the last seven years of Stalin's life. These were the postwar world's most critical years, when Soviet-American wartime cooperation -- the key to U.N. peacekeeping, as originally conceived -- gave way to disagreement and ever more bitter cold war struggle.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -Brink's Inc., offered a $25,000 reward today for information leading to two bandits who robbed one of its armored trucks of about $500,000 in cash on Saturday.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Mrs. Fred J. Tooze, the president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, had a New Year's resolution today for the nation: "Curb alcoholism and promote abstinence among the new generation."
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- The Pullman car conductor, once a familiar figure to travelers, will all but disappear from American railroading this week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The year 1968 has become the first year on record in which no executions took place in the United States.
The Board of Education last night approved an operating budget request for 1969-70 of $1,364,442,404.
The Baltimore Colts were installed yesterday as a 17-point favorite over the New York Jets for the Super Bowl game a week from Sunday in Miami.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 30 -- Steve's Luncheonette was packed the other afternoon with young radicals eating hamburgers. The owner rushed behind the counter, nervously taking orders.
The ITT Continental Baking Company has announced the appointment of Randall W. Hackett as general advertising manager, succeeding Lee M. Marshall who recently retired.
Year-end selling pressure pushed the stock market into another steep slide yesterday with prices showing one of the broadest setbacks since last summer.
Shareholders of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company voted overwhelmingly yesterday to form a one-bank holding company to take over the bank, which would be renamed simply "Chemical Bank."
