STOCKHOLM -- As chairman of Scandinavia's biggest bank, Tore Browaldh has numerous worries -- international monetary crises, the economic division of Europe, expanding business interests of the Swedish Government and insufficient hours in his own executive day.
Gounod's "Faust," just a couple months short of its 110th birthday, had its first performance of the Metropolitan Opera season last night.

JUST a few months ago Lewis Gundunas was puttering around the kitchens of his two Greek restaurants in California, making sure his special egg lemon soup was tasty enough -- and even washing dishes when the dishwasher didn't show up.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 30 -Premier Abdullah Yaffi said today, after a meeting of the combined Defense and Foreign Affairs Committees of Parliament and representatives of the Lebanese Army command, that the Israeli attack Saturday on the Beirut airport "has had no effect on our stand regarding the commandos".

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 30 -- The civil authorities searched with heavy earth-moving machinery in a canyon here today for victims of a slum landslide that sent 20 shacks and their inhabitants plunging down a hillside yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford ordered Secretary of the Navy Paul R. Ignatius today to "conduct an inquiry into the treatment of the crew of the U.S.S. Pueblo by the North Korean authorities."
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -The Chicago Bulls, sparked by 20 points from Clem Haskins, scored a 103-97 triumph over the San Francisco Warriors tonight to extend their winning streak to four games.
The Penn Central Company said yesterday it was giving up its fight to delay its taking over the bankrupt New Haven Railroad's assets and operations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The slide in mortgage prices continued at this week's "auction" of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the agency disclosed today.
PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Harold Matzner testified today that a friend of the man he is accused of murdering, Gabriel (Johnny the Walk) DeFranco, once named a deceased gambler as the killer.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 30 -- The United States military command announced tonight that it would meet with representatives of the National Liberation Front Wednesday to discuss for the second time the release of three American prisoners of war.
Prices declined along a broad front in modest trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it had awarded a $116,857 contract to Arthur D. Little, Cambridge, Mass., to investigate the feasibiliy of waterborne feeder concepts to implement unitized cargo transportation.

ANCHORAGE, Dec. 30 -- Informed Alaskans now expect that their Governor, Walter J. Hickel, who is Secretary of the Interior-designate, will probably be questioned more intensively during Senate confirmation hearings than any other of President-elect Richard M. Nixon's Cabinet choices.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -The State Department confirmed today that the Federal Government of Nigeria had complained about United States relief efforts to Biafra, but withheld immediate comment.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- Chile's central bank today fixed a new official parity for the United States dollar. The escudo was put at 7.65 to the dollar; the previous rate was 7.58.

ATLANTA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Unheralded Mike Hillman revived a sagging Louisiana State football team and directed a 61-yard drive in the final minutes that gave the underdog Tigers a 31-27 victory over Florida State in the first Peach Bowl tonight.
Clark Graebner's price to become a professional has gone up, he said yesterday, which should be good news for amateur tennis officials and more headaches for professional promoters.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Nine people were killed and 23 were injured yesterday when a bus and a train collided at a crossing 75 miles north of Bangkok, the police reported today.
BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- Walter Ulbricht declared today that all of Europe would be well on the road toward Communism by the end of the century.

All tickets to "Morning, Noon and Night," with the exception of those for New Year's Eve, have been reduced to $2. The plan went into effect yesterday at Henry Miller's Theater. The show has been announced to close Saturday night after the 44th performance.

Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board stepped into another labor-management dispute in an effort to rescue would-be revelers holding New Year's Eve reservations at the Latin Quarter.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 -A statewide group supporting striking students at San Francisco State College called today for "a mass convergence" on the troubled campus Jan. 13.
An effort to wrest control of Defiance Industries, Inc., from Victor Muscat, the financier, gained momentum yesterday.
Sales and earnings records were set by the Beatrice Foods Company in the three and nine months ended Nov. 30, the company reported yesterday from Chicago.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The United Nations Command and North Korea accused each other today of risking a new Korean war as they exchanged charges of border violations in the last year.
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -The Los Angeles Lakers, led by Jerry West's 40 points, conquered the San Diego Rockets, 131-126, in overtime tonight in National Basketball Association play.

Harold Nichols was named yesterday to the newly established post of general chairman of the Amateur Athletic Union's national wrestling committee. Appointed vice chairmen by Jesse A. Pardue, A.A.U. president, were Wesley Brown Jr., for free-style and John Dustin for Greco-Roman-wrestling.
Hundreds of jobs were offered to college students here yesterday by 31 Federal agencies as Federal Career Week opened, but there were few takers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -David Packard, a pioneer in the electronic instruments industry whose annual income approaches $1-million, was named today to be Deputy Secretary of Defense in the Nixon Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Indian Claims Commission has decided that the Ottawa Chippewa Indians of Michigan are entitled to as much as $10.8-million for land taken by the Government 132 years ago.
MIAMI, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Ted Kwalick, an all-America end, and four Penn State football teammates saved the life of a Pittsburgh man today after he was washed off a fishing boat anchored at a dock.

DANANG, South Vietnam Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Shunichi Yasuda of Tokyo, a 28-year-old cameraman for the National Broadcasting Company, suffered minor wounds from grenade shrapnel today when covering a South Vietnamese military gunmen near Danang

In the flower of babble that grows each December, when academics released for the Christmas holiday join by the thousands in scholarly conferences, there is much that deserves saying, and a little that is long remembered.

The city's 75 Criminal Court judges were directed for the first time yesterday by a State Supreme Court Justice to hold jury trials for all persons between the ages of 16 and 20 charged with a misdemeanor.

Ship operators reported yesterday that Puerto Rico, with its island dependence on seaborne supplies for industry and the tourist trade, had its ports idled by the Atlantic and Gulf longshoremen's strike.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Following is the text of a telegram sent today to the three Apollo 8 astronauts by Governor Rockefeller:

A plan to offer $225-million worth of Armour Co. common stock for the Williams Brothers Company, was discontinued yesterday. Neither management would predict whether negotiations proposed three weeks ago would be resumed and they advanced no reason for the move.

PARIS, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -President de Gaulle returned today after a 10-day Christmas vacation to work on his traditional New Year's Eve broadcast to the nation. He spent the holiday at his country home.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Explosives used in five bombings in Los Angeles last July 19 came originally from the Central Intelligence Agency, according to county grand jury testimony made public today.
A long-awaited Federal plan to rid New York harbor of unwanted and dangerous debris and driftwood was outlined here yesterday by the Army Corps of Engineers.

Air congestion at the New York area's three major airports has been less than expected during the current holiday season and Federal officials said yesterday they hoped it meant that efforts to curb the congestion were starting to pay off.
PRAGUE, Dec. 30 -- Czechoslovaks watched on television tonight a dramatic review of the Soviet-led invasion of their country Aug. 20-21, including films of the Soviet tanks and a blood-spotted flag.

Eight Negroes who figure prominently in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school dispute started a legal counterattack yesterday in reply to an indictment that accuses them of obstructing governmental administration.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 30 -- The military regime of President Arthur da Costa e Silva announced tonight that Carlos Lacerda, former Governor of Guanabara Province, 11 members of Congress and a judge had been barred from politics in Brazil for 10 years.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- Although United States and Soviet interests in preserving peace appear to converge, there is no indication here of coordinated steps to handle the situation produced by the Athens and Beirut incidents.

Almost a million city residents 65 years of age and older will be able to ride buses and subways for half fare except during rush hours by the end of 1969, according to Transportation Administrator Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff.

THE psychology of the Super Bowl has begun. In their introductory statements, the Baltimore Colts were cautiously combative, but Joe Namath, the opinionated individualist of the New York Jets, was quoted as rating Daryle Lamonica of the Oakland Raiders as a "better quarterback" than Earl Morrall, the Colt savior.

DALLAS, Dec. 30 -- The board of directors of the American Association for the Advancement of Science adopted today a statement calling for a study of the "potential risks and benefits" of the spraying of herbicides in war.

LAGOS, Dec. 30 (Agence France-Presse) -- About 1,000 antitax demonstrators were arrested yesterday in the Abeokuta area of Nigeria's Western state, the local army commander, Lieut. Col. Olu Bajowa, told newsmen today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -The personality traits that folklore associates with the founders of great fortunes are not to be found in David Packard.

The hoard of governors of the Federal Reserve System has named Albert L. Nickerson a director and chairman of the board of the New York Federal Bank and Federal Reserve Agent for 1969. He is board chairman of the Mobil Oil Corporation.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -Britain will enter 26 crews in the 2,000-mile Monte Carlo Rally Jan. 17-25, the Royal Automobile Club announced today.
R.C.A. Records will raise the price of its stereo long-playing albums of popular and classical musical, starting Feb. 1. The increase will be under 4 per cent or 19 cents.

The city and two unions representing 80,000 city employes continued negotiations yesterday to replace contracts that expire at midnight tonight, but no sense of crisis surrounded the last-minute talks.

Mayor Lindsay's annual letter to Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leaders will make unpleasant New Year's reading in Albany. Already faced with the doleful prospect of closing a $700-million gap in the state's budget, the state officials are asked by the Mayor to provide New York City with nearly a halfbillion dollars more in state aid in the fiscal year a head.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- A leading Soviet space scientist today hailed the Apollo 8 flight as an "outstanding achievement of American space science and technology" and praised the "courage" of its three astronauts.

IN 22 years of married life, Mrs. Wilfred Hinds has taken care of 52 children, none of them her own. Her ultimate ambition is to adopt a child, but not until she and her husband can afford a house with a back yard.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 30 -- Many persons favor laws that if widely enforced would cut down the high death toll predicted for the New Year holiday, according to the Gallup Poll.
William H. Booth, whose term on the city's Commission on Human Rights expired on Dec. 26, has not yet been told by Mayor Lindsay if his term will be renewed.

Sidney Poitier was the No. 1 movie star at box offices in the United States and Canada in 1968, according to a survey of motion-picture exhibitors conducted by Motion Picture Herald, the weekly trade magazine.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Sixth-ranked Kansas captured the Big Eight holiday basketball tournament tonight with a 5645 victory over Oklahoma State in the final.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Nguyen Thanh Nam, a long-time pacifist, suggests that the principal belligerents in Vietnam and their allies talk peace around an eight-sided table he has built on his island retreat in the Mekong Delta.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Fire Inspectors, whose job is to see that all buildings have alarm systems in working order. knocked on doors today to alert city employes to a freight elevator fire that sent light smoke through the City Hall annex

Following are excerpts from the statements by Fouad Boutros of Lebanon, in unofficial translation from the French, and Yosef Tekoah of Israel at a special session of the United Nations Security Council last night on the Israeli attack on the airport in Beirut:

THE new program of the American Place Theater -- it had its press performance last night -- is described as "Trainer, Dean, Liepolt and Company." David Trainer, Philip Dean and Werner Liepolt are the authors.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Fire Inspectors, whose job is to see that all buildings have alarm systems in working order. knocked on doors today to alert city employes to a freight elevator fire that sent light smoke through the City Hall annex

Following are excerpts from the statements by Fouad Boutros of Lebanon, in unofficial translation from the French, and Yosef Tekoah of Israel at a special session of the United Nations Security Council last night on the Israeli attack on the airport in Beirut:

THE new program of the American Place Theater -- it had its press performance last night -- is described as "Trainer, Dean, Liepolt and Company." David Trainer, Philip Dean and Werner Liepolt are the authors.
The Superintendent of Schools has said in a letter that principals do not have the right to forbid girls to wear slacks in school.

WINDER, Ga., Dec. 30 -- The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said today that he would ask the Navy for copies of orders given the commander of the intelligence ship Pueblo to determine why the ship had not been scuttled.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- A leading Soviet space scientist today hailed the Apollo 8 flight as an "outstanding achievement of American space science and technology" and praised the "courage" of its three astronauts.

IN 22 years of married life, Mrs. Wilfred Hinds has taken care of 52 children, none of them her own. Her ultimate ambition is to adopt a child, but not until she and her husband can afford a house with a back yard.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 30 -- Many persons favor laws that if widely enforced would cut down the high death toll predicted for the New Year holiday, according to the Gallup Poll.
A British and an American aerospace engineer have been selected to share the $10,000 Goddard Award of the American Institute of Aeronautics and astronautics.

The Government moved yesterday to set aside last summer's election of officers by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, in which Capt. Thomas F. O'Callaghan was elected president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Secretary of State-designate William P. Rogers met today with U. Alexis Johnson, the United States Ambassador to Japan, adding to speculation that Mr. Johnson would get a high foreign policy post in the Nixon Administration.

At 5:52 A.M. yesterday, a new eight-car high-speed stainless steel Long Island Rail Road commuter train pulled out of Babylon. After a burst of speed that briefly reached 80 miles an hour, the train arrived at Pennsylvania Station five minutes late.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said today the Government should regulate fees and charges under Medicaid to prevent the program from being used as "a get-rich scheme," for unscrupulous doctors, nursing homes and pharmacists.
Cushman Wakefield, Inc., real estate concern, has announced the appointment of James P. McGuire as senior vice president.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Dec. 30 (UPI) -- President Johnson steered clear today of the rebellion in the House to unseat Speaker John W. McCormack. He believes in leaving "Congressional business up to members of Congress," his press secretary said.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -Raymond Sheldon, 22 years old, of Lincoln, Neb., died today in a hospital of injuries suffered when a North Central Airlines' plane crashed into a hangar at O'Hare International Airport last Friday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Randy Mahaffey and Manny Leaks of the Kentucky Colonels were traded to the New York Nets tonight for Dan Anderson and Oliver Darden.
PERTH, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- An airliner carrying 26 persons crashed today near Port Hedland in Western Australia.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The University of Minnesota defeated previously unbeaten Detroit, 85-80, tonight. The Gophers led, 39-38, at half-time and stretched that lead by 9 points late in the second half. The Gophers withstood a late Detroit rally by sinking 21 of 23 free throws.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The troubles of the Queen Elizabeth 2 provoked dismay and embarrassment today as a blow to Britain's pride as a shipbuilding nation. Inquiries were demanded, and a hot dispute arose over who was to blame.

THE National Broadcasting Company's second "white paper" last night was devoted to multiple problems of the American cities and scattered reports on efforts to enable Negro residents to gain a degree of job security and pride.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy, in a bid for a leadership role within the Democratic party, announced today that he would challenge Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana for the post of assistant Democratic leader of the Senate.

In the most heated balloting in recent years, bringing threats of resignation from four of its 24 members, the New York Film Critics yesterday narrowly voted "The Lion in Winter" the best picture of 1968.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A new Federal report warns that the nation could lose billions of dollars and thousands of lives in the next 30 years for lack of a major program to predict and guard against earthquakes.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Nigeria's head of state, Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, today summoned the United States Ambassador, Elbert G. Mathews, and warned him that the American loan of transport planes for relief purposes in Biafra could have "serious repercussions."

The only remaining experimental pay TV television system in the United States will cease operations Jan. 31 in Hartford, after 6 1/2 years of what its sponsor. R.K.O. General, Inc., considers "a successful test" of subscription television.

THE National Broadcasting Company's second "white paper" last night was devoted to multiple problems of the American cities and scattered reports on efforts to enable Negro residents to gain a degree of job security and pride.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy, in a bid for a leadership role within the Democratic party, announced today that he would challenge Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana for the post of assistant Democratic leader of the Senate.

In the most heated balloting in recent years, bringing threats of resignation from four of its 24 members, the New York Film Critics yesterday narrowly voted "The Lion in Winter" the best picture of 1968.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Gov. Roberto Sanchez Vilella handed down a New Year pardon today for eight nationalists who had been sentenced to life in prison as a result of a 1950 revolt against United States rule.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- The Soviet bitterness at the recent events in the Middle East found expression today in a charge that Western support of Israel had emboldened Israel to execute her retaliatory raid against the Beirut International Airport on Saturday.
EARLY JAPAN. By Jonathan Norton Leonard and the Editors of Time-Life Books. 191 pages. Time-Life Books. $3.95.
For the New Year, the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund went beyond the three-quarter-million mark on the strength of contributions from 746 donors who enriched the 1968-69 drive by $25,828.26.
The Western Electric Company, manufacturing subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, received yesterday four Army contracts totaling $54.4-million.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Georgia and Arkansas put the prestige of the Southeastern and Southwest conferences on the line tomorrow before 82,000 fans in the 35th Sugar Bowl game. Georgia was a one-touchdown favorite.
The search for a teen-age babysitter and a 2-month-old baby girl she allegedly took from her crib early Sunday was expanded to 14 states and Puerto Rico yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 31 -- A chase along the Israeli-Jordanian frontier north of Aqaba in the desolate Negev ended tonight with the death of at least one Arab, said by the Israelis to have been involved in an earlier attack on copper mining installations north of Timna.

The Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Robert J. O'Keefe and John J. Shea senior vice president, it announced yesterday. Mr. O'Keefe will be in charge of the systems and standards group of the bank operations department. Mr. O'Shea will be in charge of the trust and international operations group of the bank operations department.

PARIS -- The Vietnamese peace negotiations are stalled because they have entered a new phase in which Hanoi seeks to exploit the growing divorce between policy aims of Washington and Saigon. To exacerbate this divorce, North Vietnam freezes the diplomatic ball here, threatens new offensives in South Vietnam and tries simultaneously to bring about a shift in Saigon's political leadership.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Daily index numbers and spot primary market commodity prices Dec. 17, 1968, to Dec. 24, 1968.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Third-ranked Davidson, sparked by the 29 points of Doug Cook, spurted from a 4740 half-time lead to a 20-point second half advantage and wound up with a 94-82 victory tonight over Michigan.
Directors of the Marathon Oil Company have elected J. O. Terrell Couch, general counsel, to the board, to succeed Charles A. Jackson, who is retiring, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Commerce Department moved today to counteract what it described as "recent excessive exports" of copper scrap to Canada by imposing controls on such shipments, effective Thursday.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 31 (Agence FrancePresse) -- President Ho Chi Minh addressed poetic New Year's greetings today to the Vietnamese people, the diplomatic corps and to journalists here.

THE GLASS HOUSE. The Life of Theodore Roethke. By Allan Seager. 301 pages. McGrawHill. $7.95. SELECTED LETTERS of THEODORE ROETHKE. Edited by Ralph J. Mills Jr. 273 pages. University of Washington. $6.95.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said in an interview today that he planned to look at several specific areas of the tax law in 1969 with an eye to making basic changes.

Russ Togs, Inc., showed slightly higher earnings in the quarter and 39 weeks ended Nov. 2, reflecting increased sales over the year-ago periods, according to the results announced yesterday by Henry Benach, executive vice president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A considerably larger share of Southern Negroes who were eligible to vote in the 1968 election cast ballots than did so in the Presidential contest four years before.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 -- The Studebaker Corporation today gave its 62-year-old headquarters building and three adjoining plots of land to South Bend, Ind., to be used as the administrative offices for the city's Community School Corporation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Israel has served notice on the United States that she would not accept a peace settlement with her Arab opponents that involves a permanent role for a "hostile" Soviet Union in Middle Eastern security.

The head of the Biafra Relief Fund, Inc., said here yesterday that the organization planned to build four hospital buildings in Gabon in the next two weeks to care for 200 seriously ill Biafran children awaiting evacuation.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Kentucky Colonels outscored Minnesota, 26-14, in the third period and went on to rout the Pipers, 11798, tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Johnson Administration today deplored an Arab commando attack on an Israeli airliner at Athens last Thursday, after having come under criticism for what was termed its "less than evenhanded" condemnation of the Israeli reprisal raid against Lebanon.
The stock market finally got its "year-end rally" yesterday, but it was about as feeble as they come.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- "Has Premier Sato stopped beating his wife?" is the inevitable jest on Tokyo's eggnog party circuit this week.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 31 -- Three Israeli helicopters guarded by two fighter planes attacked an internal security car today at Gharandal in the Wadi Araba, 50 miles north of the Gulf of Aqaba. A communique said three security men were killed and two wounded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Prices farmers receive for their products remained unchanged during the month ended Dec. 15 while prices they pay for items required for production rose to a record, the Agriculture Department reported today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Time to Leave, owned by Neil McCarthy, raced to her ninth victory in 15 starts this year when she captured the $23,700 Las Flores Handicap at Santa Anita today by a halflength under the top weight of 125 pounds.

For commodity futures, the year 1968 ended with a day of relatively slow volume and steady prices. For several commodities, the trading day was shortened in deference to brokers' desire to finish early and get home for New Year's Eve.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 -- A quiet, delicate drama has been unfolding in the State Attorney General's office here since the morning after William J. Brennan 3d made his now-famous remark that some legislators were "entirely too comfortable" with members of organized crime.

Mike Apfelbaum, Roslyn Heights, L. I., won the 18-year-and-younger Eastern junior indoor tennis championship yesterday by defeating Adam Baumgold, New York, 7-5, 6-2, at the Sterling Indoor Tennis Courts, Corona, Queens.
PRAGUE, Dec. 31 -- "Before the invasion we used to call them bloody Slovaks," a Czech said here this week. "After the Russians, we started calling them brothers."
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Franklin Circuit Court has been asked to set aside a ruling denying the owner of Dancer's Image first - place money in the 1968 Kentucky Derby.

Six teachers of Junior High School 71 on the Lower East Side filed suit in State Supreme Court yesterday against the acting principal of the school and the acting district superintendent of District 1, Manhattan, demanding payment for their work during the first and second teachers' strikes this fall.
MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Tommy Barrow, an experienced jockey, suffered a broken leg today in a spill at Tropical Park. He will be sidelined with a fracture of the right thigh.

Dr. Benjamin Karr, a psychologist, was appointed associate dean of students at City College yesterday. Dr. Karr, a 1937 graduate of the college, is a former Associate Dean of Students at Antioch College and has taught psychology at the University of Cincinnati. He received his masters degree from Los Angeles State College and his doctorate in counseling from the University of Cincinnati.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 31 -Victor Mosca's Double Ripple, led all the way today to win the Happy New Year Purse at the Laurel race course.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 31 -- This last Sunday at the small Lutheran church near his ranch, President Johnson sat quietly throughout the service. He did not, as is his wont, fidget in the pew, crane his neck about to look at the congregation and run a comb through his gray hair from time to time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Secretary of State-designate William P. Rogers has picked Elliot L. Richardson, Attorney General of Massachusetts and a former Eisenhower Administration official, to become Under Secretary of State.

The lame opening statement made by a zealous but ill-prepared young prosecutor has obviously encouraged New Jersey legislators to hope that they can smother in derision that state's newly launched investigation into organized crime and its political influence.

Next Monday Democrats formally affiliated with reform clubs in Manhattan's Second Councilmanic District will participate in what party leaders have termed a "procedure" to select a replacement for Councilman Edward I. Koch, who won his race for Congress. The "procedure" is ad hoc. It is unofficial.

R. T. Parfet Jr., president and general manager of the Upjohn Company, pharmaceitical company, said yesterday his concern would continue to distribute Panalba for use by physicians despite the Food and Drug Administration's plan to order the antibiotic off the market.
NASHVILLE, Dec. 31 (AP) -The NTL Corporation officially came into being today with assets of more than $2-billion -the largest financial organization in the South and Southwest.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba Canadian Press) -- The Soviet national hockey team is scheduled to arrive Jan. 15 in Montreal, where on Jan. 17, it will begin an eight-game exhibition series with Canada's national team.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 -Convinced that the country's foreign policy machinery needs an overhaul, President-elect Richard M. Nixon plans to convert the long dormant National Security Council into the central decision-making instrument of his Administration.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 31 -- The New Haven Railroad, a threadbare bankrupt with erratic schedules, shrinking rolling stock and dirty stations, was absorbed into the prosperous Penn Central system today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Following is the text of the Security Council resolution adopted today on the complaint of Lebanon against Israel's reprisal attack:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Trojans of the University of California won four of five races today to overcome a commanding lead by Tulane University and capture their third Sugar Bowl regatta in the last four years.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board of The New York Times, expressed confidence in his will that his family would carry on the newspaper as a public trust.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- Representative Donald E. Lukens sat bundled in sweaters in his hotel room, wracked with flu and still emotionally chilled from being bombed and strafed by Soviet-built planes in Biafra.
The Philadelphia-BaltimoreWashington Stock Exchange will be busy moving into new quarters today, while security markets around the nation observe the New Year's Day holiday.
GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Casey Stengel has pleaded no contest to a charge of drunken driving and drawn a $302 fine.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- A woman whose body floated up on the beach in Southampton, L. I., last Saturday was identified today as 37year-old Mrs. Chieko Kamara. The Suffolk County Police said Mrs. Kamara, a Japanese national, reportedly lived in Manhattan, but had been working as a domestic in the Hamptons. The police said it was an "apparent suicide."
Today is New Year's Day. Following is a list of services that are affected:

THE year 1968 may well go down in history as the Year of the Woman. In the last 12 months women have won new rights and offices and have been admitted to places where female faces had never been seen before. Many of these "firsts" were won by Negro women; in several cases they were the first Negro and the first woman to achieve distinction in a particular field.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago announced yesterday the appointment of four senior vice presidents: Ernest T. Baughman (the bank's chief economist), Laurence H. Jones, Harry S. Schultz and Russel A. Swaney.

Mayor Lindsay's call Monday for legislative action outlawing canes with swords concealed inside was brought about by the recent seizure of six canes from a 42d Street novelty store, it was disclosed yesterday.
DOES Victor Muscat control the biggest block of stock in Defiance Industries, the keystone of his waning financial empire? His opposition says no.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford today reported "persistent and impressive" gains in a Pentagon program aimed at forcing some rental property owners to stop discriminating against uniformed Negroes.
HOBART, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Twentyone straggling yachts in the Sydney-to-Hobart yacht race, won on handicap yesterday by Koomooloo, celebrated New Year's Eve at sea.
The three Apollo 8 astronauts have agreed to come to New York on Jan. 10 to participate in a ticker-tape parade and to attend a New York State dinner in their honor.

TOONE, Tenn., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- An experimental formula apparently exploded today, triggering a blast that demolished part of a munitions plant. Ten persons were injured, four seriously. "We don't really know what caused the explosion," said James Wray, president of the Kilgore, Corporation. "I can only speculate that it stemmed from some of the mixtures they were working with."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that Communist China's latest nuclear detonation was a thermonuclear device that probably was dropped from an aircraft.
The Young Men's Real Estate Association, all of whose members are under the age of 40, has elected Lewis B. Kaye as chairman, and Peter E. Pattison as vice chairman.
Prices closed with gains on the London Stock Exchange yesterday despite profit taking in many sections.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 1 -- Three American prisoners of war were released this morning by the Vietcong.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -The Treasury announced today that the United States has repaid all its drawings from the International Monetary Fund.

MADRID, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- The Spanish runner, Xavier Alvarez Salgado, won Madrid's international New Year's Eve around-the-houses race tonight. He covered the 3.1-mile course in 15 minutes 35.6 seconds.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 -- Ronald Sullivan, a reporter for The New York Times, was subpoenaed today to testify Jan. 7 before the Hudson County grand jury about an article he wrote disclosing that numbers and horse-race bets were taken in the Hudson County Prosecutor's office.
GENEVA, Dec. 31 -- The International Press Institute reported today that distrust of the news media had been growing in the United States.
Group taxi riding, begun as an experiment last April from La Guardia Airport, Queens, to Manhattan, sputtered to a halt last night.
For those who imbibed frivolously last night and who today feel as if they'd been bludgeoned by a horde of bloodthirsty sadists, a Rutgers University physiologist offers some advice:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- All boxes for the 1969 inaugural balls have been sold out, it was announced today. Robert M. Clark, the box committee chairman, said nearly 400 boxes at the six ball locations had been sold at $1,000 each. A box seats a party of eight.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- Thirty-five persons were injured, at least 20 seriously, when a train ran into the rear of another at a suburban station tonight.
A "distinct possibility" exists for a classic business recession in 1969, the economist for one of New York's largest banks said yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 31 -Premier Abdullah Yaffi was reported to have told the Lebanese Parliament in secret session tonight that he feared an Israeli ground attack.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- A general-alarm fire swept from a supermarket through several other stores and offices at a shopping center on the north edge of the city Monday night. No injuries were reported in the blaze which caused $200,000 in damage.
MEMPHIS, Dec. 31 (AP) -Memphis State University dominated the backboards and defeated Brown University, 70-52, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy appeared today to be within a few votes of staging a surprise coup that would break the Southern conservative hold on the Senate's Democratic leadership.

The Hong Kong flu epidemic and complaints about unheated apartments eased somewhat yesterday, but the "state of peril" proclaimed in the city by health officials continued, as did emergency measures to keep it from getting worse.

CAIRO, Dec. 31 -- With the blessing of the Egyptian Government, the Arab commando group Al Fatah announced today that it planned to step up its raids behind Israeli lines. It also denounced what it called defeatists who would accept a compromise settlement in the Middle East.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 -- Allegations that three unidentified state legislators -- among six accused of being "too comfortable with organized crime"-were dismissed tonight as of "absolutely no value whatsoever."
DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The 33d annual Cotton Bowl game tomorrow will be a confrontation of Texas' high-powered offense against the defensive muscle of Tennessee.
The election of Norman D. Blotner and Larry Maier as directors of Lane Bryant, Inc., was announced yesterday by the diversified retail apparel and shoe chain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Communist China is reported to have ignored a quiet dollarsand-cents gesture made last spring by the Johnson Administration that could have started lessening two decades of estrangement between Peking and Washington.
A prehistoric palace in Thebes, the main city of Central Greece in the Bronze Age, has been identified, after decades of surmises about its existence, by a Greek archeologist.

The New York City Housing Authority and Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters reached tentative agreement on a new labor contract last night, averting a walkout that could have shut off heat and hot water to 600,000 authority tenants.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, denied yesterday that the state planned to shut down the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School District in Brooklyn.
The American Stock Exchange closed out a record-breaking year yesterday with prices and trading volume both on the upside.

The trustees of the Community Savings Bank of Rochester have approved the nomination of Reuben K. Davis, a Rochester lawyer, city official and former City Court judge, to membership on the board, it was announced yesterday.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- President Johnson celebrated New Year's Eve at the LBJ Ranch with family and friends today.
The credit markets ended 1968--a year characterized as one of alternating hope and despair--with just a whiff of happier times ahead. The market ended the year with an uptick.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Bucks were as cold as the weather tonight and couldn't keep up with the Philadelphia 76ers who led by 24 points apiece from Bill Cunningham and Chet Walker, posted a 128-107 victory.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Les Calder's goal early in the last period snapped a 1-1 tie and sparked the Long Island Ducks to a 5-2 victory over the Johnstown Jets in an Eastern Hockey League game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- The Inter-American Development Bank announced today that Colombia would get two loans equivalent to $58.8-million to help build a 340,000kilowatt hydroelectric project near Cali.

The largest merger in the history of the oil industry, the $3.7-billion amalgamation of the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Sinclair Oil Corporation, was approved yesterday by the stockholders of both concerns at special meetings in New York and Philadelphia.

Cascading fireworks flared over the city last night--their lights obscuring the neon skyline, their rumble drowning out the cacophony of car horns, tooters and shouts--as 1969 was welcomed with an enthusiasm that was undaunted by a drizzle.
PRETORIA, Dec. 31 (Agence France-Presse) -- South Africa's gold and foreign currency reserves now stand at almost 1 billion rand ($1.4-billion), the central bank announced today.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 31 -- The Israeli Minister of Religious Affairs criticized Pope Paul VI today for expressing sympathy to Lebanon over her recent aircraft losses while remaining silent over the "murder of innocent Jews" by Arab terrorists.

YONKERS -- In the six years that Claude Cooke has been chef of the Andrus Pavilion at St. John's Riverside Hospital, patients have been treated to such dishes as Cornish hen with wild rice, chicken Cordon Bleu and swan meringue shells filled with pumpkin. The medical and maintenance staffs have come to expect elaborately garnished buffet platters and massive ice carvings for special occasions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- A total of 202,254,000 Americans are on hand to welcome in the New Year, the United States Census Bureau estimated today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A significant decline in commercial construction led to an over-all drop in the value of new construction put in place during November, the Commerce Department reported today.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced today that they were releasing their patents on the process for using rubber in bituminous paving materials to get more resilient road surfaces to the public. The process has been usd on only about 10,000 miles of road.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Customs duties will be reduced tomorrow on thousands of products imported into the United States. The reduction in most cases will be small, and there may be no immediate effect on consumer prices. But when the current series of duty reductions is complete three years from now, many prices should be lower if they have not already been affected.
Last year was leap year and, if statistics are any indicator, the women of New York City were well aware of it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- B'nai B'rith declared today that the United Nations Security Council's resolution condemning the Israel commando attack on the Beirut airport would encourage further Arab terrorism.

Sidney Leviss, who has won the key endorsement of the Democratic organization for promotion to Borough President of Queens, promised yesterday a campaign to expand the powers of the five borough chief executives.
A barnacle goose, a stray from Europe rarely seen here, has been spotted in Westport and Norwalk, Conn.

Elvin Hayes, rookie star of the San Diego Rockets, scored 95 points in three games last week, increasing his scoring average to 30.6 points a game, and strengthened his hold on the scoring lead, according to National Basketball Association figures issued yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Third-period goals by Serge Savard and Jean Beliveau gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight and moved the Canadiens into undisputed possession of first place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

The quadrennial World Amateur Theater Festival will be held from Aug. 29 through Sept. 7 in Monaco under the sponsorship of Prince Rainer and Princess Grace. The United States entry will be selected from five regional tournaments.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Britain has said happy birthday to the novelist E. M. Forster, who will be 90 tomorrow, by giving him one of the country's most coveted honors.

Israel's commando raid on Beirut Airport fully deserved the stern and unanimous condemnation voted yesterday by the United Nations Security Council. Israel will compound its recent errors if it fails to treat the resolution with utmost seriousness or to carry out the spirit of its provisions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Ralph Nader challenged the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare today to do something before leaving office about what he called the unfinished business of occupational health and safety, particularly the "black lung" disease that afflicts many coal miners.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Indiana Pacers built a 6-point first-period edge into a 123-105 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.

MONTREAL, Dec. 31 (UPI) -The Montreal Canadiens announced today that they were calling up Christian Bordeleau, a center, from the Houston Apollos of the Central Hockey League to replace Claude Provost, who has been sidelined with the flu.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 1 -- A bomb was tossed through the window of the Greenville police precinct station here early this morning. It caused no injury to the two policemen in the station and only minor damage to the building.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -Wisconsin produced one of its biggest basketball triumphs tonight by upsetting third-ranked Kentucky, 69-65, in the second game of a Chicago Stadium double-header. The loss was the Wildcats' second in eight games,

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- A book of mysterious origin accusing the entire American power structure of complicity in the assassination of John F. Kennedy has spread through Western Europe and is now crossing the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Beginning tomorrow almost one-third of the nation's housing will be covered by the Federal open housing law of 1968.
WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The National Baseball Congress today named Greenville, Tenn., the team of the year among the nation's nonprofessional baseball clubs for the past season.

The Music Box will receive "The Watering Place," starring Shirley Knight and William Devane. The premiere will take place Feb. 20. Lyle Kessler wrote the drama, his first for Broadway. Michael Langham will direct it for Gene Persson and James Walsh. Previews will start Feb. 7.

The reorganization of the General Electric Company's expanding transportation system division centered in Erie, Pa., comes into effect today. Bryce W. Wyman, the company vice president who heads the division, has announced the new structure with four new general managers each heading a product department:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- The Security Council voted unanimously today to condemn Israel's "premeditated military action" in attacking the Beirut International Airport Saturday and destroying 13 aircraft. Western sources said that care had been taken to condemn the action rather than the country.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Dave Bing scored 30 points, including 14 during a big Piston rally in the second period, to provide Detroit with a 127 107 triumph over the tired Los Angeles Lakers.

HONOLULU, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The unbeaten Santa Clara Broncos, ranked fifth in the nation, knocked 14th-ranked Columbia from the undefeated list last night to win the fifth annual Rainbow Classic. The score was 64 to 58 and it was the 10th victory for the Californians. The Lions had entered the contest with an eight-game streak.
Levitt Sons, the homebuilding company, has realigned its operations in a decentralization move that establishes three management zones.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The United States assured Nigeria today that its growing aid to war victims reflected neither current nor prospective support for the Biafran rebellion.

QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- President Jose M. Velasco Ibarra retired six army staff officers today in a reorganization of the high command. It resulted from recent legislation retiring 20 senior staff officers each year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the nation faced the prospect of increased terrorist tactics by the New Left aimed at the total destruction of the Government.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Lewis A. Little of New York has been named vice president and general manager of the Register and Tribune Syndicate, Inc., the newspaper features service announced yesterday. Mr. Little succeeds Bruce Horton of Des Moines, who retired for reasons of health.
STORRS, Conn., Dec. 31 -Students at the University of Connecticut -- members of America's most affluent generation --will get an eightweek look at what life was like in the Depression.

The Jean Shepherd who put on a one-man show in his Town Hall debut last night was not the unseen radio monologist whose tenderly acerbic streams-of-consciousness have hooked countless listeners. But a medium-sized enthusiastic flock on hand for the first of two successive programs nonetheless responded to every word every gesture and every pause.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Navy abruptly terminated the overseas assignment of a civilian petroleum inspector who prompted an investigation that uncovered widespread thefts of fuel intended for United States military operations in Thailand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Friends of Adam Clayton Powell are cautiously optimistic that when the 91st Congress convenes Friday, the Harlem Democrat will regain the House seat from which he was excluded nearly two years ago.

To begin a New Year on the first of January is a contrivance of man, not a mark of nature's seasons. But as 1969 opens, there is a genuine sense of a new beginning. In twenty days, the nation will have a new President; under his leadership, several hundred new officials will take charge of the Government.
The Coast Guard looks to 1969 as the first year in a 30-year period during which it expects an increasingly larger role in its scientific involvements in atmospheric and ocean studies.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -Connie Dierking scored 28 points, 9 of them during a furious exchange late in the game, as the Cincinnati Royals pulled out in front of the Boston Celtics early in the fourth period and held on for a 114-112 victory today.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 31 -- The Executive Commission of the European Common Market has chided France for failing to adhere to a previously agreed schedule in reducing export aids. The commission, acting in its capacity as guardian of community agreements, now threatens to prosecute France before the Court of Justice in Luxembourg, which adjudicates the Common Market internal disputes.

The Inland Steel Company initiated price rises yesterday on hot-rolled strip steel, effective today. The Armco Steel Corporation, the United States Steel Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation followed Inland's move quickly. It is expected that other produced would also act.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- In another attempt to rejuvenate the sagging state lottery, the periodic bonus drawings will be opened to more ticket holders beginning with the December sales.

FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- The rebel Florence priest, the Rev. Enzo Mazzi, yielded today in his struggle against the Roman Catholic hierarchy and handed over the keys of his parish church to a new vicar.

QUINCY, Mass., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Almost everything but the $500,000 in cash taken in Saturday night's armored car robbery in Boston was recovered today in a wooded section of this city south of Boston, the police reported.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Florida, led by the rebounding of Neal Walk and the shooting of Boyd Welsch, defeated Bucknell, 74-70, tonight.
ACCRA, Ghana Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- Two American oil companies, Texaco and Mobil, signed agreements today with the Ghana Government for offshore oil prospecting.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UPI) -Frank Mahovlich scored three goals as the Detroit Red Wings whipped the Minnesota North Stars, 6-3, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Inter - American Development Rank approved today the largest loan in its history: $58.8-million for a hydroelectric project in Colombia.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- A few months ago Edward Morgan Forster had his first ride in a glider. He remarked afterward: "There is absolutely nothing in it. You go up, and you come down."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that South Vietnam's armed forces should gain enough strength in the coming year to be able to relieve some of the 600,000 allied troops stationed in the country.

Bail of $10,000 for Michael Scandifia, a reputed Mafia enforcer, was ordered forfeited in Federal Court yesterday. He is believed to have been a victim of gangland execution, and the court stayed the forfeiture order for 30 days for proof of death, in which case the bail would be returned.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Premier Eisaku Sato told the Japanese people today that he would visit the United States next fall for talks with the President and other American leaders on the return of the Ryukyu Islands to Japan.

On the last night of 1968, the New York Knickerbockers played one of their finest games of the season and whipped the Baltimore Bullets, the first-place team in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, 121-110, last night before a crowd of 15,366 at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Special latches to keep doors and hoods from flying open are required on all United States cars manufactured after today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The national council of the Students for a Democratic Society overwhelmingly rejected today a proposal to stage demonstrations at President-elect Richard M. Nixon's inauguration ceremonies.

MANILA, Dec. 31 -- The assassination over the weekend of two town mayors in Pampanga Province, center of Communist-influenced Hukbalahap activity 40 miles north of Manila, brought renewed pressure today for the restoration of military responsibility for the anti-Huk campaign in central Luzon.

SEATTLE, Dec. 31 -- The effectiveness of a 24-hour employe strike at the Seattle-First National Bank, the nation's 25th largest, appeared inconclusive today because a major snowstorm hit Seattle about the time that employes walked out of the bank's computer and accounting center here last night.

TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Two Israelis were killed last night when Arab guerrillas from Lebanon shelled the town of Kiryat Shmoneh in upper Galilee, an Israeli Army spokesman said today.
The Cafe Figaro is defunct.
Weeb Ewbank renewed his acquaintance with some friends yesterday, and the meeting was not an especially happy occasion.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The staff of the Federal Trade Commission reported today that the chances of winning something for nothing in supermarket games were less than consumers were led to believe.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A judge denied today a request that the trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan be videotaped and presesrved for the "benefit of history."
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 -President-elect Nixon said this afternoon that he and Mr. Rogers would announce "three or four" major appointments to the State Department Saturday in New York.
Striking longshoremen from Maine to Texas have lost an estimated total of $15-million in wages alone since the walkout resumed on Dec. 20 after an 80-day cooling-off period.
The mandatory retirement age of 70 years has caught Judge Peter Maynard Horn in midstride, but he has no intentions of slowing down.

The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., disclosed yesterday that it was suspending some of its planned litigation for the coming year until it had a chance to evaluate the incoming Nixon Administration's performance on civil rights.

THE coming year will include a form of bridge contest that has been undeservedly neglected on this side of the Atlantic for some 15 years: the bidding competition. Partnerships bid some 40 pre-selected deals in the course of an evening, and the contracts they reach are marked on merit according to a scale determined in advance by the organizers.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Mecklenburg County police last night identified a skeleton found last Thursday about 14 miles north of Charlotte as that of Roy Williams.

"Geese," the over-all title for two short dramas by Gus Weill, will open Jan. 12 at the Players Theater. The other play is "Parents and Children." Philip Oesterman will be the director and Jim Mendenhall the producer. Both plays were previously announced for spring production in 1968 by Otto Preminger.

DEEP down where it matters, lurking like a serpent in the verbiage, there seems to be a cliche at the heart of "Yes Yes, No No," which opened last night at the Astor Place Theater. The play by Ronnie Paris is a fantasy picture of a cold and glittering matriarchal world of women without men. Men provide the money, and women do the shopping.
PARIS, Dec. 31 -- The New Year finds the talks here on the Vietnam war almost at a standstill.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UPI) -Front seat headrests will be come standard equipment on new cars at midnight, and sticker prices of new cars from the General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company will go up an average of $17.

ATHENS, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -Premier George Papadopoulos said tonight that the armybacked uprising he led in April, 1967, was responsible for reform and reorganization "the like of which no other period of Greek history can show." In a New Year's message, he said, "Authority is being exercised with a full sense of responsibility and national interest as the sole consideration."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Sacred Heart Academy, which had planned to close in June because of a shortage of nuns and lay teachers, said today it now planned to remain open. Ignatius J. Horstman, chairman of the Sacred Heart Overbrook School Committee, said offers of assistance had been received from any sources.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The monthly premium that 18.6 million older Americans pay for physicians' services under the Medicare program will remain at $4 during the next fiscal year.

HOBART, Australia, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals, the favored American professionals, scored easy victories over Australians today in the first round of the Tasmanian open tennis championship.
HAMPTON, Va., Dec. 31 (AP) -- A T-39 jet trainer with six airmen aboard crashed and burned tonight in a wooded area near Langley Air Force Base.
PARIS, Dec. 31 -- President de Gaulle, in an emotional and at times angry New Year's Eve message tonight, exhorted the French nation to exorcise the demons that have plagued it this year.

ABOARD THE QUEEN ELIZABETH 2, in the Atlantic, Dec. 31 -- The workmen aboard this liner really got busy today-preparing for their own New Year's Eve Party. Most of them are Scots and Hogmanay (New Year's) is Scotland's greatest day for celebrating.
BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- Children race across the polished wooden floors. They laugh, shout and scoot up and down the purple and blue and raspberry paneled stairways. The sound rocks the red metal rafters.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 31 -President Arthur da Costa eSilva appealed to the nation tonight to understand the repressive acts his military regime has undertaken in the last two weeks.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Iowa's strategy failed in the waning seconds today and the Duke Blue Devils won the Sugar Bowl basketball tournament, 85-82, over the Hawkeyes.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 -- Penn State has almost grudgingly been established the slight favorite to beat Kansas in tomorrow night's 35th annual Orange Bowl football game. The Nittany Lions gained the favorite's role because they are undefeated and untied, not because many persons believe they are a much superior team to the Jayhawks.
The Long Island Ducks will face the Greensboro Generals tonight in an Eastern League hockey game at the Long Island Arena, Commack, L.I., at 8:30.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 -With the national collegiate football title at stake, topranked, undefeated Ohio State meets Southern California's defending champions tomorrow in the 55th Rose Bowl game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Authority to construct a $392-million two-unit nuclear power station at Zion, Ill., 40 miles north of Chicago, has been granted the Commonwealth Edison Company by the Atomic Energy Commission.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Gloria Swanson, the actress, has come here as a one-woman unofficial cultural exchange program.

HOUSTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -Southern Methodist's Chuck Hixson, the nation's No. 1 passer, tossed two fourth-quarter touchdowns tonight, and then the Mustangs squelched a rally by Oklahoma to gain a 28-27 victory in the 10th annual Bluebonnet Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The appointment of Andrew J. Glass, 33 years old, as chief press aide to Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, announced today. Mr. Glass has been a reporter for the Washington Post and chief congressional correspondent for the old New York Herald Tribune.

A midtown renewal proposal being drawn up by the City Planning Commission for the West Side envisions office buildings with theaters and glassed-in concourses, midblock pedestrian malls and possibly a moving sidewalk.

NAPLES, Italy, Jan 1 (Reuters) -- The United States Sixth Fleet has been placed on a minor state of alert because of the possibility of serious fighting in the Middle East, informed sources said today.
PERTH, Australia, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The temperature reached a record 108 degrees here today.

It is unfortunate that David M. Kennedy's refusal to commit himself on maintaining the price of gold came one day after it was disclosed that he was taking a $198,750 pay cut to become President-elect Nixon's Secretary of the Treasury.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -- What does the wife of a United Nations delegate face when her husband goes off to do battle at the council table in the name of peace?

The 12th day of the longshoremen's strike along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts found a few tankers moving in and out of the Port of New York yesterday. Like passenger cruise liners, they continue to operate because they do not depend on longshoremen for loading and unloading cargo.

Leaders of the three major branches of American Judaism asserted yesterday that Pope Paul VI and other world figures had applied a double standard in criticizing recent violence and terrorism involving Israel and the Arabs.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 -- Chuck Burkhart, the Penn State quarterback, refused to count his team out and sparked a sudden strike that gave the Nittany Lions a 15-14 victory tonight over Kansas in the last 15 seconds at the Orange Bowl.
"It's going to be a profitable year because everybody's profit-oriented," said John Mack Carter, the magazine man, forecasting for the magazine industry.

The Times of Dec. 15 sheds light on housing problems, especially in New York. "The city's Housing Authority may have to increase rents in 1970 as much as 25 per cent" because of operating costs, up 126 per cent from 1952 to 1967.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Confirmation of Alaska Gov. Walter J. Hickel as Secretary of the Interior could "put effective coal mine safety legislation in jeopardy," a West Virginia Congressman said today.
PRAGUE, Jan. 1 -- President Ludvik Svoboda appointed a new federal Government today and cautioned the people that he could not promise them an easy, smooth road in 1969.
