The 47th Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball took place last night in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. Garlands of silver foliage with myriads of tiny white lights provided the background for the presentation of 34 young women who wore traditional white gowns and carried colonial bouquets in shades of pink that harmonized with the pink flowers and candles on each table.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 28 -- Some $6-billion has been spent in nuclear research and production programs at Oak Ridge since the once top-secret town was brought into existence about 25 years ago by the Army Corps of Engineers.

The key question for 1969 is whether cost and price stability can be restored in the United States economy, without a recession and without a prolonged period of slow growth, Harold S. Geneen, chairman an president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said in a year-end statement.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 1 -- The threat of a major clash on Israel's border with Lebanon loomed today with reports of military reinforcements and Arab rocket attacks.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Chuck Dicus, an Arkansas flanker, caught 12 passes to lead the underdog Razorbacks to a 16-2 victory today over Georgia in the 35th annual Sugar Bowl game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Seven girls, who apparently could not get jobs because of their overweight appearance have all been employed after losing more than 300 pounds among them in six months, the Labor Department reported today.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 1 -Prime Minister Indira Gandhi displayed a conciliatory attitude today toward India's neighbors, Communist China and Pakistan.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 22 -- Contractors for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency are working overtime to erect 10,000 galvanized steel, aluminum and asbestos shelters for Palestinian refugees who are now living under canvas.

In spite of the Greek junta's pronouncements and the statement made by Theodore Tourkovassilis in his Dec. 20 letter to The Times, there is an essential difference between criticism of Greece as a nation and a people and criticism of the present Greek regime.

A Syracuse department store has paid a former employe a month's wages as compensation for an assistant manager's referring to her German origin and calling her a Nazi, the State Commission' for Human Rights announced yesterday.
Bitter, stinging winds swept the New York area yesterday as a cold wave covered the entire eastern half of the country.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Steve B. Wilson's Papa Steve, making his first start of the winter season, scored an upset victory today in the $15,000 added New Year's Handicap at Tropical Park before a crowd of 12,375.
Mayor Lindsay and eight New York City officials are scheduled to attend the inauguration of Luis A. Ferre as Governor of Puerto Rico at 10:30 A.M. today in San Juan.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced plans yesterday for building a 60-mile-long, extra-high-voltage electric power line through Rockland, Orange and Sullivan Counties that will be designed to blend into the surrounding landscape.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Ambassador to Britain asked today for a meeting with Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart to discuss means of settling the Middle East crisis. Mr. Stewart set the meeting for tomorrow.
An extensive program to increase the amount of hotel space in Israel by more than 60 per cent in the next three years is under way.
TORONTO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Norm Ullman scored twice and Toronto bunched three goals in the second period and three in the third for a 7-3 National Hockey League victory over the Oakland Seals tonight.
Forty-three newspaper editors and executives were named journalism jurors for the 1969 Pulitzer Prizes yesterday by Columbia University.
How do people react when unsolicited credit cards turn up in their mail?

Four of the 13 alleged Mafia members seized by policemen, who raided their meeting at the La Stella restaurant in Queens in 1966, face rearrest and trial for contempt because of an Appellate Division ruling.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 1 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, in a broadcast New Year's message, forecast today that in early 1969 what could be "the last hand in the Rhodesian-British drama" would probably be played.

THE American Spaniel Club's 52d national specialty at the Statler Hilton Hotel on Saturday and Sunday will be the country's first major dog show of the year. (it starts a day before the Beverly Hills winter event in California) and one of the few that still is spread over two days.

A 21-year-old college student was shot to death at about 6 A.M. yesterday as he sat in the back seat of an automobile stopped for a traffic signal at St. James Place and Oliver Street, near Chinatown.
The 2-month-old Lower East Side girl taken away by her baby sitter on Sunday was returned yesterday, apparently healthy and unharmed.
LAUREL, Md., Jan. 1 -- Woodside Stud's Kilbegan won the $10,000 Jolly Time Handicap today after Peter Fuller's Three Quarter Girl, who finished first, was disqualified and placed fourth.
In the writing of American history, the pendulum has swung from consensus to conflict.
LONDONDERRY, Vt., Jan. 1 -- Hans Thorner, head of Magic Mountain, came up with his new New Year's resolution on this cold, snowy afternoon.
TOKYO, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Moves toward the merger of two large Japanese banks were reported in the press here today.
THE scene of "The Green House" is town and desert and jungle in northern Peru. The action is as heady as a pisco punch.

WASHINGTON -- The police, courts and correctional agencies of the United States are "shot through with inefficiency and failure," according to Patrick V. Murphy, first director of a new Federal program to improve these units' ability to control crime.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon and his advisers apparently consider foreign policy too serious a matter to be left to the diplomats.
Twenty thousand people at the Hanukkah Festival for Israel in Madison Square Garden last night paid tribute to Ida Kaminska, star and founder of the recently dissolved Jewish State Theater of Poland.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 1 -- The Government has notified Israel that Lebanon will in the future defend herself against all forms of attack.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 1 -- For the second time in just over a month, the police were investigating today an attack on the Fifth Police Precinct station in the Greenville section.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Ohio State's hard-bitten Buckeyes battled back from a 10-0 deficit today to defeat the Southern California Trojans, 27-16, in the 55th Rose Bowl game. The Bucks left no doubt they are the national collegiate champions for this season.
PARIS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- President de Gaulle tonight denounced Israel's reprisal raid on the Beirut airport as an exaggerated act of violence against a peaceful nation.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- The Soviet Union disclosed today that a converted MIG fighter had been used as a prototype to test design features and performance characteristics of a supersonic airliner, the TU-144, that made its first flight yesterday.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The second earth tremor in two months shook most of Arkansas today, but it apparently caused no major damage or injury.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- An apparent shift in Soviet medical policy was reflected today in a detailed description of the first Soviet heart transplant that took up an entire page of the newspaper Literaturnaya Gazeta. The operation was performed last Nov. 4.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city's economic health in 1968 was excellent and that it promised to be even better this year.

A team of airline and government officials is busy these days seeking a solution to the summer and holiday nightmares when parking lots at Kennedy International Airport become glutted and traffic backs up for miles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Two leaders of the New Democratic Coalition said today that members in 15 to 20 states were urging their Senators to support the candidacy of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts for Senate whip, of assistant majority leader.

The insincerity of the Board of Education and its administrative leadership was amply demonstrated by the manner in which it sabotaged the make-up days scheduled over the holidays to compensate for strike time lost.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- The Mamaroneck Frostbite Association's annual Founders Trophy regatta, a scheduled three-day series, was curtailed to two parts today by a strong northwest wind that caused cancellation of the concluding portion of the Dyer dinghy competition.

AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Jordanian military spokesmen said Israeli forces attacked Jordanian troops twice today with a helicopter raid near Gharandal, 40 miles north of the Gulf of Aqaba, and with machine-gun fire near El Shuna, 6 miles south of the Sea of Galilee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- A Navy petroleum inspector who sparked investigations that disclosed huge thefts of United States military fuel in Thailand said today other losses worth "considerably more money" still had not been discovered.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- The Air West agreement put Mr. Hughes, who once had controlling interests in Trans World Airlines and Northeast Airlines, back in the air travel business.
THE following 10 Sportsmen of The Times did more in 1968 than could have been expected of them in proving that it does not really matter whether you win or lose, or even if you play the game.
Algeria, long one of the most steadfastly anti-capitalist nations in the Arab bloc, seems to be turning a friendly eye toward the United States.

Wilbur R. Nordos, acting state trustee of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville experimental school district in Brooklyn, announced last night that charges of harassment against Leslie R. Campbell, a teacher who was suspended from Intermediate School 271, had been dropped and that Mr. Campbell would return to classes this morning.

When the Board of Education begins hearings on its decentralization proposal today, virtually everybody will speak out in favor of decentralization. But many witnesses and special-interest groups will disagree vehemently about the meaning of decentralization and whether it is synonymous with community control.

THE possibility of gaining illicit information from a hesitation by partner is a built-in defect in bridge. Ethical players do their best to avoid making a revealing hesitation and to avoid taking advantage of one made by partner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Almanac for 1969: Jan. 3 through 19: Stormy with intermittent cold spells and bone fractures. Congress meets, elects leaders whose average age is 103 1/2 and decides to do nothing until the White House sends it free flu shots.

A dazzling exhibition called "The Gold of Ancient America" now at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and scheduled to travel to the Art Institute of Chicago and the Virginia Museum in Richmond, is probably the most comprehensive gathering of this precious sculpture yet seen.
"Baseball players?" Boom Boom Geoffrion once said with a sneer. "Why, for crying out loud, they don't play if they got a hangnail."

Governor Rockefeller, although expressing sympathy for New York City's fiscal problems, has indicated that the magnitude of the demands on the state budget will make it impossible to grant anywhere near the $496-million in new aid sought by Mayor Lindsay.
A 36-year-old woman who said she had no idea she was pregnant until less than an hour before delivery gave birth yesterday to a full-term, 6-pound baby girl.

The heart and kidneys of a 48-year-old doctor who died yesterday were successfully transplanted into three men at New York Hospital a few hours later. The three transplant patients were reported to be doing well.

UMUAHIA, Biafra (Nigeria), Jan. 1 (AP) -- A limited truce in the Nigerian civil war has proposed by the Biafran secessionist leader, Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu. He said a truce period could allow the delivery of massive relief, which is needed.
Paul O'Dwyer suggested yesterday that Democratic leaders set up a broad-based committee to recommend a party slate for this year's citywide election.
DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The National Guard has outlived its usefulness and should be abolished, a Wayne State University study has concluded.

FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 30 -- In the wealthier and completely repaired parts of Florence, marble markers with incised and painted lettering constitute the only visible reminders of the disastrous Arno River flood 26 months ago.
The note to the New York Times Neediest Cases fund was very brief and to the point.
HOBART, Tasmania, Australia, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Top-seeded Mrs. Billie Jean King was upset today in the third round of the Tasmanian open tennis championship here.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (UPI) -- More than a million persons watched at curbside and an estimated total of 65 million more watched television broadcasts today of the 80th New Year's Day floral pageant.

New tendencies in modern poetry and new gamesmanship in expressing it can be found in the first issue of a just-published international of poetry, Stony Brook. The publication, named after the branch of the state university on Long Island, will appear biannually.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 1 -- King's Cross, the Times Square of Sydney, welcomed the new year last night with the most boisterous demonstration in the lively history of the raucous entertainment area.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A city official said today that a court-ordered delay in a new tax package might cause a strike by municipal employes, including policemen and firemen.

A stroller's guide to New York that focuses on the city's buildings and landmark's -- sometimes unflatteringly -- has been compiled for visitors and residents by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

NEWARK, Jan. 1 -- Assistant State Attorney General William J. Brennan 3d was criticized by the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey today for what it termed the "irresponsible manner" in which he had accused six state legislators of being "entirely too comfortable with members of organized crime."

The life insurance industry has already committed more than 80 per cent of the funds it pledged late in 1967 to finance projects that are intended to improve living conditions for people in blighted urban areas.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 1 -- The inauguration tomorrow of Puerto Rico's new Governor, Luis A. Ferre, brings to a close a major era in the island's history.
CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A bill to permit abortion in cases of "justified medical termination," was entered in the state Legislature today as it convened for its first session in 1969.
WESTERNVILLE, N.Y., Thursday, Jan. 2 -- A man with a rifle killed four persons and wounded five others last night, then stole a Jeep equipped with a snowplow and fled in a driving snowstorm.

DENVER, Jan. 1 (AP) -- About 60,000 union oil workers were on the job without a contract today as stalemated negotiations between the nation's oil companies and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union were in a New Year's Day recess.
Dr. Paul L. Niebanck of the University of Pennsylvania, an authority on urban housing problems, was designated yesterday to head a study of New York's City housing supply.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Representative Morris Udall and Senator Ted Kennedy are getting the Democratic party off to a lively start for 1969 with their challenges to the Congressional Establishment of their party.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A drastically revised foreign aid program is being shaped by Republican Congressmen along lines suggested by President-elect Richard M. Nixon and his advisers.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Nineteen members of the 82-man crew of the U.S.S. Pueblo traveled to Pasadena today for the Rose Bowl football game while many others took New Year's Day liberty in this Navy town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Reies Lopez Tijerina, the leader of a group of Spanish-speaking Americans in New Mexico, cabled Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain today, asking him to place the group's property claims against the United States before the United Nations.
IF you have a friend to whom the call of the running tide is both wild and clear, he would probably appreciate a subscription to the National Fisherman.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon watched the Rose Bowl Game today between Ohio State University and the University of Southern California.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Highway Administration has told West Virginia and Ohio that it is willing to pick up the full $14.4-million tab to replace a bridge across the Ohio River between Point Pleasant, W. Va., and Kanauga, Ohio, which collapsed in 1967, claiming the lives of 46 persons.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Jim Street's touchdown passes of 78 and 79 yards to Charlie Speyrer, a slashing running attack and a tough defense carried fifth-ranked Texas to an easy 36-13 victory over Tennessee in the Cotton Bowl football game today.

SEATTLE, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Directors of Air West, Inc., said late last night they had decided to sell the airline to Howard Hughes. In making the decision, they beat by only a few hours a midnight deadline set by the financier.

ROME, Jan. 1 -- Pope Paul said today that continuing actions of "guerrilla warfare, terrorism and reprisal" in Africa, Palestine and Vietnam sent "a painful quiver" through a mankind hungry for peace.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The body of Marina Elizabeth Habe, 17-year-old daughter of an actress and a writer, was found late yesterday in a ravine off Mulholland Drive, sheriff's officers said. Her body was fully clothed.
Theodore H. White, the author who straightens out the crazy quilt of Presidential campaigns, is once more at work discerning a thread and sparing the needle.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 1 -- Two neighboring countries in East Africa opened separate limited revolutions today -- one "cultural" and one economic.

The large trading gap between developed and developing nations was basically untouched by the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations, according to a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 1 -- Two hours after their release by the Vietcong today, three tired American soldiers were eating a lunch of hamburgers and ice cream at an Army hospital near Saigon.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCH-EN, West Germany, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Bjoern Wirkola of Norway scored 241.2 points today to gain his second successive victory in the German-Austrian four-hill ski jumping competition.
The New York Jets will have their first look at their greatest victory today, but tomorrow it will be July 15 all over again.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- The six surviving members of Sir Winston Churchill's wartime "secret circle" condemned a play today that insinuated that he had a hand in the death of the Polishe Prime Minister, Gen. Wladyslaw Sikorski.
ROME, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- President Giuseppe Saragat said today that Italy was in a state of crisis because politicians and bureaucrats were unable to keep up with changes in the society.

LONDON, Jan 1 -- War risk rates for shipments by air and sea to or from the Middle East were increased sharply today by the Institute of London Underwriters. A spokesman cited the present "crisis" as the reason.
More than 200 pints of blood were donated yesterday in the city's continuing effort to replenish its dwindling emergency blood supply.

IT is curious, or perhaps it is not curious, that for a children's ballet "Coppelia" normally possesses a remarkable amount of mayhem and malice. The characters are scarcely sympathetic: The hero, Franz, although supposedly in love with Swanilda, is only too willing to initiate an extracurricular affair with the doll, Coppe1ia.
Porters, food handlers, maids and other service employes at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn walked off their jobs yesterday a few hours after their contract had expired.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- The united States and North Vietnamese delegations to the talks here are maintaining "some sort of contact" despite an unusually long interval between more formal exchanges, an American source said today.

South Vietnam's President Nguyen Van Thieu continues to resist any recognition of the National Liberation Front and talks boldly -- though vaguely -- of carrying on the war, with South Vietnamese troops bearing an increasing share of the burden. Nevertheless, pressure is mounting for a breakthrough in the stalemated Paris peace talks.
LISBON, Jan. 1 -- A Solemn group of Roman Catholics occupied one of Lisbon's' principal churches in the early hours of the new year and called for peace in Portuguese Africa.
ARTHUR BISGUIER, the grandmaster from Yonkers, commands a deceptive style. In the opening, particularly, his offbeat way can well conceal an early blow against an unwary foe.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- The deputy chief of Hanoi's negotiating team here, Colonel Ha Van Lau, was recently asked where he had been meeting with Cyrus R. Vance, deputy head of the United States delegation, for their confidential contacts.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Countries outside Britain that use the pound for international trade had a combined surplus for their world transactions in the second quarter of 1968, the British Government announces.
The nation's commercial and naval shipyards are suffering from a chronic and severe shortage of skilled shipwrights.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 1 (UPI) -- President Johnson will tear a page out of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's book and head for a Vacation at Palm Springs, Calif., in February when his White House days are over.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The 91st Congress convenes tomorrow with the Democratic majority divided between young and old as well as between liberals and conservatives over how to organize its opposition to a Republican administration.

The money market churned violently during the week ended Wednesday, as financial institutions struggled to make normal yearend transactions, and at the same time adjust to the Federal Reserve's newly restrictive stance in credit policy. Member bank borrowings from the central banking system, which normally are a sensitive indicator of money market conditions, soared to a daily average of $1.32-billion, the highest since May 13, 1953.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- United States Government analysts found Premier Fidel Castro's 10th anniversary speech far milder than they had expected.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Two prominent Democrats announced today that they would ask Congress on Monday to increase the electoral vote for President-elect Richard M. Nixon.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- United States and North Vietnamese negotiators met for more than four hours late today on new allied proposals to break the procedural impasse on the Vietnam talks here.
A nonexistent bathroom on the second floor, a bathroom without a window on the third floor and a disappearing woman merged to become something of a mystery in State Supreme Court here yesterday.

The Human Resources Administration yesterday requested a budget of $1.9-billion for the next fiscal year -- 91 per cent of it to be spent on a record welfare budget of $1.7-billion for a caseload expected to rise to 1.3 million people by June, 1970.

In the history of mankind might has never made right, yet Israel persists under the guise of retaliation in justifying her acts of aggression and expansion. On Dec. 28 Israel attacked Beirut International Airport, destroying thirteen aircraft and causing damage of over $50 million in a so-called reprisal raid for the shelling of an El Al airliner by two commandos in Athens.

Two stockbrokers were walking along a street in downtown New York the other day when they came upon several workmen busily digging among cobblestones. The light danced like silver off the pickaxes and shovels. "What's all the excitement?" asked Stockbroker A. Stockbroker B, a pundit who has never for gotten a budding career on The Yale Record, his college humor magazine, replied:

Justice John R. Starkey of Brooklyn State Supreme Court signed a temporary restraining order yesterday against a union striking Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn. But the workers remained away from their jobs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- E. R. Squibb Sons said today that its antibiotic prescription drug Mysteclin-F, which the Government plans to remove from the market, "has its proper place in medical practice."

TRENTON, Jan. 2 -- The chairman of the legislative committee investigating alleged associations between organized crime and a number of legislators said tonight that the inquiry was "still wide open" and that more witnesses would be called to testify.

Stewart R. Mott, heir to a General Motors fortune who contributed $50,000 each to Governor Rockefeller and Senator Eugene J. McCarthy in their efforts to obtain Presidential nominations, yesterday made known nine grants for unconventional social crusades.

Your Dec. 13 editorial ["Good-by to the Waterfront"] on the relocation of the Fort Greene wholesale meat market presented a number of sound reasons for not using the area which has been approved by this city's Site Selection Board.
A $27-million project for widening one of the principal traffic bottlenecks in Queens -- a three-mile scetion of the Grand Central Parkway -- was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

Despite a warning last month by the Transit Authority that insufficient 1969-70 capital-budget funds for transit would jeopardize the 20-cent fare, the City Planning Commission refused yesterday to recommend a higher allocation.
The advance in prices in the money and capital markets that began on the final trading day of 1968 carried over into the new year.
More than 60 clerical and professional workers at the American Jewish Congress walked off their jobs yesterday in a contract dispute with the nonprofit human rights agency.

Seventeen lawyers were sworn in as State Supreme Court justices yesterday with a somber warning from Governor Rockefeller that "we are now undergoing a national trial ourselves, a trial of the very values by which we live."

Brooklyn detectives seized 14 men yesterday in an investigation of the theft of more than $100,000 in welfare checks from mailmen and mailboxes over the last two months. Checks totaling $20,000 also were confiscated.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railroad and its more than 90 per cent controlled subsidiary, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, reported yesterday consolidated earnings for 1968 of $55.2-million, equal to $6.35 a common share.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 2 -- The Queen Elizabeth 2 steamed into her home port today, her arrival virtually ignored.

As expected, volume on the American Stock Exchange dropped yesterday as a result of the 2 P.M. closing, an hour and a half early. Volume at the end of trading totaled 5,372,415 shares, compared with an average of over 7 million shares a day with the later closing.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan 21 (UPI) -- President Johnson an-[ nounced today the recess ap-J pointment of Robert C. WoodJ as Secretary of Housing and[ Urban Development during the/ remaining clays of the JohnsonT Administration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Congressional leaders agreed today to try to pass a quick pay increase for President-elect Richard M. Nixon.

MAGHERA, Northern Ireland Jan. 2 -- Militant Protestants forced youthful civil rights marchers into back roads and country lanes of Northern Ireland today during the second day of a 73-mile march to protest Roman Catholic grievances.

DENVER, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Lewis W. Dymond will resign immediately as board chairman, president and chief executive officer of Frontier Airlines, it was announced here today. The reason given was a "basic difference in operating philosophy" with the carrier's majority stockholder, RKO General, Inc.
ATHENS, Jan. 2 -- A Greek spokesman said tonight that the hijacking suspect was an "antisocial element" who had been court-martialled for antiregime activities.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau refused tonight to rule out the possibility of Canada's leaving the North Atlantic Treaty Organization after reviewing her foreign policy.
PARIS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The French Government is offering the Maginot Line for apartments.

For reasons known only to themselves, the Rangers allowed themselves to be intimidated by the Boston Bruins last night and if the visitors' 4-2 victory is any indication of the New Yorkers' attitude, the Rangers are in deep trouble.

I wish to object to one statement in your editorial on Brazil (Dec. 18), which holds that the military had a "good case" for overthrowing the constitutionally elected Government of Joao Goulart in 1964.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had approved for original listing on the exchange 9 million Class A common shares of The New York Times Company.
Mayor Lindsay's glowing report on the city's economy, made public on New Year's Day, was held by various experts yesterday to tell only part of the story.
At 25 Sutton Place South a doorman in a fresh uniform opens the glass door and a visitor steps in on a thick-piled gold and brown rug.

PARIS -- There has been much pleasant speculation that the Nixon Administration will get American foreign policy back to an emphasis on Europe at Asia's expense, but facts indicate little reality in this surmise.
Western Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to release its decision on the domestic phase of the Trans Pacific route case -- the biggest airline route realignment in history.
The City Human Rights Commission yesterday received its first complaint of discrimination against a physically handicapped person.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Less inflation and slightly more unemployment were predicted for 1969 by a top Government economist today.

INTO each life some fig leaves must fall, but too many have fallen in mine. In fact, there is nothing much wrong with "The Fig Leaves Are Falling," which last night boldly arrived at the Broadhurst Theater, that a new book, new music, new lyrics, new settings, new direction, new choreography and a partially new cast would not quite possibly put right.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Post Office Department said today that it had denied a concern in North Hollywood, Calif., the right to receive funds through the mail for magazines the department found to be obscene.
The Brotherhood of Railway Carmen announced yesterday that it would not strike the Long Island Railroad for up to 90 days if public hearings were held on what it called mismanagement by the railroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President - elect Richard M. Nixon has decided to put up to Ray C. Bliss the question of whether he should remain as Republican National Chairman
TEL AVIV, Jan. 2 -- Israel today rejected a role for the four major powers in seeking a peaceful solution to the crisis in the Middle East.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
Gilbert Miller, for more than half a century a major Broadway and London producer, died in his sleep yesterday at his Park Avenue home. He was 84 years old.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would take a major step this year toward the complete automation of odd-lot orders, those generally involving less than 100 shares.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Republicans outspent the Democrats, $5-million to $3-million, in the use of television during the Presidential election campaign, the Federal Communications Commission reported today.

The Latin Quarter, closed since last Friday because of a strike of its chorus girls, has filed charges of unfair labor practices against the American Guild of Variety Artists with the National Labor Relations Board.
The Grand Union Company had the highest sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended Nov. 30 in its 96-year history, according to its report issued yesterday.

Events in the Middle East this week indicate that the United Nations will be taking a great risk if it pins all its hopes for a peaceful settlement in the area on the essentially passive role now assigned to Ambassador Gunnar Jarring. It becomes increasingly probable that the Arabs and Israelis, left to their own devices, will make war, not peace -- perhaps in a matter of weeks.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 2 -- President Arthur da Costa e Silva made 10 changes in the Constitution and decreed eight new laws today to increase his military regime's control over Government spending and to reduce distortions in the economy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- John W. McCormack of Massachusetts trounced a liberal challenger today to win a fifth term as Speaker of the House of Representatives.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller has appointed five State Supreme Court justices to serve on the court's Appellate Division.

The head of the city teachers' union yesterday described as "shocking" the reinstatement of Leslie R. Campbell, a controversial Negro teacher at Junior High School 271 in Ocean HillBrownsville and one of the key figures in the dispute there that resulted in the teachers' strikes last fall.
An appeal to President Johnson to intervene in the 13-day-old longshore strike along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts was made yesterday by the New York Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Hounse Democrats and Republicans decided today not to make a party issue over the seating of Adam Clayton Powell when the 91st Congress convenes tomorrow, leaving the issue in doubt.

AS a detailed autopsy of the New York City public school system, David Rogers's "110 Livingston Street" is one of those books that are more important to the average reader for their existence than for what they offer as a reading experience.
Max Baer, Philadelphia Jack O'Brien and Jacob Hyer have been elected to boxing's Hall of Fame, bringing the list of members to 97.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon received his annual physical examination today and was told by his doctor that he was "in full good health to assume the challenges of the Presidency."
Record Christmas sales sharply lifted December volume at five of the country's largest retail chains as the holiday season wound up with a traditional big surge.

The Hong Kong flu epidemic here, which peaked earlier this week, appeared to have weakened further yesterday, although health officials said they were not ready yet to rescind their declaration of "a state of peril" in the city.
The First National City Bank said yesterday that private hoarding of gold continued through all of 1968, even after the creation of the two-tier gold market last March.

The Delacorte Fountain, designed to throw a jet of water 400 to 600 feet high off the southwestern tip of Welfare Island is rapidly approaching completion as the first stage in the redevelopment of New York's most desolate piece of real estate.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today the 1968 winners of the National Medal of Science, the Government's highest award for distinguished achievement in science, mathematics and engineering.
PROFESSIONAL football coaches and players have been accused of overstating the violence of their game with the use of such vivid descriptive terms as "blitz," "bomb" and "red dog."
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
A $91.8-million proposal by the Sundstrand Corporation to acquire Standard Kollsman Industries, Inc., led the way on the active merger-acquisition front yesterday

The New York City Ballet left the world of childhood fantasy last night at the New York State Theater for the world of -- adult fantasy. Swan queens and sylphs replaced sugarplum fairies as the company settled into a six-week repertory period, following the record holiday season at the box office during its 38 performances of "The Nutcracker."
The New York Philharmonic played music by Bonporti, Schubert and Verdi in its concert in Philharmonic Hall last night, and it sounded as fresh as the new year.
HAVANA, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Premier Fidel Castro has changed little from the revolutionary who led his guerrilla troops to victory over government forces 10 years ago this week.
The baseball players who have been threatening for a month not to sign their 1969 contracts -- and not to play -- will soon have a chance to back up their words.

Beverly Sills will make her debut at La Scala in Milan on April 11 as Palmira in Rossini's "The Seige of Corinth."
ANCHORAGE, Jan. 2 -- The first topic of conversation here in a bright, sub-zero New Year's season was not the weather but "Udall's freeze."

The conservative style of the Democrats in the House of Representatives made easily predictable the defeat of Morris K. Udall's challenge to Speaker John W. McCormack. But the magnitude of the Udall defeat in no way detracts from the significance of his effort. Thanks to him, a change in the Speakership two years from now has moved from the probable to the virtually inevitable.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 2 -- Luis A. Ferre pledged "La nueva vida," a new life, for "the thousands of destitute Puerto Ricans," at his inauguration today as Governor of this tropical island.

UNDERLEADING aces against suit contracts is a perilous venture. Players who make a rule never to do so cannot go far wrong, and indeed one international team once made such a rule in a world championship.

" TO BE YOUNG, GIFTED AND BLACK," a moving evening, sentimental in the best sense of the word, came to the Cherry Lane Theater last night in words by the late Lorraine Hensberry, who certainly more than met the title qualifications when she died at the age of 34 in 1965.

Cafe La Mama, the theater group that first experimented, under workshop conditions, with such commercial hits as "Hair," "America Hurrah" and "The Concept," will resume activities even though it does not have the funds to finish reconstruction of its new home at 74A East Fourth Street.
DOUBLE-DECKER, multi-functioning environments, a mere glint in the eyes of furniture designers in 1968, have become a furnishing reality in 1969.
Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., announced yesterday the election of eight new stockholders, including Miss Jane C. Mack, its first woman stockholder.
LAUREL, Md., Jan. 2 -- William Rayne's Spooky Wooky won the $4,200 Good Luck Purse at the Laurel Race Course today.
Eight City Councilmen from Queens will meet at City Hall this morning to elect a new Borough President, but a 4-to-3 split of the Democratic delegation may allow a Republican to cast a decisive vote.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Underwater photographs of the nuclear submarine Scorpion, which sank mysteriously off the Azores last May with 99 men aboard, have convinced some Navy experts that they can eliminate foul play as a possible cause of the sinking.

Dell Publishing Company, a major paperback reprint concern, has acquired complete ownership of the Dial Press, Inc., a hardcover publisher, marking another step in Dell's movement into the category of all-around book producers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam -- After days of overoptimism, false starts, half-completed programs and lost opportunities, the allied forces in Vietnam appear to be making major progress against the enemy.

An appropriate symbolism marked Fidel Castro's "birthday present" to the Cuban people yesterday -- his announcement of the introduction of sugar rationing. That curb was the latest reminder of the numerous economic difficulties a decade of Castroism has brought, difficulties the ordinary Cuban experiences daily in the limitations on his food, clothing, gasoline and now even sugar supply.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Representative John Bayard Anderson complained to his wife recently: "The reporters always call me 'articulate.' Why don't they ever call me 'adroit'?"

HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Three Australians -- Tony Roche, Fred Stolle and Mal Anderson -- and Roger Taylor of Britain reached the semi-finals of the Tasmanian open tennis championship as expected today.

The second election for officials of the National Maritime Union got under way here quietly yesterday.
HAVANA, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Premier Castro spoke today before a crowd estimated at a million.
The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday a brief report on the recent changes in ownership of shares by corporate officials or major stockholders.
Emile Griffith, knocked out of a pay night in Madison Square Garden by the Hong Kong flu, learned yesterday that his financial loss was only temporary.

HOPATCONG, N. J., Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Borough Police Chief Hubertus Jacoby was relieved of all duties tonight by the Borough Council following charges by a local man who said he was the victim of an extortion.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Soviet Ambassador, Mikhail M. Smirnovsky, met at his request today with Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart to discuss the situation in the Middle East.
MIAMI, Friday, Jan. 3 -- A huge Eastern Airlines jet, flying nonstop from New York to Miami, was hijacked and routed to Cuba late last night with 138 passengers and a crew of eight aboard.

MANILA, Jan 2 -- Carlos P. Romulo enunciated a nationalistic foreign policy for the Philippines today as he returned to the post of Foreign Secretary, which he held before in the early nineteen-fifties.

The Schaefer beer boys, pleased as punch with the result of their 1968 talent hunt, are going to give it a go again this year. What they'll be looking for once more will be musical groups or soloists to belt out an old favorite, "Schaefer Is the One Beer to Have When You're Having More Than One," in all of their radio advertising in their 14-state marketing area.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- President de Gaulle discussed his proposal for major-power action in the Middle East with Ambassador Valerian A. Zorin of the Soviet Union today.

MIAMI, Jan. 2 -- Premier Fidel Castro committed Cuba today to a long-range agricultural development plan and by implication indefinitely postponed the country's industrialization, once a major economic goal.

A special two-day round-trip fare has become the first casualty of the New Haven Railroad's merger with the Penn Central Company. The merger took place Tuesday.

The eight-story Stadium View Inn near La Guardia Airport in Corona, Queens, has been purchased for $2.9-million by the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene, which plans to establish a social and vocational training center for mentally retarded persons. The hotel has 220 rooms and was one of many erected in the area to serve visitors to the New York World's Fair of 1964-65.
The Board of Education's proposed decentralization plan came under criticism from many sources yesterday at the first of a series of public hearings.
The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation said yesterday it would increase prices of nickel-bearing stainless steel sheet strip plate and bar products 3 1/2 per cent, effective next Monday.

No commodity has a more interesting take in 1969 than world sugar. Yesterday marked the first day for the new international sugar agreement, which has set a minimum price 3.25 cents a pound.

IN the first six months that the cadets of New York Maritime had at their disposal a real ocean-racing yacht, they treated her like anything but a toy. In fact, the new boat -- she was commissioned last May 14 -- rapidly gained a respected reputation by winning six trophies in 11 races.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Ken Buchanan of Scotland, the British lightweight champion, stretched his unbeaten record to 29 fights tonight by gaining a 10-round decision over Frankie Narvaez, a Puerto Rican who boxes out of New York.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- Gov. John A. Volpe delivered his valedictory today in his seventh annual message to the Massachusetts legislature. It is a new experience for the world to read of Jews avenging crimes perpetrated against them instead of turning the other cheek. Defense can be the only "final solution to the Jewish problem" -- not praying while digging one's grave.

Two major New York banks -- the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Charter New York Corporation -- reported sharply higher 1968 profits yesterday as year-end statements began to arrive from the nation's banks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Manufacturers' inventories rose by $616-million in November, slightly more than the monthly average for 1968 but less than in some individual months, the Commerce Department reported today.

Jack Adlerblum, the recipient of the first heart transplant of 1969, was described as in "almost excellent condition" yesterday by officials at New York Hospital, where the operation was performed early Wednesday

The new chairman of the Emergency Committee for American Trade said here yesterday that the Nixon Administration would probably not make any significant changes in the liberal trade policies followed by President Johnson.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Richard M. Nixon tonight used what he desribed as his "last public dinner" before the Inauguration on Jan. 20 to deliver an emotional tribute to "the Presidency of the United States" and its incumbent, Lyndon B. Johnson.

HONG KONG, Jan. 3 -- A new constitution of the Communist party of China is expected to name Defense Minister Lin Piao as the heir to Mao Tse-tung's position as leader of China, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Victor J. Orsinger, a Washington lawyer, was sentenced today to three to nine years in prison on charges that he converted to his own use $1.5million entrusted to him by an order of Roman Catholic nuns.
The London Stock Exchange turned irregular yesterday on profit taking that followed Thursday's strong gains. Leading industrials were easier.

The dome pictured in the Dec. 15 article, "Connecticut Opens a Dinosaur Park," was incorrectly identified as a geodesic dome. The term geodesic dome is generally used in reference to the type of dome structure developed by the architect Buckminster Fuller. It is built up of metal tubular members and panels, which may be of various materials; the metal frame makes the structure self-supporting.

Johnny Winter has spent years playing bars and lounges in the South and now, with fingers that fly across his guitar like a Texas tornado, he is moving to New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 7 -- Dr. Le Minh Tri, the South Vietnamese Minister of Education, who made a reputation and enemies by fighting corruption, died last night of injuries received yesterday morning when a hand grenade exploded in his sedan in downtown Saigon.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed with losses yesterday. Trading was moderate. Brokers attributed the decline to profit taking and a report that capital spending in Britain might be leveling off.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 6 -- Zambia's campaign against both Asian traders and supporters of the opposition African National congress gained momentum today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The House voted today to increase the pay of the President to $200,000 a year from $100,000, effective with the inauguration of Richard M. Nixon on Jan. 20.

Two snowstorms moved eastward across the northern half of the nation yesterday, one headed toward the Appalachians and the other toward the Rockies. Schools were closed, air traffic curtailed and highways blocked.
Plans for the nation's first atomarium -- a small, nuclear research reactor on permanent display to the public -- were announced yesterday by the Atomic Energy Commission.
The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday that it had taken an important step to block the allegedly illegal use of Swiss banks in American financial transactions.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Jan. 6 -- A group of Negro students accompanied by some white sympathizers walked out of the Lawrence High School this morning because their terms of a "black students' manifesto" had not been met by school authorities.

The United States Lines announced last night that its 51,000-ton passenger liner United States had been declared "exempt" from the strike of the longshoremen's union and that the ship would sail on her next scheduled cruise on Jan. 23.
ATLANTA, Jan. 6--Ivan C. Allen Jr., Mayor of Atlanta since 1962 and one of the South's most liberal elected officials, announced today that he would not seek re-election to a third term.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Ever since World War II, a mysterious force called the "winds of change" has been blowing through Africa, Asia, Europe, the American South, the Middle East and all points west; but only just now has this hardiest of cliches been able to penetrate the Congress of the United States.
The Hammermill Paper Company, Erie, Pa., and the Thilmany Pulp and Paper Company, Kaukauna, Wis., announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge through an exchange of stock valued at $48-million.

A mild weekend sent frozen orange juice futures tumbling during yesterday's session. The downturn, which proved temporary, was not unexpected following the recent strong rise based on freezing conditions in the Florida growing areas.

Mrs. Carol Greitzer, a Greenwich Village Democratic district leader and civic leader, early today won the Reform Democratic endorsement to fill out the last year of Representatice Edward I. Koch's term in the City Council.
Both of New York's recipients of heart transplants this year were reported in satisfactory condition yesterday at New York Hospital.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The wife of Eldridge Cleaver, the fugitive Black Panther leader, said today that eight carloads of armed policemen stopped her car on the Oakland Bay Bridge and forced her and two friends to stand in the cold for about 20 minutes.
Bob Foster formally signed a contract yesterday to defend his world light-heavyweight boxing title Jan. 22 against the Jersey City roughhouse, Frank De Paula.
ROME, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- Will Maslow, executive director of the American Jewish Congress, berated American Negro leaders tonight for turning a blind eye to black anti-Semitism.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted 9-3 against tightening money further at its meeting of Oct. 8, it was disclosed today.
The stock market, bending under the weight of assorted worries, returned to the five-day trading week yesterday and thereupon suffered its sharpest decline in more than a year and a half.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Eight Senate Democrats and eight Republicans -- almost all of them liberals or moderates -- strongly criticized today the United Nations Security Council censure of Israel last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Congress refused today to cancel the electoral vote cast by a North Carolinian who ran pledged to Richard M. Nixon, then switched to George C. Wallace.

TOURNAMENTS frequently schedule pair events in which players must play with partners in their own class, as measured by master points. The Westchester tournament played during the weekend included a variation: each partnership had to consist of one master, possessing more than 50 master points, and one non-master, with fewer than 50 points.

CAMAU, South Vietnam, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Maj. James N. Rowe, the Special Forces officer held prisoner for five years by the Vietcong, evaded the enemy for nine days after his escape before finally being picked up by an American helicopter, according to reports in this Mekong Delta town.
The pictures of the earth televised from Apollo 8, you said in your editorial of Dec. 24, reminded humanity that "nature is the basic antagonist, not other men."

I MAY be shouting before I am burned, as the cat said as he fell into the furnace, but I do feel extraordinarily strong about one particular aspect of the performances by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater on Sunday.

Investors purchased more United States Savings Bonds and Freedom Shares than they cashed in last year, but the resulting net cash Treasury inflow of $67-million was the worst performance since 1959, when there was a net outflow of $316-million.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 6 -- Five Opposition political parties announced today that they would not participate "at any level" in the next elections if their five "minimum conditions of democracy" were not accepted.

In his letter favoring pupil tuition grants, Prof. Matthew Holden said that both liberals and conservatives "must surely admit that 'public education' really means 'public responsibility for education.'" From this he argues that tuition grants directly from the public treasury to parents satisfies the essential concept of public education even though the result would be for parents to use the funds to buy private education for their children in a free competitive market.

PIERRE CARDIN, the French couturier, has joined forces with Gunther Oppenheim, a Seventh Avenue manufacturer, to set up "Pierre Cardin Pour Les Femmes," the designer's sole licensee of women's ready-to-wear in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- The chief examiner of the Federal Communications Commission ruled today that a marijuana party televised on a Chicago station's news program was prearranged for the benefit of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The Israeli Embassy said tonight that France, without any warning, was now preventing the delivery of arms to Israel, except spare parts for training planes.
Minority stockholders of S. H. Kress Co., obtained yesterday Federal Court approval of a $2-million settlement of a suit against Genesco, Inc., which owns 95 per cent of the retailing chain.
At least 20 student demonstrators invaded the Queens College registrar's office and the school's library yesterday, overturning admissions records, card catalogues and books.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 6 -- The Australian stock exchanges agreed today to implement the Federal Government's plan to protect businesses from takeover raids by overseas groups.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 6 -- Among the command performances for participants in the Super Bowl game is "photo day" when the players are ordered to be available in uniform for newspaper cameramen and television crews.

Every two years a new Senate meets and every two years its members have to decide whether they wish to live by the first principle of democratic politics -- majority rule. Up to now, the Senate has been content to accept the tyranny of the minority. Under Senate Rule 22 approximately one-third of the members can hold up a decision by the other two-thirds indefinitely.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The United States has asked France to pay compensation for the cost of American installations vacated when North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces were expelled by President de Gaulle two years ago.
Derald H. Ruttenberg, a lawyer turned investor and merger broker, was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of Studebaker-Worthington, Inc.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 6 -- A spokesman of the Lebanese high command said tonight that villagers aged 18 to 50 in southern districts bordering on Israel had been asked to report immediately to military centers, for training in the use of weapons.
Three nuns -- a principal and two teachers -- accused of teaching "evolution vs. creation" have been dismissed from a Roman Catholic parochial school on Staten Island.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon yesterday chose as Under Secretary of Agriculture a Georgian who switched from the Democratic party to the Republican last year to protest the policies of the Johnson Administration.

BRADFORD, Pa., Tuesday, Jan. 7 -- An Allegheny Airlines propjet crashed while trying to land during a light snow last night, almost precisely the same way as a sister flight that crashed here two weeks ago.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 6 -- This is the place where the New York Yankees trained when they were winning world championships. This is the place where the Green Bay Packers trained when they were winning world championships. Now the New York Jets are here, living in the Packer Hotel and flexing their muscles on the Yankee Field.

BELMONT, Mass., Jan. 6 -- Robert Welch, founder and president of the John Birch Society, decried today the appointments of Robert D. Murphy, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Henry A. Kissinger as key advisers to President-elect Richard M. Nixon.

LOGAN, W. Va., Jan. 6 -- "Here," said the physician, holding up something thin, dry and fragile before his audience of miners in the high school auditorium, "is a slice of one of your brother's lungs."
The Board of Health declared an end yesterday to the three-week old "state of great and imminent peril" brought on by the combination of Hong Kong flu and the fuel oil strike.
WQXR, the long-time bastion of solid classical radio programing, will broaden its sound to include contemporary folk and pop music like that of the Beatles, Simon and Garfunkle and the Tijuana Brass.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 6 -- American troops who were sent home last year came back to West Germany today in huge silver troop-transport planes to open the biggest United States military maneuvers here since 1963.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- The Department of Justice presented an hour and a half of film clips today at a preliminary session of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit on the appeal of Dr. Benjamin Spock and three other defendants convicted of violation of the draft law.
A day packed with nearly 12 hours of activity was outlined by the city yesterday for the Apollo 8 astronauts, who are scheduled to visit New York on Friday.
PARIS, Jan. 6 -- North Vietnam's chief spokesman indicated today that his Government would reject the latest allied proposals for the shape of the conference table for the expanded talks on Vietnam.

PRAGUE, Jan. 6--A compromise proposal aimed at settling the controversy over the future of Josef Smrkovsky, the progressive chairman of the National Assembly, came today from the Communist party Bureau.

Robert Channing Seamans Jr., whose appointment as Secretary of the Air Force was announced yesterday, is an aircraft and space specialist who is a member of the increasingly enlarging elite of government and industry -- scientist - administrators.
Prices fell sharply yesterday in active trading on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Defense Secretary-designate Melvin R. Laird today chose three men -- a scientist, a politician and a proved administrator -- to serve as the top civilian chiefs of the three armed services.

The nation's retail industry, which has been gradually moving toward diversification under the spur of Government antitrust action, yesterday heard a leading business-empire builder predict that a Federal law on conglomerate companies would emerge from Washington's concern about mergers.
A 10-year-old boy who took religious instruction at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn was seized yesterday afternoon and admitted setting 12 fires in the center, the police said.

The United States Trust Company of New York has appointed Angus C. Littlejohn as president of the United States Trust Company International Corporation, the Edge Act subsidiary, it was announced yesterday.

ROME, Jan 6. (AP) -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, the president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that Pope Paul VI told him the papal message of sympathy to President Charles Helou of Lebanon did not mean that the Pope had an anti-Jewish attitude in the Israeli-Arab conflict.

A HUNDRED THOUSAND New Yorkers must pass the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 50th Street every day, unaware that they are missing a chance to see a bas-relief by one of the world's foremost sculptors. Giacomo Manzu's bronze panel depicts a barefoot Italian immigrant with her clinging child, their worldly goods wrapped in a kerchief, coming to America.

The network of 22 offices, bureaus and special programs under the direct supervision of Mayor Lindsay is seeking $21.3-million in the fiscal year begining July 1, or $9.4-million more than the current budget.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today that thousands of veterans had been "cruelly deceived" by a false rumor concerning a special dividend on G.I. insurance.

NEWARK, Jan. 6 -- A 12-man "strike force" of Federal investigators moved into offices in the Federal Courthouse here today to begin a statewide inquiry into criminal activities reported by some law-enforcement agents to net racketeers $1-billion a year.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Damage to the turbines of the Queen Elizabeth 2 appeared today to be more severe than expected, threatening further delay in completion of the $70.8-million luxury liner.
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- A Jordanian military spokesman said that Israeli artillery and helicopters fired on a Jordanian village today, killing three civilians and wounding five.
DETROIT, Jan. 6 -- Volkswagen, the German car maker, reported 569,292 retail vehicle sales in the United States in 1968, a 28 per cent increase from the 443,510 sales in 1967.

Dick Fosbury, once the backward boy over the bar, is In. He has arrived, with his Olympic gold medal, the celebrated "Fosbury Flop" and a style that, like those of Tiny Tim and Dustin Hoffman, has become natural, comfortable and popular.

When Ron Davis gets his 27 Ron Davis Dancers, aged 14 to 20, together for their three weekly classes at the Harlem branch of the Young Men's Christian Association on 135th Street, the eight girls start out with traditional dance exercises.
IF you work for the Competitive Capital Fund, never look back -- four other guys may be gaining on you.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 -- Superior Court Judge Herbert V. Walker held a lengthy pre-trial conference today with defense and prosecuting attorneys to lay procedural ground rules for the trial of Sirhan Bishara Sirhan.

Amid reports in publishing circles that The Saturday Evening Post may be discontinued, directors of the Curtis Publishing Company and the Saturday Evening Post Company are expected to meet this Friday to decide the future of the ailing biweekly.
PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The Premier of North Vietnam, Pham Van Dong, complained to a visiting French photographer recently that the United States negotiators in the Paris talks were being petty.
Electronic data processing equipment and auxiliary gear stole the spotlight yesterday at the trade show of the 58th annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Friends of Paul B. Zuber, a civil rights lawyer imprisoned for six days last week for contempt of court in connection with his failure to pay a six-year-old-libel judgment. announced plans today to raise the $5,700 needed to pay the judgment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Rev. Robert J. Henle, S.J., was named today to be the 45th president of Georgetown University, the oldest Roman Catholic institution of higher learning in the United States.

The United States Government dispatched an Air Force jet to Trinidad early this morning on a mercy mission to pick up the gravely ill Algerian Ambassador to the United Nations and bring him to a New York hospital.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Federal Judge John F. Kilkenny said today that three prospective jurors in a $2.5-million libel suit against Time, Inc., had notified him that the publishing company's investigators had got in touch with them.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- A civil rights suit charging 82 real estate companies, mortgage bankers, and savings and loan associations with swindling and exploiting Chicago Negroes in the sale of property was filed today in Federal court.
GANGTOK, Sikkim -- India faces an awkward problem over whether to recognize or try to stifle mounting aspirations in Sikkim for some of the benefits that are supposed to flow from full independence.

The pall of Dallas overhangs the courtroom in Los Angeles as the trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan for the murder of Senator Robert F. Kennedy begins today. Had not Lee Harvey Oswald been shot down in a Dallas jail after the murder of President John F. Kennedy, a circus atmosphere might have prevailed in the Sirhan trial.

The Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, Bridgeport, Conn., said yesterday it planned to proceed with plans to set up a holding company, despite objections from the American Water Works Company, which owns 8 per cent of Bridgeport Hydraulic's stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A spoilsport by the name of Arno Karlen writes in The Saturday Evening Post that the celebrated sexual revolution is mostly hot air, or more appropriately perhaps, hot print.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn is virtually assured election as Democratic minority leader of the Assembly tomorrow, top Democratic officials said today.
The Housing Authority began serving eviction warrants yesterday on 53 low-income tenants who had withheld rents since last summer to protest rising crime in their Bronx public-housing project.
YONKERS, Jan. 6 -- "I'll put 'em right up, eh, judge?" John Cashman asked the presiding judge, Charles Plumb, after the fourth race tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 6 -- Five young demonstrators against the draft disrupted inaugural ceremonies in Wisconsin's state Capitol today, delaying an inaugural address by Gov. Warren P. Knowles, who had just been sworn in for a third two-year term.

Lesley Gore, a petite 22-year-old, emerald-eyed strawberry blonde, is making her New York nightclub debut at the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel. She is trying to work her way up from the top, where she started six years ago.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 6 (AP) -- A daughter of Gallant Man, in foal to Bold Bidder, brought the top price of $60,000 today as Keeneland's horses of all ages sales completed the first of two sessions.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 6 -- Prisoners under sentence at the Nassau County Jail for misdemeanor offenses will be permitted to hold outside jobs under a work release program approved by the County Board of Supervisors today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) -- Lawyers for Adam Clayton Powell, back in Congress after nearly two years in exile, asked the Supreme Court today to declare unconstitutional his exclusion by the House of Representatives March 1, 1967.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7--In searching for a remedy to the ever-increasing costs of intercollegiate athletics, many members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association have found that scholarships to student-athletes and recruiting expenses are the major areas where costs can be cut.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7--Justice Byron R. White received the National Collegiate Athletic Association's annual Teddy Award today. The Mill Factors Corporation and James Talcott Factors, a division of James Talcott, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement in principle under which Talcott would purchase the factoring portfolio of Mill Factors for a cash price at face value, plus a premium to be agreed upon later.

J., Jan. 9 -- Ernest Hemingway's unpublished manuscripts contain little that would add to his literary luster, Carlos Baker, his official biographer and a long-time Hemingway scholar, said yesterday in an interview evaluating for the first time the novellas, short stories and poems left by the Nobel Prize writer at his death in 1961.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The first legal test of the Government's shield of secrecy surrounding the autopsy photographs of President Kennedy has begun in the courts here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- President Johnson pinned the Distinguished Service Medal today on Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and praised him as "a soldier for every season." General Wheeler has been chairman since the middle of 1964.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 10 -- Patrick Lalor of the Philadephia Skating Club and Humane Society took a slim lead in figures over Jim Stuart, who represents the Skating Club of New York, in the men's class of the Eastern figure skating championships at the Skating Club of Wilmington today. Gordon McKellen Jr. of Lake Placid, N. Y., was third. Gary Jones of Syracuse held fourth place.
GLENDALE, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Casey Stengel was successfully operater on tonight at the Memorial Hospital for what the hospital termed the closing of a "perforated peptic ulser."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- President Johnson said today Richard M. Nixon would inherit an army of career Government employes "able and anxious to help him" when he assumes the Presidency Jan. 20.

Tickets will go on sale at noon tomorrow at the box offixe for the Metropolitan Opera's 21st week. During the week, Theo Adam, the German bass, will make his Metropolitan debut as Hans Sachs in Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" and Montserrat Caballe will sing Liu in Puccini's "Turandot" for the first time at the Metropolitan.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -- Disturbed onlookers ask: Why has San Francisco State College, with seven presidents in the last 10 years, become the focal point of so much unrest and violence -- a leading target of militants?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Engineers at the Langley Research Center, Hampton, Va., have developed jet shoes to enable astronauts to move about in space. The wearer of the equipment operates a valve with his\ toes, releasing gas through a nozzle under the sole.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 10 -- Like so many Dutchmen of the professional classes, the man in the Oesterbar had a fine B.B.C. accent and ironic pride in his country.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The most far-reaching rules change in the jumper division of horse shows was overwhelmingly approved today by the delegates to the American Horse Shows Association convention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, who yesterday quit the prestigious Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today took a back seat on a secondary investigative panel, which most members shun.

The Office of Collective Bargaining ruled yesterday that more than 50 demands submitted by a social workers' union to the city were not negotiable, but that 13 other demands the city did not want to discuss were negotiable.
Mother Earth, a seven-member rock band appearing through tonight at The Scene, hits hard with a classic rock punch but also -- influenced by the smooth and lifting sound of gospel music -- soothes.
The seventh annual Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition for conductors will begin at Carnegie Hall on Monday.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- Superior Court Judge Herbert V. Walker has denied a motion by attorneys for Sirhan Bishara Sirhan to further delay his trial.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Israel has acquired a "threshold capability" to become a nuclear power, but so far as United States officials know she has not yet produced a nuclear weapon.

TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- A state highway official told a legislative investigating committee today that a projected Federal interstate highway would pass through property jointly owned by State Senator Sido L. Ridolfi and a reputed "top rackets figure in Trenton."

MONTREAL, Jan. 10 -- The International Civil Aviation Organization, a specialized United Nations agency with headquarters here, has called an "extraordinary session" of its 27-member council to deal with the Israeli raid on the Beirut airport.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 10 -- The Navy announced today that the court of inquiry into the capture of the intelligence ship Pueblo would start next Thursday in an amphitheater on the sprawling Naval Amphibious Base across San Diego Bay in Coronado.
Question: How can a state budget that contains a 5 per cent cutback in projected spending be $900-million larger than the previous year's budget, which had no cutback?

MENTION the over-the counter market and thoughts turn to hot new issues and unseasoned companies. But this is a fallacy, as every investor in bank and insurance stocks -- the bulk of which are still traded over-the-counter -- knows.

SANA, Yemen, Jan. 7--The republican regime of this impoverished little country on the Red Sea believes that it has reduced its bitter civil war with the royalists to manageable proportions. If so, it is at least partly because the hero of the other side is settled comfortably here in the republican capital, having changed his mind about where his loyalties lay.
The dismissal of Columbia University's board of trustees was requested yesterday by 12 Columbia students of conservative leanings in a suit filed in State Supreme Court.

A helicopter operated by radio station WOR as a traffic spotter crashed into the roof of a garden apartment in Queens yesterday evening, killing its pilot, Frank McDermott, and touching off a raging fire.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 10 -- Into a dark and chilly nightclub, its bandstand muffled and bare, comes Weeb Ewbank, a stumpy man with a limp. This is his morning news conference in a resort motel in Fort Lauderdale. There is really nothing he wants to tell the world and so he is protective and careful, acting like the bank dick he resembles.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 10 (UPI) -- The University of Wisconsin regents, angered by use of obscene words in the student newspaper, notified The Daily Cardinal today it must move its business office off the campus or pay rent.

Directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company elected yesterday Donald M. Graham chairman and chief executive officer, succeeding David M. Kennedy, who has been nominated as Secretary of the Treasury in th-e Nixon Administration.

President Johnson's General Advisory Committee for Foreign Assistance Programs has issued a report sharply contradicting members of Congress and others who have recommended that President-elect Nixon further cut and fragment foreign aid.

The Coburn Corporation of America, the nation's 40th largest finance company, announced yesterday that it would discontinue its $50-million retail installment finance business. The announcement came as the Rockville Centre, L. I., company reported a loss of $2.5-million for the nine months ended Nov. 30, 1968, including an extraordinary loss of $3.1-million.
The stock market extended its technical rally of Thursday into yesterday's morning session but then ran out of steam to close slightly lower.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- A major expansion of the Soviet Union's fleet of weather-reporting and other research vessels has been made public. Some United States officials believe these vessels, equipped with variety of radio antennas, radar and other electronic devices are also being used to gather intelligence.
The fatal shooting of two men on Dec. 22, which appeared at first to have involved a duel, was described yesterday by Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts as "a gangland-type execution."

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has established a new policy making retirement mandatory for pastors at the age of 75 and optional at 70.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The State Department said today that one crew member was killed and three were rescued after their helicopter was shot down by Cambodian antiaircraft guns near the Cambodia -- South Vietnam border Jan. 3. No further details were available.

The Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society will hold a benefit fashion luncheon Tuesday, Jan. 21, at the New York Hilton to stimulate public interest in the society's Thrift Shop. Guests are urged to bring rummage for sale at the store, which is at 1237 Third Avenue, near 71st Street.

Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, has turned down an offer to become Under Secretary of Transportation despite the personal entreaties of President-elect Richard M. Nixon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -- Gump's, a 108-year-old San Francisco store stocking a wide variety of arts and crafts from around the world, is being sold to Crowell Collier and MacMillan, Inc.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- Funeral services were held today for Jane Britton, a 22-year-old Harvard graduate student who was bludgeoned to death Tuesday, as the Cambridge police pressed their investigation of the murder.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 10 -- A suburban school district in a biracial residential area of Westchester County has resolved to make Jan. 15 a school holiday in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
ROME, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- Traffic jams blocked roads in and out of Rome today as thousands of people used private cars when bus and streetcar workers went on strike for the second time in 18 days.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Mrs. Margaret Court, seeking her sixth Victorian tennis championship, advanced to the final today by defeating her fellow Australian, Kerry Melville, 6-2, 6-2.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- Charlie Sifford, aided by medication in his battle with the flu and playing a sound game, Scored a par-71 for a 36-hole aggregate of 134 today over the Rancho Park Municipal course to lead the $100,000 Los Angeles open by two strokes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Haleakala National Park on Hawaii's island of Maui gained 4,300 acres today through gifts from Laurance S. Rockefeller of New York and the Nature Conservancy.

EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK, Fla. -- In the pleasant heat of the subtropical winter the Florida Everglades are drowsy and contented. Out in the saw grass shallows, which look like vast meadows anhingas are nesting. They sit on nests that look like baskets of sticks, or they tend their young in the wooded hammocks where wild plum, Florida holly and gumbo-limbo trees grow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- The Vietcong ambushed a United States patrol and opened mortar attacks on a number of towns and military bases before dawn today.
