FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 10 -- In a disciplinary ritual reminiscent of a boarding school or a penitentiary, the New York Jets and the Baltimore Colts will be confined to their hotel rooms at 11 P.M. on the eve of their Super Bowl confrontation Sunday in Miami.
A break in the 21-day waterfront strike appeared imminent yesterday, and Federal mediators called a full-scale meeting of bargaining committees for tomorrow morning.

The appointment of John H. Long as president of the United States Steel Corporation's American bridge division, effective Jan. 15 was announced yesterday. He will succeed J. Donald Rollins, who has been appointed president of United States Steel's new subsidiary, USA Engineers and Consultants, Inc.

IN an almost offhand way, the Metropolitan Museum has produced an exhibition of 100 drawings, prints and illustrated books to represent as they put it, "several thousand" acquired by gift, bequest and purchase during 1968.

The advisory council of the City University's SEEK program yesterday took over investigation of the dispute between some participants and the director of the project at Queens College, and its director, Joseph P. Mulholland.

Secretary of Labor-designate George P. Shultz introduced yesterday what will be his high command at the Department of Labor. The group has a liberal cast, is made up mostly of Democrats and includes the first major Negro appointment in the Nixon Administration.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 10 -- President Chung Hee Park said today that he desired to see an Asian collective security alliance formed to cope with the threat of Communist China and other Asian Communist nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Administration proposed today that airlines provide plastic bags for passengers to put over their heads to protect them from smoke and fire long enough to escape from a fire in a crash.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- North Vietnam's delegation to the Paris peace talks voiced elation today over the recognition of the Hanoi Government by Sweden and said it was a "step in the right direction" that other Western nations would take soon.

An executive producer for the Public Broadcast Laboratory experimental series was dismissed Thursday night in a disagreement over last Sunday night's program on defense spending, it became known yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- Leaders of Italian Jewish communities published today a list of 18 incidents of what they termed anti-Semitism in Italy since May, 1967. The leaders declined to speculate whether these were the work of isolated cranks or part of a directed campaign.

YONKERS, Jan. 10 -- The second of four rounds in the $250,000 Snowball Pacing Series will be held at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night with the focus centered on the activities of Orbiter N., the 10-year-old New Zealand-bred gelding.

Jho Archer, a Haitian dancer turned singer who is attempting to mix Haitian voodoo music with jazz, appeared last night at Philharmonic Hall. Mr. Archer, whose career as a singer has developed in Paris, was presented by the cultural attache of the French Embassy in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Justice Department claimed today that the major automobile companies had conspired for more than a decade to delay the development and use of devices to control air pollution from automobiles.

Arthur Krock, former columnist and Washington bureau chief of The New York Times, will be interviewed by Eric Sevareid on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network tomorrow at 6 P.M. Channel 2 here, however, will carry the telecast at 11:30 P.M. because of a conflict with "1968, The Correspondents Report," which runs from 5 to 6:30 P.M.
The nation's machine-tool builders came close to setting records in the year just ended, it was reported yesterday by Donald H. McIver, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Senator Stuart Symington accused South Vietnam today of deliberately stalling at the Paris talks and said the United States should set a firm date for starting discussions with the North Vietnamese, "with or without the South Vietnamese."

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Prime Minister Wilson, in a reply to his critics in the Commonwealth, today strongly defended British policy on Rhodesia and denounced the use of force there as both undesirable and impracticable.

Dr. Boris Schwarz characterized Roslavetz as both an experimental composer and a staunch Marxist who believed that the proletariat was fully capable of digesting the most advanced contemporary music.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- United States and North Vietnamese negotiators met this afternoon for the first time in 10 days in a futile effort to break the procedural impasse that has been delaying broadened Vietnam talks here.

THE recent 18-man International round robin at Mallorca, Spain, which included ten grandmasters, was won by Viktor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union, 14-3, without an outright loss. Tied for second and third were Bent Larsen of Denmark and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the challenger for the title, each with 13-4.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan 12 -- After playing through a driving rain here Friday and well into the dark of night Saturday, the New York-Palm Beach Croquet Tournament suddenly up and postponed this afternoon's final matches until tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that he had received an "extremely large" amount of mail opposing the nomination of Walter J. Hickel as Secretary of the Interior in the Nixon Administration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Johnson has decided to propose that the 10 per cent income tax surcharge be extended in full beyond its expiration date of June 30, Administration sources said today.

A spokesman for union teachers at the Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn called yesterday for the transfer of 1,100 Negro students out of the school following student disorders and alleged assaults on teachers in the last two weeks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 -- A new step in search of peace on the unhappy campus of San Francisco State College was taken today while pickets paraded in a heavy rain.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13 -- After deciding that no further expansion would take place for at least a year, the National Basketball Association cleared the decks today for its 19th annual East - West All - Star basketball game tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Plans for the creation of Soul City, N. C., a "new town" of 18,000 built, owned and occupied by Negroes, were announced today by Floyd B. McKissick, former head of the Congress of Racial Equality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Scientists tracing the origins of five major developments in technology found that the indispensible basic research was already 90 per cent complete before anyone conceived of the development itself.

Most track coaches in the metropolitan area are pointing toward tomorrow's Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior meet but Jim McHugh of Manhattan College admits his "big objective" is three days further away.

The City Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that the advertising and broadcasting industries continued to discriminate against members of minority groups in employment practices and "imagemaking," but found "a slight degree of progress" since its first hearings on the subject last March.

To the Editor: No area represents such a continuing threat to world peace as does Southwest Asia. From the riots of Pakistani students who object to Ayub Khan's conciliatory stance toward India, to Israeli attacks on a U.S. ship and on the Beirut airport, all parties have given ample evidence of the deep reservoir of pride, hatred, and combativeness that underlies the entire region.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Richard B. Ogilvie today became the 35th Governor of Illinois.

A new service, yoking the genius of the telephone company to the genius of living poets, now makes it possible for anyone with access to a dial to listen to ready-to-roll verse at any hour of the day or night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Two Democrats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee warned the incoming Nixon Administration today against resuming the cold war, "or even a cool war," because of the Soviet Union's hardened policies in Eastern Europe.
MIAMI, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- A shotgun - wielding passenger who demanded to be taken to Cuba was foiled early today when a Delta Air Lines pilot completed his Detroit-to-Miami flight instead.
TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed into law today a measure opening a multibillion - dollar urban frontier on 18,000 vacant acres across the Hudson River from Manhattan.

MOSCOW, Jan. 13 -- The Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan has been denounced by the Soviet Union's Communist party leadership for corruption, agricultural failures, falsified reports and toleration of nationalism and Moslem customs such as child marriages.

NAMES on beauty salon facades are usually masculine -- Kenneth or Norbert, Michel Kazan or Monsieur Marc. But behind the scenes, there is often an efficient woman hairdresser, hiding her light behind the more glittering name of her employer.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- Starting a week-long round of farewell appearances here, W. Averell Harriman stressed today that United States objectives in Vietnam were limited.
Mayor Lindsay personally doused the fires "once and for all and for good" yesterday in what he termed "one of the worst" air pollution offenders in the city.
Renewed speculative demand for shares of companies recently mentioned as merger prospects led to widespread gains on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Negotiators for The Associated Press and the striking Wire Service Guild met today in their first joint session since the strike started last Thursday, but no progress toward a settlement was reported.

Dr. David B. Truman, vice president and provost of Columbia University, who was once considered to be in line for the university's presidency, was appointed president of Mount Holyoke College yesterday.

Shouting and jeering Puerto Rican militants seeking the appointment of Luis Fuentes, the ousted Ocean Hill-Brownsville principal, as superintendent of District 1 on the Lower East Side, forced cancellation of the local school board's monthly meeting last night.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 13 -- Pollution of the environment by DDT has reached the level of "great worldwide damage," a New York scientist testified today.

The City University is considering a plan to establish four-year "professional" programs at its two-year community colleges, primarily to help meet "severe manpower shortages" here in such fields as teaching, nursing, business and public service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- For lovers of the underdog -- the types who used to root against the New York Yankees on general principle and who voted for Harry Truman not least because he put up such an admirable fight against the odds -- this is one of those rare days of glowing satisfaction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives told the Supreme Court today that there was no longer any controversy between the House and Representative Adam Clayton Powell.
The stock market continued under pressure yesterday as declines outpaced advances by a three-to-one ratio throughout the session and popular averages showed modest losses.
Prices of orange-juice futures took a tumble yesterday under the impact of a rush to sell largely by speculators.

HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- A quarter of a million cheering persons showered the Apollo 8 astronauts, Col. Frank Borman, Capt. James A. Lovell Jr., and Lieut. Col. William Anders with confetti and Confederate money today in the biggest parade in Houston's history.

An etymologist might well find the dispute over the nomination of Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska to be Secretary of the Interior rather confusing. Noting that the words "conservative" and "conservation" have the same Latin root, he would assume that a conservative politician like Mr. Hickel would naturally sympathize with the conservation of natural resources.

The Federal aid that is being given directly to local hospitals for community health centers because of "apparent mismanagement" in the city's Human Resources Administration supports the training of medical technicians and the development of family-care centers in underprivileged neighborhoods.

REVERE, Mass., Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The police early today recovered $7-million in processed checks, possibly several million dollars of which were negotiable, which had been hijackd from a panel bank truck in downtown Boston.

Saying that "it's a shame to subject helpless riders to arrest and harassment," a Queens Criminal Court judge yesterday dismissed charges against three young women and a young man who refused to show their tickets to a Long Island Rail Road conductor.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 -- A Scandinavian Airlines System jet carrying 45 persons crashed into the Pacific Ocean eight miles west of here late this afternoon.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third largest banking institution, reported yesterday that earnings climbed 13.3 per cent to a record $119.5-million during 1968.

MIAMI, Jan. 13 -- Norm Van Brocklin, a noted wisecracker, who was a great quarterback himself, delivered an opinion when asked about Joe Namath a few days before the Super Bowl game. You should understand that Van Brocklin, now the coach of the Atlanta Falcons, is an establishment man who believes in the National Football League and the status quo of 1950-60, his great decade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- An effort to force Electoral College reform through court action failed today as the Supreme Court held that the Constitution does not prohibit the present system of electing Presidents and Vice Presidents.

The bond market barely moved off dead center in trading yesterday as the investment banking community awaited the offering today of several new issues whose reception will reflect the current appetite of investors for fixed-income securities.

Negotiators for the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association continued joint talks yesterday to solve "minor" problems still balking an agreement that would end the 24-day-old waterfront strike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to examine a challenge by two broadcasting networks to Government regulation of "personal attacks" and "political editorials" voiced over the air.

To the Editor The decision by a group of Reform Democratic Assemblymen, mainly from Manhattan, to cast its votes for Stanley Steingut as minority leader of the Assembly marked a sad day for residents of Brooklyn.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- The impression here is that President de Gaulle misjudged the temper of his country and inadvertently provoked a domestic crisis when he imposed an arms embargo on Israel last week and then blamed "Israeli influences" for the criticism that swept the French press.
What does it feel like to be a patient in a mental hospital?

Judson Church offered an unusual dance concert last night with a program by the Gruppe Motion Berlin, a modern-dance group founded in 1962. Its three German founders, Brigitta Herrmann, Manfred Fischbeck and Hellmut Fricke-Gottschild, who have reformed the company in Philadelphia since the summer to include four American members, offered a display of strength, discipline and technique seen only in major American troupes and not consistently in them.

Russian exiles and about 200 of their American friends went to the St. Regis-Sheraton last night to get themselves a bit of luck at midnight by touching a white rooster. The event, Le Bal Blanc, ushered in the Old Russian New Year and raised money for the American Russian Aid Association.
About 15 demonstrators ransacked an administrative office at Queens College yesterday, ripping out telephones, tearing down pictures and dumping furniture on the street.

To the Editor: The New Jersey firearms' control law may be constitutional, but it certainly is useless. According to the F.B.I. Uniform Crime Report, during the past year New Jersey experienced an increase in crimes of all kinds. This is roughly the period of time in which the new gun law has been in effect.
Benton Bowles has just jointed the Lorillard Corporation's agency line-up and the membership cards are Kent cigarettes ($14-million in billings) and Century 100s ($2-million).

President-elect Richard M. Nixon, in a meeting yesterday with six Negro leaders, was reported to have pledged that he would surpass the efforts of his predecessors to improve the economic and social condition of Negroes.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Not the least of the Royal Court Theater's achievements has been to restore naturalistic drama to something like the self-respect it had in the nineties. The latest example of this policy is "Life Price," a new play directed by Peter Gill, who single-handedly last year restored D. H. Lawrence to favor as a playwright.
Roy Wilkins, a moderate civil rights leader, voiced strong opposition yesterday to demands by Negro students for all-black studies departments on college campuses.

Norton Simon, Inc., a consumer-oriented company operating in food, beverages, publishing, printing and packaging, registered a 36 per cent increase in earnings for the six months ended Dec. 31 over the year-earlier period, William E. McKenna, chairman reported yesterday.
YONKERS, Jan. 13 -- Miss Prim Trim scored her second straight victory of the year tonight at Yonkers Raceway, winning in 2:06 2/5.

The following are the texts of statements by Mayor Lindsay and Administrator Mitchell I. Ginsberg on the Human Resources Administration, a letter from J. Terrell Whitsitt, Regional Manpower Administrator, to the Mayor on the Neighborhood Youth Corps program, and a report on the city programs by the Department of Labor:

To the Editor: Your editorial of Jan. 9 entitled "Liberated Hospital" unfortunately failed to give your readers a complete enough summary to permit them to make a fair judgment. While you decry strikes by hospital workers, you incorrectly placed the blame for the recent strike at Wyckoff Heights Hospital on the workers.
THE Rangers, nine points out of first place and only one point from last, are the most disappointing of the six National Hockey League East Division clubs this season.
Only one week from the transition of power to the Nixon Administration, Hubert H. Humphrey offered some poignant reflections yesterday on the "awkward office" of the Vice-Presidency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- An Assistant Secretary of Commerce called today for "vigorous, across - the - board Government action" to reach an exporting target of $50-billion by 1973.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Homer Rice, head football coach at the University of Cincinnati, was named athletic director at the University of North Carolina today.
PANAMA, Jan. 13 -- Copies of the Sunday issue of The New York Times and of today's Miami Herald were barred from distribution in aPnama today by the military Government.
ADEN, South Yemen, Jan. 13 -- The Sana radio announced last night that the American-built road linking Sana and its twin capital of Taiz in the south of Yemen had been opened to civilian traffic.
Denny McLain of the Detroit Tigers predicted yesterday that spring would come late this year because of the pension dispute between the club owners and the 600 baseball player's in the major leagues.

IT has taken a lot of time and a special Ford Foundation grant to bring Merce Cunningham and his company to the bright lights and loud noise of Broadway. And once here it must be admitted that their lights are brighter and noise louder than any of the competition.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- The French police announced today the arrest of a fourth Breton nationalist priest and the discovery of about 65 pounds of explosive under the floor of a classroom in a parochial school.
GENEVA, Jan. 13 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it would have to consider ending its relief work in Nigeria should it continue to be prevented from aiding Biafra.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that the Nixon Administration would face an irreconcilably incoming divided nation if it did not enforce the nation's civil rights laws.

MILAN, Italy, Jan. 7 -- A handful of students have taken over an empty hotel in the heart of Milan, hoping to turn it into the headquarters of a "practical" rebellion in behalf of disadvantaged students specifically and "the rights of man" in general.

CHIMPANZEES and children have a great deal in common: No two are alike; both bite when they are teething; have temper tantrums when they are frustrated; and require a firm but kindly hand. So says Dave Pitts, a 33-year-old skater who is currently appearing here in his seventh season with the "Ice Capades" along with Spanky Jr., a 5-year-old chimp he has trained to perform on skates, and Spanky's understudy, Marvin.
Federal arms-control agents posing as black-market buyers seized a large quantity of stolen United States Army weapons and ammunition in suburban New Jersey last night.
BONN, Jan. 13 -- Eugen Gerstenmaier, President of the West German Parliament, held an hour-long news conference today to reply to accusations about foreign policy and his political past.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 13 UPI) -- The National Baseball Congress praised Leroy (Satchel) Paige today for his ageless contribution to the game and offered the recently signed Atlanta Braves hurler $1,000 to throw out the first pitch at its 100th national championships.
Metals again led the inflationary parade yesterday, with the aluminum price increase initiated over the weekend taking hold throughout the industry and spreading among mill products.

There were just about as many people involved in the arrangements for last night's party as there were guests. It wasn't considered at all unusual. The guests of honor were Lyndon Baines and Lady Bird Johnson.
WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 13 -- Negotiations between the Brandeis University administration and 65 Negro students barricaded in the communications center remained in a stalemate today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 13 -Both pro-Nasser and right-wing newspapers here are becoming increasingly critical of the Soviet proposals for a Middle East settlement.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 13 -- This city's firemen, represented by Local 777 of the Internation Association of Firefighters, and Local 9 of the Firemen's Mutual Benevolent Association, today rejected a proposal by Mayor Thomas G. Dunn that they voluntarily assume some police functions.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- Near car sales ran at a relatively slow pace in early January despite sales gains reported today by two manufacturers.

"Musical chairs" is a frivolous activity accessible to all. But "musical creatures," to coin a game, is a diversion reserved for masters of choreography. It is a game that no one plays better than George Balanchine. Sunday night at the State Theater, the New York City Ballet crackingly presented his "variations" for the first time this season, demonstrating the various activities and possibilities that can co-exist with any musical score.

NEWARK, Jan. 13 -- Representatives of Newark's black community today pledged their support to 20 Roman Catholic priests who last week accused Archbishop Thomas A. Boland of having a "white racist attitude" towards Negroes.

MIAMI, Jan. 13 -- Joe Namath talks big. He also acts big. It was the wizardry of this quarterbacking marvel that lighted the afterburners of the New York Jets yesterday and sent them rocketing to unexpected heights in a Super Bowl upset of historic proportions. The Jets beat the supposedly invincible Baltimore Colts, 16-7, and thereby became the first American Football League team to humble the proud and condescending National League in world championship action.

MADRID, Jan. 12 -- Don Juan of Bourbon, the Pretender to the Spanish throne, said today that he disagreed with a recent statement by his son, Prince Juan Carlos, declaring, in effect, his willingness to supercede his father.
One corporate take-over fight ended yesterday and two others accelerated.

President Johnson said last night that "what really matters is not the ultimate judgment that historians will pass" on his Administration "but whether there was a change for the better in the way our people live."

THE Greater New York Bridge Association's double knockout team championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy has entered the fourth round, with seven undefeated teams and 25 once-defeated teams surviving from an original entry of 64 teams.
The promotion of Moore Gates Jr., Robert R. Maller and Lloyd W. Pedersen as senior vice presidents of the United States Trust Company of New York was announced yesterday.

THIS is black art and difficult fiction -- as difficult to read as to review. "I wanted," says Nicholas Mosley, "to write you something impossible, like a staircase climbing a spiral to come out where it started. . . . [It] cannot exist in three dimensions but can be drawn in two; by cutting out one dimension a fourth is created.
The world's most recent heart transplant recipient died yesterday a week after he underwent the operation. The death reduced the survivors of 109 transplants so far to 38 -- little more than a third.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 13 -- Common Market finance ministers stepped up their efforts today to harmonize tax rates and eliminate nuisance taxes paid by tourists traveling from one member state to another.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court rejected without comment today appeals by Vito Genovese, reputed leader of the Cosa Nostra, and Robert M. Shelton, Imperial Wizard of the largest Ku Klux Klan organization in the country.
The nation's furniture business is displaying many signs of success -- and some of the problems that come with it.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 13 Norman M. Thomas left the bulk of his estate, estimated to be worth $100,000 to $150,000, to his family and close friends.
CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 13 -- The Navy announced today that the court of inquiry into the capture of the intelligence ship Pueblo would be delayed from Thursday until Monday.
NOW that life insurance companies are entering the mutual fund business by the score, successful mutual fund management companies are bringing fancy prices indeed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 13 -- A special Harvard faculty committee urged the university today to revise its housing, employment, educational and admissions policies to improve relations with the communities surrounding the school.
The Norwegian freighter Forra left last night, carrying more than 550 tons of foods collected in the New York area for the Biafrans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the New York State rules that require welfare clients to repay their benefits if they later inherit real estate or receive insurance benefits or personal-injury awards.
MIAMI, Jan. 13 -- The Cunard Line cruise ship Carmania, with 471 passengers on hoard, was fast aground today on San Salvador Island in the Bahamas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- President Johnson acted today to head off a railroad strike by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers against nearly every major railroad in the country.

But even more to the point is Mr. Wilkins's attempt to stem the spineless retreat by many white administrators and faculty members under separatist pressure from a radical and immature minority among Negro undergraduates.
DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- The Ford Motor Company reported today that its dealers sold 51,912 United States-made cars in the period Jan. 1-10, down 7 per cent from the 55,879 total a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has recommended to Congress that some important out-of-hospital drugs for elderly patients be paid for under Medicare.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- The problem of how to keep farmers on the land has plagued the Soviet Union increasingly in recent years.
Parishioners in the Newark Archdiocese are being asked to drop notes of protest instead of money into church collection baskets on Sunday.
LIMA, Ohio (AP) -- Thousands of residents began returning to their homes tonight in a 110-block area they evacuated when oil from a broken pipeline set off fires and explosions last night.

The heroic escape of a large force of young Cubans through a cordon of crack Russian- trained troops to sanctuary in the United States naval base in Guantanamo holds several lessons for us. [Editorial, Jan. 13.]

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Federal mediators held an evening session with both sides today in an attempt to settle the six-day strike by the Wire Service Guild against The Associated Press. No progress was reported.
NEWARK, Jan. 14 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the world's largest insurance organization, announced today the election of Donald S. MacNaughton as president, effective April 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- Karel Kral, a correspondent of the Czechoslovak press agency C.T.K., who was recalled to Prague after having made remarks to a New York audience that offended his country's Government, has decided to remain in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon's Task Force on Urban Affairs has recommended a system of revenue sharing with the states similar to one proposed four years ago to the Johnson Administration.
The stock market in London moved to its highest level in five weeks yesterday in moderate trading.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Democratic minority in the Assembly almost staged its first revolt of the legislative session against today the Republican majority today.
Vice President Humphrey has struck a sharp blow against the filibuster, but a majority of the Senate must now back him up if it is to have lasting effect.
The nation's major Jewish organizations are promoting protests across the country against France's embargo on military equipment and spare parts for Israel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The nation's total output of goods and services, the gross national product, rose by $16.8-billion in the final quarter of 1968, the Commerce Department reported today.

The battle for leadership of the Negro civil rights movement is going into another critical phase. The Negro moderates are beginning to fight back against the Negro militants and the controversy again is agitating several university campuses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- With American officials in the midst of transition to a new administration, another changing of the guard in this city is taking place at the British Embassy.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 14 -- The Government warned the newspapers of Kenya today to cease "highlighting and sometimes exaggerating" its program to break the grip of Indians on trade lest the press finds itself next to be purged of its non-African elements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A California Congressman today challenged the reliability of official American claims that 73 per cent of the South Vietnamese people are living under Government control.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Democratic National Committee today licked its wounds, made confession of error and after electing a new chairman resolved to repair its organization, its treasury and its shattered national constituency.
Preliminary work on refloating the stranded Cunard Line cruise ship Carmania is scheduled to begin at San Salvador Island in the Bahamas at daybreak today.

NAPA, Calif., Jan. 14 -- The impact of Charlie Sifford's victory in the $100,000 Los Angeles open is being measured along the pro circuit. Already the $20,000 Sifford won Sunday has proved encouraging to the little band of Negro professionals on tour.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- For the first time in the history of Soviet space exploration, excerpts from a video tape film of the launching were shown promptly on Soviet television.

RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 14 -- Four men were sentenced to death here today for plotting to assassinate King Hassan II five years ago when Morocco and neighboring Algeria were involved in an armed conflict on their frontier.

HOUSTON, Jan. 14 -- The principal objective of the housing policies of the Nixon Administration will be production of dwelling units, a leader who will be a key figure on the Republican side in shaping Congressional action said here today.

LAKE PLEASANT N. Y., Jan. 14 -- The elderly man chuckled several times as he read a newspaper account of how Governor Rockefeller had ordered a special investigation into the fiscal affairs of the town of Arietta, nestled in the snow-covered Adirondack Mountains.
LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- West European legislators called today for a meeting of heads of government to pave the way for a politically united Europe.
The teachers' union dissociated itself yesterday from a demand of its chapter chairman at the Franklin K. Lane High School for the transfer of 1,100 Negro students.

YONKERS, Jan. 14 -- Westchester County officials and the local police arrested 14 persons and seized narcotics valued at $480,000 during early morning raids today on three apartments. They said that the apartments were the center of the largest known illicit narcotics operation in Westchester.

A MINOR miracle was accomplished by Gunnar Johansen last night in Philharmonic Hall. The Danish-born pianist, for many years artist-in-residence at the University of Wisconsin, stepped in at the last minute and played the Beethoven Concerto in D with the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy. He replaced the indisposed Peter Serkin.
Hayden, Stone, Inc., one of the nation's largest and most widely known brokerage concerns, has set aside $16-million for possible losses due to operational problems.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Jan. 15 -- The Soviet Union launched today a three-man spaceship, which joined a one-man craft launched into earth orbit yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 15 -- Top United States military officials in South Vietnam were reported today to be opposed to any withdrawal of American forces from the country before July.
The duo-recital given by Michael Haran, cellist, and Nathan Brand, pianist, last night in Carnegie Recital Hall was an excellent example of two young artists playing as one unit.

Wall Street is watching Washington more closely than usual these days and the stock market evidently liked what it saw yesterday. After some hesitation in pre-noon trading, prices moved steadily higher during the afternoon.

Plans for a merger of National Equipment Rental, Ltd., with American Export Industries, Inc., through an exchange of American Export stock valued at about $53.7-million were announced yesterday by American Export.

PARIS, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- A French-born Canadian and four priests were among 13 persons charged here today in connection with the terrorist activities of an underground nationalist network in Brittany.

KILVENMANI, India, Jan. 12 -- On a long pole at the center of this desolate hamlet, a torn and faded red flag fluttered in the evening breeze.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday in moderate trading.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- The American Jewish Committee announced here today that it had received word privately from Paris this morning that "at least four Iraqi Jews have been secretly condemned to death" in Baghdad for espionage and "may be facing execution."

The multibillion-dollar assignment to build the supersonic Navy fighter that will replace the abandoned F-111B fleet-defense plane was awarded yesterday to the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation.
The Class A common shares of The New York Times Company were admitted yesterday to listing and trading on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- To reflect his many moods in this final week, Lyndon Baines Johnson's farewell address might have been a catalogue of successes and satisfactions or an accounting of his accumulated resentments.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The venerable Punch has at last received a proposal, at the age of 127. The weekly magazine, thought of abroad as typifying the British sense of humor, is the target of what was described tonight as a friendly take-over bid.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Johnson Administration is about to hand down to the incoming Nixon Administration another conservation legacy.

Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city Human Resources Administrator, denied yesterday a New York Times report that "apparent mismanagement" in the antipoverty program was the reason three local health centers were receiving funds directly from Washington instead of through his agency.
COPENHAGEN, Jan. 14 -- The first-draft plans for an economic integration of Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden into a "Nordic Economic Union" were published today by the four Governments.
Doctors at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx, one of the city's largest municipal hospitals, urged pediatric patients yesterday not to pay their bills as a protest against the costs of health care.

The Columbia Broadcasting System replied yesterday to charges by Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, that "Black Heritage," a locally produced series, is biased and "hopelessly flawed."
Following are quotations from previous State of the Union Messages:

Congress has a "traditional responsibility," Senator Fulbright has written, "to serve as a forum of diverse opinions and as a channel of communication between the American people and their Government. The discharge of these functions is not merely a prerogative of the Congress; it is a constitutional obligation, for the neglect of which the Congress can and should be called to public account."

More than 300 members of the New York Civil Liberties Union have resigned to protest a report it issued criticizing the United Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school dispute.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that he protested when he heard that talks were scheduled between striking teachers and members of the State College Board of Trustees. The meeting was canceled after the Governor's call to the chairman of the trustees.

WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 14 -- As the stalemate continued today between Brandeis University and 65 Negro students barricaded in the communications center, it appeared that the center more and more was being isolated from the mainstream of the community.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Melvin R. Laird, the incoming Secretary of Defense, said today that it would be next summer or fall before the Nixon Administration would be willing to enter into talks with the Soviet Union on control of the nuclear arms race.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13 -- "Oscar is the greatest," said Gene Shue, the winning coach, his face wreathed in a huge smile, as he commented on what he considered the vital factor in the East's victory over the West tonight in the N.B.A. All-Star game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate Republican leader, confirmed today that he had interceded with President Johnson to save the life of the seldom-active Subversive Activities Control Board.
Norman J. Lewis, vice president of the Pace Company, advocated yesterday the establishment of a cabinet-level post to handle the nation's over-all petroleum interests.
The Rev. Dr. Robert A. Edgar, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, 64th Street and Park Avenue, was installed yesterday as moderator of the Presbytery of New York City for 1969.
The current battle in New York's long-running waterfront dispute was settled last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Vice President Humphrey set the stage today for a showdown with supporters of the Senate's filibuster system by giving its opponents a new parliamentary weapon.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Bill Flett scored two goals tonight as the Los Angeles Kings snapped a seven-game winless streak with a 3-1 victory over the New York Rangers.

MANCHESTER, England, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- Sir Matt Busby, who built a new Manchester United soccer team after several players were killed in a plane crash in 1958, quit as coach today, but agreed to stay on as general manager.
ROME, Jan. 14 -- The Vatican issued two new warnings today, one by Pope Paul VI himself, against modern trends that undermine elements of Roman Catholic doctrine or that contest papal authority.
NEWARK, Jan. 14 -- Three New Jersey National Guard sergeants were formally charged here today with a "huge" black-market weapons operation, following a Monday night raid by Federal and state agents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon named Mrs. Lucy Alexander Winchester of Lexington, Ky., today as White House social secretary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The Department of Defense conceded today that the Vietnam War may be having a larger adverse impact on the United States balance-of-payments problem than had previously been estimated, but not as much as some civilian estimates.
The city's public and parochial schools will memorialize the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today on what would have been his 40th birthday.

Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's recent actions in the Senate (his vote for Senator Russell Long in the Democratic caucus and his surrender of a seat on the Foreign Relations Committee to Senator Gale McGee) are more than "disappointing."

CAIRO, Jan. 14 -- Many observers here feel that the Egyptian leaders have been making an effort lately in minor, symbolic ways to play down Cairo's ties to Moscow. At the same time, Cairo has been undergoing a wave of pro-French feeling since the news that President de Gaulle has barred shipments of military equipment and spare parts to Israel.

The Carpenter Technology Corporation announced yesterday price increases of 5 to 14 cents a pound for nickel-bearing alloys used for electronic, magnetic and electrical applications, effective Jan. 22.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The House Education and Labor Committee moved today to start a Congressional investigation into allegations of corruption in New York City's anti-poverty program.
This report on the Human Resources Administration was prepared by Richard Reeves, Barnard L. Collier, Richard Phalon and Richard Severo of The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater returned today to his old seat on the Senate Armed Services Committee and Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York was assigned to the only vacancy on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

President Johnson's sixth and last State of the Union Message was a personal valedictory to Congress. He spoke as much to his former colleagues on Capitol Hill, where his career was nurtured and his outlook formed, as he did to the nation. His remarks were properly veined with sentiment and breathed of the spirit of compromise which Congress cherishes as its highest institutional value.

If anyone keeps records on shooting percentage by college basketball teams in one-half of a game, that statistician would probably have to place Columbia as the record holder. In an amazing display of field-goal shooting, the Lions hit on 73 per cent of their floor shots in the first half and easily went on to trounce Georgetown, 103-62, at University Hall on the winner's campus last night.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 15 -- United States forces killed 122 enemy soldiers yesterday while beating back an attack on an American supply convoy northwest of Saigon. It was the heaviest combat in South Vietnam in several weeks.
The annual Viennese Opera Ball, to be held in the Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 31, will have as its theme the 100th anniversary of the Vienna State Opera.

The political ties which once bound a quarter of the world to the British Isles have almost totally vanished. The economic ties between Britain and her former colonies are steadily shrinking. But the old school ties that followed the British flag around the globe live on in the Commonwealth, whose Prime Ministers have been holding another sentimental London reunion.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 -- The toll in the Scandinavian Airlines DC-8 jet crash here last night stood at four dead and 11 persons missing as the National Transportation Safety Board today began an investigation of the accident.

Stockholders of Uniroyal, Inc., approved a two-for-one split of the company's common stock at a special meeting here yesterday. Certificates for the additional shares will be mailed about Feb. 10. An increase in the authorized common stock to 60 million shares of $1.25 par from 30 million shares of $2.50 par also was approved.

BASSINGBOURN, England, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The British heir to the throne, 20-year-old Prince Charles, made his first solo flight today over eastern England. He was at the controls of a small trainer aircraft.

In his usual way, Newell Jenkins did many different things in the Clarion Concerts program he conducted in Town Hall last night. He resurrected two 18th-century works, Porpora's Overture to his opera "Polifemo," in which it was impossible to find anything interesting, and a Flute Concerto in D by Sammartini, in which it was possible.

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- A special legislative investigating committee today criticized two legislators who had been accused of being "entirely too comfortable with members of organized crime" and referred the case of a third to a grand jury.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14 -- An autopsy performed on the body of Jane Britton, a 22-year-old Harvard graduate student murdered last Tuesday, provided no new clues, the District Attorney of Middlesex County said today.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The French Government pledged tonight in effect to come to the aid of Lebanon in case of an attack by Israel.

Louis F. Polk Jr., who was elected yesterday afternoon as president and chief executive officer of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., met a barrage of criticism about the company at the annual meeting before he was officially installed.
Operations of Loew's Theatres, Inc., in the first fiscal quarter, which ended Nov. 30, resulted in record earnings of $5,148,200, equal to 36 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Major exporters of steel to the United States, uncertain of the incoming Administration's attitude toward tariffs and quotas, announced today a 5 per cent limit on the growth of such exports in each of the next three years.

ROSLYN, L. I. -- For year's it was known in the neighborhood as the "haunted house." The former dairyman's cottage from which countless gallons of milk were cheerfully dispensed is the last vestige of Harbor Hill, the 480-acre estate of the late Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the board of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, whose daughter Ellin made head-lines in 1926 by marrying a promising young song writer named Irving Berlin.

The stockholders of Young Rubicam, Inc., a privately held company, got together at 9 A.M. yesterday in the Grand Central Theater to hear a report on international operations. The press was invited, too, so you can just figure they had something good to say. They did.
Morton Sobell, sentenced to 30 years for a wartime espionage conspiracy to deliver vital national secrets to the Soviet Union, was released from prison yesterday after serving 17 years and 9 months.
In an item tucked away in the public notices of yesterday's New York Times, a Great Neck, L. I., housewife issued a blunt warning to the airlines and the Federal Government.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Walter R. Peterson Jr., New Hampshire's first Republican Governor in six years, is planning to fly to Washington with his wife for the inauguration of President-elect Richard M. Nixon. He will fly tourist class -- and a his own expense.

REVERE, Mass., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- About $7-million worth of stolen canceled checks belonging to the National Sahwmut Bank of Boston, stolen in a hijacked truck late yesterday, were recovered early today from a roadside field.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Several hundred book lovers jammed Leary's Book Store today for the auctioning of 700,000 volumes of rare and assorted books.

PARIS -- The most explosive foreign policy question to face President Nixon will not be a waning Vietnam war but a waxing Palestine war. To be sure, the Johnson Administration, in its carefully arranged handover, deferred major decisions on both problems until its successor has a chance to act.

At 10 o'clock sharp last Monday night, Simeon Golar went quickly up the front steps at City Hall, got past the guard and the gate and made his way to an almost cave-like basement office, still busy and ablaze with lights in the otherwise dimmed and empty hall.

MADRID, Jan. 14 -- A large group of Spanish professional men, intellectuals and artists have submitted to the Government 31 pages of testimony about police mistreatment of political prisoners and have called for an investigation and punishment of those responsible.
SYDNEY, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Pancho Gonzalez stormed off the court today during a doubles match in the New South Wales open tournament, saying:

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 12 -- They were big on Nehru jackets and turtlenecks at the annual awards dinner, so you can see the United States Auto Club is coming along. The club has decided to take a few modest steps toward catching up with the times, which gives U.S.A.C. a one-point lead over the baseball owners.
A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted a union official, a reputed Mafia figure, two partners in a moving concern and the owner of a yarn company.

THE Harkness Ballet, under almost entirely new management, last night returned to New York, at the Music Box Theater, for a second Manhattan season. It has a new director in Lawrence Rhodes, and at least to some extent a new policy. On this first night it looked like a policy of going Dutch, for the initial program was dominated by two works first given by Dutch companies.

The question of why four young people arrested at the request of a Long Island Rail Road conductor were held in bail and jailed is being investigated by the administrative division of the Criminal Court.
TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes urged the New Jersey Legislature to support "decisive action by the state" to help urban and suburban communities overcome grave financial difficulties.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 14 -- Premier Levi Eshkol warned today that reports of Israeli troop concentrations along her borders, similar to those that preceded the Arab-Israeli war of June, 1967, were "being concocted" again.
PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Jan. 14 -- Explosions and fire swept the flight deck of the nuclear aircraft carrier Enterprise today, killing at least 24 crewmen and destroying 15 planes.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller, in preparing his legislative proposals for reducing state-aid formulas, is seriously considering cutting the per pupil ceiling in the school - aid formula to $726 from $760.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Officials of the Federal Communications Commission challenged reports today that some of its rulings on the cable television industry would result in labor layoffs in upstate New York and Pennsylvania.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 14 -- In a hard-fought game in which the momentum and excitement were tarnished by extra time-outs to accommodate television, the East defeated the West, 123-112, in the 19th annual National Basketball Association All-Star game tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Britain's trade balance worsened in December, the Board of Trade reported today.
ANYONE phoning the New York Jets' offices now is greeted with the salutation, "Hello, world champions."

ATLANTA, Jan. 14 -- The umbrella organization for ballet, opera and repertory theater in the new Atlanta Memorial Arts Center announced today that it was discontinuing operations because of a financial crisis.
SCHRUNS - TSCHAGGUNS, Austria, Jan. 14. (AP) -- More than 100 women skiers from 15 countries took final practice runs today before the Golden Key Alpine race tomorrow.
SEATTLE, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- A onetime "Public Enemy No. 1," Alvin Karpis, a friend of Bonnie and Clyde, came out of Federal prison today with airline tickets to his native Montreal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Johnson said farewell to the nation tonight by urging it to press "the quest for peace" in Vietnam and the Middle East and to commit itself at home to the fulfillment of his social programs.

THERE is nothing restrained about Vince Lombardi's laugh. It is full-bodied and emerges from the depths with the explosiveness of a volcano. Only close friends normally hear it because the retired coach of the Green Bay Packers is in the habit of keeping his emotions under firm control. But when Lombardi lets go with one of his guffaws, the room shakes.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 Prospective jurors for the trial of Sirhan Bishara Sirhan were interrogated intensely by defense attorneys today about their attitude toward the death penalty.
The Williamsburgh Savings Bank has promoted Louis Miller and Russell M. Hoverman to trustees and executive vice presidents, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Wiretapping and other electronic surveillance will be used in the Nixon Administration's fight against crime, Attorney General designate John N. Mitchell said today.

HONG KONG, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -Sarnuel D. Berger, the United States' Deputy Ambassador in Sai;on, was married here today Io Mrs. George Pressey, widow nf Adm. George . Pressey of the United States' Navy.

GENEVA, Jan. 14 -- The European Free Trade Association estimated today that, by its fifth year, trade between its eight member states was $830-million more than it would have been had they not joined together.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court opened the way today for Negroes to break what they contend is the discriminatory hammerlock of union rules barring them from promotion and better pay.
SEVERAL days before the inauguration of President-elect Richard M. Nixon and Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew, it is faintly amusing to come across this paragraph in a new book about Republicans:

CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 14 -- The United States Navy has quietly made a legal decision that blunts several possible charges of wrong-doing against Cmdr. Lloyd M. Bucher and the crewmen of the intelligence ship Pueblo.
The Treasury auctioned $1.75-billion of tax anticipation bills yesterday in a financing that reflected somewhat more aggressive bidding on the part of the nation's banks than was anticipated.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Rod Laver of Australia reached the quarter-finals of the South Wales open tennis championship today by trouncing Ray Moore of South Africa, a fellow professional, 6-3, 6-2, 6-1.
NOT everything's changed as the Nixon Administration prepares to take over from President Johnson next Monday. A lot of the names are the same and so are the fashion-buying procedures.

YONKERS, Jan. 14 -- In the backstretch at Yonkers Raceway tonight, Charlie Coon sat in the 22-foot-long customized Chrysler that serves as the starting gate, his brown eyes darting nervously at the horses rushing up to the gate, his mouth moving, counting horses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Johnson Administration has been consulting members of the incoming Nixon Administration before replying to the latest Soviet proposal for a Middle East settlement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a group of paper box manufacturers violated the antitrust laws by exchanging price information, even though competition thrived, new companies sprang up and prices declined.

State Controller Arthur Levitt has urged further testing of the simplified declaration system of applying for welfare, asserting that the ineligibility rate in some areas is significantly higher than the low figure quoted by welfare officials

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The French Foreign Minister, Michel Debre, told the top United States negotiators today that the talks here on Vietnam were well along on an "irreversible road" toward peace, even in the present impasse.
Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson was physically barred yesterday from inspecting a Long Island Rail Road repair shop in Queens on the orders of the president of the railroad.

SEATTLE, Jan. 14 -- Walter J. Hickel, Governor of Alaska and President-elect Richard M. Nixon's nominee for Secretary of the Interior, agreed to pay a Federal income tax deficiency of $26,235 in 1963.
The following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by Mitchell I. Ginsberg, head of the Human Resources Administration:
IOWA CITY, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Chad Calabria sank a jump shot with six seconds to go to give Iowa a 77-76 victory over Michigan State tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Demands by four East African governments that Britain acknowledge the right of nonwhite immigrants holding British passports to enter this country have led to a breakdown in discussions by Commonwealth delegates here on migration.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Prospects for reform of the state's 86-year-old abortion law by the Legislature appeared better today than at any time since the movement for reform accelerated two years ago.

A WORLD record for slow play, or, more accurately, slow bidding, was set in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Tournament here last month. On the diagramed deal, played in the Knockout Team Championship, one bid took 20 minutes and the whole deal took 55 minutes.
Rudolf Bing, after 18 years as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, believes he knows how to choose his company's repertory, and wants no advice from critics.
WASHINGTON; Jan. 15 (UPI) Two constitutional amendments to change the method of electing the President were introduced today in the Senate.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Earl W. Brydges, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, said today that serious consideration was being given to increasing the annual tuition of the nearly 260,000 full- and part-time students in the State University of New York.
The stock market, taking President Johnson's farewell speech to the nation in stride, continued to push ahead yesterday in its mild rally.
TOKYO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Premier Eisaku Sato was quoted by a major Japanese weekly today as admitting that he beat his wife in the early years of their marriage, more than 40 years ago.
Low-priced mining issues helped raise prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in expanded trading.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Iraq, which maintains 20,000 troops near the Jordanian-Israeli cease-fire line, announced over the Baghdad radio today her rejection of the United Nations Security Council resolution for a Middle East settlement.

In refusing recently to increase the insurance premiums elderly persons pay for medical coverage under Medicare, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Cohen charged that physician fees have been rising much more sharply than industrial wages. He warned that unless physicians themselves moderate their fees legislators might enact restrictive laws.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President - elect Richard M. Nixon has personally endorsed a last-ditch effort by the Johnson Administration to break the procedural impasse at the Vietnam talks in Paris.

Columbia University's Society of Older Graduates presented its 1969 Great Teacher Awards last night to Sebastian B. Littauer, professor of industrial engineering, and Everard M. Upjohn, professor of art history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today demobilization dates for 13,000 Air Force Reserve and National Guard members called to active duty in January and May, 1968.

NO one can say enough about the brilliance of the National Basketball Association players who took part in Tuesday's annual All-Star game at Baltimore, won by the East, 123-112, after a battle that was in doubt until the last three minutes.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he hoped the city would buy the old Astor Library from the New York Shakespeare Festival and lease it back to the organization for its continued operation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Department of Justice filed a civil antitrust suit today to halt the creation of a giant oil concern through the proposed merger of the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Sinclair Oil Corporation.

YONKERS, Jan. 15 -- Lucien Fontaine, the leading driver of Yonkers Raceway's winter, meeting, posted his 16th triumph of the campaign by guiding Meditation to a three-quarter-length victory in the first division for New York bred horses tonight.

LONDON Jan. 15 -- Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the 49-year-old Canadian Prime Minister, who is a bachelor, criticized the British and Canadian press today for prying into his private life. He has been here for the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference, which ended today.

WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 15 -- Rebellious Negro students, their ranks slightly depleted by a mother who invaded their stronghold, remained encamped today in a Brandeis University building they commandeered a week ago.
ATLANTA, Jan. 15 -- The directors of the Atlanta ballet, theater and opera companies indicated today that they would try to survive on their own.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (Reuters) --Senator Edward /[ Brooke. Republican of Massachusetts, introduced today legislation designating Jan. 15, each year as Martin Luther King Day.

Many New Yorkers will, I am sure, share the dismay of The Times at the course taken by the City Council in filling the vacancy in the Council Presidency caused by the election of Frank D. O'Connor to the State Supreme Court. [Editorial Jan. 8.]

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 15 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson, who was rebuffed yesterday in his attempt to inspect a Long Island Rail Road repair shop, asked the head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority today for access to the shop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Early this morning, two of Richard M. Nixon's most trusted aides slipped out of New York and flew to Key Biscayne, where the President-elect has secluded himself with his thoughts, his familiar yellow legal-sized pad, and several pens.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon and his senior foreign affairs advisers are "fully aware" of a need for a cooperative United States policy toward Latin America, David Rockefeller said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Johnson sent Congress today a budget of $195.3-billion that included the first reduction in the cost of the war in Vietnam.

WARSAW, Jan. 15 -- Two former university teaching assistants were each sentenced to three and a half years' imprisonment today as "spiritual instigators" of nationwide student turmoil last year that imperiled the authority of Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Communist leader.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee appeared ready today to relax its stringent conflict-of-interest criteria to permit David R. Packard to become Deputy Secretary of Defense and still retain $300-million worth of stock in his electronics concern.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed yesterday to sell its teletypewriter exchange service -- better known as TWX -- to the Western Union Telegraph Company for about $80-million.
Nearly 150 Negro and white students ended a 24-hour occupation of the University of Minnesota administration building yesterday after the Negroes came to terms with the university.

COLLECTIONS that attain a certain measure of fame generally fall into two classes: those that reflect the investment of large sums of money and those that recall us to significant periods of art history.

Peggy Guggenheim, one-time hellion famous art collector and long-time expatriate, came home this week, and 1,000 denizens of the art and social worlds turned up to greet her last night at the snail-shaped museum designed by Frank Lloyd Wright and named for her uncle, Solomon R., the copper magnate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Congress took a cautious, exploratory attitude today toward the $195-billion budget that President Johnson sent to Capitol Hill as a parting gift.
Willie J. Smith, a high-ranking official in the city's anti-poverty program, was subpoenaed early yesterday to testify tomorrow before a Manhattan grand jury.

The memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the Nobel Prize-winning crusader for civil rights, was honored yesterday in schools of the metropolitan area and by a procession in lower Manhattan and a service on the steps of City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- The United States had a "miserable $500-million" international trade surplus in 1968 -- the worst showing since before World War II -- but registered its first over-all balance-of-payments surplus in 11 years, a Treasury official said today.

The title of Jean Dupuy's "Chorus for Six Hearts," seen and heard in the Founders Room of the Museum of Modern Art last night, tells only part of the story. The "Chorus" is also for foreheads, temples, mouths, noses, cheeks, throats, necks, high intensity light beams and trays of dust, six of each of them.
A strike by 400 drivers of special school buses yesterday forced 28,000 city schoolchildren to find other means of transportation to and from school.
Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, called attention yesterday to what he called a worsening backlog of paperwork for the commission's staff.

Daniel Roth's letter "Joint Moon Effort" [Jan. 5] points out a long overdue approach to man's landing and colonizing on the moon. Neither Russia nor the United States apparently has enough money to solve its domestic problems, yet both nations will proceed on a competitive basis to grab the moon for themselves.

TRENTON, Jan. 15 -- State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills was asked this evening if he thought a legislative investigation had vindicated his assistant, William J. Brennan 3d, who charged three legislators with being "entirely too comfortable with members of organized crime."

A dissident group of stockholders, attempting to wrest control of Defiance Industries, Inc., from Victor Muscat and his associates, disclosed yesterday that it had demanded the concern's list of stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today the today question of what to do about daily newspapers that entered, into price-fixing arrangements to survive the Depression and are now enjoying noncompetitive prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic has sent a private message to President-elect Richard M. Nixon raising the possibility of a resumption of diplomatic relations provided that the United States follows a "just policy" in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Federal budget is three things in one -- and only one of the three has much resemblance to a family budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska will probably have to divest himself of a "substantial" portion of his financial holdings before he wins confirmation as Secretary of the Interior, informed Congressional sources said today.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 14 -- The president of the students at the University of California's Berkeley campus produced copies today of the university's long-guarded investment portfolio, showing that as of last June 30 its stock and bond holdings totaled almost $664-million.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the New York City Board of Education had acted legally in bypassing Civil Service lists to appoint principals to experimental school districts, but it strictly limited the application of the decision.

Edward L. Saxe was named yesterday as president of the Columbia Broadcasting System's Television Services Division. He succeeds Frank J. Shakespeare Jr., who was appointed director of the United States Information Agency this week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- President Johnson is leaving office still firmly convinced that Congress should substitute a lottery for the current drafting of youths into the armed forces. Congress seems just as intent on resisting the idea.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- U. Alexis Johnson, the United States Ambassador to Japan, arrived today for a three-day inspection of Vietnam on behalf of President-elect Richard M. Nixon.
IN "Bruno's Dream," Iris Murdoch gives her characters hot, wild, late-blooming love affairs. Then she tears their passions to tatters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A minimum 10 per cent increase In Social Security benefit payments next year, with a corresponding rise in taxes to pay for them, was proposed today by President Johnson.
The city's first bilingual street signs were permanently installed yesterday at the intersection of Mott and Bayard Streets in the heart of Chinatown.
Mounting losses were reported yesterday in the 26-day long-shoremen's strike as desultory bargaining sessions began in three ports along the Atlantic seaboard.
Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for the establishment of a four-platoon police shift to put more policemen on the streets during the peak crime hours at night.
ATLANTA, Jan. 15 -- Dressed in black, Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. announced today plans to build a memorial here to her husband, the slain civil rights leader.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Rod Laver and Ken Rosewall, the top-seeded players, were pressed today but came through with victories in the quarter-finals of the New South Wales open tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Increased funds to build the Charles A. Buckley Post Office and Federal Office Building in the Bronx and to dredge anchorages in New York Harbor were sought today in President Johnson's budget.
A faculty group at Queens College announced its support yesterday for Joseph P. Mulholland as director of a campus assistance program under attack by militant Negroes.
The Congress of Racial Equality and Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., announced yesterday the details of an agreement on setting up a branch of the brokerage house in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- In his final Budget Message today, President Johnson made a nostalgic Odyssey back through four years of his Great Society, declared it to be good, and challenged Congress and the incoming Republican Administration to keep it going at a higher level.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 15 -- The Harvard faculty of arts and sciences voted yesterday to put on probation 57 students whose sit-in last month caused the faculty to cancel its last meeting.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15 -- Allied troops have been deployed in an arc west and northwest of Saigon in anticipation of a major enemy attack within the next few days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Johnson Administration's final defense budget, which at $79-billion is only about $600-million above anticipated spending for the current fiscal year, nevertheless appears to narrow the so-called "security gap" criticized by Richard M. Nixon during the Presidential campaign.
DAKAR, Senegal, Jan. 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- President Sekou Toure of Guinea has disclosed details of what he says is a plot to overthrow his regime, the Conakry radio reported last night.
Silver futures, which ran up early this week in line with the higher price for gold, lost a little impetus yesterday as speculators liquidated some contracts.

Major league soccer in New York, such as it is, came close to extinction yesterday when the Generals threatened to pull out of the North American Soccer League unless the league went back to its original format.

THE Dutch choreographer Rudi van Dantzig, director of the Netherlands National Ballet, is one of the most highly regarded of Europe's younger choreographers. CLEVELAND, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- James H. Rand 3d, inventor of a controversial "cancer vaccine," pleaded not guilty today to charges of stock manipulation and mail fraud in connection with development of the drug.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- Two spacecraft of the Soviet Union's Soyuz project with a total of four men aboard circled the earth today amid rising expectations that the Russians would soon attempt the first docking of two manned spaceships in orbit. The Russian name of the project significantly means "union."

The reason Gunnar Johansen played Beethoven's Sixth Piano Concerto at Philharmonic Hall in his business suit the other night was not disrespect. "My full-dress never came back from the valet service," the 62-year-old pianist explained yesterday, describing his emergency performance on Tuesday night, which the critics hailed.

The United Federation of Teachers has complained to the Federal Communications Commission about an anti-Semitic poem read over a local radio station by Leslie R. Campbell, a controversial Negro teacher in the Ocean-Hill Brownsville school district.

WHATEVER excitement there was in last night's Boston Symphony Orchestra concert in Philharmonic Hall came from Andre Watts. The young pianist had the last half of the program, and rather than a large-scale concerto he chose two one-movement works -- Franck's Symphonic Variations and the Liszt E flat Concerto.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to put first class mail and airmail into a single category at 7 cents an ounce. Present rates are 6 cents for first class mail and 10 cents for airmail. In the new category, to be called first class mail, letters would be moved by the most expeditious means of transportation. Usually, this would be by air for distances of more than 200 miles.
DETROIT, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Mrs. Dennis Bruce fed her 6-month-old twin daughters Terry and Tracy today. Or maybe it was Tracy and Terry. Not even their mother knows for sure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a bill to double the President's salary, just hours after President Johnson had proposed substantial pay rises for Senators and Representatives.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- Equatorial Guinea has formally banned the nightime mercy airlift that the International Committee of the Red Cross had been using to fly food and other relief supplies to Biafra, it was learned tonight.

Parents of nine seventh-grade pupils recently expelled from St. Aloysius Roman Catholic School in Harlem have asked the vicariate delegate of Harlem to intercede and reinstate the pupils.

Darwin, a 52- year-old 4-H leader, who fought a five-year legal battle to clear himself of a murder conviction, was found guilty today for the second time of strangling a 17-year-old girl. The verdict was returned by a three-judge panel in Tolland County Superior Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A new management proposal to end the seven-day strike of the Wire Service Guild against The Associated Press will be submitted by the guild to its membership for a vote.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- About 300 pickets marched at the main gate of San Francisco State College today in the student strike that began Nov. 6 after a long dispute with Negro students. WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Formidable and mathematical though it appears, the Government's budget is a human and therefore political document. Today's is decidedly Johnsonian, reflecting the retiring Administration's deep involvement in Vietnam (13 cents of the tax dollar) and its deep commitment to education, health and social welfare programs (35 cents).

The will of Billy Rose, showman, that nearly all of his $35-million estate go to a charitable foundation he established before his death, was upheld yesterday in a unanimous decision by the Court of Appeals.

AT a time when many in Wall Street buy and sell securities so quickly that they speak of renting rather than owning them, Morton Adler seems almost anachronistic. For Morton Adler, a gentle man who becomes caustic only when he feels his investments are in jeopardy, buys shares for life.
