The word when it came, though both friendly and courteous, was right out of the blue and what it added up to was that Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn would probably be losing the United States Steel Corporation account after 33 years.
MONTREAL, Jan. 20 -- Hockey - watchers had to do more than their usual share of interpreting the baroque world of the National Hockey League today. They had to decipher smiles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that Senator Charles E. Goodell may fill the Senate seat of the late Robert F. Kennedy until Dec. 1, 1970.
A 13-year-old girl filed suit yesterday to force the Board of Education to allow her to enter the all-boy Stuyvesant High School in lower Manhattan.

A 21-year-old Wisconsin college student, on his first visit to New York, dove into the chill waters of the Upper Bay yesterday to rescue another passenger who had jumped or fallen from the Staten Island ferry Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

The results of the balloting for baseball's Hall of Fame will be announced today at 11 A.M. at the commissioner's office, 680 Fifth Avenue. Ballots from about 350 members of the Baseball Writers Association of America were counted late last night.
The SCM Corporation said yesterday it had been issued a patent that may lead to a new method of office copying.
The Foreign Policy Association announced yesterday the election of 12 business, civic and professional leaders to its board of directors to replace board members who have completed their terms.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Jan 20 (AP) -- Colgate University, which will celebrate its 150th anniversary as a man's college this year, will become coeducational beginning with the fall semester in 1970.
The other shoe has finally fallen for the International Business Machines Corporation.

Roy M. Cohn pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to an indictment charging bribery, conspiracy, extortion and blackmail in connection with the city's take-over of routes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.

Since the days when the plantation system violated the solidarity of Afro-Americans, many of their most treacherous opponents have come from their own people. Roy Wilkins -- by his tragic lack of empathy with the current struggles of the black American, and by his clumsy assessment of current black events -- has upheld this regrettable tradition.

" Carnevale Italiano," an Italian mardi gras, will be held next Monday in the New York Hilton's Grand Ballroom. Proceeds will go to the scholarship fund of the America-Italy Society and to the Fifty-Two ,Association.
Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, warned yesterday that the nation faced "a long and arduous way" before it returned to satisfactory price stability.

The Pro Arte Symphony Orchestra, which gave its first Manhattan concert last night at Carnegie Hall, demonstrated more than enough ability to deny one the right to label it the Semi-Pro Arte Orchestra. That was too bad for the sake of the weak joke (though you'll notice that it did sneak in there, somehow), but a good portent for the group's artistic future under its new conductor, Eleazar de Carvalho.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 20 (UPI) -- A jury of nine women and three men was picked with surprising swiftness in United States District Court today to hear a $30-million antitrust suit evolving from the sale of Maine Chance Farm.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia -- From his 20th-floor office atop 505 Burrard Street, Takeshi Sakurauchi need only spin his swivel chair around for what may be the best executive view in North America -- snowcapped mountains, new white and pastel apartment towers, small aircraft skimming along the water, freighters and bulk carriers hauling trans-Pacific cargo through Burrard Inlet.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Changes affecting exemptions from qualifying and prize money for the lower places in this year's $72,804 British Open golf championship at Royal Lytham and St. Annes were announced today by the Royal and Ancient Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Nixon Administration has asked at least two White House foreign policy specialists from the Johnson Administration to serve under the new Republican regime.

An East Harlem woman whose 7-year-old son was found dead of suffocation in a vacant building last week was shot and critically wounded early yesterday. The police said they were seeking a family boarder for questioning in both cases.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 20 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic declared today in a speech to the National Assembly that he would fight again rather than agree to cede an inch of Arab territory. "Nor will we ever sit to negotiate with an enemy who is occuping our territory," he said.
The Seattle Supersonics don't relish losing even if it may eventually get them into the bidding derby for Lew Alcindor of the University of California, Los Angeles.
The appointment of Norman C. Amaker and Michael Meltsne as first assistant counsel was announced yesterday by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- President Johnson has awarded to 20 Americans the Medal of Freedom, the highest civil honor the President can bestow, the White House announced today.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The two top Democrats in the Republican-controlled Legislature today labeled as "crude" and "promiscuous" Governor Rockefeller's plan to balance the new budget by increasing the sales tax and cutting projected spending by 5 per cent across the board.

HONG KONG, Jan. 19 -- In a recent diatribe against the Soviet Union, Peking's official newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao declared that a Pravda editorial was as "nauseating as a robber feigning kind-heartedness and a prostitute preaching chastity."
PANAMA, Jan. 20 -- Rising hostility and fear mark Panama's political scene as her military rulers attempt to implement their "revolution" before the return of civilian rule, promised for next year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Eight years ago today this essentially Southern city lay under a blanket of snow that all but paralyzed it. Nevertheless, the business of inaugurating John F. Kennedy as the 35th President of the United States proceeded apace; and at 12:41 P.M. Richard M. Nixon went out of office, turning the Vice-Presidency over to Lyndon B. Johnson.

An undertone of caution has been noted in consumer buying attitudes, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. Consumers, however, continue to express strong optimism about the economy, despite the tax surcharge and higher interest rates.
NEW LONDON, Jan. 20 -- A large discharge of oil has coated 20 miles of beaches on Long Island Sound and imperiled hundreds of ducks, the Coast Guard said today.
PRAGUE, Jan. 20 -- A second young man set himself afire today, apparently in another protest for Czechoslovak freedom.

More than 150 demonstraors, blocked by policemen from halting military recruiting in a Columbia University building on 116th Street, invaded the student placement offices on the campus yesterday and broke glass door panels, smashed an electric typewriter, ripped out a telephone, tore posters from bulletin boards and overturned shelves of books.

MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Crew members of an Ecuadorian airliner that was hijacked to Havana yesterday arrived in Miami today and said they had been forced to fly to Cuba by 15 hijackers, including three with machine guns who threatened to kill them.

Cocoa futures dropped the penny-a-pound limit yesterday. One broker described the continuation of the recent decline as "a money market" in cocoa. He explained that speculators were dumping their long positions because of margin problems.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Nixon has started his Administration with a simple statement of priorities: peace abroad and reconciliation at home.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 20 -- The Lyndon B. Johnson family came home to Central Texas today, and there were tears in the eyes of Texas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- "Do you realize there have been four Presidents since I've been Governor," Nelson A. Rockefeller commented today.
Mrs. Helynn R. Lewis, the former director of fiscal affairs for the Human Resources Administration, was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing $48,340 in city antipoverty funds.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Bob Cousy, one of pro basketball's greatest playmakers, announced today his retirement as coach at Boston College at the end of the season to devote more time to his business interests.
The Martin Marietta Corporation, aerospace and materials concern, has joined with Oscar S. Straus, financier and mining executive, to explore for minerals.

YESTERDAY was a time for investitures -- political in Washington, oenological in New York. No less solemnly than politicians were oathed in the capital, knights in the flashing white of full dress were dubbed here.
The general manager of radio station WBAI yesterday rejected charges of anti-Semitism made against the station by Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers.
The Sperry Rand Corporation attained record sales and earnings in the three months and nine months ended Dec. 31, J. Frank Forster, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The inauguration of Richard M. Nixon was marked by an intensified focus on the spiritual aspects of the nation's problems and the tasks of government.
MINEOLA, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- A teen-ager testified in her aunt's murder trial today that she alone had killed her uncle because he had made her pregnant.
BONN, Jan. 20 -- A German army munitions depot near Lebach in the Saarland was raided early today by a gang that shot five sentries, killing three and severely wounding two.

The fight for control of the United Fruit Company accelerated yesterday as the AMK Corporation and Zapata Norness, Inc., increased their bids for shares of the producer of bananas and other food products.

The inauguration of President Nixon and the advent of a Republican Administration appeared yesterday to have a thoroughly neutral influence on the stock market. Advances eked out a 670-to-663 lead over declining issues, and popular stock averages produced small losses.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- What President Nixon promised in his inaugural address, The Times of London will say in an editorial tomorrow, "was a sensitive and workmanlike approach, after a period in which he feels that the grandiose projects of the New Frontier and the Great Society delivered, at rather heavy cost, somewhat short weight."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 -- A joint venture involving the sale of up to 85 million tons of Australian coking coal to Japanese interests, the financing of a new state-owned railway in Queensland and the possible building of large coal-carrying ships was announced today by the Utah Construction and Mining Company.

Mr. Knoedler Co., one of the nation's most prestigious art dealers, will move this summer from 57th Street, but without Andrew Wyeth, who has been one of the gallery's leading artists for more than 16 years.

TRENTON, Jan. 20 -- A controversial section of New Jersey's gun-control law requiring applicants to disclose past membership in subversive organizations was upheld unanimously today by the State Supreme Court.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 20 -- A new odometer that foils attempts of turning back a car's mileage has been developed by the AC Spark Plug Division of the General Motors Corporation. The "telltale" device that provides visual evidence of tampering has been introduced this month on all cars produced by the corporation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Supreme Court limited today the authority of cities to repeal fair housing laws through popular referendums.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Henry Cabot Lodge, arriving tonight to assume his duties as the new head of the United States delegation to the Vietnam peace talks, promised "to do all in our power" to make them a success.

To copy these reactions chemists often require elaborate equipment working at high pressures and temperatures.

BONN, Jan. 20 -- West Germany, which does not recognize East Germany as a separate country, will nevertheless permit its Communist-ruled neighbor to fly the East German flag and play the East German national anthem at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 -- Lebanon demanded today that Israel be punished for her Dec. 28 attack on the Beirut airport, by "appropriate sanctions" or expulsion from the International Civil Aviation Organization, or both. Thirteen planes were destroyed in the raid.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange plunged 3,281,720 shares in the month ended Jan. 15 for the sharpest month-to-month fluctuation in stock exchange history. Franklin K. Lane High School will be closed today, tomorrow and Friday so that a plan can be worked out for reducing the enrollment of the violence-scarred school from 5,100 students to 4,350.

Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, apologized last night to "all persons who have been offended" by the controversial catalogue for the museum's "Harlem on My Mind" exhibition.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Rockefeller sent the Legislature an "austerity" budget today that calls for a record $900-million increase in state spending and a 1-cent rise in the state sales tax.
The White Elephant Ball, a benefit for the Child Adoption Service of the Children's Aid Society, will be held Jan. 30 in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

MIAMI, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Manuel Ycaza and Trainer Downey Bonsal shared the spotlight today with Jorge Velasquez at Hialeah Park. The first two combined to score two major upsets and Velasquez won four races.
A former city securities analyst who was hired on the basis of a resume that the Department of Investigation said was untruthful was indicted yesterday on charges of bribery and conflict of interest.

MONTREAL, Jan. 21 -- Canadian motor buffs mix English phrases like "a bit of tweaking" and "needs breathing on" with American ones like "going Gangbusters" and "it goes like stink." Having no domestically owned automobile production facilities, Canadians are comfort able with a broad range of imports.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- "This is the best act I've ever seen," one influential Republican legislator said sardonically today about Governor Rockefeller's $6.4-billion state budget (or should it be called $6.7-billion marked down to $6.4-billion?).
Reaction abroad to President Nixon's inaugural address was generally favorable, with expressons of satisfaction over his promise to work for peace.

Robert W. Cutler, a partner in the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings Merrill, was elected president of the Fifth Avenue Association yesterday. He is the first architect to head the 62-year-old association.
Prices turned mixed yesterday in moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A controversial school desegregation ruling was upheld today in a 4-to-3 decision by the Federal appeals court here.

Mayor Lindsay said last night that two Negro teachers accused of making anti-Semitic remarks did not have "any place teaching" in the city's schools and that he had asked the Board of Education to "take appropriate action."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 21 -- With the support of its Negro students, Harvard University moved today towardthe establishment of a full degree-granting program in American Negro studies on a par with all other academic disciplines.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- An odd feature of this epoch is the parallel drive for bigger supranational organizations such as the Common Market, or what Moscow fondly calls its "Socialist Commonwealth." and that for smaller tribal groupings. One must view currently riotous Northern Ireland against this paradoxical background.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Nixon conducted his first full day of business as the nation's 37th President today and plunged immediately into the question of Vietnam.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Jan. 21 -- Police Commissioner John L. Barry of Suffolk County said today that the District Attorney was "discouraging" the police narcotics squads by allowing students arrested on felony charges of selling narcotics to plead to lesser charges.
MADRID, Jan. 21 -- Indignation over the death of a student in police custody boiled over today into the most serious student demonstrations seen here for more than a year.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 -- Japanese industry, convinced that the economy of Communist China is moving forward again after the long stagnation of the cultural revolution, is eagerly anticipating increased sales to the huge mainland market.

SYDNEY, Australia -- Before the influx of thousands of immigrants from Europe in recent years, the best-known Australian contribution to international cuisine had been kangaroo tail soup. Yet an Australian has just signed a multi-million-dollar contract to share culinary expertise with television viewers in the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today that invitations to White House social events would not be confined to "the big shots" but would encompass a broad range of friends and campaign allies who will be entertained on a rotating basis.

If you like your media mixed, the Whitney Museum of American Art was a good place to be last night. Several highly successful experiments in the genre known these days as environmental art were put on display under the over-all title of "A Mixture of Sight and Sound."
JERUSALEM, Jan. 21 -- After six weeks of maneuvers, the elite Golani Brigade of the Israeli Army staged its final dramatic exercise starting at dawn today.
The bond market sagged under the weight of heavy new offerings yesterday, nudging interest rates up after more than a week of declines.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 21 (AP) -- More than 1,000 teachers will strike the Jersey City public school system Thursday if their salary demands are not satisfied.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Rauno Aaltonen of Finland and Henry Liddon of Britain, who won the 1967 Monte Carlo auto rally, abandoned this year's event tonight after their Lancia slammed into the side of a mountain road.
Roy Innis said yesterday that Roy Wilkins was consistently opposing "the legitimate aspirations of black people."

Shareholders of the AMK Corporation voted yesterday to approve an exchange of their company's stock for that of the United Fruit Company. The special meeting, held at the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, also voted to increase AMK's common from the present seven million shares to 45 million.

A Columbia University faculty committee will begin considering tomorrow the implications of a little-known Federal statute that bars schools that prohibit military recruiting on their campuses from getting research grants from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 17 -- Some desperate and determined women have set this city's officialdom on their ears simply by moving into empty, state-financed apartment buildings and refusing to move out.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 -- The dispute between the Black Panther party and rival black nationalists continued today despite the surrender of two men accused of slaying two Panthers last week on the U.C.L.A. campus.

WHILE many in Wall Street have been speculating that a fight would develop between Loew's Theatres, Inc., and Northwest Industries, Inc., for the billion-dollar B. F. Goodrich Company, a close reading of the data on Northwest suggests that such a contest is not in the cards.

Chas, Pfizer Co., Inc., operated at near capacity at plants throughout the world last year to meet the demand for its products, John J. Powers Jr., chairman and president, said yesterday in reporting the company's highest sales and earnings for the quarter and the year ended Dec. 31.
IT'S getting to be that a man's hairdressing bills may top his wife's. At least, if he goes to Jerry, who is the Kenneth of the men's hair stylists.

BONN, Jan. 21 -- A dramatic rise of NSU stock prices on West German exchanges has prompted expectations that Germany's smallest, but much-renowned, automobile factory may soon become the next merger partner in Europe's increasingly competitive automobile industry.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 -- Eight long-range enemy rockets smashed into the coastal resort city of Vungtau this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Nixon awoke this morning in a city where during the last week an 81-year-old District of Columbia "mother of the year" was mugged and thrown down a flight of stairs in a pocketbook snatching; Mrs. Gwen Cafritz, a well known society matron, was the victim of a $250,000 armed robbery, and street crime, particularly armed robberies, showed a steady rise.

Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, coach of the New York Rangers, was back in action yesterday following four days' absence after his collapse Friday night in Oakland, Calif. He directed the team during its morning practice at Skateland in New Hyde Park, L.I.
The proposed $60.5-million consolidated passenger terminal along the Hudson River between 46th and 50th Streets was approved yesterday by the City Council's Finance Committee.

MONTREAL, Jan. 21 -- Like a house guest who steals the host's best china, the West Division took advantage of a polite East Division squad tonight and skated away with a 3-3 tie in the first confrontation between the all-stars of the National Hockey League's two divisions.

SANTA, PAULA, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Ten persons fleeing a rainstorm in the Los Padres National Forest were swept late yesterday from a Navy amphibious tractor stalled in the Sespe Creek and were "presumed lost."

Newly organized nonprofessional workers at St. John's Queens Hospital in Elmhurst staged a nine-hour sit-in strike yesterday to protest alleged "stalling" by hospital officials in negotiating a contract.
PRAGUE, Jan. 21 -- Workers and students appraising Government statements today found little hope that their demands on the leadership would meet with any early success.

Arthur D. Lewis resigned yesterday as president and a director of Eastern Air Lines, effective March 1. Floyd D. Hall, 52 years old, will succeed Mr. Lewis as president, in addition to retaining his other responsibilities as chairman and chief executive officer.

NEWARK Jan. 21 -- The Board of Education plans to place special security guards in city schools here as soon as they can be trained, to reduce violence.

In its second concert of the season, the National Orchestral Association brought to Carnegie Hall the young Israeli cellist Michael Haran. Along with Mr. Haran, the orchestra brought a new cello concerto by Claude Pascal, which served as a vehicle for the mostly French-trained soloist.
GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- Narcotics experts brought together by the World Health Organization came out strongly today against legalization of the smoking of marijuana.

The APA-Phoenix repertory company yesterday announced that it had obtained about two-thirds of the money needed to wipe out a deficit of $1.5-million. This will permit the group to do "Hamlet" on March 3 at the Lyceum Theater, as the fourth and final offering of the 1968-69 series.
DOVER, Del., Jan. 21 -- Russell W. Peterson, a 52-year-old former director of research for E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. was inaugurated as Governor of Delaware shortly after 1 P.M. today.

Milton Galamison to head the negotiating committee for the Board of Education to negotiate a new contract with the United Federation of Teachers. SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 -- The chancellor of the University of California's Berkeley campus countered a strike threat today with a 10-page statement detailing steps his administration had taken during the last four years to aid minority and disadvantaged students.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Federal District Judge Julius J. Hoffman denied today a Government request for a temporary restraining order to block efforts of the General Host Corporation to gain control of Armour Co.

Robert Montgomery, the motion-picture and television star and one-time television consultant to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, has been named president of the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater.

The nomination of Walter J. Hickel to be Secretary of the Interior would have been better unmade. Instead of seeking out the best man for this sensitive and onerous position, President Nixon chose a businessman with exactly the wrong kind of background.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposal to reduce protected state spending across the board this year is coupled with long-range plans to drastically curtail future increases of state aid to localities for schools, welfare and health programs.
Pressure mounted yesterday on the Federal Administration to act in the 32-day coastwide longshore strike as damage to the nation's economy deepened.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- Western shipping lines agreed today to admit the Soviet Union to their shipping conference on the Australian route, thus ending a freight war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Talking tough about protesting "activists," criminal law enforcement and antitrust efforts, the incoming Attorney General, John N. Mitchell, pledged today a "vigorous" law enforcement policy by the Nixon Administration.

The High School Principals Association of New York City said yesterday that mounting student disorders that the Board of Education was "unwilling or unable" to stop were threatening to destroy the city's high schools.

The Jeunesses Musicales of Israel and the America-Israel Cultural Foundation joined forces with Carnegie Hall - Jeunesses Musicales, Inc., last night to present Miriam Fried, a 21-year-old violinist, in her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- Take a long, skinny, silk scarf and wrap it tightly around your head, loop it loosely around your neck, or use it as a band to cover a bared bosom. That's the idea in a lot of the Italian couture collections for spring and summer going on here this week.
" C.B.S. Children's Playhouse," a new daytime series for children that will include original dramas, will be presented next season on the television network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Office of Economic Opportunity, which had threatened to cut off Federal funding for local antipoverty programs on Jan. 31, agreed yesterday to waive that deadline to give the city's Human Resources Administration time to implement new financial safeguards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Vice President Agnew made his debut as presiding officer of the Senate today and learned two quick lessons: You can only hear about half the members' remarks, and, when they are trying to be funny, it is probably just as well.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- The USM Corporation today clarified reports on an agreement between USM and the Department of Justice for settling antitrust litigation. The reports made it appear that the settlement would cost the company $8.5-million a year.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- A Navy President missile veered off course and was destroyed by radio signal seconds after its launching today on its third test flight. JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 21 -- A massive savings campaign for South Africa, one of the world's richest countries in terms of individual wealth and reserve holdings, was announced today by Dr. Nicholaas Diederichs, the Finance Minister.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 21 -- Ch. Vaught's John Paul, a foxhound, was selected tonight as best in show at the 26th all-breed show of the Fort Lauderdale Dog Club. The 8 1/2-year-old dog, owned by the estate of Fred A. Vaught of Hartsville, Tenn., was handled by Dick Cooper.
Some 750 relatives, friends, co-workers and supporters of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy attended a dinner paying tribute to him at the Pierre Hotel last night.

Taller by 7 inches and with a 9-inch advantage in reach, Bob Foster of Washington will defend his world light-heavyweight championship for the first time tonight against Frankie De Paula of Jersey City at Madison Square Garden. The bout is scheduled to start at 9:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A former member of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the director of its most famous recent study of securities market was among those named today to an advisory committee for the special study of institutional investors.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 21 -- The Wayside Chapel off King's Cross, the Times Square of Sydney, is "the scene" for scores of articulate young people representing Australia's new "switched-on" generation.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed slightly higher yesterday after a minor rally late in the session.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- The Soviet Union gave its four latest astronauts the traditional heroes' welcome today, from embraces by the nation's leaders at the airport to a mass meeting in the Kremlin's modernistic Palace of Congresses.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. Friday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Scattered firebombings and rock-throwing incidents were reported in Jacksonville late last night. The police said they were apparently related to a trial earlier in the day in which a white man had been found not guilty of killing a Negro.

THE Metropolitan Opera has long needed a new production of Richard Strauss's "Rosenkavalier." It also has needed a cast that was strong down the line. Last night it received both. Happy days are here again.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 23 -- Gold prices fell today in European bullion markets following the declaration by Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy that the United States saw no need or reason for changing the official price of $35 an ounce.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 23 -The chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Mass Transportation asked Governor Rockefeller today for an additional $5-million from the deficiency budget for an emergency fund for repairs and maintenance of the Long Island Rail Road.

LUSAKA, Zambia -- Zambia's economic position has weakened considerably since the bright October day in 1964 when independence was granted, but corrective measures are in the offing for this year's budget.
At the end of a letter (Jan. 15) commenting on Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's recent actions in the Senate, Marvin Swartz wrote:

ROME, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The Vatican radio today applauded youths who burn themselves "for freedom" in Eastern Europe. But high Vatican sources expressed amazement at the comment and said that it did not conform with Roman Catholic teachings.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 23 -- There's no doubt that the January thaw is taking its toll on snow depths at ski areas. But no one seems to be worrying yet. Most of the North Country has been buried in white cover ever since early December.

Joe Frazier and Nino Benvenuti loomed yesterday as possible opponents for Bob Foster, the world lightheavyweight chamipon who retained his title with a firstround knockout of Frankie De Paula Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.
BONN, Jan. 23 -- Dr. Eugen Gerstenmaier announced today his decision to quit the presidency of the West German Bundestag (lower house of Parliament).

If Robert Willoughby really likes and believes in all the pieces he played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, he is a man of curiously catholic and inconsistent musical tastes. Mr. Willoughby, a flutist who has taught at the Oberlin College Conservatory of Music since 1955, offered a program of seven 20th-century works prefaced -- for some strange reason -- by Bach's Sonata in A minor for unaccompanied flute.

SAINT GERVAIS, France, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Skiers from France took first and second places, but the United States' teen - age - dominated squad turned in a remarkable team performance today by capturing five of the first 10 places in the Saint Gervais special slalom.

A spokesman for the New York Urban Coalition said yesterday that the group had not devised its own plan on school decentralization but was preparing to consider a study group's draft paper on the topic.
Mayor Lindsay urged yesterday that the Board of Education publish a code of ethics for teachers to make clear what is "intolerable" with regard to anti-Semitism and racial slurs.

Midweek matinees of "Jimmy Shine," starring Dustin Hoffman, have been canceled for eight weeks, next Wednesday through March 19, to enable Mr. Hoffman to appear in the filming here of "John and Mary."

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission may set off the world's first industrial nuclear explosion in Australia, David E. Fairbairn, Minister for National Development, said today.
An assortment of helicopters and STOL aircraft will be demonstrated at Mitchel Field on Feb. 5.

LISBON -- Despite the change of regime in Lisbon, nothing politically upsetting has occurred in Portugal's African territories. In fact, the new Government has given assurances that the policies of former Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar will be continued.

A YEAR ago Katherine Sue Dillon, then 17, thought she might go into advertising as a career. She had just won a prize for a lingerie ad. A little later she considered becoming a decorator. She had won a prize for a "dream bedroom."
Will Sparks is the man who took the "whereas" out of Presidential proclamations.

Residents of a scenic, treelined East Side street that includes houses designated as historical landmarks banded together last night in a march to protest the construction of a subway power station they regard as a threat to the street's beauty.

Orenthal James (Orange Juice) Simpson, college football's jewel from Southern California, is not going to rock the establishment of pro football. At least not right away, according to Charles M. (Chuck) Barnes Jr., Simpson's recently appointed business manager.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -Mayor Lindsay is making an intensive personal effort to improve New York City's relations with the Federal Government, now that the Nixon Administration has taken over.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 -- United States planes, artillery, tanks and infantrymen tried unsuccessfully again today to dislodge an enemy force dug in for the last four days in an abandoned village near Quangngai, on the northern coast of South Vietnam.

ACCRA, Ghana -- Wigs have become a major import item here and in other African countries despite considerable male opposition to the female fashion. But, however much men may condemn the foreign fashion as "un-African," it is evident that their women consider wigs an indispensable adornment.
PepsiCo, Inc., the soft-drink company, plans to enter the restaurant field through the acquisition of Hardee's Food Systems, Inc., for about $60.4million in securities and cash.

With concern for his failing spirits and well-being, the Rangers last night relieved Coach Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion of his duties for three weeks, "on the advice of his doctors," who said he needed a complete rest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Charles McDowell Jr., 42 years old, Washington correspondent and columnist for The Richmond Times-Dispatch, was high man today in an election to membership on the Standing Committee of Correspondents.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The police reported an explosion tonight at the Albuquerque headquarters of the Alliance of Free City States, commonly known as the Alianza, an organization led by Reies Lopez Tijerina.
MONTE CARLO, Friday, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -Vic Elford of Britain was knocked out of the Monte Carlo rally today when his car careened off the road during a high speed test.

General de Gaulle's announcement that he intends to serve the remaining four years of his second Presidential term became inevitable once speculation about an earlier retirement swept the country. Silence, while his would-be successors began campaigning, would have made him a lame-duck in both domestic and international politics.

Striking longshoremen looked the other way yesterday while 750 travelers boarded the superliner United States to sail far away from the labor dispute that has paralyzed shipping along the East and Gulf coasts.

The nation's chain stores scored outstanding gains in 1968 and finished the year with a plus of 15.1 per cent over 1967. With few exceptions, the chains enjoyed good gains in December, indicating that their Christmas business was well ahead of a year earlier.

ATHENS, Friday, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- An Athens courtmartial sentenced three men and a woman early today to 16 years in prison on charges of having plotted to overthrow the army-backed Government. An actor, Nicholas Armaos, 25 years old, was sentenced to five years' imprisonment on similar charges.
MEMPHIS, Jan. 23 -- More than 200 of the nation's leading churchmen marched in solemn procession through downtown Memphis today to pay tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
THE world of physical sport sometimes overlaps with the world of intellectual recreation.

From bourbon to Gatorade, from investment possibilities to technical aids for collecting data, the 2,000 money managers and security analysts attending the Institutional Investors Conference yesterday had quite a selection.
The London Stock Exchange was generally quiet but firmer yesterday.

IT is part of the conventional wisdom that a company that earns little, cuts its dividend and has lots of money in its treasury is not only a good take-over possibility but also is a poorly managed company that deserves to be gobbled up.

BONN, Jan. 24 -- A West German official said today that the Federal Government planned to institute proceedings against the editor of the right-wing weekly National Zeitung next week on the ground that he had incited anti-Jewish feelings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- An interdenominational religious service in the East Room of the White House, for which no one could remember a precedent, will take place Sunday at 11 A.M.

HOUSTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Lennox Miller of the University of Southern California broke the world indoor record in the 100-yard dash tonight with a clocking of 9.4 seconds in the Astrodome Federation National Relays.
A Brooklyn youth was sentenced to 10 to 20 years in prison yesterday for killing a Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute student who had been unable to give him a cigarette.
The freeze in coastwide longshore negotiations hardened yesterday on the strike's 35th day.

A 25-year-old Miami man, Keith Barish, a 32-year-old former Cuban businessman, Rafael Navarro, and an American, Pierre Salinger, 43, stopped off briefly here yesterday to disclose plans to buy $100-million of choice New York real estate this year.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 24 -- The golf news along the Pacific today was that the first round of the Bing Crosby pro-amateur tourney was completed. After a rainout yesterday, and the experience at Napa, Calif., last weekend, where a $135,000 event had to end at the 36-hole halfway mark because of rain, overcast skies and light drizzle, this seemed consoling to worried officials and players.
The sprawling old Brooklyn Navy Yard may have a bright future as an industrial park, but yesterday its massive, deserted structures had the ghostly look of a long-ago past.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- The American Bar Association released today a proposed new Code of Professional Responsibility, which is designed to replace the legal profession's antiquated and much-criticized Legal Canons of Ethics.

The expected appointment of Mayor Floyd H. Hyde of Fresno as administrator of the Model Cities program assures that program of leadership by a strong advocate of more Federal aid to urban areas. Equally encouraging as a guarantee of top-level support is the emphasis Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Finch has put on the program's importance.
THE Morvan district of Burgundy is famous for mildly cured hams -- the basis for the jambon a la morvandelle, or ham with cream sauce, recipe given below.
The Doors, one of the country's most popular rock groups and the possessor of the current hit record "Touch Me," played before a sellout audience of 20,000 last night at Madison Square Garden.

The battle for control of Italy's dominant Christian Democratic party has been stimulated, not resolved, by the victory of the country's new Premier, Mariano Rumor, in electing Deputy Flaminio Piccoli to succeed him as party secretary.

After three days of patting one another on the back, trade exhibitors went back to their boats and booths, and the 59th National Boat Show at the Coliseum prepared to open its doors today to the public.

NATIONAL EDUCATIONAL TELEVISION once again has the British Broadcasting Corporation to thank for a perfectly delightful little comedy about the human frailties of a group of Trappist monks in an Irish monastery.

Good prospects and prospects that might be good confront the New York Rangers in their next two games. The good outlook is the one for this afternoon, vhen the home outfit skates against the Chicago Black Hawks in Madison Square Garden. Chicago is on a bad streak that shows three defeats and one tie in its last four games.
The School Custodians' Union charged yesterday that the Board of Education was trying to goad the union into a strike by refusing to carry on contract negotiations.

MEMPHIS, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Judge W. Preston Battle of Criminal Court told the Rev. James Bevel today he may not help defend James Earl Ray against a murder charge in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Juther King Jr. This, the judge said, is because Mr. Bevel is not a lawyer.

WHERE are the snows of yesteryear? Well, in case you've been wondering, some of them may be found at John Gibson, 27 East 67th Street, which is presenting "Below Zero," a series of snow projects by Dennis Oppenheim.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, one of the nation's largest brokerage firms, was censured and penalized by the Securities and Exchange Commission today in two separate cases involving alleged illegal actions by its employes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The United States has urged the British Government not to permit the sale of supersonic jets to Malaysia for fear it would touch off an arms race in Southeast Asia.

MADRID, Jan. 24 -- When he became Minister of Information and Tourism in 1962 and startled Spain by announcing his intention to abolish censorship of the press, Manuel Fraga Iribarne was a nervous and brilliant man, and decidedly overweight.
Wings Wheels Express, Inc., a major air freight forwarder, has elected John C. Wisener president and chairman, succeeding the company's founder, Edward L. Richter, who died last November.
ZULFIKAR Ghose's novel can not only be read on two levels, but also can not be read otherwise if it is to be more than a cinematic excursion into the art of fiction.
The stock market finished yesterday on a fairly even keel following its brisk rally in the two preceding sessions.

YONKERS, Jan. 24 -- Armed with charts and graphs, which he explained in professorial tones, Governor Rockefeller traveled through Rockland and Westchester Counties today seeking support for his proposed $6.4-billion state budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Illinois Central Railroad is the prospective beneficiary of a $25.2-million grant made by the Department of Transportation while Alan S. Boyd was Secretary of Transportation and was being considered for the post of president of the railroad.

Hopes for ending the school bus strike which has lasted eight school days, dimmed yesterday when union drivers turned down a company proposal that drivers work without compensation while settlement efforts continued.

CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Cmdr. Lloyd M. Bucher, looking pale and drawn, testified today at a closed session of the naval court of inquiry into the capture of the intelligence ship Pueblo last January.
THERE is more Whieldon, the colorful 18th-century English earthenware, at this year's Winter Antiques Show than there has been in years.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- A Frankfurt appeals court today cut two months from an eight-month suspended prison sentence given to Daniel Cohn-Bendit, militant student leader.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 -- Greeted by a loud ovation, Dr. S. I. Hayakawa, the acting president of beleaguered San Francisco State College, told a Commonwealth Club luncheon crowd today that a "systematic plan" was under way "to bring the college to a halt."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- It looks is if life is going to be a bit more formal in the White House for at least the next four years.

Five years after the Surgeon General's landmark report confirming the existence of a definite cause-and-effect link between heavy smoking and lung diseases, there is reason to believe that the public is beginning to get the message.
The London Stock Exchange ended the week on a mixed note yesterday. Investor interest was centered on issues figuring in take-over situations.
A new attack on plans for the Hudson River Expressway was begun yesterday in Federal Court, where residents of the Hudson Valley filed suit to enjoin the project.
THE policy of WBAI-FM in providing a public platform for anti-Semitic poetry and interviews could represent an exceptionally difficult matter for the Federal Communications Commission to consider.

MANY players are not aware that the game has two distinct national bridge organizations. In addition to the American Contract Bridge League, with a membership of 173,000, there is the American Bridge Association, with a membership of 5,000, primarily Negro players.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 24 -- Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the man blamed by many commuters for assertedly poor service on the Long Island Rail Road, was exposed to further criticism here today at a "fall guy" luncheon of the Sky Island Club.

Assemblyman Franz S. Leichter, a West Side Democrat, charged the Lindsay administration yesterday with the "misuse" and "squandering" of $13-million in state funds intended to improve housing-code enforcement.
IN a few more months it will be all over. Lew Alcindor will pack his degree and his Charlie Mingus albums and, like most college graduates, will start looking for a job and a place to live.

WASHINGTON, Jan 24 -- President Nixon ordered his Administration today to prepare an urgent, comprehensive review of United States relief efforts for civilian victims of the 19-month old Nigerian civil war.
TRENTON, Jan. 24 -- The American Civil Liberties Union accused the New Jersey state police today of deliberately harassing a reputed Mafia figure in Monmouth County.

In successive days New York City has witnessed widespread dissemination of anti-Semitic literature, first by radio station WBAI, and then by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In both cases, responsible officials denied the writings were anti-Semitic.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24 -- The teachers' strike here went into its second day today despite yesterday's court order prohibiting the walkout and the threat of contempt citations against its leaders.

The chairman of a Congressional group investigating the city's antipoverty programs said yesterday that the loss of Neighborhood Youth Corps funds could have been prevented if the Human Resources Administration had submitted certain reports when they were due.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Two hundred students of the London School of Economics sat down outside the Bow Street police station today chanting for the release of arrested fellow students. Policemen four deep ringed the station.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Nixon seems to have set up a Rube Goldberg contraption in the White House to make sense out of the bigger Rube Goldberg device former Presidents and Congress have created in the domestic departments and agencies.

Cocoa futures strengthened yesterday here in moderate trading, backed by a steady London market. Good demand for spot sales of cocoa beans was reported from Eastern Europe, and this was reflected by some trade and speculative buying in the London market.
MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Pilots of planes likely to be detoured to Cuba have been given bilingual cards of what to say to hijackers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Nixon today blocked former President Lyndon B. Johnson's controversial awarding of Pacific airline routes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- An electrolytic cell about the size of a navy bean has won respect for its ability to add, subtract and remember information. It is finding varied uses, from computing when a car should be serviced to recording the strain a man's heart undergoes during the day.

MOUNT SNOW, Vt., Jan. 24 -- Hias Leitner, the silver medal slalom winner in the 1960 Olympics at Squaw Valley, raced through a steady rainfall this afternoon to capture the first professional Alpine competition of the season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Lloyd W. Bailey, Republican elector from North Carolina, told a senate subcommittee today the Electoral College must be retained as America's last bulwark against democracy.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- A cosmonaut who took a "walk" in space in March, 1965, Col. Aleksei A. Leonov, dismissed with a quip today the incident two days ago in which a man fired several shots at a car occupied by himself and three fellow astronauts.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 24 -- The Sea of Galilee stood at its highest level in recorded history today after a week of torrential rains that have flooded vast areas of northern Israel, isolating villages causing millions of dollars worth of damage.

Debbie Meyer of Sacramento, Calif., the first swimmer in Olympic history to win three gold medals in individual events, became yesterday only the fourth female in 39 years to win the Sullivan Award as the outstanding amateur athlete in the United States.

DORTMUND, West Germany, Jan. 14 -- Shoppers passing between children's bicycles and bedroom furniture in the modern Kaufhof department store these days find themselves staring at glass cases containing a cracked skull, murder weapons and other grim reminders of crime.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Jan. 24 -- Eighteen of 28 persons charged with murder in the recent abortive revolt in southern Guyana were freed today after the prosecution withdrew charges against them. All but one were whisked away from the magistrate's court under armed guard and put aboard a plane for the Rupununi area, scene of the uprising.

Stephen E. Kaufman, assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, and chief of the criminal division, has resigned his post to join the investment banking firm of L. M. Rosenthal Co., Inc., here.

ROME, Jan. 24 -- Hopeful things can happen here even after a week of soggy (some say insipid) spring-summer haute couture collections by Rome's most important and expensive designers. Something hopeful happened, as many things do, at lunchtime in Nino's, the restaurant here on Via Borgognona, where the beggest butterflies in the Italian fashion world brush wings.

Music that deliberately memorializes war is seldom as effective as that which unconsciously reflects a war period during which it is written. Shostakovich's Piano Trio in E minor (Op. 67) is a product of 1944, and with smaler means is more bleaky expressive of the Soviet experience during World War II than the same composer's huge "Leningrad" Symphony of 1941.
The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday a rise in 1968 earnings and proposed a two-for-one split of its common stock, on which the dividend rate would be increased.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The West German Porsche factory swept top honors today in the 1969 Monte Carlo auto rally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- The appointment of Creed C. Black, executive editor of The Chicago Daily News, as Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare for legislation was disclosed today.

PRAGUE, Jan. 24 -- Thousands of Czechoslovaks filed calmly today past the bier of Jan Palach, who committed suicide by fire to protest the Soviet occupation. The calm contrasted with nervous official statements indicating fear that his funeral tomorrow might produce violence.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24 -Baltimore showed its enormous gratitude tonight to Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, a native son and former Governor, for breaking the 180-year-old hex that had denied a Marylander a top place in the executive branch of the Federal Government.

The choreographer Stuart Hodes is an old-fashioned storyteller who makes the audience use its own imagination and gains thereby. Last night, at the Music Box, the Harkness Ballet presented his "Abyss" for the first time this season and demonstrated that the offstage horror is far more effective dramatically than the sweaty reality.

Perseverance appears to have paid off for the North American Rockwell Corporation, which announced yesterday preliminary agreement on a merger with Miehle-Goss-Dexter, Inc., in a deal of approximately $211-million.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 24 -- Brian Faulkner resigned as Deputy Prime Minister today in an angry exchange of letters with Prime Minister Terence O'Neill.

MEMPHIS, Jan. 24 -- Dr. M. M. Thomas, chairman of the central committee of the World Council of Churches, today urged religious leaders to help guide the "fermenting" world-wide social revolution toward a global Christian community transcending political systems land class structures.

The Jan. 6 letter from Frederick L. Strong criticizes The Times for its support of Maine's proposal to locate an oil refinery in a foreign trade zone in Machiasport. Mr. Strong suggests that The Times has been unfaithful to its normally strong conservationist outlook.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 24 -- The acting charge d'affaires of the Chinese Communist diplomatic mission in The Hague resigned his post today and asked Dutch authorities for permission to remain in the Netherlands.
The bond market displayed a mixed pattern yesterday, ending a week in which interest rates changed very little.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y. -- This glass box, this house, this glittering shelter set in a snowy wood, is home to Rita and Augustus Aldo Mino and their four alley cats -- Misu, Coco, Busy and Puddy.

Two members of the Black Panther party, accused of carrying concealed, fully loaded pistols as they were about to board a San Francisco-bound jetliner, were held in $50,000 bail each yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

Public Television is crackling with static -- an uncertainty about objectives, a dissonance of conflicting interests, a plethora of double-images. Unless the confusions are resolved, it will surely languish and possibly perish.

THE exhibition entitled "1969: Twelve Afro- American Artists," which opened this week at the Lee Nordness Galleries, 236 East 75th Street, proves once again the futility of categorizing contemporary works of art according to the racial origin of the artists who produce them.
Conflicting views on the merits of bigness in business were presented yesterday by the top officers of two leading conglomerate companies and an official of the Justice Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird has been urged to conduct a $1-million study of the feasibility of ending the draft in favor of an all-volunteer military force, Pentagon sources said today.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam arrived here from Saigon today and said that "peace can be restored as soon as the Communists abandon their scheme of expansion by force."
MIAMI, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- A National Airlines 727 jet carrying 47 persons from Key West to Miami was hijacked today by "a kid with a knife" who ordered the plane to Havana.

In the case of the four reinstated Ocean Hill-Brownsville principals, the Court of Appeals took the position that a new job classification had been created -- to wit, demonstration-principals, for which "the ability to run a more community-centered school" would be added as a qualification.

Robert V. Roosa, former Under Secretary of the Treasury and a widely respected authority on international money matters, ticked off a lengthy list of problems and crises yesterday, but optimistically said it was wrong to think the system was disintegrating.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 -- The last of the 12 jurors was seated today for the first-degree murder trial of Sirhan Bishara Sirhan.
To Miss Connie Liguori, who has worked in the mail and telephone room for 38 years, "It's shocking to think of the predicament we're all in."
See what can happen to a New York girl, 18 years old, not long out of Julia Richman High School, former national president of the Barbra Streisand fan clubs?

The Federal Bureau of Railroad Safety sent a team of inspectors to the Jamaica yards of the Long Island Rail Road yesterday to look into safety conditions on the line, Representative Lester L. Wolff's office announced.

Ten special matinee performances of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" will be presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for students of the New York metropolitan area. The series will be sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild in cooperation with the Brooklyn Academy, and the performers will be from the Metropolitan Opera Studio and the Hudson Valley Philharmonic Orchestra under the musical direction of George Schick. The opera will be sung in English.

CHULAI, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- A heavy United States force, which had been beaten back for three days by a tenacious band of some 200 enemy soldiers, has overrun and wiped out the defenders of a fortified village, a United States military spokesman said today.

THE Mannes College of Music believes that its performance last night of Chabrier's "L'Etoile" was the first in New York, and it probably was. Chabrier is not a composer heard hereabouts very often, and his operas and operettas are an unknown quantity here.
LISBON, Jan. 24 -- Portugal's Minister of Interior has served notice that the Government would not tolerate a disorderly election year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Nixon took pains today to give his most controversial Cabinet nominee, Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska, a warm welcome as his Secretary of the Interior.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Five Senators, including J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, called on the Nixon Administration today to use the scheduled meeting with the Chinese Communists in Warsaw next month to signal the start of a new China policy.

Francis X. Smith, President of the City Council, and Bernard Botein, retired Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, urged immediate action yesterday to meet increasing acts and expressions of anti-Semitism.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Nixon Administration enters the expanded Vietnam talks in Paris tomorrow without having settled on any long-term negotiating strategy.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Trailing by as much as 25 yards during the race, Sam Bair overtook Jurgen May in the stretch and won a memorable one-mile race tonight in the Philadelphia Track Classic at Convention Hall.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The General Foods Corporation, the $1.7-billion producer of packaged foods, was formally rebuffed today by Rowntree Co. in its efforts to buy out the important British producer of chocolates and confectionery.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Senator Philip A. Hart of Michigan is drafting legislation for the establishment of a grassroots arbitration system to settle disputes between merchants and consumers.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge ruled today that Ronald Sullivan, a reporter for The New York Times, must tell a Hudson County grand jury "if there exists any source, other than himself" for an article that asserted "witnesses saw bets being taken" in the County Prosecutor's office.
Thinking back 40 years to the time when she was young and a tap dancer in the Brown Skin Revue, Ophelia Hill started to sing, "I'm saving up my means to go back to New Orleans."

The Navy court of inquiry into the seizure of the Pueblo off North Korea a year ago has now degenerated into a personalized inquiry into the conduct of Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher, the skipper who gave up his ship.

PANAMA, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- The Italian Cruise liner Fair-sea, carrving 986 passengers, was adrift without power today about 1,000 miles off Panama in the Pacific. The 13,317-ton ship was reported to be in no immediate danger.
IT is common knowledge that Warner Brothers-Seven Arts, Ltd., is a hot take-over candidate -- the stock closed up 11 3/8 to 56 for the week -but the question is: Merger with whom?

KARACHI, Jan. 24 (AP) -A member of the West Pakistan Legislative Assembly resigned last night and said he would work with Mohammad Asghar Khan in his campaign for the presidency against the Marshal Ayub.
Franklin K. Lane High School will reopen Monday at 8 A.M. with a shorter day than in the past and tighter security measures.

GENEVA, Jan. 24 -- Members of the United Nations Narcotics Commission, responding to Sweden's plea for urgent action, agreed today to ask governments to impose strict controls on the use of amphetamines.

The charges by Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold of large-scale pilferage on the borough's piers have a familiar ring. The reported scale of the thefts, the complicity of guards and the suggestion of loan-sharking and other rackets are all echoes of the testimony before the State Crime Commission in its classic investigation in 1952-53.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Two hundred suburbanites crowded into a school auditorium the other evening to voice, sometimes in shouts, their frustrated involvement in one of Westchester's most ubiquitous problems: garbage disposal.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- The twin miseries of faulty execution and a short-handed bench continued to plague the New York Knickerbockers tonight as they bowed to the Detroit Pistons, 107-106, in a fiercely contested National Basketball Association game at Cobo Arena.

American rowing, the country's oldest intercollegiate sport (it dates to 1852), is 10 years behind the rest of the world, according to Thomas Keller, a Swiss businessman from Zurich who heads the International Rowing Federation.
Leaders of the Roman Catholic "left" in Latin America opened a three-day conference here yesterday under the auspices of the United States National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Senator Peter H. Dominick, Republican of Colorado, charged today that the Navy was trying to blame Commander Bucher for the Pueblo affair rather than the officials who denied him the means to destroy the ship's secret equipment.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Enemy gunners shot down two United States helicopters, one of them a Marine regimental command craft and the other a medical helicopter, in separate incidents that killed 15 American servicemen, military spokesmen reported today.
A 26-year-old Cuban refugee went to sea from New York yesterday on his fourth stowaway voyage in 15 months, still hoping that his roundabout route would lead eventually to life in America.

MEGEVE, France, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Henri Duvillard, the latest French skiing sensation, thwarted Austria's favored forces today as he hurtled an icy course and won the "Emile Allais" downhill race at an international meet.
The city is planning to reduce the fees charged in the clinics and emergency rooms in the 19 municipal hospitals next month.

Stern Brothers, the 102-year-old Manhattan department store that has drawn white-collar executives and office girls in to shop during the noon hour, but not enough other customers, will close May 1 because of continuing losses.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Ambassador Gunnar V. Jarring will return here Monday for consultations with Secretary General Thant and the representatives of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union on a stronger role for the United Nations in the quest for peace in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Federal Government has agreed to sell the Brooklyn Navy Yard to New York City for $22.5-million, $1-million below a previous tentative agreement that the Government had rejected as too low.

THE Metropolitan Opera has long needed a new production of Richard Strauss's "Rosenkavalier." It also has needed a cast that was strong down the line. Thursday night it received both. Happy days are here again.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 24 -- Tears welled up in the eyes of the Indian President, the Prime Minister and the Vice President, as well as many others in the large and distinguished audience as Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. sang "We Shall Overcome."

BRUSSELS, Jan. 24 -- France and West Germany are understood to want to exclude American subsidiaries from newly proposed Common Market directives that would eliminate obstacles in mergers across frontiers.
PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The Bank of France has quietly moved to recapture $500-million from the New York money market.

MADRID, Jan. 24 -- The Spanish Government, hitting back hard at signs of growing opposition, announced today that the country was being placed under a "state of exception," under which five articles of the Constitution were being suspended.

THE Soviet grandmaster, Viktor Korchnoi, reverting to his invincible form, topped the recent 18man round robin at Mallorca, Spain. PARIS -- After two months of haggling about conference tables that smacked of the Theater of the Absurd, the Paris conference on Vietnam has finally begun talking about the essence of the war's problems. The expanded negotiations opened yesterday, with a new United States team at the huge round table.

A boat that puts its owner afloat for $50 is the Kayak Corporation's Tahiti K-56, an inflatable one-man, kayak type designed for surf riding, but also useful for just paddling. The boat is 7 feet long and weighs 8 pounds. A foot pump for quick inflation costs $2.25 and paddle $7.50.

QUESTA, N. M. -- Several times on early morning scrambles into the Rio Grande gorge west of here, I have heard the eerie, lonely honking of Canada geese up ahead and have started small flocks of mallards panicking up from the river. Always there have been some elusive mule deer, and now and then a half-wild horse or cow to crash through the brush, stirring up a clatter of jays.
