WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Agriculture Secretary Clifford M. Hardin will name Roy W. Lennartson, a Government administrator, to head the Agriculture Department's consumer and marketing service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Justice Department proposed today that the financially hard-pressed Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad be permitted to be sold to the Union Pacific Railroad, provided the Union Pacific agreed then to sell portions of the old Rock Island to other western railroads.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Nguyen Cao Ky, Vice President of South Vietnam, said today that he was prepared to conduct at a future time "private talks with the other side if they are willing."

Top city and state Democratic leaders have agreed to engage all elements of the party in drafting "a blueprint for urban development" that they believe will bring victory to this year's Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York City.
Two new contenders for the acquisition of Warner Bros.-Seven Arts, Ltd., appeared on the scene yesterday now that the National General Corporation is out of the picture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Five years ago, President Johnson turned off the lights on the White House lawn to save the taxpayers' money. Today, President Nixon said he had turned them on again to reduce crime in the neighborhood
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 27 -- Jersey City's striking school teachers voted overwhelmingly today to reject the Board of Education's latest salary increase proposal.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 27 -- The American Basketball Association agreed tonight to let Lew Alcindor play for any franchise he wants -- a decision that seemed to favor the New York Nets.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The American Bar Association's House of Delegates overrode the objections of the association's board of governors and the United States Solicitor General today and condemned "no fault" automobile insurance plans.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 27 -- According to the Baghdad radio, a large crowd of Iraqis stayed up all night to be on hand for the hangings at dawn today in Liberation Square.
Brooklyn's troubled Franklin K. Lane High School reopened yesterday without incident as policemen patrolled the corridors.
WALTHAM, Mass. -- For those persons worried about current unrest at universities, Prof. Henry D. Alken of Brandeis has words of cold comfort: Conflict is good for you.

DANIELLE HUNEBELLE, French producer and journalist, took sharp exception yesterday to the manner in which the Public Broadcast Laboratory had edited her film entitled "Negroes Next Door," seen Sunday night over Channel 13.
CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 18 -- In New Hampshire, as in many snow belt states, the Fish and Game Department is bearing the brunt of policing the activities of snowmobile operators.

CUERNAVACA, Mexico, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Five priests from the diocese of Cuernavaca protested today against the Vatican's action in prohibiting priests and members of religious orders from taking part in activities of the Center of Intercultural Documentation, of which Msgr. Ivan Illich, of the Archdiocese of New York, is the director.

Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday that he had called an emergency meeting of the union's executive council in an attempt to force a breakthrough in the 38-day-old waterfront strike along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Nixon made the following main points at his news conference today:
The state asked yesterday for dismissal of a suit to ban construction of the conrtoversial Westchester-Nassau bridge across Long Island Sound.

Spurred by increased demand for textile fibers, both sales and earnings improved last year for E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and for the Monsanto Company, the two large chemical concerns reported yesterday.
A 40-year-old English woman was accused of fraud yesterday in her widely publicized efforts to raise funds for starving children in Biafra.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 -- Little combat activity was reported in South Vietnam during the last 24 hours, but a battlefield accident killed seven United States Marines.
For more than 80 years the Forsyth Street neighborhood -- a nine-block patch on the Lower East Side -- has been a slum and a part of somebody's ghetto.
The completion of a small downtown park that was once praised by the Lindsay administration as "a great planning achievement" will be delayed at least until early 1980 by a holdout restaurant.
Thirty-five clergymen demanded yesterday that the Army drop charges against six soldiers scheduled to face court-martial today in San Francisco.
THE really surprising thing about the triumph of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the Billy Rose Theater last night was that Mr. Ailey has had to wait nearly a decade for the experience.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Courts in the United States may not undertake to judge whether or not a religious body has violated its own beliefs, the Supreme Court declared today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Federal efforts to improve education for the poor have decined over the last year despite awesome needs for reform in this area, according to a new national survey.
ATHENS, Jan. 27 -- Greek university students have been brought under a rigid "code of behavior," which the country's army-backed regime hopes will deter student agitation.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Assemblyman Vito P. Battista, who ran for Mayor of New York City in 1961 on the United Taxpayer party line, is expected to announce Thursday that he will seek the Republican nomination for Mayor this year.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 -- A city building inspector was selected tonight for the jury to try Clay L. Shaw, a retired New Orleans businessman, on a charge of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy in 1963.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Five persons were reported to have been killed in Pakistani rioting today, as the death toll in the last week of anti-Government disorders rose to more than 20.
The bond market reflected yesterday a cautious attitude on the part of purchasers and traders of fixed-income securities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills proposed today a new approach to limiting textile imports in order to avert mandatory, legislated import quotas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A brisk dispute broke out today over President Nixon's withdrawal of five judicial nominations sent to the Senate in the waning days of the Johnson Administration.
CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher said today that the court of inquiry into the seizure of the intelligence ship Pueblo was "completely fair."
Tommy Trotter, the racing secretary and handicapper for the New York Racing Association, yesterday released his list of stakes events for the New York thoroughbred campaign.
The President of the City Council, Francis X. Smith, said last night that if Mayor Lindsay did not call a "summit conference" of civic leaders to deal with racial tension, he would do so himself.
Cream, the British blues-rock group that found a home in the United States, has released its last album, "Goodbye."
Detectives raided what they called a leased drop for hijackers in Brooklyn yesterday and recovered more than $300,000 worth in merchandise.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 27 (AP) -- New and stiffer regulations proposed by the New York Stock Exchange would enable it to discipline member firms when needed, Robert W. Haack, president, said today.

LAS VEGAS, Jan. 27 -- The Stardust Hotel, said to be the largest resort hotel in the world, is being sold for about $15-million to the Parvin-Dohrmann Corporation, a Los Angeles-based restaurant supply company.
MOSCOW (AP) -- Soviet housewives, who often complain about the small size of their kitchens, are being offered as a model of the future an apartment with no kitchen at all.

MANILA, Jan. 27 -- President Ferdinand E. Marcos said in his State of the Nation message to Congress this afternoon that it has become "obvious" that the United States will withdraw militarily from Asia and that the Philippines has revised her defense plans and foreign policy accordingly.

It was a good day yesterday for the oil industry as the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the Gulf Oil Corporation, the Marathon Oil Company and the Union Oil Company each announced gains in earnings for 1968.

Armour Co. gained a suitor -- the Greyhound Corporation -- and lost a legal round against another one -- the General Host Corporation -- as the fight for control of the large Chicago-based meat packer widened yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Liza Minnelli, the daughter of Judy Garland, showed tonight that brave hostesses do not flinch. At a party in Drugstore 13 given by Menley James, the Philadelphia cosmetics manufacturers, to introduce a new make-up, Miss Minnelli welcomed hundreds of people -- French and American -- whom she had never met.

The Ad Hoc Committee for a Better Harlem demanded yesterday that the construction of a new state office building in Harlem be postponed until the plans were revised to include ample space for community programs.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- Detroit's public schools are threatened with an extended closing in the next school year unless they-receive extensive financial assistance, school leaders warned today.
A mother and her three young sons died in a fire that destroyed their home in Astoria, Queens, last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Fifteen to twenty million Americans, give or take a few, probably watched Richard Nixon's first news conference and it well may be that the impression they received will be lasting.

HOUSTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Two youths were charged today with killing a Houston man whose heart was later used in a transplant by Dr. Denton A. Cooley. Their attorney said he would contend the heart was removed before the victim was dead.

Audiences att he Metropolitan Opera are getting snappish. Historically a sedate group, inclined to treat failing artists with indulgence and famous for calmness in the face of musical disaster, Met audiences are beginning to pounce upon artists.

THE pole vaulting competition at the Olympic Games in Mexico City last October had been in progress for almost seven hours and Bob Seagren of the United States was weary. So were the other aerial acrobats because there never had been a vaulting competition in history to come close to this one.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Secretary General Thant today deplored the hanging of 14 persons in Iraq as an impediment to peace in the Middle East. His comment provoked a blunt rejoinder from Iraq, which said that the executions were "entirely an internal affair."

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The Lindsay administration has let it be known that it is amenable to some kind of compromise on school decentralization in the Legislature, and there are signs that a moderate plan has a fair chance of passage.
Oil shares were active again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but they were unable to spark any price momentum. The list was well mixed at the close.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Chuck Noll, defensive coach of the Baltimore Colts for the last three seasons, got his first job as head coach today when he was named to direct the Pittsburgh Steelers for the next three years. Salary terms were not disclosed.

An Iraqi Jew whose brother was one of those executed yesterday in Baghdad as an alleged spy for Israel said here that the 3,000 Jews remaining in Iraq faced dire circumstances that bordered on genocide.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Nixon proposed today that arms talks with the Soviet Union be linked with progress on political issues of concern to both nations, particularly on the Middle East.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union warned today that United States bombing of Vietnamese Communist supply lines in Laos could hamper the Paris peace talks and "spread the war."

A duo recital in which the musical high point turns out to be a solo may go against logic, but last night's program at Carnegie Recital Hall was such a one, and it suffered none for upsetting expectations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission to block mergers if the merging companies have made false statements to their shareholders in proxy statements.

ATLANTA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- National Communicable Disease Center officials said today that the largest outbreak of trichinosis in the United States in five years had occurred in Washington, Mo., a town of about 8,000. Forty-seven cases of the disease have been reported -- two-thirds as many as are usually reported in a year throughout the country, a spokesman said.

A Greenwich Village district leader, a former State Senator and a linen salesman have been recommended by their respective Democratic county organizations for interim terms as City Councilmen ending next Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, Jan 27 -- The Federal Reserve's open market committee voted by 11 to 1 at its Oct. 29 meeting to keep monetary policy unchangd, a report of the meeting disclosed today.
ONE young New York expert has an unusual distinction. Larry Edwards became the youngest life master in the American Bridge Association, an organization principally Negro, at the age of 16.
More than half the male student body at St. Michael's High School in Union City, N.J., is on the varsity basketball team and the other 12 boys join the girls as rooters.

The New York Knickerbockers, weakened and strengthened by events of the last week, tonight embark upon a 12-day National Basketball Association stretch that may well determine whether they will improve their fourth-place status in the league's Eastern Division.

If enough of the 13 teams ahead of them disregard that cliche about the college draft -- "We're taking the best available athlete regardless of position" -- and fill their needs instead, the New York Giants might have a shot at Joe Greene of North Texas State or Bill Stanfill of Georgia.

In a surprise announcement yesterday, Genesco, Inc., the country's largest apparel producer and retailer, announced that Ben H. Willingham, president and chief executive officer, would take a leave of absence because of a "continuing health problem" and that Franklin M. Jarman, an executive vice president, would succeed him.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 27 -- More than 200 policemen and a paramilitary unit armed with automatic rifles, tear-gas grenades, clubs and shields cleared Nairobi University today and evicted 1,200 students on the orders of President Jomo Kenyatta.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 27 -- The Soviet Union, after a long period of refusing to recognize the European Economic Community, has had its first contact with the community's Executive Commission.

When winter comes, even when it is uncertain whether spring training will be far behind, conscientious young baseball players keep themselves in condition for what the club owners like to refer to as a "seven-month occupation.'' At Shea Stadium these days, Bud Harrelson, Art Shamsky, Al Jackson and Don Shaw come around to do their off-season road work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, asked President Nixon today to amend the Uniform Code of Military Justice so servicemen in the position of the Pueblo crew could sign confessions with impunity.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The French Government disclosed today that it had pleaded unsuccessfully with the Iraqi Government to obtain clemency for the men executed on charges of espionage for Israel.
" Gee, look at the sleek lines of that Bertram," a man remarked yesterday on the second floor of the Coliseum where the 59th National Boat Show was in its third day of a nine-day run.

BURBANK, Calif., Jan. 27 -- The United States Forest Service announced today approval of a master plan of the Walt Disney organization for a $30-million year-round recreational development in the Mineral King Valley area of Sequoia National Forest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel asked his bureau directors today to bring him their best ideas without worrying too much about money at this stage.

ALTHOUGH custom decrees wariness bordering on high terror when confronted with Greeks beating gifts, there is little need for reserve toward the present Aristophanes prepared for delivery last night at the Astor Place Theatre on Lafayette Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Theodore C. Sorensen and the Democratic task force he heads have proposed major revisions in the state Election Law and changes in Democratic party procedures, with a view toward winning the statewide elections next year.
Gorilla Monsoon and Killer Kowalski beat Bruno Sammartino and Victor Rivera in two of three falls last night in the feature professional heavyweight wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 -- Shocked and angered by the execution at dawn of nine Iraqi Jews as traitors, Israeli leaders pleaded today for help in averting any further such executions.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Claude Schoenlank, a power hitter from Wagner, scored the most impressive victory today in the opening round of the Concord Hotel's annual intercollegiate indoor tennis tournament.
Three of the nation's major tire manufacturers replied yesterday to Senator Gaylord Nelson's accusations that they were violating the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1966.
PRAGUE, Jan. 27 -- Policemen scuffled with Czechoslovaks again today near St. Wenceslas Square and security officials reported that 199 persons were seized there yesterday during demonstrations.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Homeowners with shovels and brooms and city crewmen with bulldozers fought back today against mud and debris throughout flood ravaged Southern California after nine days of torrential rain had finally ended.

The University of Michigan has received a gift of $1.6-million for the construction of the Power Center for the Performing Arts at Ann Arbor. The donation brings contributions for the center to a total of $3-million, making it possible for construction to begin in March.
HONG KONG, Jan. 27 -- The Chinese Communist regime launched a new attack on President Nixon today in an abusive joint article in two official Peking publications.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- The Chrysler Corporation ordered today a sharp auto production cutback. But other car manufacturers say they are holding to present schedules and are not pulling back.

Changes "right down the line" in the treatment of anyone accused of minor offenses in the state will be recommended as the result of an inquiry into the arrest of four Long Island Rail Road commuters.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Mysterious "Friends of St. Gobain" were widely believed tonight to have fended off a take-over bid by buying from $150-million to $200-million of stock in the giant glass company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- A dramatic pyramidal office building 55 stories high, capped by a 240-foot spire, is to rise in San Francisco's financial district as the world headquarters of the Transamerica Corporation.

THE disintegration of a body politic and the defeat of noble aims are not exhilarating subjects to write about. Perhaps that is why the end of World War I in Germany -- the period covered in Richard M. Watt's "The Kings Depart" -- has not been the focus of many books.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 27 -- Ten cast members -- six men and four women -- who appeared nude onstage last night during a performance of "Dionysus in 69" were arrested after the show was given at the University of Michigan. The audience included policemen and state legislators.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- As official Soviet sources continue their silence on last Wednesday's shooting incident in the Kremlin, Muscovite rumormongers are having a field day.

A committee with the missionary purpose of persuading businessmen to put their money where their music is -- as well as their drama, dance and other arts -- held its second annual meeting yesterday and learned that its first results had been relatively penny ante.

Yale University's School of Drama is intensifying its recruiting to get black and other disadvantaged non-college graduates to take part in its acting program, which is being aided by a $150,000 grant from the Ford Foundation.

Rudy Perez has an ear as well as a choreographer's eye peeled for the significant and often bizarre nuances of the day. He is also a rigorously logical man who follows a train of thought even though it might lead him into roller skates or on top of a folding chair during the course of a dance.
The National Steel Corporation reported yesterday an increase in earnings to $4.65 a share for 1968 from $4.40 in 1967. But the gain was attributable to an accounting change.
The Interchemical Corporation has elected Frank B. Cameron and Dr. Russell N. Clark as executive vice presidents, it was announced yesterday. Both are members of the company's board of directors.

The heavy rains which have afflicted Southern California have produced a major human tragedy. President Nixon has properly made Federal disaster funds available to help overcome the effects of floods and mudslides which have caused 88 deaths and enormous losses to private homes and public property.

DELUGED by the cascade of strange hockey happenings in recent weeks, the average fan could finally relax yesterday, secure in the knowledge that there still were some old, comfortable values. The National Hockey League and the New York Rangers give an annual Lester Patrick Trophy for outstanding service to hockey in the United States.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 -- A hunger strike by a group of Arab women from the former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem went into its second night tonight in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, warned his colleagues today that the basic character of the Senate as a deliberative body might be changed unless they reached a compromise on the antifilibuster rule.

The 1,400-room Manhattan Hotel has been acquired by a European hotel group in a deal that gives the London-based company its first holding in the Western Hemisphere. The transaction will also give the 41-year-old hotel a new name and, its new owners say, a new character.

Against the background of his Inaugural Address a week earlier, the most disappointing section of President Nixon's press conference yesterday was his negative tone toward relations with Communist China. Though the question asked him did not require it, he chose to announce that this country's long opposition to the admission of Peking into the United Nations remains unchanged.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- As business becomes more centralized it takes on governmental power and it must guard against abusing that power, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

The directors of radio station WBAI-FM have rejected demands by a Jewish group that it eliminate all expressions of an anti-Semitic nature and that it dismiss Julius Lester, on whose program an anti-Semitic poem by a 15-year-old Negro girl was read last month.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 27 -- Rick Barry and 23 other players began arriving today for the American Basketball Association's All-Star game tomorrow night between the East and West squads.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Senate chamber, for more than 100 years a rumbling, mumbling cave of the winds, is poised on the brink of the electronic age.

A master plan for the City University approved by the State Board of Regents calls for the admission to the university of all city high school graduates who request admission by 1975 and for the creation of five new senior colleges.
Steel production rose 2.5 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
" Silver was lusterless yesterday," one broker noted as silver futures turned in a bleak showing, with only 726 contracts changing hands, the smallest volume traders can remember in a long time.
Hertz, Warner Co., a medium-sized brokerage firm, notified its branch managers and account executives yesterday that it planned a drastic reduction in its retail securities business.

HOUSTON, Jan. 27 -- The International Heart Gala at the new Neiman-Marcus store last night was far more than a merely extravagant dinner dance for hundreds of rich and elegant Texans. It was a rare gathering of heart surgeons, and they were a charismatic group indeed.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 26 -- In all of the Arab world, but especially in little Lebanon, where French is the second language, France is getting maximum mileage out of President de Gaulle's embargo on arms to Israel.

Our new Attorney General, John Mitchell, seems off to a bad start. In his initial news conference, as reported in The Times of Jan. 22, he urged two courses of conduct which are not merely repressive but unconstitutional.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
The first real indicators in the expected evolution from campaign oratory to Nixon foreign policy came in the new President's comments yesterday on missile talks with Moscow.
MINEOLA, L. I., Jan, 27 -- The state and the defense rested their cases today in the trial of Mrs. Shiela Pappas, who is accused of murdering her husband, Angelo, a restaurateur, in November, 1967.
Steel production rose 2.5 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
" Silver was lusterless yesterday," one broker noted as silver futures turned in a bleak showing, with only 726 contracts changing hands, the smallest volume traders can remember in a long time.
Hertz, Warner Co., a medium-sized brokerage firm, notified its branch managers and account executives yesterday that it planned a drastic reduction in its retail securities business.

HOUSTON, Jan. 27 -- The International Heart Gala at the new Neiman-Marcus store last night was far more than a merely extravagant dinner dance for hundreds of rich and elegant Texans. It was a rare gathering of heart surgeons, and they were a charismatic group indeed.

MADRID, Jan. 28 -- The Spanish Government moved today to stem what it called ridiculous reports in the foreign press about the severity of the repressive measures it is taking after proclaiming last Friday a "state of exception," the equivalent of a state of siege, short of martial law.
The election of John L. Loeb Jr. as chairman of the board of the Holly Sugar Corporation was announced yesterday. He succeeds Dennis O'Rourke, who has resigned.
A minister who earns $6,500 a year has invested $10,000 of his own cash to publish a book that browses lovingly through the history of the Northwest Bronx.
HAMDEN, Conn., Jan. 28 -Forty students were suspended from Hamden High School today in the investigation of a racial brawl that broke out yesterday in the school cafeteria.

A murmur of surprise greeted the declaration that the San Diego Chargers had chosen Marry Domres, Columbia quarterback, as their first choice in the professional football draft yesterday. Domres was the ninth player selected in the first round and the second quarterback.
MIAMI, Jan. 28 (AP) -- W. A. Lofton's Miss Danalee, the longest priced filly in the field, outfinished Li'l Puss by half a length today to win the seventh race at Hialeah before a crowd of 15,426.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that Louis H. Roddis Jr. would join the utility on April 2 as vice chairman and a member of the board. He formerly was director of nuclear activities for the General Public Utilities Corporation and chairman of the Pennsylvania Electric Company, one of the four companies in the General Public system.

SAIGON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -United States B-52 bombers dropped thousands of bombs today on a Central Highlands battlefield where South Vietnamese forces said they killed 320 enemy soldiers in a 27-hour battle over the weekend.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 28 (AP) -- The bells were right on cue today at the antinoise trial of the Tompkins County Savings Bank carillon.
HONG KONG, Jan. 28 -- Communist China's denunciation of President Nixon and the American system yesterday appeared to observers here today to be a calculated blow at detente with the United States.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- An all-University of Virginia final was assured today in the Concord Hotel's annual intercollegiate indoor tennis tournament.

GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross announced tonight that it would operate its relief airlift to Biafra from Cotonou, the capital of Dahomey, while continuing its efforts to persuade Equatorial Guinea to permit a resumption of flights from the island of Fernando Po.

"FIRE!" which sizzled damply for the first time at the Longacre Theater last night, is presumably a play about the human condition. The success of such a play is inevitably conditional upon its humanity, and humanity seemed among the chief of this allegory's deficiencies.
MOUNT MORRIS, Pa., Jan. 28 (AP) -- A dozen men battled heavy smoke deep in a burning coal mine today before their foreman found a rescue team, and they were led around the fire to safety.
A small oil painting by Paul Cezanne, "Portrait of a Child," has been acquired by the Wadsworth Atheneum of Hartford, one of the country's oldest museums.

The Department of the Army, acting on a Federal Court order, yesterday withheld a permit it had authorized on Monday for New York State to dredge and fill a portion of the Hudson River for a controversial riverside expressway.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 28 -Gov. Raymond P. Shafer proposed to the Legislature today a budget of $2.5-billion, a record, for the fiscal year 1970. He recommended $493-million in new taxes to balance the 25 per cent increase in spending.

TRENTON, Jan. 28 -- William E. Ozzard, a member of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners and a former New Jersey Senate Republican leader, announced his candidacy this afternoon for his party's nomination for Governor.
Holiday and Venture, look out! The American Express Company is out to make its newly acquired Travel Camera the nation's No. 1 travel magazine and is willing to spend to do it.
Trading was extremely active yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, but prices remained mixed.
Hopes for a settlement this week or the longshoremen's strike that has tied up drycargo shipping along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts for 39 days appeared dim yesterday.
Josephine Herbst, the novelist and critic, died yesterday of cancer at New York Hospital. She was 71 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -Key Senate leaders voiced guarded approval today of proposed legislation to enable New York City to acquire the Brooklyn Navy Yard at a reduced price.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The American citizen, aroused by the increasing number of airline hijackings, has come up with several cures -- some serious, some frivolous and most pretty unusual.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart expressed horror tonight at the hangings. He also voiced sympathy and concern for those awaiting trial.
Adelphi Hospital in Brooklyn rebuffed an attempt yesterday by a striking union to send its supporters back to work.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- O. J. Simpson said today he did not expect any contract trouble with the Buffalo Bills.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 28 (AP) -Peru's state oil agency took full control of the International Petroleum Company, Ltd., today and ordered its American officials to leave the country. The company is a Canadian subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Charles E. Fiero, director of the Office of Foreign Direct Investments, disclosed today that he would resign to rejoin the Chase Manhattan Bank.

The Rev. Wesley Shrader [letter Jan. 17] repeats the question, "Why this costly space race at the expense of medical and social progress?" As a former NASA scientist and presently professor of astronomy at West Connecticut State College I should like to answer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Secretary General Thant called on the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union today to exert "moral pressure" on the Arabs and Israelis to bring peace to the Middle East.

Deep differences over Yale University's policies toward professional theater on campus, student expression and faculty opportunities to dissent on school matters have led to the dismissal of Gordon Rogoff, head of the directing department, by Robert Brustein, dean of the School of Drama.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- John Havlicek stole the ball three times within 23 seconds early in the fourth period tonight to spark the Boston Celtics to a 108-96 National Basketball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks.
The City Council approved yesterday the spending of $28,962,000 to build a new Police Headquarters and make related improvements in the downtown Civic Center.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 28 (AP) -Minnesota's Republican Chairman, George Thiss, said today that Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota had used free mailing privileges to send out at least 25,000 copies of his book, "Limits of Power."

THE Hague Philharmonic, currently touring the United States, was heard last night in Carnegie Hall and sounded even better than it did on its last visit. It is an orchestra somewhat along the lines of its more famous cousin, the Amsterdam Concertgebouw -- a virtuoso ensemble that never stresses its virtuosity, capable of a deep, golden tone, with rich strings and top-notch solo players.
In his first White House news conference, President Nixon has followed quite closely the ideas of Dr. Henry Kissinger, his new foreign affairs adviser, on how to negotiate with the Russians.
Parishioners of the Brick Church and the Church of the Good Neighbor will present "Once Upon a Mattress" tomorrow evening at the Brick Church, Park Avenue at 91st Street.
Sports fans have heard of Nino Benvenuti. He is the middleweight boxing champion of the world. But very few people, other than knowledgeable boxing fans, have ever heard of Doyle Baird.
Roy Wilkins should be congratulated for speaking such sorely needed good sense in condemning the Jim Crow black separationist movement on campus. [Editorial Jan. 15.]

Jazz is taking root in the far western reaches of Greenwich Village, drifting in among the packing houses and trucking depots that dominate the area around 14th Street as it starts in from the Hudson River docks.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 23 -- A small group of Panamanians with more determination than equipment is keeping alive in the mountains and jungles of western Panama the only spark of physical resistance to Panama's military regime.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Jan. 28 -- The fans at Skateland today viewed Emile Francis as a star-spangled hero. They crowded around the Rangers' general manager after his squad worked out for tomorrow night's Madison Square Garden contest against the Detroit Red Wings.

The Consolidated Edison Company filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to recover triple damages from 13 contracting companies and nine individuals it accused of rigging bids submitted to the utility during the last decade.
WHEN Edward I. Koch, the Reform Democratic leader, vacated his City Council seat recently to go to Congress, it seemed almost inevitable that Carol Greitzer would succeed him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -The Democrats, emerging from eight years of reliance on White House leadership, do not see any prospect of confronting President Nixon with a unified party legislative program in Congress.

PRAGUE, Jan. 28 -- Jan Pelnar, Czechoslovak Minister of Interior, announced today a vaguely defined reorganization of the security forces apparently aimed at tightening control over this Soviet-occupied country.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 28 -- The Australian Wheat Board announced today an agreement to sell 2.2 million long tons of wheat worth $140-million to Communist China.

TIME was when the world manufacturers' championship was a private affair between Ferrari and Ford. No more. Both factories withdrew after the Federation International de l'Automobile changed the rules in the fall of 1967 by putting a 3-liter limit on the size of the en gines -- thitherto unlimited -- powering the Group 6 prototypes.
A new pop music group called Tomorrow will make its motion picture debut in a United Artists feature called "Tomorrow," Harry Saltzman and Don Kirshner, the co-producers announced here yesterday.

Every Jan. 30, when Roosevelt Day dinners and speeches observe the birthday of the New Yorker who served longer than any other President has or will, the city is reminded of a historical omission. There are monuments or statues galore to Presidents here but none for Franklin D. Roosevelt.

NOTHING less than the story of the human race, done as a sober caricature, now serious, now humorous, sometimes wordy, often rewarding, is the stuff of "Watch-Pit," a new play by Kit Jones now being offered by the Chelsea Theater Center at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

A BIG green bullfrog with bulging eyes sits on a lily pad in the center of a lacy white card and says: "Why! You don't mean to say 'you'll not marry me.' What next? As the frog said when his tail fell off."

Sharply higher earnings for 1968 were reported yesterday by thre major oil concerns -- the Standard Oil Company of California, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Hess Oil and Chemical Corporation.
The American Broadcasting Company has reduced from 26 to 3 the number of outside commentators and analysts for its evening newscasts.

Irish International Airlines, which has been leading an airline revolt against nine seats abreast in the forthcoming Boeing 747 jets (it has ordered 10 seats abreast and wants cheaper fares), gave up the fight yesterday -- temporarily.
This report on the Human Resources Administration was prepared by Richard Reeves, Barnard L. Collier, Richard Phalon and Richard Severo of The New York Times.

Mayor Lindsay's Urban Task Force is being expanded to improve community-city relations in changing and middle-income neighborhoods, in addition to its original mission in "communities identified by the police and the Youth Board as potentially explosive."
The International Longshoremen's Association yesterday asked President Nixon to intervene in the 40-day-old waterfront strike.

The Greater New York Fund announced yesterday that Theodore Pearson had been elected its president. He is a partner in the law firm here of Kelley Drye Newhall Maginnes Warren and had been vice chairman of the fund since 1963.
New York City Controller Mario A. Procaccino withdrew $30.01-million of tax-exempt housing bonds that were to be put up for bids yesterday because of the low state of the municipal bond market.
ROME, Jan. 29 -- Pope Paul VI said today that the execution of 14 persons convicted by Iraq of spying for Israel had aroused dismay and execration in the world.
Clifford Holland in his appraisal of the Middle East situation [Letter Jan. 27] seems to forget that a little historical perspective would be in order.
The selection of two more Yale players, a second Negro quarterback and three basketball stars marked yesterday's conclusion of the pro football draft at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The current wave of arrests and show trials in Iraq is interpreted by qualified Western specialists here as an outgrowth of the extreme instability and insecurity of Iraq's left-wing Baathist regime.
Warren Hinckle 3d resigned yesterday as president and editorial director of Rampart magazine amid efforts by the radical publication to reorganize.

ACOMPULSIVE horseplayer with years of distinguished pari-mutuel service disgraced himself the other day by trying to throw his wallet on the battlefield. "If you're interested in my welfare," the distraught bettor told the Colorado Racing Commission, "please ban me forever from your tracks."

TORONTO, Jan. 29 -- The head of an international mutual-fund network said today that citizens of the United States withdrew $2-million, or 40 per cent of their shares in the network, under a no-loss withdrawal opportunity insisted on by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The Board of Education suspended the local school board of District No. 1 on the Lower East Side last night for alleged failure to run its schools efficiently.

The Seaboard Coast Line Railroad reported yesterday a loss of $2,123,000 for the last quarter of 1968. This was in contrast to net income of $4,943,000, or 57 cents a common share, in the 1967 quarter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A blast of hot air from a compressor being used to start a jet aircraft engine is suspected of having set off the first of a series of explosions and fires aboard the nuclear - powered carrier Enterprise on Jan. 14, the Defense Department disclosed today.

Raph Doubell will return to Australia soon with a world record, a color television set, the memory of a kiss from Meredith MacRae and, he hopes, the Charles H. Howe Trophy for winning the 880-yard run in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 29 -- With army patrols on the streets of five major Pakistani cities, President Mohammad Ayub Khan was reported today to be ready to invite opposition leaders to confer with him on their demands for sweeping constitutional reforms.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29 -- There was a mysterious shooting incident in the capital of Iraq today involving a Syrian diplomat and it prompted a strong protest from the Syrian Government.

MIAMI, Jan. 29 -- It was one of those days at Hialeah. In the seventh race the South American wonder horse, Rafale, went off at 6-5 and finished seventh. In the next race, the $34,500 Mimosa Stakes, Tartan Farm's Ta Wee went off at 6-5 and just did manage to finish in the money as Florida-bred Nutty Donut scored.
When a teacher at Bushwick High School meets a wandering student in the halls and asks to see his program card, the student takes out the card and shows it.
The nation's shareholders increased by a record 2.5 million persons last year to 26.4 million, ccording to an estimate released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
Futures prices for wheat, sorn and soybeans continued in the doldrums yesterday.
Two large proposed corporate mergers were called off yesterday and another was delayed.

THE Sidney Lenz Memorial Trophy was won last week by Maureen Rosen and Calvin Cohen of New York. By scoring 70 per cent at the Duplicate Club of Brooklyn, they headed a field of 259 tables spread over 16 sites.

AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 29 -- Wind, rain and snowstorms, which swept over the eastern Mediterranean last night and today, have imposed a temporary peace on the Arabs and the Israelis. Not a single military action on the Jordanian border was reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The assembly of about 1,200 was a compatible mixture of Negroes, Jews, labor leaders, clergy and little old ladies who had put on furs and high heels for the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn urged the Federal Communications Commission today to use its "full powers" against radio station WBAI for permitting the expression of anti-Semitic views.
Airline representatives are meeting in New York this week to slice up a pie that they already know is too small to satisfy their appetites.
Several companies announced price increases on a variety of items yesterday.
SHAREHOLDERS of Defiance Industries, Inc., who have not had a chance to attend a stockholders get-together in three years, have taken the burning issue of annual meeting into their own hands.

Clive Rush, one of the New York Jets' assistant coaches who helped design the Super Bowl blueprint, has been offered the job as head coach of the Boston Patriots. He is expected to be named today at a news conference in Boston.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 29 -- A sudden trip to Europe by South Africa's Finance Minister, Nicolaas Diederichs, has raised conjecture that the world's biggest gold producer is running short of foreign exchange and needs to sell more gold.
Mayor Lindsay has promised that more new building projects will be started this year and next than in any comparable period in the city's history.
Despite their stature as members of the Super Bowl champions, several of the lesser known New York Jets appear to be in jeopardy for the 1969 season.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Japan Petroleum Development Corporation, and Tenneco, Inc., have broken off negotiations for joint production of petroleum from the Athabasca tar sands in Alberta, the Japanese concern said today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- The Russian TU-144 supersonic airliner did extremely well in its first series of tests Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- All the women are suddenly wearing transparent dresses this winter, but only in Vogue. This is because in Vogue we are in "the year of the anatomy" while, every place else, we are in the year of the spoilsport.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation is challenging an effort by Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., to take over the Piper Aircraft Corporation, one of the nation's leading manufacturers of private airplanes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The House Ways and Means Committee announced today that it would begin hearings next month on tax-exempt foundations as the first step in a re-examination of dozens of sections of the tax law that grant preferential treatment to certain persons or businesses.

Russell Lynes, the author and editor, took over the presidency of the MacDowell Colony yesterday on the retirement of Aaron Copland, the composer. Mr. Copland had held the post for the last seven years.

A NEW YORK master, Edmar Mednis, triumphantly returned to serious tournament play by winning the recent second annual Goldwater-Marshall invitation event. He had a score of 4-1 in the six-man, all-New York round-robin tourney.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Leaders of the Legislature are amenable to passage of a moderate abortion-reform bill that would allow abortion when the pregnancy would "materially impair" the mothers physical or mental health, according to high legislative sources.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 29 -- For the last three years the Rev. Ian Paisley of Belfast has participated in the annual Bible conference held by Bob Jones University, a fundamentalist institution in Greenville, S. C.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- The Bank of America disclosed today that it had become the trustee of nearly $300-million in stock owned by David R. Packard, the new Deputy Secretary of Defense, and his wife, Lucile.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission announced its opposition today to a proposed acquisition of the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company by the American Electric Power Company.

The fact that Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher of the Navy is telling us something which we did not know before makes his intelligence mission more complete than what it started out to be. Physically and emotionally battered, yet still supporting profound courage for his men and his country, Commander Bucher has returned to warn us about a grotesque enemy which stands against men and human dignity.

Harold Stirling Vanderbilt, almost a revered figure in American yachting, was awarded the Nathaniel G. Herreshoff Trophy last night for his accomplishments. The award was made public at a dinner that followed the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union at the Essex House.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 29 -- Israeli officials are consulting with friendly governments and international organizations over ways to help the Jewish community in Iraq, which they believe is seriously threatened.

Richard F. Sonneborn, president and director of the Mohawk Brush Company, a subsidiary of the Fuller Brush Company, has been named first vice president of the Fuller Brush Company. Fuller Brush merged recently with Consolidated Foods Corporation of Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- General Manager George Selkirk and Jim Lemon, the field manager, were dismissed today from their jobs with the Washington Senators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The nation's surplus of exports over imports fell last year to the lowest level since the Depression of the Thirties -- and it would have been a deficit if exports paid for by government aid programs had been decided.
A major realignment of management at the Union Camp Corporation was announced yesterday.

The Council of Churches of New York City has filed suit charging 22 individuals with illegally withholding $185,025 collected from the last council-sponsored awards dinner of the Society for the Family of Man.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29 -- Crowds in Baghdad took to the streets today to protest Britain's official condemnation of the execution Monday of 14 Iraqis as spies for Israel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The State Department disclosed today that Paul Bail, an American oil technician, and his wife had been arrested in Iraq on unspecified charges.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 29 -- In his first "State of the Commonwealth" message before the legislature today, Gov. Luis A. Ferre of Puerto Rico proposed that incoming industries be required to pay Federal minimum wage levels in exchange for tax exemption.

CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 29 -- Rear Adm. Frank L. Johnson, former chief of United States naval forces in Japan, said today that there were "no forces" in his command to help the intelligence ship Pueblo when she was seized by North Korea last January.
A bill designed to make life more pleasant for elderly people on the New York Thruway has been filed in the State Legislature.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 -- A blanket of snow added today to the danger and discomfort that has descended on this region after more than a week of heavy rains.

The Ford Foundation has asked City University to review its relationship with a community committee in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section that is headed by Albert Vann, an administrator in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville district and president of the African-American Teachers Association.
The owners of the 6,800 fleet taxicabs here reported yesterday that there had been a sharp decline in the number of assaults and robberies on cab drivers in the second half of 1968.

The open Navy court of inquiry into the seizure of the intelligence ship Pueblo is producing useful evidence on the risks and confusions created by new types of ships engaged in new styles of missions under new conditions of undeclared war.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Assembly Minority Leader Stanley Steingut accused Governor Rockefeller today of proposing a socially retrogressive state fiscal plan for 1968-1970.
TRENTON, Jan. 29 -- Frank McDermott, the State Senate president and a genial, self-styled "Brand X" contender, today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor.
NEW ASHFORD, Mass., Jan. 29 -- "Sixty years ago you went skiing alone," said 72-year-old Francis Head today. "Nobody else would risk his neck."

Performances of the Bruckner Sixth Symphony are not common, and glorious performances of it are rarer still; so the glorious performance last night by the Hague Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall must be noted.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Nixon's first request to the Democratic-controlled Congress will be to restore Presidential authority to reorganize the executive branch of the Federal Government.
The Dodge Index of nationwide construction activity declined in December for the second consecutive month, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

The Federal Railroad Administration informed Representative Lester L. Wolff yesterday that its inspectors had found no evidence of unsafe equipment or of falsified safety records on the Long Island Rail Road.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that outstanding letters of credit for Latin America confirmed by 11 reporting banks here rose by $24.6-million last month, to $346.6-million, the highest level since the record of $396.2-million set in July, 1947.

Out of professional football's draft of 442 college players, which ended yesterday, the New York Giants hope they acquired the pass-rusher that they seek and that's about it. Anything else they gain from the selections will be considered a bonus.

The city has bought peace with its police force in the fashion that has become depressingly familiar to New Yorkers. Faced with the threat of slowdowns and other disruptions of law-enforcement after membership rejection of a generous initial settlement, the city has put a lot more money into the wage pot.

About a half-dozen babies born to drug-taking mothers in the last six months are believed to have the same type of limb deformities known to result from the ingestion of thalidomide in early pregnancy, a birth defects expert reported yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP) -- An arbitrator has upheld The Detroit News's dismissal of seven men who distributed an interim newspaper in a 267-day strike that shut down the city's two dailies in 1967-68.
Volkswagen, the German auto manufacturer that found success in the United States by defying Detroit's folklore, is going to imitate General Motors Corporation's marketing practice.
MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 29 -- A 12-member, all-male jury started its deliberations tonight on the innocence or guilt of Mrs. Sheila Pappas, who is accused of murdering her husband in November, 1967.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Senate minority leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, said today that some resistance was building up in the Senate against immediate action on the nuclear treaty because of fear that the Soviet Union might be planning military action against Rumania.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Len Wilkens's 7 points in the overtime period led the Seattle Supersonics to a 124-122 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
The city's Board of Education, by a vote of 7 to 3, approved its school decentralization plan last night for submission to state authorities.

Two new Broadway productions, "Here Lies Jeremy Troy" and "The Gingham Dog," were announced yesterday. The former, a comedy by Jack Sharkey, is due March 25. "The Gingham Dog," a drama by Lanford Wilson, will be presented in April. Theaters have not been selected.

Pens scratching in notebooks, 17 upstate college students listened solemnly to a lecture in Manhattan on modern art the other day, then frowned even more solemnly as they wrote down abstruse subway directions to an out-of-the-way gallery in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Officials in the Nixon Administration are quietly examining legal precedents, political realities and their consciences this week as they consider how to deal with arrested persons who appear likely to continue to rob, rape or riot if they are released pending their trials.

MORE, I suppose, than any other modern dance company, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater belongs to Broadway. Jackie Robinson said yesterdayl that President Nixon was "on a collision course" with the black and Spanish-American minorities if he did not continue the loan assistance for the slums that was started by the Small Business Administration.

MADRID, Jan. 29 -- The proclamation of a "state of exception" in Spain last Friday followed warnings that military discipline would be endangered unless drastic action was taken, reliable sources said today.

A note seemingly indicative of defection in an American expedition during the race for the North Pole at the start of this century has been found by Russian explorers on Rudolf Island, northernmost point in Soviet territory.

The Illinois Central Railroad denied yesterday that any control relationship exists between it and the Union Pacific Railroad. The denial was an answer to a published report that the Chicago North Western Railway was seeking subpoena powers to prove its contention that the Union Pacific and certain related interests actually control the Illinois Central.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Matthew Rubino, termed in Congressional testimony "one of the big men" in Mafia operation's in Detroit was found guilty today of evading $130,129 in income taxes from 1958 through 1961.

Worldwide condemnation of the barbaric public executions and continuing secret trials in Iraq should provide useful lessons to both sides in the Arab-Israeli conflict and to those who seek to promote a peaceful settlement in the area.
American Telephone, bluest of the stolid blue chips, came to life yesterday as the general market continued an indecisive course.
Arthur J. Goldberg emerged late yesterday as the leader of a unity drive among state and city Democrats.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30 -- Iraq angrily assailed Arab information organs today over what was described as a failure to support her against worldwide criticism of the hanging of 14 Iraqis last Monday as spies for Israel.

Publication of the Board of Education's final decentralization proposals moves the reform of the city's school system one step closer to implementation. The specific aspects of the Board's blueprint are discussed below, but it is imperative first to reaffirm the need for reorganizing the city's public education in ways that will give parents a greater involvement in their neighborhood schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Nixon Administration, in office for less than a fortnight, is trying to avoid being drawn into a quarrel with the military regime in Peru. According to several experts here, however, Peru appears to be spoiling for a fight.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30 -- Lebanon announced today that she would take steps to strengthen her defenses against Israel.

Manhattan Cable Television will begin to originate programing on Channel 6 tonight with an 8 P.M. live broadcast of the Columbia-Brown basketball game. The game will be followed by the taped proceedings of a public hearing on the City's capital budget conducted Tuesday night by Planning Board Number 3. (for the Lower East Side).
City streets glistened again yesterday under a thin rain, but except in outlying areas there was no repetition of the icing that crippled transportation and rendered walking perilous on Wednesday.

The fight for control of Armour Co. intensified yesterday as the Greyhound Corporation raised its bid for the meat packer's stock and announced that it now owns more than 1 million shares of Armour stock.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 30 -- J. L. (Jake) McCandless, an assistant to Dick Colman for the last 11 seasons, was named today to succeed Colman as head football coach at Princeton University, effective July 1.

Paced by strength in some higher-priced blue chips, popular stock averages managed yesterday to post uniform gains for the first time this week. The Big Board, showing 641 advances and 698 declines, continued its indecisive pattern of recent sessions.
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 30 -- Israeli aircraft were reported by the Iraqi radio today to have swept over Jordanian territory three times during the day and attacked one position.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Allen W. Dulles, Director of Central Intelligence from 1953 to 1961, died last night in Georgetown University Hospital. He was 75 years old.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- Policemen on foot and horseback broke up a demonstration by striking students at San Francisco State College today and chased some of them two blocks from the campus.

PRAGUE, Jan. 30 -- Under renewed Soviet pressure, the Czechoslovak leadership has decided to remove about 120 reform-minded journalists in another effort to establish complete control over publishing and broadcasting, informed sources said today.

A psychologist at Rockefeller University has demonstrated that animals can learn to control such automatic responses as heart rate, blood pressure, glandular secretions and brain waves in responses to rewards and punishment, just as a dog learns to heel and beg.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Throughout a superb boxing career, Emile Griffith has gone his way with a light heart, a winning smile and even some acceptance of the black man's lot in the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Representative Allard K. Lowenstein of Nassau County, L. I., the newest member of the House Agriculture Committee, was assigned today to the Subcommittee on Oilseeds and Rice. He promptly got off it.

PARIS -- A kind of blind man's buff is under way between Communist China and the United States in an effort to improve their relationships. This tentative and uncertain process gives the willies to Moscow, which dislikes Peking as much as Peking dislikes it and which fears Chinese territorial claims along a lengthy, disputed frontier.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30 -- The city's 35 public schools reopened on a tentative basis today as striking teachers agreed to a "cooling-off" period while negotiations resumed under the guidance of Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator.

New York City's budget tax loophole, the vast holdings of real estate on which no property taxes are paid, will never be entirely sealed. But the acute shortage of tax revenues has spurred Finance Administrator Fioravante G. Perrotta to actions that should close at least a small part of this drain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that the United States, by moving ahead with the Sentinel antiballistic-missile system, would strengthen its bargaining position in possible talks with the Soviet Union on limiting missiles.
TWO into one traditionally -- so they tell me -- does not make two. Yet the Murray Louis Company, for years an autonomous yet integral part of the Alwin Nikolais company, has now broken away.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI) -- A huge oil slick, oozing from an offshore well, spread across an 8-by-20-mile area of the Pacific off Southern California today, threatening sea life and beaches.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin. introduced today a bill designed to protect people from tile "doWnright malicious gossip and hearsay" and other abuses in SOmE credit rating reports. The measure seeks to insure the accuracy, relevance and confidential nature nf information in credit reports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Nixon has ordered the Defense Department to devise a "detailed plan" to replace the military draft with an all-volunteer Army when expenditures in Vietnam have been "substantially reduced," the White House announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- In a move to force brokerage firms to catch up on their backlogs of paperwork, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a more restrictive rule regarding the computation of net capital for firms that have failed to deliver securities.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 24 -- To the frustration of some of its white liberal administrators, Wesleyan University is getting unsettling returns from an investment in racial diversity.

Leonard Bernstein will conduct the New York Philharmonic in scenes from Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" in a special benefit concert for the New York Philharmonic Pension Fund on Feb. 26. Soloists will be Eileen Farrell, Jess Thomas and Joanna Simon.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 30 (AP) -- The chief Republican spokesman on civil rights in the House introduced a bill today calling for a five-year extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

Music from Marlboro, that aristocrat of concert series, presented its second program of the season in Town Hall last night. In customary fashion, it presented four soloists associated with the Vermont summer music festival, who combined their talents in offering a varied sequence of masterpieces.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Walter P. Reuther and a committee of figures in medicine, economics and politics are preparing to fight for a complete reshaping of the system of American health care.
The Bell Aerosystems Company has released an artist's concept of a 100-ton ship that skims the ocean surface on a bubble of air.

A New York County grand jury yesterday charged 11 contractors and 12 companies with rigging bids on $16-million worth of contracts to do trenching and paving work for the Consolidated Edison Company in Westchester County.
The Penn Central system said yesterday that it had asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a 10 per cent increase in many long-distance fares, effective March 1.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Minnesota Pipers dismissed Jim Harding from his duties as coach of the American Basketball Association team today.

Three members of the Board of Education said yesterday that they would ask the State Legislature to adopt their proposal for decentralizing the city school system, rather than the board's official plan.
Several recently popular oil issues declined yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The market as a whole also closed on the downside.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 30 -- The all-male jury hearing the murder trial of Mrs. Sheila Pappas deliberated for a second day today without reaching a verdict. It was locked up for the night and will resume deliberations tomorrow.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Harbor View Farm's American Native beat Social Song by a neck today in the Whopper Purse at Hialeah Park. Stu Agogo was third and Fearless Night finished fourth.

BUFFALO NARROWS, Saskatchewan, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Seven persons -- four of them children -- were killed with an ax today in this remote Sree Indian community in northwestern Saskatchewan.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

ROME, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A crippled French nun, born in 1751, who founded a religious community that spread in Europe and to the United States was approved today for canonization by the Roman Catholic Church.

MONTREAL, Jan. 30 (AP) -- An American who flew on an unauthorized flight to Havana says he was told there that Cubans took "a bloody dim view" of hijackers, that some were imprisoned and others were sent to work camps.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- President Nixon has picked a cozy second-floor sitting room with a fireplace and a view of the Washington Monument as his personal workroom in the White House.
A Brooklyn jury announced late yesterday it had been unable to agree on a verdict in the case of a 29-year-old Negro man accused of assaulting the principal of Junior High School 117 in Brooklyn.
Assemblyman Vito P. Battista, for many years a battler for lower taxes and a variety of other causes, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for Mayor in the June primary.
Trading on the London Stock Exchange closed on a firm note yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 30 -- The Yale College faculty voted today to strip the Reserve Officers Training Corps of its academic standing here and relegate it to the status of an extracurricular activity.

The excitement of last October's Olympics will be renewed tonight at Madison Square Garden when 41 Olympian track and field athletes, including eight gold medalists, compete in the 62d annual Millrose Games.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 30 -- In his autobiography, "Friends, Not Masters," published in 1967, President Mohammad Ayub Khan writes that he has had only one "vested interest" -- "to save and protect the system for which I have sweated blood."

Each member of the Musical Arts Quintet, a woodwind ensemble that played last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is individually a capable performer. As a group, the musicians from Ball State University in Muncie, Ind., turned in a pleasant, straightforward job.
One of the first matters of importance for the new Administration is Senate consideration of the so-called "Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 -- In a game that had 11,500 fans screaming hysterically through the final seconds of play, the New York Knickerbockers built up a 22-point lead early in the third quarter, then held on to repulse the Baltimore Bullets, 109-106, in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at the Civic Center.

Daniel Melcher, chairman of the R. R. Bowker Company, a publishing concern which last year was merged into the Education Division of the Xerox Corporation, has resigned because he felt out of touch with his executive associates.
In an apparent response to pressures by the Uniformed Firemen's Association, Mayor Lindsay will propose $5,689,500 for new fire apparatus in his executive capital budget for 1969-70.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 -- The General Motors and Chrysler Corporations, Nos. 1 and 3 in the automobile business, yesterday reported record fourth-quarter sales and profits.

Michael J. Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association here, reported a forward step yesterday in a long campaign by firemen in the nation's larger cities to obtain a greater voice in the parent union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, appears to have staked out a middle course in his first decision on enforcement of the school desegregation guidelines.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Adnan Pachachi, Iraq's permanent representative at the United Nations, disclosed today that he had resigned. He denied that his resignation was connected with the spy trials and executions in his country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Will the American public ever see firsthand the "ugliest" thing that President Johnson ever saw? The answer may well be no.

Record sales and earnings in 1968 and an increase in the quarterly dividend were announced yesterday by the American Home Products Corporation. William F. Laporte, chairman, said the board had increased the dividend from 32 1/2 cents to 35 cents a share, payable March 1.
Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries achieved records in 1968 operating revenues, net income and volume sales of electricity, Gerald L. Andrus, president, reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 30 -- A Federal Government suit charging Parke, Davis Company, a drug maker, with discrimination in hiring was ended today by a consent decree. The decree, signed by a Federal judge said that the court made no finding on the merits of the case.

We've got three mildly weirdo advertising efforts to talk about this morning. Compton, with the help of an artist from Mad magazine (weird already, righ?), has created a subway campaign for L cigarettes that plays up the faults of some odd but common types of subway riders.
JUBA, the Sudan, Jan. 25 -- Samuel, John and Martin, all Christian tribesmen, were gloomy as they sat drinking marisa, the local beer of the Southern Sudan.
The appointment of four vice presidents, three of them senior officers, has been announced by the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, mortgage brokers.
The prices of most fixed-income securities retreated again yesterday in generally light trading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The United States has asked several third parties to use their influence with the Iraqi Government to obtain the release of two arrested Americans and to discourage further public executions.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Qualifying heats were completed this afternoon for 75 starting positions in a 250-mile road race tomorrow for the world championship of Formula Vees, the diminutive race cars based on Volkswagen components.
Heavy snows and low temperatures in the Pacific Northwest will reduce this week's West Coast plywood production to less than two-thirds of capacity, the American Plywood Assocation said yesterday.

In the opening days of his Administration, President Nixon has stated in unequivocal terms that his Administration will "continue to oppose Communist China's admission to the United Nations." There is a rather tragic irony in the fact that America's stanchest advocate of the hard anti-Communist posture may well be playing into the hands of the Soviet Union. [Editorial, Jan. 28.]

The National Conference of Catholic Bishops announced yesterday that for the first time in this country women could take an active part in the worship service of the Roman Catholic Church under certain circumstances.
The country's three largest department store and catalog chains have concluded their fiscal years with strong sales gains in January.

Marble donated by Italy for the walls of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington lies in the holds of ships immobilized by the longshoremen's strike. The daily loss to the center is $2,700, and the total cost so far is more than $50,000.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The South African Embassy in London confirmed today that South Africa was seeking to arrange to float a large loan on the European market later this year.
Leaders of Roman Catholic and Protestant relief agencies assisting Nigerian war victims yesterday denied in separate statements allegations that their help was politically motivated.
The appointments of John G. Duba as Administrator of the Municipal Services Administration and Frederic A. Davidson Jr. as Commissioner of Public Works were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The mail stopped, telephone operators remained home, the bank cashiers left their cages today.

Richard Roisman is correct in his Jan. 17 letter scoring the Metropolitan Taxi Board of Trade for its "scare" advertising campaign. But his assumption that the taxi industry should behave "as an industry" is naive.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 30 -- Observing the customary scenario of seasonal warfare in Laos, North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troops have recently taken the offensive in the mountainous region of Samneua and Xiengkhouang Provinces. Both have large non-Laotian populations and adjoin North Vietnam.
Air transport is getting so much international cargo diverted to it by the long dock strike that one airline has declared an embargo and other carriers report serious congestion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- Frederick C. Mitchell, publisher of Ramparts, declared today that the magazine would continue publishing despite the resignation of Warren Hinckle 3d, its president and editorial director.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- Two of the 27 young soldiers charged with a stockade mutiny at the Presidio of San Francisco came to trial today before a court-martial of seven officers.
PATERSON, N. J., Friday, Jan. 31 -- Four of 12 children in a family died in a fire that broke out in a three-story house here last night.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- Electric and Musical Industries, Ltd., claimed success in a 60-million ($144-million) take-over bid for the Associated British Picture Corporation, a large movie theater chain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Dr. Clarence C. Walton of Columbia University has been appointed president of the Catholic University of America.
The Union Pacific Railroad formed a holding company yesterday -- the Union Pacific Corporation.

ST. ANTON, Austria, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Annie Famose of France, the world's top woman skier and leader in the individual World Cup competition, was sidelined for the rest of the season today from injuries suffered in a bad fall during a practice run.
PETER HUTCHINGS of New York and Michael Libman of Fort Lee, N. J., had the best score in games played here Monday night in aid of the American Contract Bridge League's International Team Fund.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Nearly 300 students occupied the University of Chicago's administration building today in a protest against the university's refusal to rehire a sociology teacher.

At the heart of the Board of Education's specific plan is the effort to accomplish a workable balance between the decentralized districts' right to choose suitable personnel and the professional staff's legitimate concern over job security, due process and vigilantism.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 (AP) -- From 15 to 30 American B-52 bombers have been attacking Communist supply routes through Laos each day, and some have been hitting Laotian areas north of the 17th Parallel, United States military sources said today.
MANILUS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- One of the Penn Central's cabooses is missing -- and Peter Brown, a 40-year-old restaurant owner here, doesn't think it's a laughing matter.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, bowing to pressures from Mayor Lindsay and other political leaders and Jewish organizations, yesterday withdrew its "Harlem on My Mind" exhibition catalogue, which had been attacked as anti-Semitic.
Joseph P. Hoey, United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, was appointed yesterday as chief counsel to the City Council committee investigating the Human Resources Administration.
With a realistic promise to strive for improvement rather than "instant success," Clive Rush took command as head coach of the Boston Patriots yesterday.

CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 30 -- The naval court of inquiry into North Korea's capture of the U.S.S. Pueblo moved into closed session today, hearing testimony by an intelligence officer who has emerged as a key, and somewhat mysterious, figure in the case.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The arrival of a family of seven from Morocco has started a Jewish refugee movement to this city already jammed with Cuban exiles.

Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan moved yesterday to bolster the administration of School District 1 on the Lower East Side, where the local school board was suspended Wednesday night for its asserted inability to run the district efficiently.

In his first news conference as Secretary of Defense, Mel Laird said that the goal for U.S. nuclear strength was "sufficient power to deter the enemy," but he added, "I have not given up the idea of maintaining a superior force."

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller's special labor relations committee has recommended stiffer penalties for striking public-employe unions and their members, including unlimited fines against the unions.
TORONTO, Jan. 30 -- In an unannounced shift of policy, the Canadian Government has moved to keep deserters from the United States military service from finding a haven in Canada.
PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Hanoi and the Vietcong told the allies today that reduction of the fighting in South Vietnam must be tied to a political settlement.
A subsidiary formed yesterday by Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., appeared to be the framework for a spin-off in the L-T-V pattern of the company's holdings in the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.

VIENNA, Jan. 30 -- Hopes rose today in Roman Catholic circles that a solution might soon be found in the case of Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, who has spent the last 12 years in the United States Embassy in Budapest.
Joseph H. Murphy, the State Tax Commissioner, said yesterday that the tax burden could double within five years under present formulas.

ALTHOUGH rain drenched the metropolitan New York area yesterday and paid its damp respects to much of the northern snow country, ski area entrepreneurs were surprisingly optimistic about the weekend outlook.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30 -- The regular jury panels of all eight divisions of the New Orleans Criminal Courts were exhausted today without the selection of a complete jury to try Clay L. Shaw on a charge of conspiring to murder President Kennedy in 1963.
MONTREAL, Jan. 30 -- Man and His World, the successor to the Expo 67 World's Fair, will not reopen for the 1969 season.

ALTHOUGH rain drenched the metropolitan New York area yesterday and paid its damp respects to much of the northern snow country, ski area entrepreneurs were surprisingly optimistic about the weekend outlook.
