MIAMI, Jan. 30 -- Court-appointed attorneys for Willis Jessie, facing trial for his life in the air piracy of a private plane to Cuba, filed Federal Court motions today hinting at an unusual defense.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- A Soviet educator urged yesterday that schools and employers institute aptitude tests on a wide scale to insure proper allocation of manpower in the increasingly complex national economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A Government report made public today said that the key to violence in American society seemed to lie with the young, possibly with a relatively small number of them, whose identity science may be able to establish early for purposes of preventive action.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Federal mine inspectors have shut down underground mines more than 100 times since the Mannington, W. Va., mine disaster of Nov. 20, the Bureau of Mines said today.

CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 30 -- From the outset, the Navy has gone to great pains to explain that it is not trying Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher for surrendering the intelligence ship Pueblo or for signing a prison camp confession.
MONTREAL, Jan. 30 -- Man and His World, the successor to the Expo 67 World's Fair, will not reopen for the 1969 season.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 -- Sirhan Bishara Sirhan will take the witness stand next week to testify in support of a defense motion to set aside the first-degree murder indictment against him.
The credit policy instituted by the Federal Reserve in mid-December -- described as firmly but not drastically restrictive -- has begun to give clearer signs of starting to take hold.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 -- Allied casualties in the Vietnam war decreased slightly last week, statistics made public today showed.

Litchfield, to whom the torch had been passed.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- Communist sources said today that the 22d meeting of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, or Comecon, had concluded here with a stalemate on key issues: projected currency convertibility, price coordination and centralized direction of trade with the West.

IT MAY be like flogging a dead horse, especially in Leonard Bernstein's last season as music director of the New York Philharmonic and the season before acoustic renovations are to take place in Philharmonic Hall. But Mr. Bernstein led the Philharmonic last night in Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis," and it was a labor of love that was almost suicidal because of the properties of that unhappy auditorium.
More than 30 free performances of half a dozen plays are scheduled for off Broadway -- actually, all the way from. Greenwich Village to Morningside Heights -- between now and the first week of March.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 30 -- Continental central bankers are warning that tighter money policies may be needed to check inflation in their booming economies.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Scarves wind around everything from heads to hips. Waistlines sink lower and are looser. A low cardigan neckline shows lots of skin. Wide trousers have pleats. Culottes give dresses a big run for the money.
STATESBORO, Ga., Jan. 25 -- The big dog stopped in midstride and snapped into a beautiful point on the edge of the field.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The World Council of Churches moved today toward a new study of racial conflicts, "with particular emphasis on white racism."
BONN, Jan. 30 -- Student unrest flared anew in three major German cities today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, ordered today no easing of guidelines, no special concessions and no wavering in efforts to help five Southern school districts comply with the Federal school desegregation law.

The same Brown basketball team that gave Columbia its biggest fright of the season three weeks ago succumbed meekly to the Lions last night, 79-46, in an Ivy League contest in Columbia's bandbox gymnasium on Morningside Heights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Navy, applying some of the bitter lessons learned in the seizure of the spy ship Pueblo, is altering both mission procedures and equipment to try to prevent intelligence ships from falling into unfriendly hands in the future.

Tickets for the 24th week of the Metropolitan Opera season, which begins on Monday, Feb. 24, will go on sale at the company's Lincoln Center box-office at noon tomorrow. The schedule includes a nonsubscription performance of Puccini's "Tosca" on Saturday evening, March 1, with Leonie Rysanek appearing in the title role for the first time this season.
Several companies, mentioned yesterday in a report of a major copper discovery in Panama, deny knowledge of any new developments about the project which was announced last June.

TRUE to its tradition of bringing the best of new music to Lincoln Center that decade or so before Philharmonic Hall, or that century or so before the Met, the New York City Ballet last night revived George Balanchine's Xenakis ballet at the New York State Theater.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Navy reported today that the loss of the nuclear submarine Scorpion remained a mystery after months of study. It said, however, no evidence had been found indicating "foul play or sabotage."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP) -- A jury of six fathers today found a young ex-policeman, Robert Erler, guilty of the murder of 12-year-old Merilyn Clark, whose death Erler once investigated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Senator Charles E. Goodell announced plans today to fly to Nigeria and Biafra next Tuesday to aid the delivery of food supplies and to study "the critical problems of starvation in this area."

President Nixon has moved to fulfill a campaign promise by ordering the Defense Department to devise a "detailed plan" for replacing the military draft with an all-voluntary army when manpower requirements in Vietnam subside. The practicality of such an approach is unquestionably worth assessing anew, but it is important that no final decision be made without considering the strong arguments against a professional army raised in other high-level studies.

TOMORROW'S the day Sam Light puts on his cutaway and silk hat, picks up his gnarled acacia cane and ventures out to Gobbler's Knob. He won't be alone, in spite of the predawn hour; other, somewhat less resplendently attired companions will be along.
The Granite City Steel Company, of St. Louis, reported yesterday a net loss for 1968 of $6,660,000, the equivalent of $1.53 a share.

The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reported yesterday a surge in net earnings for 1968 to $94,724,361, equal to $3.33 a share. This is in contrast to $893,051, or 3 cents a share, earned the year before.
It was three-quarter time at the Waldorf-Astoria last night as 400 couples waltzed to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Vienna State Opera.

Is there anything more fascinating than a recital by a master guitarist? Answer: yes, a recital by two toaster guitarists. In the case of Pomponio and Zarate, who appeared last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, one should be more accurate and refer to them as a master and a mistress of the guitar.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 31 -- Jack Nicklaus took four putts today at the fourth green. He also equaled par with a 72 in the second round of the $150,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open, but his 72 for a total of 140 dropped him from the opening-round lead into second place.

SEATTLE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Fifteen-year-old Dawn Glab, skating despite a slight case of influenza, took a slender lead in the senior women's event of the national figure-skating championship here today.

BONN, Jan. 31 -- Fresh student violence erupted in Cologne, Frankfurt and Munich last night and today.
Governor Rockefeller called last night for a massive new Federal aid program to the states for education, amounting to $2.5-billion more each year until at least 1975.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Students at predominantly Negro Allen University said today "We have a dream" -- getting their school out of debt.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Four Englewood business concerns have been awarded $24,000 riot damage.

We appreciate the interest of The Times in the Committee for Economic Development's proposals for "financing a better electoral system," and Tom Wicker's excellent commentary column (Dec. 31) on them.

Forty-five students at the Harvard Medical School, who said they believed that "an unhealthy relationship exists between the drug industry and the medical profession," decided yesterday to return a $40 bag of diagnostic instruments that each had been given by a pharmaceutical company.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 31 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic has received a message about the situation in the Middle East from Leonid I. Brezhnev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, according to Al Ahram, the authoritative Cairo newspaper.

ST. ANTON, Austria, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- Olga Pall, the Austrian gas station attendant who won the Olympic downhill championship a year ago, captured the women's downhill ski race of the Arlberg-Kandahar meet today, when she defeated the silver medalist, Isabelle Mir of France.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Enemy gunners fired five large rockets into Hue early today on the first anniversary of the fierce battle for the central coastal Vietnamese city.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Lieut. Susan Schnall, a 25-year-old Navy nurse, accused of helping to throw antiwar leaflets from an airplane and participating in uniform in a "G.I. March for Peace," was convicted by a general court-martial today of conduct unbecoming an officer and of failing to obey an order.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Charles W. Yost, the United States representative, conferred again today with Dr. Jarring as part of the continuing negotiations on the Middle East.
Coach Red Holzman of the New York Knickerbockers, who like most professional coaches and managers says he plays his ball games one at a time, will have to double his rate this weekend.
CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 31 -- The Navy turned down last night a request to release the transcripts of the court of inquiry into the capture of the intelligence ship Pueblo.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- A State Supreme Court justice upheld today an order by the State Education Commissioner for a total integration of Mount Vernon's elementary schools through busing.

MIAMI, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- A gunman who said he was "tired of TV dinners and tired of seeing people starve in the world" diverted a National Airlines jet to Havana today -- the 11th hijacking of the year.

There are longer, wider and deeper canyons in the world, but none is so fantastic in form and color or so difficult to describe adequately.

ROCKY MOUNT, N. C., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Houston Mavericks announced last night the acquisition of Bob Verga, Levern Tart and Hank Whitney from the New York Nets in exchange for Willie Somerset and Leary, Lentz.
BOQUERON, P. R. -- This resort village on the southwest shore of Puerto Rico is probably about as far away from bustling San Juan as one can get and still be on the same island.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 1 -- Ceylon's tea crop last year was nearly nine million pounds more than in 1967.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- The Select Legislative Committee on Civil Disorder and Urban Problems proposed today a program for aiding education, housing and slum redevelopment that its chairman said might require a state income tax.

The pale, wintry sunlight of late afternoon shimmered across Nancy Forsdick's icy backyard last week as she walked down the path, swinging a dress on a hanger in a dry-cleaner's plastic bag. Like many housewives on their way home from work, she hurried a little to get out of the 23-degree cold into the warmth of her home.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 1 -Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy heads the list of women Americans admire most, the Gallup Poll reported today. The widow of Senator Robert Kennedy owes her selection in large measure to her great appeal with young adults reached in the survey.
VIENNA, Feb. 1 -- The manuscript of a fantasy for piano by Franz Schubert has been found and authenticated in Austria.

We quite agree with your Jan. 24 editorial "How Not to Reform the Draft." The bill introduced by Senator Mark Hatfield and others for its abolition as a means of recruitment for the armed services and replacement by all-volunteer personnel, is not the answer to the present need.

SYDNEY, Australia -- To many vacationists from the States, this city resembles San Francisco, for it has a burgeoning skyline, a bridge and a sparkling blue harbor. It is also a good place from which to head south to the snowfields during Australia's winter season (June, July and August), and the trip of about 200 miles is an easy one by airconditioned bus or by plane.

HONG KONG, Feb 1 -- The worldwide campus rebellion has spread to Hong Kong and created some concern that a student upheaval here could be exploited by the Communists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Defense Department is being caught in a pincer movement in the Senate. A bipartisan coalition is threatening to block the deployment of a ballistic missile defense system and to investigate the influence of what former President Dwight D. Eisenhower called the "military-industrial complex."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 1 -Demonstrators charging down Montevideo's main avenue this week, paused in front of the ticket office of Pan American World Airways long enough to smash its huge front window.

SAN DIEGO, Feb. 1 -- As an amateur, Gene Littler won the 1954 San Diego open and received a trophy as the pros shared in the $15,000 prize money. But today, Littler scored a 67, the low round of the tourney that now is the $150,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open and took the 54-hole lead with a total of 209.

Wyeth as the natural complements to such old favorites as "The Merry Adventures of Robin Hood" and "Treasure Island." The wistful, Pre-Raphaelite manner of Pyle's drawings and the sober drama of N. C. Wyeth's paintings seem to reflect perfectly the genteel, romantic flavor of late Victorian literature.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Gene Cantrell and Mickey Stratton were elected to the Hall of Fame yesterday by commissioners of the Amateur Softball Association of America.

HONG KONG, Feb. 1 -- Tsinghua University, Peking's main institution for engineering and other technological studies, has been given a passing grade after six months of rigorous political rectification under a worker - soldier propaganda team.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Feb 1 -- The Y-12 Plant, a sprawling industrial complex -- 170 buildings and 4.5 million square feet of floor space -is one of the big producers in the nation's nuclear energy program.

MOAB, Utah -- In a last-minute move that delighted outdoors-men and conservationists, infuriated oil and mining men, confounded cattle and sheep men and almost left Western Congressmen speechless, former President Lyndon B. Johnson doubled the size of Arches National Monument, enlarged Capitol Reef National Monument six fold and created a 26,000-acre Marble Canyon National Monument along the last unprotected stretch of the Colorado River in its cliff-girt journey from Lake Powell to Lake Mead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- United States economic aid to Colombia -- totaling $732-million from 1962 through 1968 -- has "fallen far short" of the social and economic goals of the Alliance for Progress and may even have "contributed to the postponement" of reforms in Colombia, Senator J. W. Fulbright charged here today.
HONG KONG, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Communist China and North Vietnam criticized President Nixon today saying his ideas on achieving peace in Vietnam were "deceptive talk."
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 31 -- For the last nine days, a young-looking Yale man with brown curly hair and a gentle manner has been Governor of the nation's seventh-largest state.

DELTA, Utah, Feb. 1 -The non-Communist world's largest source of beryllium will go into production in this isolated area of central Utah by midsummer. That is the schedule of construction forces battling winter wind and snow to complete an ore processing mill 10 miles north of here and to simultaneously carve out a mile-long open pit mine in the Topaz Spor Mountains 47 miles west of this little ranching community.

PARIS -- In contemplating resumption of bilateral talks with China, scheduled in Warsaw this month, American diplomacy should consider the possibility of a fundamental switch in Peking's view of the outer world.

A ROOT feeder called JetFeed penetrates the soil to root level to carry moisture and fertilizer to shrub and tree roots. Water from the garden hose travels through a chamber containing fertilizer tablets.

NEW DELHI -- At a mass rally near Calcutta one recent evening. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was inspired to make the most outlandish campaign promise the increasingly skeptical Indian electorate is likely to hear for many years.
